Speaker: NA
Text: Wednesday, 23 November 2016

Speaker: NA
Text: The SPEAKER (Hon. Tony Smith) took the chair at 09:30, made an acknowledgement of

Speaker: NA
Text: country and read prayers.

Speaker: NA
Text: BILLS

Speaker: NA
Text: Corporations Amendment (Professional Standards of Financial Advisers) Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: First Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Ms O'Dwyer.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a first time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: Ms ODWYER
Text: Higgins-Minister for Revenue and Financial Services) (09:31): I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Today I introduce a bill that will amend the Corporations Act. It will raise the education,

Speaker: NA
Text: training and ethical standards of financial advisers by requiring financial advisers to hold a

Speaker: NA
Text: degree, undertake a professional year, pass an exam, undertake continuous professional

Speaker: NA
Text: development and comply with a code of ethics.

Speaker: NA
Text: In introducing this bill today, we are implementing our commitment set out in the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's response to the Financial System Inquiry (FSI). With its introduction, we are

Speaker: NA
Text: also responding to recommendations made by the Parliamentary Joint Committee (PJC) on

Speaker: NA
Text: Corporations and Financial Services inquiry into proposals to lift the professional, ethical and

Speaker: NA
Text: education standards in the financial services industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: This government is committed to ensuring Australia has a financial services regulatory

Speaker: NA
Text: regime that enhances confidence and trust by fostering an environment in which financial

Speaker: NA
Text: firms treat customers fairly.

Speaker: NA
Text: Creating a holistic professional standards framework to raise the competency and

Speaker: NA
Text: professionalism of financial advisers is an important part of our commitment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Raising the professional standards of financial advisers will play a significant role in

Speaker: NA
Text: improving consumer trust in the financial advice industry, which has had repeated instances

Speaker: NA
Text: of inappropriate behaviour.

Speaker: NA
Text: Reduced trust acts as a barrier to consumers seeking financial advice, which is an

Speaker: NA
Text: extremely poor outcome for both consumers and industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: We probably should not be surprised then, that right now only one in every five Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: seeks financial advice.

Speaker: NA
Text: Appropriate financial advice can significantly improve people's financial wellbeing. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: why we simply must improve trust in the industry so that consumers can have confidence in

Speaker: NA
Text: the advice they are seeking-so that they can have recourse to the kind of strategic advice,

Speaker: NA
Text: expertise and knowledge that most everyday people do not normally hold.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Equally important is the sustainable future of the financial advice industry, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: integral to our economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: I note that the proposed reforms follow important steps already taken by the government to

Speaker: NA
Text: improve the transparency and accountability of financial advice.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have already established a register of financial advisers that allows consumers to verify

Speaker: NA
Text: the credentials of financial advisers and be confident that they are appropriately qualified and

Speaker: NA
Text: experienced.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are also progressing reforms to life insurance advice remuneration structures. These

Speaker: NA
Text: reforms are an important step in addressing concerns that remuneration incentives are

Speaker: NA
Text: affecting the quality of advice provided to consumers and encouraging the unnecessary

Speaker: NA
Text: turnover of policies.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government has consulted extensively on the measures in this bill, which build on the

Speaker: NA
Text: model proposed by the PJC on Corporations and Financial Services, chaired by my colleague

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator David Fawcett, and the recommendations of the FSI. This is an excellent example of

Speaker: NA
Text: different segments of industry working together to build a workable model.

Speaker: NA
Text: I note that both the FSI and PJC reviews identified that the existing professional standards

Speaker: NA
Text: for financial advisers are too low and do not ensure that all financial advisers have the

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary skills to provide high-quality advice to consumers.

Speaker: NA
Text: These reviews recognise that the current regulatory framework was not enough to build

Speaker: NA
Text: professionalism in the financial advice industry and has not encouraged this industry to take a

Speaker: NA
Text: greater lead in setting standards.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is clear that the current framework lacks the incentives to encourage industry to go above

Speaker: NA
Text: and beyond the minimum.

Speaker: NA
Text: For example, under the current law, advisers can become qualified to provide financial

Speaker: NA
Text: advice after just four days of training, and there are no specific ongoing training requirements

Speaker: NA
Text: beyond that.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is now widespread support among industry, consumer groups, the government and

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament to raise education, training and ethical standards of financial advisers.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is clear that the time is right and we must take advantage of this momentum.

Speaker: NA
Text: The establishment of the standards body will be the first important step on the road to

Speaker: NA
Text: professionalism.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under this proposed legislation, we will establish a standards body, as a Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: company limited guarantee, to set education standards, professional year and continuing

Speaker: NA
Text: professional development requirements.

Speaker: NA
Text: The body will also develop an exam and a comprehensive code of ethics for all financial

Speaker: NA
Text: advisers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Establishing the standards body as a Commonwealth company will balance the body's

Speaker: NA
Text: independence with industry and consumer engagement.

Speaker: NA
Text: It will also minimise the government's footprint and allow for the possibility of easily

Speaker: NA
Text: transferring the standards body back to industry once trust and confidence in the sector is

Speaker: NA
Text: restored.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: The government will have no direct control over the entity's day-to-day operations, but,

Speaker: NA
Text: should the body not comply with its obligations, the responsible minister may give the body a

Speaker: NA
Text: written direction.

Speaker: NA
Text: Such a direction would only occur in very exceptional circumstances.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government will be responsible for all appointments to the board, which will comprise

Speaker: NA
Text: an independent chair, three industry representatives, three consumer representatives, an

Speaker: NA
Text: academic and an ethicist.

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry will have a key role in the proposed model and will be consulted extensively as

Speaker: NA
Text: the body sets standards.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is critical because industry must have a stake in the standards-making process if it is

Speaker: NA
Text: to be truly professional and to develop standards above the minimum.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the reforms, financial advisers who provide personal advice to retail clients on more

Speaker: NA
Text: complex products will need to meet these new standards.

Speaker: NA
Text: Financial advisers who are only authorised to provide general advice or personal advice on

Speaker: NA
Text: less complex financial products, such as general insurance, will not be required to comply

Speaker: NA
Text: with the new standards.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Securities and Investments Commission will continue to set education and

Speaker: NA
Text: training standards for advisers who are only authorised to provide general advice or advice on

Speaker: NA
Text: less complex products.

Speaker: NA
Text: New financial advisers will require a degree, while existing advisers will need to meet a

Speaker: NA
Text: standard equivalent to a degree set by the standards body.

Speaker: NA
Text: While the detail will ultimately be set by the new standards body, it is important to note

Speaker: NA
Text: that not all existing advisers will have to return to university and complete a three-year degree

Speaker: NA
Text: program.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some may not, but a majority are likely to receive credit for the education or training that

Speaker: NA
Text: they have already completed and will need only to gap-fill or undertake bridging courses to

Speaker: NA
Text: meet the standard required.

Speaker: NA
Text: Existing advisers have from 1 January 2019 to 1 January 2024 to meet the new education

Speaker: NA
Text: standards.

Speaker: NA
Text: While I commend the actions of some licensees who have already introduced a degree

Speaker: NA
Text: requirement for their financial advisers, government action is necessary in this space to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: minimum standards apply across the whole industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: The FSI found that low adviser competence was a factor in many of the recent high-profile

Speaker: NA
Text: instances of consumers receiving inappropriate financial advice and contributed to the low

Speaker: NA
Text: demand for financial advice.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact that an adviser could reach accreditation in four days has given the industry a bad

Speaker: NA
Text: image.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is obviously not good enough and there is clearly room to do better if the industry is

Speaker: NA
Text: to reach its true potential.

Speaker: NA
Text: A core feature of these reforms is the requirement that all advisers complete an exam set by

Speaker: NA
Text: the new standards body.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Such a requirement already exists in the United States, Britain, Canada, Singapore and

Speaker: NA
Text: Hong Kong.

Speaker: NA
Text: New advisers will need to complete the exam from 1 January 2019. Existing advisers will

Speaker: NA
Text: have from this date until 1 January 2021 to pass the exam.

Speaker: NA
Text: Collectively with the other measures in this bill, the exam will play a significant role in

Speaker: NA
Text: improving professional standards of financial advisers.

Speaker: NA
Text: It will objectively test and strengthen the practical and ethical knowledge of existing

Speaker: NA
Text: advisers with immediate effect and will help renew confidence in the industry without

Speaker: NA
Text: significant lag times.

Speaker: NA
Text: From 1 January 2019, all new entrants will need to undertake a professional year set by the

Speaker: NA
Text: new standards body.

Speaker: NA
Text: This will involve at least one year of work and training to ensure that new entrants are

Speaker: NA
Text: mentored and assessed before they are fully authorised to provide unsupervised advice to

Speaker: NA
Text: clients.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the reforms, new entrants who have completed their degree and passed the exam

Speaker: NA
Text: will be able to provide advice on a supervised basis during the professional year.

Speaker: NA
Text: The professional year trainee will be required to disclose to clients that they are completing

Speaker: NA
Text: the professional year and that they are not permitted to give advice unsupervised.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Register of Financial Advisers will clearly show that the person is completing their

Speaker: NA
Text: professional year and only authorised to give advice under strict supervision.

Speaker: NA
Text: A supervising adviser will need to ensure that the new financial adviser is appropriately

Speaker: NA
Text: supervised and take responsibility for all advice given by the new financial adviser during the

Speaker: NA
Text: professional year.

Speaker: NA
Text: The standards body will develop guidelines on what constitutes 'appropriate supervision'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Existing advisers will not need to undertake a professional year.

Speaker: NA
Text: All advisers, both new and existing, will be required to undertake continuing professional

Speaker: NA
Text: development.

Speaker: NA
Text: The new standards body will determine the requirements for continuing professional

Speaker: NA
Text: development, including the number of hours that advisers need to complete and which courses

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfy the requirements.

Speaker: NA
Text: This requirement will ensure financial advisers are keeping up to date with relevant

Speaker: NA
Text: training, information, skills and knowledge to make sure that they remain competent in

Speaker: NA
Text: providing advice to consumers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Roy Morgan reported in its 2014 State of the nation report that only 25 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians rate financial planners' standards of ethics and honesty as 'very high' or 'high'.

Speaker: NA
Text: This percentage must improve if the financial services industry is to meet the expectations

Speaker: NA
Text: of consumers.

Speaker: NA
Text: In a more recent survey, up to 85 per cent of practicing financial advisers indicated that

Speaker: NA
Text: they support the introduction of a single unified code of ethics.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is clear that financial advisers are hearing these concerns.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: On the back of these concerns and the recommendations by the PJC, the government is

Speaker: NA
Text: requiring all financial advisers to subscribe to a code of ethics by 1 January 2020.

Speaker: NA
Text: The new standards body will establish a single uniform code of ethics that will set out

Speaker: NA
Text: principles designed to help financial advisers conduct business honestly and with integrity.

Speaker: NA
Text: All financial advisers will need to be covered by an ASIC approved compliance scheme,

Speaker: NA
Text: which will set out how the code will be monitored and enforced.

Speaker: NA
Text: The compliance scheme will set out the arrangements for monitoring compliance, the

Speaker: NA
Text: sanctions for breaching the code, the process for consumers to make complaints, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: process for resolving disputes between the monitoring body and the financial adviser.

Speaker: NA
Text: The compliance scheme will specify which 'monitoring body' is responsible for enforcing

Speaker: NA
Text: compliance-this could be either a professional association or a third party who is

Speaker: NA
Text: independent of the licensee.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is important to note the significant role that professional associations, independent third

Speaker: NA
Text: parties and licensees will play in implementing these reforms.

Speaker: NA
Text: These institutions will be directly responsible for ensuring financial advisers comply with

Speaker: NA
Text: the new standards.

Speaker: NA
Text: Professional associations are likely to offer training and education services to their

Speaker: NA
Text: members, to assist them to prepare and to meet the new standards.

Speaker: NA
Text: I note that many of these associations, particularly those in the Industry Consensus Group,

Speaker: NA
Text: have been instrumental in the development of these reforms.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to thank Senator David Fawcett and the members of the PJC for their

Speaker: NA
Text: important contributions and I also wish to acknowledge the work of my predecessors.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is anticipated that the new standards body will be established by mid-2017.

Speaker: NA
Text: The new education, exam, professional year and continuing professional development

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements apply from 1 January 2019.

Speaker: NA
Text: Existing advisers will have until 1 January 2021 to pass the exam and 1 January 2024 to

Speaker: NA
Text: meet the degree-equivalent requirement.

Speaker: NA
Text: The provisions relating to the code of ethics take effect from 1 January 2020.

Speaker: NA
Text: In closing, I note that these reforms represent a necessary and valuable change to the

Speaker: NA
Text: current regulatory environment for financial advisers, and are important steps in

Speaker: NA
Text: professionalising the industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: Not only will they deliver significant benefits to consumers, they will also help maintain

Speaker: NA
Text: trust and confidence in the financial system. I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: Crimes Legislation Amendment (International Crime Cooperation and Other

Speaker: NA
Text: Measures) Bill 2016

Speaker: NA
Text: First Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Mr Keenan.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a first time.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: Mr KEENAN
Text: Stirling-Minister for Justice and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Counter-Terrorism) (09:46): I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government is committed to ensuring Australia's criminal justice framework is as strong

Speaker: NA
Text: as it can be-striking the right balance between protecting fundamental rights while ensuring

Speaker: NA
Text: justice is served. We are committed to ensuring our law enforcement and justice agencies

Speaker: NA
Text: have the requisite powers to appropriately contribute to the fight against crime at home and

Speaker: NA
Text: abroad.

Speaker: NA
Text: To that end, we keep our criminal justice framework under constant review-our agencies,

Speaker: NA
Text: policies, laws and processes-to ensure that we have a regime in place that is well equipped

Speaker: NA
Text: for the job of tackling crime.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill about which I speak today-the Crimes Legislation Amendment (International

Speaker: NA
Text: Crime Cooperation and Other Measures) Bill 2016-is an another example of our efforts in

Speaker: NA
Text: this respect. It is a comprehensive bill-11 schedules in length-which contains a range of

Speaker: NA
Text: measures that will strengthen the Commonwealth's already robust criminal justice

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill will enhance Australia's position globally in the fight against crime, making

Speaker: NA
Text: improvements to our international crime cooperation arrangements and our ability to assist

Speaker: NA
Text: international courts and tribunals.

Speaker: NA
Text: It will make amendments to the Commonwealth's Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-

Speaker: NA
Text: Terrorism Financing Act to both strengthen that regime and make reporting requirements

Speaker: NA
Text: within it more flexible.

Speaker: NA
Text: It will amend the AusCheck Act to bolster the government's ability to address serious risks,

Speaker: NA
Text: such as national security and safety risks, related to large-scale events of a national character.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill will also enhance the Commonwealth's anti-human trafficking and slavery regime

Speaker: NA
Text: and the protections afforded to vulnerable witnesses within our criminal justice system.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, the bill will make a number of minor amendments to:

Speaker: NA
Text:  streamline the annual reporting processes under the War Crimes Act, and

Speaker: NA
Text:  enhance the Australian Federal Police's drug and alcohol testing arrangements, enabling it

Speaker: NA
Text: to maintain the integrity of its workforce and enforce its zero-tolerance policy regarding

Speaker: NA
Text: illicit drug use.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill also contains minor consequential amendments to facilitate the use of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Criminal Intelligence Commission as an alternative name for the Australian Crime

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not propose elaborating in detail on all of the measures I have just outlined that are

Speaker: NA
Text: contained in the bill. I would, however, like to draw the attention to some of the more

Speaker: NA
Text: significant measures.

Speaker: NA
Text: International crime cooperation measures

Speaker: NA
Text: As many of us here appreciate, international crime cooperation is an essential part of

Speaker: NA
Text: fighting crime in Australia and across the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia needs to ensure that criminals cannot evade prosecution or profit from crime

Speaker: NA
Text: because the evidence or proceeds of their crimes are located in different countries, or because

Speaker: NA
Text: they can move easily across borders.

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendments in the bill will ensure Australia can respond effectively to requests for

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance from foreign countries and international bodies, in accordance with our

Speaker: NA
Text: international obligations. They will also ensure that the rules on adducing foreign material in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian proceedings apply consistently throughout Australia. The amendments have been

Speaker: NA
Text: identified from practical experience and will provide certainty in the operation of key

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Specifically, the bill will enhance Australia's ability to assist international courts and

Speaker: NA
Text: tribunals. These bodies are responsible for investigating and prosecuting individuals accused

Speaker: NA
Text: of committing the most serious crimes of concern to the international community, including

Speaker: NA
Text: the crime of genocide, crimes against humanity and war crimes.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill will align the assistance Australia can provide to the International Criminal Court

Speaker: NA
Text: and international war crimes tribunals with the assistance we can provide in criminal matters

Speaker: NA
Text: to foreign countries. Australia's authority to provide assistance to these bodies is currently

Speaker: NA
Text: more limited than our capacity to assist foreign countries. The bill will permit forensic

Speaker: NA
Text: procedures, surveillance activities and telecommunications information to the international

Speaker: NA
Text: bodies.

Speaker: NA
Text: The assistance would be subject to the same processes that currently apply to the assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: provided to foreign countries and to similar safeguards that apply to the use of these powers

Speaker: NA
Text: for foreign and domestic law enforcement purposes.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill will also amend Australia's mutual assistance regime, to enhance the assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: that Australia can provide in response to a mutual assistance request from a foreign country in

Speaker: NA
Text: a criminal matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: These amendments will ensure that proceeds of crime investigative tools in the Mutual

Speaker: NA
Text: Assistance Act align with those in the Proceeds of Crime Act. They will also modify

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions in the Proceeds of Crime Act appropriately for the foreign context.

Speaker: NA
Text: The amendments will also clarify the types of foreign proceeds of crime orders for which

Speaker: NA
Text: mutual assistance can be provided and confirm that the Mutual Assistance Act applies to

Speaker: NA
Text: interim foreign proceeds of crime orders that are issued by non-judicial government bodies.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill will also amend the Extradition Act to ensure that judicial officers and relevant

Speaker: NA
Text: courts have sufficient powers to order the remand of a person in an appropriate facility to

Speaker: NA
Text: await extradition following a surrender decision. This will improve the operation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: extradition process and assist Australia to meet its international extradition obligations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, the bill will also make amendments to the Foreign Evidence Act. These

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments will ensure consistent application of the rules relating to foreign evidence

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: They will provide a process to certify material received from a foreign country in response

Speaker: NA
Text: to a mutual assistance request in terrorism-related proceedings. This will ensure that the

Speaker: NA
Text: certification is prima facie evidence of the fact of such receipt.

Speaker: NA
Text: Vulnerable witness protections

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: I would also like to highlight the bill's proposed enhancements to the Commonwealth's

Speaker: NA
Text: existing vulnerable witness protections.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government is committed to supporting and protecting vulnerable witnesses giving

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence in Commonwealth criminal proceedings.

Speaker: NA
Text: The amendments will ensure the existing offence of identifying child witnesses or

Speaker: NA
Text: vulnerable adult complainants also extends to child complainants.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill will also amend relevant legislation to clarify that the protections afforded to

Speaker: NA
Text: vulnerable witnesses apply to future criminal proceedings, regardless of when the alleged

Speaker: NA
Text: offence occurred.

Speaker: NA
Text: In relation to the Commonwealth's human trafficking and slavery offences, the bill seeks to

Speaker: NA
Text: broaden the definition of 'debt bondage'. It will also expand the relevant evidence that may be

Speaker: NA
Text: taken into account in determining elements of human trafficking and slavery-related offences.

Speaker: NA
Text: Anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: In respect of the Commonwealth's anti-money laundering and counterterrorism financing

Speaker: NA
Text: framework, the bill makes several amendments. Firstly, to allow travellers departing Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: to electronically report cross-border movements of physical currency-currently, travellers

Speaker: NA
Text: who are carrying $10,000 or more in cash must provide a written report at a specific time and

Speaker: NA
Text: point. The proposed amendments will maintain existing reporting requirements, but provide

Speaker: NA
Text: the necessary flexibility to ensure that a new digital form can also be used.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill will also list the Australian Charities and Not-For-Profits Commission-the

Speaker: NA
Text: ACNC-as a designated agency under the AML/CTF Act. This will enable the ACNC to

Speaker: NA
Text: access financial intelligence information to assess money laundering and terrorist financing

Speaker: NA
Text: risks associated with charities that register with the ACNC. In turn, this will enable the ACNC

Speaker: NA
Text: to better detect, monitor and halt money laundering, terrorist financing and other criminal

Speaker: NA
Text: activities involving ACNC-registered entities.

Speaker: NA
Text: AusCheck Act amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, I would like to mention the AusCheck Act amendments.

Speaker: NA
Text: These will enable AusCheck, a business unit within the Attorney-General's Department, to

Speaker: NA
Text: conduct and coordinate background checks in relation to major national events such as the

Speaker: NA
Text: 2018 Commonwealth Games.

Speaker: NA
Text: These amendments will enable the government to prevent persons who pose serious risks,

Speaker: NA
Text: such as persons of national security concern, from working or volunteering at major national

Speaker: NA
Text: events and contributing to serious incidents.

Speaker: NA
Text: The amendments will provide me-as the minister-with a power to declare a major

Speaker: NA
Text: national event by legislative instrument. They will also permit regulations to be made in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to the conduct and coordination of background checks for a major national event.

Speaker: NA
Text: The term 'major national event' is intended to capture a type of event that is of such a large

Speaker: NA
Text: scale and national character that it would benefit from the coordination of security and other

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements by the Commonwealth or across more than one jurisdiction in Australia. Some

Speaker: NA
Text: examples of events that, if held in Australia, could be characterised as major national events

Speaker: NA
Text: include the Commonwealth Games, the G20, the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation meeting

Speaker: NA
Text: and major international sporting events. In declaring an event as a major national event, I-as

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the minister-must be satisfied that it is in the national interest that the Commonwealth be

Speaker: NA
Text: involved in the conduct and coordination of background checks in connection with the

Speaker: NA
Text: accreditation of people in relation to the event.

Speaker: NA
Text: Using the established AusCheck scheme for these purposes will ensure that the background

Speaker: NA
Text: checks can be facilitated through established mechanisms, which are well supported by

Speaker: NA
Text: technical channels and legal frameworks.

Speaker: NA
Text: Conclusion

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's criminal justice framework is both fair and strong. But it never serves to be

Speaker: NA
Text: complacent. Where we find opportunities to fine-tune aspects of our regime, we will take

Speaker: NA
Text: these up. This bill, which is very comprehensive in nature, is an example of the government

Speaker: NA
Text: doing exactly that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: MOTIONS

Speaker: NA
Text: Equal Rights

Speaker: NA
Text: Reference to Federation Chamber

Speaker: Ms MARINO
Text: Forrest-Chief Government Whip) (09:57): I declare that the following

Speaker: NA
Text: order of the day, government business, is referred to the Federation Chamber for debate:

Speaker: NA
Text: Equal rights for all Australians-Resumption of debate on the motion of the Prime Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS

Speaker: NA
Text: Annual Investment Statement

Speaker: Mr CIOBO
Text: Moncrieff-Minister for Trade, Tourism and Investment) (09:57): by

Speaker: NA
Text: leave-I have the honour to present the coalition's third Investment Statement to the

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: Introduction–why investment

Speaker: NA
Text: This annual statement is to update the parliament-and the Australian people-on our

Speaker: NA
Text: work promoting Australia as a place for productive foreign investment. There are many strong

Speaker: NA
Text: views on the sort of investment Australia should accept. This is an important and welcome

Speaker: NA
Text: discussion and we need to engage with the range of views expressed by the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: community.

Speaker: NA
Text: Like most important things, there are sensitivities, risks and opportunities. However, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: only by examining them and considering our options that we can best respond and make sure

Speaker: NA
Text: we are doing the right thing. At a time when there are questions around globalisation and

Speaker: NA
Text: rising protectionist sentiment I do not resile from liberalisation and this investment statement

Speaker: NA
Text: is an opportunity to explain why.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have just come from the APEC ministers' meeting in Peru, where I saw firsthand how

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's leadership is continuing to shape the development and implementation of pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: growth trade and investment rules and standards in our region. Liberalised trade and openness

Speaker: NA
Text: to foreign investment builds productive economies-this is how we prosper and grow.

Speaker: NA
Text: Foreign investment in context

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is the world's sixth largest landmass, with the world's 13th biggest economy, but

Speaker: NA
Text: ranks only 52nd by population. So it is only natural that our tremendous national endowments

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: generate greater investment opportunities than we can fund from our own savings. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: been tapping savings from abroad-foreign investment-for almost every decade for at least

Speaker: NA
Text: 150 years.

Speaker: NA
Text: By supplementing our savings with the savings of others from overseas, we drive more

Speaker: NA
Text: investment here at home, generating higher growth, more jobs with higher wages, and raise

Speaker: NA
Text: more tax revenue to fund for example our schools and hospitals, than if we only invested what

Speaker: NA
Text: we saved ourselves and shunned foreign investment.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is why the coalition government expanded the traditional role of trade minister to be

Speaker: NA
Text: the minister for investment as well. My job as minister for investment, and the work of my

Speaker: NA
Text: agencies, is to promote and attract productive foreign investment and to ensure Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: remains an attractive destination for that investment.

Speaker: NA
Text: This means investment that:

Speaker: NA
Text:  builds on our strengths

Speaker: NA
Text:  helps us retain and create new jobs

Speaker: NA
Text:  build competitive industries here at home; and

Speaker: NA
Text:  helps us deliver our expertise to the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: The areas this government has made a priority-in partnership with Australia's states and

Speaker: NA
Text: territories-are these areas which back our strengths:

Speaker: NA
Text:  major infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text:  tourism infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text:  food and agribusiness

Speaker: NA
Text:  resources and energy; and

Speaker: NA
Text:  advanced manufacturing, services and technologies

Speaker: NA
Text: To support these priorities, since 2013 the coalition has:

Speaker: NA
Text:  Delivered Australia a unique 'FTA investment advantage'. The North Asian FTAs deliver

Speaker: NA
Text: unmatched preferential access, providing a powerful incentive for investors to expand

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses here and hire more workers to capitalise on our newly-won trade advantage in

Speaker: NA
Text: these key markets.

Speaker: NA
Text:  Held around 100 investment roundtables with companies investing, or interested to invest,

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia. I have hosted 28 of these since February this year as well as many bilateral

Speaker: NA
Text: investment meetings that have encouraged new investment, helped maintain our

Speaker: NA
Text: relationships with existing investors, and helped resolve issues and facilitate investment

Speaker: NA
Text: that otherwise may not have happened.

Speaker: NA
Text:  - Because we know that most new foreign direct investment is additional; re-investment by

Speaker: NA
Text: those who already see the value of investing in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text:  Austrade, our investment attraction agency, has recorded 271 new investment outcomes,

Speaker: NA
Text: with a reported value of almost A$17 billion, creating or safeguarding at least 30,000 jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: here in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text:  Over this term, I will continue to promote Australia as a destination for global investment

Speaker: NA
Text: dollars, to drive jobs and growth.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: In 2015 the stock of foreign investment in Australia was made up of portfolio and other

Speaker: NA
Text: investment, representing some $2.3 trillion, and foreign direct investment, representing some

Speaker: NA
Text: $735 billion, for a total of around $3 trillion.

Speaker: NA
Text: The major sources of this investment were the United States, some $860 billion, the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingdom, around $500 billion, the remainder of the EU, representing some $491 billion, and

Speaker: NA
Text: Japan, of some $200 billion. Chinese investment is growing rapidly from a low base and at

Speaker: NA
Text: the end of 2015 represented around A$75 billion. The emergence of China is the latest in

Speaker: NA
Text: successive waves of foreign investment in our history which started with the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingdom, then the United States and then Japan.

Speaker: NA
Text: The quantum of new foreign direct investment into Australia in 2015 was valued at $117.9

Speaker: NA
Text: billion. This was down some $38.7-or roughly 24.7 per cent-on the amount invested into

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia in 2014.

Speaker: NA
Text: These trends are outlined in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade's third annual

Speaker: NA
Text: International Investment Report which I will release today.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although annual investment data tends to be lumpy, with large investments in one year-

Speaker: NA
Text: such as through the recent peak of the LNG investment boom-which causes spikes, these

Speaker: NA
Text: figures show that we cannot be complacent about our attractiveness as a destination for

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign investment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Amidst subdued global growth, there is fierce competition for global investment. So

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia must redouble its efforts if we are to remain internationally competitive, to attract

Speaker: NA
Text: new investment, to retain and expand existing investment, and thereby safeguard Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs.

Speaker: NA
Text: This means ensuring Australia keeps up with the pack in terms of a globally and regional

Speaker: NA
Text: competitive corporate tax rate-this is why the coalition plans to lower company tax to 25 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent over the medium term.

Speaker: NA
Text: This means providing an attractive environment for start-ups and entrepreneurs-as was

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced last year through the coalition's National Innovation and Science Agenda.

Speaker: NA
Text: This means deepening our trade and investment relationships with key markets including

Speaker: NA
Text: Indonesia, the European Union and the United Kingdom; and progressing transformational

Speaker: NA
Text: regional agreements such as the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership, to link us

Speaker: NA
Text: into regional value chains.

Speaker: NA
Text: As for the TPP, the government has been clear on the very substantial new opportunities

Speaker: NA
Text: for our exporters and investors that would flow from this agreement, in particular the creation

Speaker: NA
Text: of a more seamless trade and investment environment across the region. My recent meetings

Speaker: NA
Text: in Lima revealed a widespread view among all TPP parties on the value of the deal. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: since seen public comments by President-elect Trump which appear to signal an intention to

Speaker: NA
Text: withdraw from the TPP. We will need to wait for more detail from the US administration after

Speaker: NA
Text: it has come to office, but in the meantime the Australian government remains committed to

Speaker: NA
Text: pushing to realise the high ambition, comprehensive outcomes that were embedded in the

Speaker: NA
Text: TPP.

Speaker: NA
Text: Importance of foreign investment

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has long had export awards, but we are introducing something new this year. A

Speaker: NA
Text: national investment award.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tomorrow night, I will announce the winner of our inaugural Investment Award.

Speaker: NA
Text: This award will highlight some of the enduring, substantial, creative and new investments

Speaker: NA
Text: in our country that we should recognise and celebrate.

Speaker: NA
Text: If we look at the nominees for the inaugural Investment Award, put forward by states and

Speaker: NA
Text: territories and Austrade, those seven companies and their joint venture partners have invested

Speaker: NA
Text: more than A$138 billion in Australia and created or retained over 53,000 jobs.

Speaker: NA
Text: We will be talking more about those seven in the coming days.

Speaker: NA
Text: More generally, if you look at the 37 per cent of Australia's top 2,000 companies that are

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign-owned, these companies firms account for A$1.1 trillion of assets in Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: generate revenue of A$629.3 billion and employed nearly 700,000 people in 2014-2015.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is important we celebrate the jobs that new investment drives. Not everyone sees the

Speaker: NA
Text: value of investment openness. As with liberalised trade, some see it as a threat to their

Speaker: NA
Text: standard of living, rather than an opportunity to improve it.

Speaker: NA
Text: When it comes to investment, we often hear about the bad but not the good. The nature of

Speaker: NA
Text: news means the factory that is closing gets more coverage than the one opening.

Speaker: NA
Text: You have heard about the Ford plant closing, but not the $1 billion Boeing has invested in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia that is creating opportunities for engineering and machining companies to diversify

Speaker: NA
Text: and win new markets in the international aerospace market.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the case for Lovitt Technologies, a supplier to Boeing, one of the finalists,

Speaker: NA
Text: incidentally, for the investment awards.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has had an enviable 25 years of economic growth, but this does not mean people

Speaker: NA
Text: have been unaffected by the challenges posed by disruptive technologies and global

Speaker: NA
Text: competition.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know people are concerned about whether we can overcome these challenges.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whether working hard will be sufficient to hold on to their jobs and their standard of

Speaker: NA
Text: living.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whether our children will have the same opportunities to build good lives.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whether our economic success story can continue.

Speaker: NA
Text: Productive foreign investment, the investment this government promotes, is one of our best

Speaker: NA
Text: ways of confidently meeting those challenges.

Speaker: NA
Text: Investment from outside of Australia has been critical to the development of our world-

Speaker: NA
Text: leading export industries.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our mining boom would not have happened without foreign investment to develop the

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure, expertise and supply chains around the world we needed to make us the global

Speaker: NA
Text: resources powerhouse we are today.

Speaker: NA
Text: For example, companies like Mitsui, whose long term investments and joint ventures in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia employ an estimated 20,000 Australians, were instrumental in the development of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Pilbara's iron ore and the Bowen Basin's coal.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: With Australia's transition to a new economy, opportunities in renewable energy are

Speaker: NA
Text: driving significant investments, particularly in hydro, wind and solar.

Speaker: NA
Text: Companies like Neoen, from France, RATCH, from Thailand, and Goldwind from China

Speaker: NA
Text: are helping Australia reach its clean energy targets.

Speaker: NA
Text: Investment award nominee Neoen out of France has close to A$1 billion investment

Speaker: NA
Text: planned to date, including projects in South Australia, Western Australia and New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales. Neoen sees ongoing opportunities in Australia across all states and is ready to commit

Speaker: NA
Text: another A$1 billion in renewable energy projects by 2020.

Speaker: NA
Text: And, Australia is poised to become the world's largest exporter of LNG, when major

Speaker: NA
Text: projects come online. Projects like US company Chevron's Gorgon and Wheatstone

Speaker: NA
Text: developments in WA, and Japanese company Inpex's Ichthys project in Darwin.

Speaker: NA
Text: These investments support the growth of smalland medium-size businesses like Total

Speaker: NA
Text: Marine Technology in Bibra Lake, Western Australia, whose CEO Paul Colley says:

Speaker: NA
Text: We weren't sure our credentials were established enough to supply … to a project as large as

Speaker: NA
Text: Gorgon. Chevron listened to us and TMT was awarded one of the most significant contracts in our

Speaker: NA
Text: history. … In addition to doubling our number of employees, we've grown internationally with offices

Speaker: NA
Text: in Brazil and Malaysia.

Speaker: NA
Text: We understand that in today's global world it is important for small Australian businesses, the

Speaker: NA
Text: engine room of our economy, to be part of the global economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Global value chains-where many countries are involved in producing a final good or

Speaker: NA
Text: service-now support 75 per cent of the world's trade and investment activity.

Speaker: NA
Text: Boeing's investment in Australia is a great example of foreign investment that is creating

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs, driving innovation and supporting access to global value chains at the same time.

Speaker: NA
Text: In Melbourne alone, Boeing has created jobs for around 1,200 Australians who make

Speaker: NA
Text: control surfaces and flaps for Boeing aircraft at Fisherman's Bend.

Speaker: NA
Text: Working with the CSIRO-and ten local universities-Boeing's R&D investment in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has also helped us to become world leaders in developing new aviation products.

Speaker: NA
Text: And Boeing's global supply chain has supported Australian companies win global supply

Speaker: NA
Text: contracts. In 2015 alone, more than 1,000 Australian companies were suppliers in Boeing's

Speaker: NA
Text: global supply chain. That year, Boeing spent approximately $400 million on its Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: suppliers. Companies like Lovitt Technologies that have worked with Boeing for over 20

Speaker: NA
Text: years.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bruce Ramsay, Lovitt's Manufacturing Director says, 'Working with Boeing has given

Speaker: NA
Text: Lovitt the opportunity to grow from an automotive tooling supplier into a globally

Speaker: NA
Text: competitive aerospace component manufacturer.'

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me be perfectly clear, this is investment that enables Australian businesses to connect

Speaker: NA
Text: with multinational companies.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is investment that brings enduring jobs in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Investment is a two-way street

Speaker: NA
Text: Let's not forget-Australia does not just receive investment from overseas, we have

Speaker: NA
Text: significant investment abroad.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: We want an open and transparent global playing field for trade and investment. And

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is helping to drive those objectives regionally and globally-in the G20 through

Speaker: NA
Text: developing guiding principles for investment policymakers and in the FTAs that we negotiate,

Speaker: NA
Text: including provisions to support Australian firms' ability to deliver goods and services

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas.

Speaker: NA
Text: Promoting global openness matters for Australian companies. More than two-thirds of the

Speaker: NA
Text: goods and services supplied by Australia to the European Union, New Zealand and the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States are by Australian firms on the ground in those countries, using Australian skills and

Speaker: NA
Text: expertise.

Speaker: NA
Text: For example, when I was in London recently I rode the iconic red London buses, operated

Speaker: NA
Text: by Australia's very own Transit Systems which runs part of the bus network in London and

Speaker: NA
Text: also in Singapore.

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is protecting the national interest

Speaker: NA
Text: The Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) monitors foreign investment to ensure it is

Speaker: NA
Text: not against our national interest. It is important to note that just because we accept foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: investment we do not lose the ability to set the rules that all companies (both domestic and

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign-owned) must comply with.

Speaker: NA
Text: All companies are subject to our legislation and regulations, be it our taxation laws, our

Speaker: NA
Text: environmental and safety standards and our labour market requirements. We are not losing

Speaker: NA
Text: control of these things by accepting foreign investment.

Speaker: NA
Text: In terms of critical infrastructure, we know risks must be managed carefully, and we will

Speaker: NA
Text: have more to say on this in the near future. In those rare cases where substantial problems are

Speaker: NA
Text: identified, the government will not hesitate to take appropriate action to safeguard Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: national interests. This is why the Treasurer rejected the proposed acquisition of Ausgrid.

Speaker: NA
Text: But outright rejections are rare; we continue to welcome foreign investment in critical

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure. For example, I was pleased to see a consortium comprising Australian and

Speaker: NA
Text: international investors participate in the Port of Melbourne lease.

Speaker: NA
Text: Investment in agricultural land is also a touchstone issue here. This is why we have

Speaker: NA
Text: tightened the FIRB screening thresholds for agricultural land and agribusiness and established

Speaker: NA
Text: an agricultural land ownership register to help provide some facts around levels of foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: ownership.

Speaker: NA
Text: It turns out that foreign investors held only 13.6 per cent of Australian agricultural land (as

Speaker: NA
Text: at 30 June 2016), and the biggest investors in agricultural land are the United Kingdom and

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States. China comes in fifth, holding only 0.4 per cent of Australia's agricultural

Speaker: NA
Text: land.

Speaker: NA
Text: But we need investment to build on the great potential of our agricultural and food sector

Speaker: NA
Text: and to maximise its capacity to take advantage of the growth opportunities throughout our

Speaker: NA
Text: region. ANZ has estimated we need additional investment of $1 trillion if we are to double

Speaker: NA
Text: our agricultural exports by 2050.

Speaker: NA
Text: We can look to examples of where there has been controversy and reflect on the results. At

Speaker: NA
Text: 96,000 hectares, about the size of Iceland, Cubbie Station is one of Queensland's most

Speaker: NA
Text: significant agricultural land holdings. Less than five years ago, Chinese textile firm Shandong

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Ruyi lifted Cubbie out of five years of voluntary administration with an investment of $240

Speaker: NA
Text: million. Today, it is hard to find a bad word about Cubbie Station or its foreign owner in

Speaker: NA
Text: Dirranbandi. Despite all the initial concerns, Cubbie's operations have stayed local. It is the

Speaker: NA
Text: lifeblood of farmers and local businesses. It is reported that more locals than ever are working

Speaker: NA
Text: on the crops, which will be worth more than $85 million when they ripen next April.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not just those on the farm that benefit. Local businesses that might otherwise have

Speaker: NA
Text: suffered are benefiting from what is now a viable business at Cubbie. In the words of John

Speaker: NA
Text: Travers, Manager of the local agricultural machinery and truck dealership, Vanderfield:

Speaker: NA
Text: Any concerns around the acquisition were quickly allayed because changes in the operations were

Speaker: NA
Text: unnoticeable. They remained loyal to their contractors and suppliers and recognised that we are part of

Speaker: NA
Text: the supply chain.

Speaker: NA
Text: Foreign investment delivers not just jobs for those directly employed, but also practical,

Speaker: NA
Text: tangible benefits for many other Australians through the goods and services that are produced.

Speaker: NA
Text: The benefits of foreign investment can come in all sorts of different ways.

Speaker: NA
Text: For instance, the entry of German discount supermarket Aldi has not only increased

Speaker: NA
Text: competition in Australia's supermarket sector. With plans to sell groceries and wine online to

Speaker: NA
Text: China in the first half of 2017, to be followed by establishing stores there, its regional

Speaker: NA
Text: expansion is building Australian jobs and Australian exports.

Speaker: NA
Text: State and territory governments are also harnessing foreign investment. With assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: from foreign money and capability, they are creating tens of thousands of jobs across the

Speaker: NA
Text: country, while building the infrastructure we need to cut travel times and to get us to and from

Speaker: NA
Text: home even faster.

Speaker: NA
Text: Projects like the Sydney Metro Northwest will cut travel time from 90 to 35 minutes and

Speaker: NA
Text: reduce car trips by 14 million a year. It will be delivered with investment from Hong Kong

Speaker: NA
Text: company MTR. It means new jobs now and broader benefits for decades to come.

Speaker: NA
Text: And let us not forget our tourism sector, which directly accounts for one in every 20

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian jobs. It is of particular importance to the regions, where 45 cents in every tourism

Speaker: NA
Text: dollar is spent. In my constituency alone, tourism directly employed some 30,400 people,

Speaker: NA
Text: with another 20,000 indirect jobs, and contributed some $4.9 billion to the Gold Coast

Speaker: NA
Text: economy in 2013-14. But major investment in tourism is needed if we are to sustain this and

Speaker: NA
Text: fully benefit from the higher demand predicted to flow from the growth of Asia's middle

Speaker: NA
Text: class, from 600 million to three billion by 2030.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our hotels, resorts and tourist attractions need upgrading with new investment. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Sheraton Mirage Port Douglas Resort was relaunched in August this year following an

Speaker: NA
Text: extensive $43 million refurbishment of the resort's 294 guest rooms and their public spaces by

Speaker: NA
Text: Chinese company Fullshare Industrial Holding Group. Here again, foreign investment is

Speaker: NA
Text: helping to make Australia globally competitive, continuing a pattern of successive waves of

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign investment. We saw significant Japanese investment in Queensland hotels and resorts

Speaker: NA
Text: in the 1980s. Many of these assets eventually ended up in local hands. Sources of capital may

Speaker: NA
Text: change but the resulting infrastructure endures.

Speaker: NA
Text: Today we welcome investment in tourism from new sources. TFE Hotels, established in

Speaker: NA
Text: 2013, is a joint venture between Australia's Toga Group and Singapore's Far East Hospitality

Speaker: NA
Text: Holdings. Operating 70 hotels nationally, with brands like Medina, Travelodge and Vibe, its

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: presence sprawls across Australia opening doors to tourism in northern cities such as Darwin

Speaker: NA
Text: and Rockhampton.

Speaker: NA
Text: Conclusion

Speaker: NA
Text: We are a proud and capable country. We have world-leading ideas, technology, and skills.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are embracing the challenges the global economy presents. Investment is a crucial

Speaker: NA
Text: element in our strategy to retain and create new jobs and economic opportunities-to

Speaker: NA
Text: safeguard what we have now and what we want for the future, and to project our capability

Speaker: NA
Text: into the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: The right investment will support substantial and enduring jobs, sustain our businesses and

Speaker: NA
Text: local communities, build on our strengths and our potential. That is why as the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade, Tourism and Investment I will continue to welcome foreign investment here at home

Speaker: NA
Text: and be at the forefront of efforts to maintain Australia's openness abroad.

Speaker: Dr LEIGH
Text: Fenner) (10:22): I rise representing the member for Blaxland, who is Labor's

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow minister for trade and investment and is presently on parental leave. At the outset I

Speaker: NA
Text: note that the opposition were not provided in advance with a copy of the statement or the

Speaker: NA
Text: document that the minister has tabled, so my comments will be of a general nature responding

Speaker: NA
Text: to the minister's speech and discussing the coalition's role in the fall in Australian investment

Speaker: NA
Text: that we have seen over recent years.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor acknowledges the benefits to Australia of foreign investment. As Senator Wong

Speaker: NA
Text: recently noted:

Speaker: NA
Text: Last year Australians saved just over $363 billion, yet investment in our economy was nearly $425

Speaker: NA
Text: billion. This was, of course, nothing out of the ordinary.

Speaker: NA
Text: Over the last four decades, the gap between Australia's national savings and investment has averaged

Speaker: NA
Text: around 4 per cent of GDP.

Speaker: NA
Text: By tapping into foreign investment Australia is using the savings of other nations in order to

Speaker: NA
Text: finance investment in our own country. Foreign investment ensures that we enjoy higher

Speaker: NA
Text: living standards and that we have a more productive economy and more sustainable

Speaker: NA
Text: industries. To do away with foreign investment would be to see employment decrease, wages

Speaker: NA
Text: fall, prices rise and the choices offered to consumers decrease.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the shadow minister for trade and investment, Jason Clare, has noted:

Speaker: NA
Text: Asia is the key to Australia's success in the years ahead. There'll be three billion middle class consumers

Speaker: NA
Text: north of us by 2030 and the key for Australia is making sure that we sell our products and our services

Speaker: NA
Text: to Asia-that we get our fair share of that market.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Blaxland has noted Labor's strong history of support for open markets.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the minister has noted, the statistics on inbound investment are concerning. An OECD

Speaker: NA
Text: report brought down in April this year noted that foreign direct investment flows to Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: fell by A$23 billion, or 44 per cent, last year. That came despite inbound FDI inflows across

Speaker: NA
Text: the OECD's 34 member nations almost doubling in 2015. And it followed disappointing

Speaker: NA
Text: investment results for Australia in 2014, when foreign direct investment inflows declined by

Speaker: NA
Text: 30 per cent. So under the coalition in recent years we have seen a decline in Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: inbound investment. I will return later in my remarks to the role that coalition policies may

Speaker: NA
Text: have played in that fall.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: But it is important to put on record the role that foreign investment has played in the

Speaker: NA
Text: development of the Australian economy. In 1855 CSR's investment helped to shape our sugar

Speaker: NA
Text: industry. In 1877 we saw the United States firm Schweppes set up in Australia. In the 1920s

Speaker: NA
Text: we saw Kraft and Kellogg investing in Australia and, as David Uren points out in his terrific

Speaker: NA
Text: book on foreign investment, one of the great ironies is that Vegemite may never have become

Speaker: NA
Text: the global success story that it is without foreign investment from Kraft.

Speaker: NA
Text: Foreign investment in our beef industry from Britain, the United States and Japan has been

Speaker: NA
Text: critical in developing that industry. Investors like the controversial Vestey family,

Speaker: NA
Text: International Ranchers and King Ranch, from Texas, have been important in our beef

Speaker: NA
Text: industry. Kodak set up here in 1908, Coca-Cola and Heinz in the 1930s and of course there is

Speaker: NA
Text: automotive foreign investment. The foreign investment in Australia by automotive firms,

Speaker: NA
Text: including General Motors, Ford, Chrysler, Leyland, Toyota and Nissan, were important in

Speaker: NA
Text: creating well-paying Australian jobs. And the role of this government in goading Holden to

Speaker: NA
Text: leave has had a damaging effect, particularly on the South Australian economy. The

Speaker: NA
Text: withdrawal of foreign investment is one of the chief challenges that South Australia faces at

Speaker: NA
Text: the moment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Foreign investment has also been important in the media industry. I often have to chuckle

Speaker: NA
Text: when I see stories in tabloids railing against foreign investment. Without foreign investment

Speaker: NA
Text: from companies such as News Limited there would be fewer Australian journalists employed

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's support for foreign investment is longstanding and is of a piece with Labor's

Speaker: NA
Text: support for a strong immigration system and for the benefits of a global trading system. Those

Speaker: NA
Text: on the other side of the House have a track record which has not always been strongly in

Speaker: NA
Text: favour of foreign investment. Black Jack MCEwen-John MCEwen-once said:

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not good enough for this country to live by selling a bit of its heritage every year. We do not

Speaker: NA
Text: want to see Australia have its industries unduly owned in foreign hands.

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister John Gorton, travelling in Britain, once said:

Speaker: NA
Text: … it has seemed to me that the posture of Australia in seeking overseas capital has been the posture of a

Speaker: NA
Text: puppy lying on its back with all legs in the air and its stomach exposed saying please, please, please

Speaker: NA
Text: give us capital. Oh, tickle my tummy. On any conditions.

Speaker: NA
Text: While MCEwen and Gorton are long gone, their heirs are still here in this parliament in those

Speaker: NA
Text: who would prefer to fear-monger over foreign investment rather than acknowledge its

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits.

Speaker: NA
Text: On this side of the House, Labor has been strong in arguing for economic openness. As

Speaker: NA
Text: David Uren has noted, 'Labor has staked an even more liberal position than that espoused by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Liberals.' That was starkly on display when Archer Daniel Midlands made their bid for

Speaker: NA
Text: GrainCorp-a bid that those of us on this side of the House said, based on the publicly-

Speaker: NA
Text: available information, should have been broadly supported. But it was ultimately blocked by

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition Treasurer Hockey, making it the first major United States foreign investment bid to

Speaker: NA
Text: have been blocked.

Speaker: NA
Text: The coalition has also introduced significant amounts of red tape around Australia's foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: investment. Senator Wong has pointed out that when it came to the Foreign Acquisitions and

Speaker: NA
Text: Takeovers Legislation Amendment Bill 2015 the exposure draft and regulations accounted for

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: more than 170 pages and were accompanied by a 105-page explanatory guide. As one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: former Minister for Trade's own investments specialists pointed out:

Speaker: NA
Text: … the new fees have fuelled the narrative around Australia being a high-cost destination to invest in.

Speaker: NA
Text: What did the Office of Best Practice Regulation have to say about this?

Speaker: NA
Text: They admitted that this new red tape burden was being imposed last year without proper

Speaker: NA
Text: assessment and with the increased regulatory burden.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the government's proposals, we have 22 different screening thresholds and

Speaker: NA
Text: categories, which vary depending on the value and type of investment, and the nationality of

Speaker: NA
Text: the investor. When it comes to application fees, there are 33 different levels and categories of

Speaker: NA
Text: application fees, ranging from $5,000 to $100,000-a twentyfold difference in application

Speaker: NA
Text: fees. To take one straightforward example, we can look at the screening threshold differences

Speaker: NA
Text: for investments in agricultural land. For investment that comes from Chile, New Zealand and

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States, the screening threshold is $1,094 million; for investments from Singapore

Speaker: NA
Text: and Thailand-but with the caveat that the land is used wholly or exclusively for a primary

Speaker: NA
Text: production business-the screening threshold is $50 million. For investment in agricultural

Speaker: NA
Text: land coming from other countries, the screening threshold is $15 million.

Speaker: NA
Text: These differential screening thresholds have raised concerns among many. When the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Legislation Amendment Bill was released,

Speaker: NA
Text: it was criticised by the Business Council of Australia, the National Farmers' Federation, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Food and Grocery Council, the Queensland Farmers' Federation and the Chamber of

Speaker: NA
Text: Commerce and Industry of Western Australia. As the Business of Council of Australia noted:

Speaker: NA
Text: The government has declared that it is 'open for business', however its recent decisions have sent the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite message to potential international investors considering investing in the Australian agrifood

Speaker: NA
Text: sector.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those of us on this side of the House have no objections to new investment awards, but no-

Speaker: NA
Text: one is giving this government a gold medal for its investment policy, which has

Speaker: NA
Text: discriminatory screening thresholds applied inconsistently.

Speaker: NA
Text: We should note, too, that the government's approach to foreign investment in agricultural

Speaker: NA
Text: land has been ad hoc. The minister correctly noted that agriculture is a very small share of all

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign direct investment into Australia. As at the end of 2014, foreign direct investments into

Speaker: NA
Text: agriculture were just $1.3 billion out of a total of $688 billion of foreign direct investment-

Speaker: NA
Text: that is just 0.2 per cent of all foreign direct investment. By comparison, mining accounted for

Speaker: NA
Text: 39 per cent and manufacturing for 13 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: But concerns have been stoked over foreign investment into Australian agricultural land,

Speaker: NA
Text: chiefly by the member for New England who is, if anyone is, the heir to 'Black Jack' MCEwen

Speaker: NA
Text: in this chamber today. The minister promised that there would be a public register which

Speaker: NA
Text: would allow members of the public to see the location and size of agricultural properties with

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign ownership. He said it would be like a map of all properties 'to see who owns what'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Now the member for New England has changed his tune, saying that only the aggregated data

Speaker: NA
Text: for the new registry will be made public. To the extent that we have those data, the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Bureau of Statistics' Agricultural Land and Water Ownership Survey showed that 99 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australian farm businesses were fully Australian owned in 2013, that 88 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: farmland by area was Australian owned and that a further five per cent was majority

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian owned. This stands in contrast with the corporate sector, where Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: financial corporations are nearly 55 per cent foreign owned and non-financial corporations are

Speaker: NA
Text: over 40 per cent foreign owned. To take one example of a large multinational, the big

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian-BHP-has the majority of its shareholders overseas.

Speaker: NA
Text: The debate over foreign ownership of agricultural land needs to be grounded in facts, not

Speaker: NA
Text: fear. Labor supports an evidence based approach to this issue, but we are concerned when the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for New England seeks to make political capital from this issue. Indeed, his

Speaker: NA
Text: comments stand starkly in contrast to the more sober and considered statements from the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister in the chamber today.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the last election, Labor took a policy to the Australian electorate pledging to make

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia a more attractive destination for investors and to support jobs by liberalising

Speaker: NA
Text: screening thresholds for the farm and food sectors. We pledged that Labor would increase the

Speaker: NA
Text: screening threshold for investment in agricultural land to $50 million, non-cumulative,

Speaker: NA
Text: bringing all investors into line with the agricultural land threshold under the Howard

Speaker: NA
Text: government's trade agreements with Singapore and Thailand. We said that we would remove

Speaker: NA
Text: the agribusiness screening category, a reform that would put agribusiness on the same footing

Speaker: NA
Text: as other investors. We said that we would review the current system's discriminatory

Speaker: NA
Text: treatment of investments in non-sensitive sectors by investors from Singapore, Thailand and

Speaker: NA
Text: non-free trade agreement trading partners, as well as the treatment of agricultural land under

Speaker: NA
Text: the Foreign Investment Review Board's framework.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor supports the role of the Foreign Investment Review Board, established in 1972 in

Speaker: NA
Text: response to the then horrifying prospect that the Chiko Roll might be sold off to foreigners,

Speaker: NA
Text: but we do see it as important that our foreign investment screening process has more

Speaker: NA
Text: consistency to it, that it does not have discriminatory screening thresholds based on

Speaker: NA
Text: nationality.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the few minutes remaining to me, I cannot but respond to the minister's comments on

Speaker: NA
Text: company tax. It seems that, whatever the problem is that Australia faces, this government's

Speaker: NA
Text: response is to cut the company tax rate. As the member for Blaxland noted over the weekend,

Speaker: NA
Text: if you asked them what their solution was to the current woes of the Australian cricket team,

Speaker: NA
Text: they would probably say, 'Let's bring down the company tax rate.' But we have to compare

Speaker: NA
Text: our Australian company tax rate with the company tax rate in the largest economies of the

Speaker: NA
Text: world. In the United States, the corporate tax rate is 35 per cent. In Germany, the European

Speaker: NA
Text: Union's powerhouse, it is 29.65 per cent. In the top 10 economies in the world, the average

Speaker: NA
Text: corporate tax rate is 29 per cent. Here in Australia it is 28½ per cent for small businesses and

Speaker: NA
Text: 30 per cent for larger businesses. So, even without considering imputation, the corporate tax

Speaker: NA
Text: rate in Australia is comparable to the corporate tax rate in the largest economies in the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yes, there have been suggestions that, under President-elect Trump, the United States

Speaker: NA
Text: might cut its corporate tax rate. But does Australia really want to be going down the road of

Speaker: NA
Text: Trumponomics? Do we really want to get into the prospect of following a tax plan which,

Speaker: NA
Text: according to independent experts, could add between $5 trillion and $10 trillion to debt in the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States?

Speaker: NA
Text: Here in Australia we have had debt rising rapidly under the coalition. Since the coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: won office, debt has risen by over $100 billion-more than $5,000 for every man, woman and

Speaker: NA
Text: child in Australia. The rate of increase in Australia's debt has been more rapid under the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Abbott-Turnbull governments than it was under the Rudd and Gillard governments. Under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Rudd and Gillard governments, Australian debt rose on average by $4.5 billion per month. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, that debt was taken on largely in order to address the global financial crisis, the largest

Speaker: NA
Text: downturn since the Great Depression. Every serious commentator accepted that Australia had

Speaker: NA
Text: to take on debt, because after all we were only left with razor-thin surpluses from the Howard

Speaker: NA
Text: years. All serious commentators-and I think it was even accepted by sensible people in the

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition at the time-knew that Australia needed to take on debt to deal with the global

Speaker: NA
Text: financial crisis.

Speaker: NA
Text: But, since the coalition has taken over office, in a period in which we did not have a global

Speaker: NA
Text: financial crisis, debt has risen at a rate of $4.9 billion per month. That is right: the rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in Australia's debt has been more rapid under the Abbott-Turnbull governments with

Speaker: NA
Text: no global financial crisis than it was under Labor with a global financial crisis. So now is

Speaker: NA
Text: surely not the time to talk about a massive corporate tax giveaway, a $50 billion corporate tax

Speaker: NA
Text: cut, at a time when Australia's headline company tax rate is in line with the largest 10

Speaker: NA
Text: economies in the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, no serious conversation about company tax can proceed with acknowledging

Speaker: NA
Text: that we have dividend imputation, a system shared only with New Zealand in the OECD,

Speaker: NA
Text: which ensures that we give about a third of the company tax revenue back through the

Speaker: NA
Text: personal income tax system. A 30 per cent company tax rate with imputation raises about as

Speaker: NA
Text: much revenue as a 20 per cent company tax rate without imputation. So, from a fiscal

Speaker: NA
Text: perspective, Australia's headline corporation tax rate for large companies of 30 per cent ought

Speaker: NA
Text: to be compared to other countries that have a 20 per cent tax rate without imputation. This

Speaker: NA
Text: point is often either ignored or deliberately left off the table when people are comparing

Speaker: NA
Text: company tax rates. But to do so is deeply misleading and ignores the impact on the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: So, in conclusion, Labor concurs with the coalition about the value of foreign investment in

Speaker: NA
Text: creating jobs, raising productivity, ensuring that we have more competition and lower prices.

Speaker: NA
Text: But we do believe that the coalition has presided over a fall in inbound investment and that

Speaker: NA
Text: that fall in inbound investment can be traced in part to the hodgepodge of restrictive rules that

Speaker: NA
Text: have been placed around foreign investment, to the discriminatory screening thresholds and to

Speaker: NA
Text: this government's willingness to play footsy with the extremists who want to scaremonger

Speaker: NA
Text: over a foreign investment.

Speaker: NA
Text: The debate over foreign investment needs to be conducted soberly and sensibly,

Speaker: NA
Text: recognising its historic benefits to Australia and recognising that, through a sensible system of

Speaker: NA
Text: screening under the Foreign Investment Review Board, foreign investment can be of benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Australian economy over the long run.

Speaker: Mr CIOBO
Text: Moncrieff-Minister for Trade, Tourism and Investment) (10:41): I present

Speaker: NA
Text: a copy of my ministerial statement. I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House take note of the document.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: Reference to Federation Chamber

Speaker: Mr CIOBO
Text: Moncrieff-Minister for Trade, Tourism and Investment) (10:41): by

Speaker: NA
Text: leave-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: That the order of the day be referred to the Federation Chamber for debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: BILLS

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Jobs Path: Prepare, Trial, Hire)

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill 2016

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Consideration resumed of the motion:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: to which the following amendment was moved:

Speaker: NA
Text: That all the words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

Speaker: NA
Text: "Whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House notes that the Turnbull

Speaker: NA
Text: Government cannot guarantee that, under Youth Jobs PaTH (Prepare, Trial, Hire):

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) jobs will not be displaced by cheaper labour;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) wages will not be undercut and some participants will be paid below minimum award wages;

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) participants' safety will not be compromised and that adequate insurance arrangements will be

Speaker: NA
Text: provided;

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) participants won't be used to help businesses sidestep unfair dismissal protections; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) it will prioritise using small to medium enterprises in PaTH because they have a demonstrated

Speaker: NA
Text: track record of employing more job seekers through the jobactive programme".

Speaker: Mr BANDT
Text: Melbourne) (10:42): Right now, young people are getting screwed. Year

Speaker: NA
Text: after year, successive Labor and Liberal governments have been making life harder for young

Speaker: NA
Text: people. They have managed the economy in the interests of the few, instead of in the interests

Speaker: NA
Text: of everyone. And it is getting harder and harder for young people to get a job, as youth

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment is high, and it has doubled over the general unemployment rate. The jobs that

Speaker: NA
Text: young people often do get are very highly insecure and often not well paid at all.

Speaker: NA
Text: Study is getting less and less affordable, because university and TAFE are getting more

Speaker: NA
Text: expensive. The dream of owning your own home is getting further and further out of reach,

Speaker: NA
Text: with Australian house prices skyrocketing and incomes stagnant. Yet the government is not

Speaker: NA
Text: doing anything about this. In fact, if the government has its way the problem for young people

Speaker: NA
Text: will get much, much worse. If right now young people are getting screwed, if the government

Speaker: NA
Text: gets its plans through they will be right royally stuffed.
