Speaker: NA
Text: Let's have a look at the current situation. Youth unemployment is at nearly 13 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is more than double the general national rate. An Anglicare report that was recently

Speaker: NA
Text: released found that only one job is advertised for every six low-skilled jobseekers, who are

Speaker: NA
Text: often young people who have not had the opportunity to gain much work experience. Getting

Speaker: NA
Text: a job can be even harder for people living in a regional area or for people from non-English

Speaker: NA
Text: speaking backgrounds. Young people in Melbourne have told me that if they put 'Mohammed'

Speaker: NA
Text: in their CV and they send off their job application, they hear nothing; but when they change

Speaker: NA
Text: their name to 'David', the phone starts ringing.

Speaker: NA
Text: And increasingly there are fewer entry level jobs available for young people, making it

Speaker: NA
Text: harder for young people to get their foot in the door, to build their skills and experience, to

Speaker: NA
Text: establish a career, to gain independence, and to plan and progress their lives. The youth

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment rate is always higher than the general unemployment rate, and in some

Speaker: NA
Text: respects that makes sense; young people are, as a whole, doing other things, whereas older

Speaker: NA
Text: people tend to be more likely to look for work.

Speaker: NA
Text: What we also know, as a general historical trend, is that every time there is an economic

Speaker: NA
Text: downturn, we strike hard times or there is a recession young people are hardest hit first. The

Speaker: NA
Text: lines of the youth unemployment rate and the general unemployment rate diverge when we

Speaker: NA
Text: reach hard times, and it becomes proportionately harder for young people to find work. The

Speaker: NA
Text: youth unemployment rate for them skyrockets. What we have also found historically over

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's history is that those two lines, after a year or so, tend to converge again and it

Speaker: NA
Text: becomes easier for young people to find work. Since the GFC that has not happened in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. For young people the line has stayed higher. Since the GFC it has become harder

Speaker: NA
Text: proportionately than at any other time in history for young people to get back into work. The

Speaker: NA
Text: entry-level jobs since the GFC are disappearing. Those jobs that you might walk into straight

Speaker: NA
Text: out of school or that you might walk into if you do not finish school are disappearing. The

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs that this government wants young people to get just are not being created any more in the

Speaker: NA
Text: way that they used to, and it is a national crisis.

Speaker: NA
Text: So what is this government's response? Rather than listening to expert advice on how to

Speaker: NA
Text: tackle youth unemployment or invest in new industries that might create those jobs for the

Speaker: NA
Text: future, the Liberals have taken it upon themselves to be every young Australian's tough

Speaker: NA
Text: parent, serving up some tough love by telling them to pull themselves up by their bootstraps

Speaker: NA
Text: and earn or learn. Their first plan was to kick young people off Newstart, which is itself so

Speaker: NA
Text: low that it is below the poverty line and is a barrier to people finding work, because you do

Speaker: NA
Text: not have that money to invest in yourself-to get some training, to buy the new clothes for the

Speaker: NA
Text: job interview, to even get a haircut. Their first plan was to kick people off Newstart and make

Speaker: NA
Text: them wait six weeks before they can receive this measly payment to try and support

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves. Luckily, the Senate took a stand for young people and refused to pass this

Speaker: NA
Text: ridiculous measure. Yet, the Liberals are refusing to listen, saying they only want to make

Speaker: NA
Text: young people wait four weeks before they can get Newstart. Well, four weeks-the landlord

Speaker: NA
Text: does not care that you do not have money coming from the government to pay the rent, the

Speaker: NA
Text: public transport does not care that you do not have money because it is the government's fault.

Speaker: NA
Text: But the government's approach is still to say, 'Well, we'll deal with the national youth

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment crisis by making life tougher for young people.'

Speaker: NA
Text: At the same time the government wants to make learning more expensive, less accessible

Speaker: NA
Text: and more exclusive by cutting support for students and deregulating our universities-a move

Speaker: NA
Text: that experts have warned could see the creation of US-style $100,000 degrees. So it is harder

Speaker: NA
Text: to earn by getting a job because, under this government and since the GFC, the jobs are not

Speaker: NA
Text: there in the same way, it is more expensive to try and learn, and even if you are lucky enough

Speaker: NA
Text: to get a job and to keep it and to earn an income, owning your home is becoming a

Speaker: NA
Text: pipedream.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 1990 house prices were approximately six times a young person's income. In 2013 that

Speaker: NA
Text: had doubled to approximately 12 times a young person's income. It is not the fault of smashed

Speaker: NA
Text: avocados that housing is becoming increasingly unaffordable for people. Even if you find a

Speaker: NA
Text: job and even if you find a secure job-which is pretty tough to do these days-the ratio of

Speaker: NA
Text: your income to house prices is just skyrocketing. And that has happened under the watch of

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal and Labor. The old parties' policies of allowing negative gearing to happen and the

Speaker: NA
Text: capital gains tax discount to continue turned housing into an unproductive investment class,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it caused an explosion in house prices, meaning that overwhelmingly the only people who

Speaker: NA
Text: could afford to buy a house are those who already have one.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government should be making it easier for people to buy their first home not helping

Speaker: NA
Text: people who already have one to buy their second, third or fourth. The Grattan Institute found

Speaker: NA
Text: that under these and other government policies real wealth held by older households from

Speaker: NA
Text: 2003 through to 2012 grew by $215,000, but for younger households it went backwards. In

Speaker: NA
Text: 1994 young households had nearly 10 percent of the country's wealth, but by 2014 that had

Speaker: NA
Text: effectively halved to 5.5 per cent. So over 20 years young people went from having 10 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of the country's wealth to having about five per cent. At the same time it dramatically

Speaker: NA
Text: increased for older generations. This is why young people are getting screwed: successive

Speaker: NA
Text: governments have worked against them, dealing them an increasingly bad hand and growing

Speaker: NA
Text: intergenerational inequality. Governments have allowed the economy to run rampant and to

Speaker: NA
Text: screw young people.

Speaker: NA
Text: The good news is that as a society we are becoming more and more aware of just how

Speaker: NA
Text: much young people are getting screwed. Academics, think tanks and civil society

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations are all pointing out how the odds are no longer in young people's favour and

Speaker: NA
Text: how, under Liberal and Labor, we may be creating a situation where we are leaving the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy and household budgets and the planet worse off for generations that come after us

Speaker: NA
Text: rather than better. But the bad news is that the government are refusing to look at the bigger

Speaker: NA
Text: picture and are refusing to listen. They are being the unreasonable parent instead of listening

Speaker: NA
Text: to their children or experts, having blind faith that they know what is best-that is, to make

Speaker: NA
Text: people work for either nothing or next to nothing. If it were a lesson on safe sex, this is a

Speaker: NA
Text: government that would be pushing abstinence not condoms. If it were a lesson on good

Speaker: NA
Text: behaviour, this is a government that would be sending young people to their rooms rather than

Speaker: NA
Text: talking the issue through.

Speaker: NA
Text: Instead of working systematically to even the odds and deliver a better deal for young

Speaker: NA
Text: people, on budget night this year the Liberals unveiled their master plan for getting young

Speaker: NA
Text: people a job-this Prepare, Trial, Hire scheme. What it really meant, though, was that earn or

Speaker: NA
Text: learn became burn and churn. Essentially, this government's plan to tackle high youth

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment and help young people get a job is to lure them to work for below the

Speaker: NA
Text: minimum wage. The Liberals' plan will not provide secure and meaningful work for the

Speaker: NA
Text: hundreds of thousands of young people who are unemployed. What will do is drive down

Speaker: NA
Text: wages for other workers and see employers burn and churn through young people. In fact, it

Speaker: NA
Text: could see people currently working in these roles kicked out in favour of free money and

Speaker: NA
Text: labour, courtesy of the government. Under the program being enabled by this bill, by not

Speaker: NA
Text: having to hire someone at the usual wage employers could bank more per week than the

Speaker: NA
Text: young people who are supposedly going to get a job. In other words, this scheme will allow

Speaker: NA
Text: employers, on the public purse, to take home more money than the young people who are

Speaker: NA
Text: going to be forced to work under it. The Greens do not accept that to get young people into

Speaker: NA
Text: work they need to be paid as little as $4 an hour, which is well below the minimum wage.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is what this scheme is about.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Following the government's unveiling of this flagship program, the Secretary of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Council of Trade Unions said 'this internship program is a path to nowhere' and

Speaker: NA
Text: 'gives business access to free, exploitable workers'. He asked:

Speaker: NA
Text: Why would a business employ a minimum wage or lower paid worker when the government is ready to

Speaker: NA
Text: supply them with free labour and a $1000 handout?

Speaker: NA
Text: He pointed out that these internships could include low-skilled work such as work in

Speaker: NA
Text: supermarkets, which is not a plan to create real, lasting jobs. It is simply substituting existing

Speaker: NA
Text: low-paid labour with even cheaper, government subsidised labour rather than creating new

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us be clear about this: internships, if they are structured correctly, can be a good thing.

Speaker: NA
Text: They can provide opportunities for young people to learn and build their skills. We have had

Speaker: NA
Text: internships for a very long time. Every political party in this place, I am sure, offers

Speaker: NA
Text: internships. Community groups offer internships. Organisations like community groups and

Speaker: NA
Text: political parties thrive on getting young people involved, but when we do it-and I speak here

Speaker: NA
Text: on behalf of the Greens-we do not offer out hope to people that this is some pathway to

Speaker: NA
Text: secure employment; it is about you and increasing your skills. You are not here doing

Speaker: NA
Text: government subsidised work where you are required to turn up at a particular time and clock

Speaker: NA
Text: off at a particular time. It is not a false job-because that is not what an internship is or should

Speaker: NA
Text: be. But when you ask people, as the government is doing under this program, to clock on and

Speaker: NA
Text: clock off and get the equivalent of $4 an hour while they hold out hope of a secure job, and

Speaker: NA
Text: you pay employers $1,000 from the public purse to put them on and displace other workers,

Speaker: NA
Text: that is not a scheme to create lasting employment.

Speaker: NA
Text: The simple fact is this: this is a flawed plan dreamt up in isolation by a government that

Speaker: NA
Text: thinks it knows best, but it will not help people find secure long-term work. In fact, it could

Speaker: NA
Text: just see handouts to business to force young people to work for below the minimum wage and

Speaker: NA
Text: potentially force people from a job who are currently working in these roles. There is nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: in this bill that provides protection for someone currently working in a low-paid job from

Speaker: NA
Text: being forced out of that job by this new scheme so that government subsidised cheap labour

Speaker: NA
Text: can come in instead.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have to take action to help make life easier for young people. That means tackling

Speaker: NA
Text: rising job insecurity and tackling housing unaffordability, but this program will not do that. If

Speaker: NA
Text: we were serious, we would be investing in education. We would be investing in big job-

Speaker: NA
Text: creating projects that will provide secure work for young people-like public transport and

Speaker: NA
Text: clean energy. We would be making it easier for people to get into education and complete it

Speaker: NA
Text: and we would end the unfair tax breaks that are pushing up the cost of housing and pricing

Speaker: NA
Text: young people out of the market. And we have to do it now because otherwise we run the risk

Speaker: NA
Text: of locking an entire generation out of secure work and locking an entire generation out of

Speaker: NA
Text: owning their own home.

Speaker: Ms HENDERSON
Text: Corangamite) (10:56): It is my great pleasure to rise and speak on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Jobs Path: Prepare, Trial, Hire) Bill 2016.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill gives effect to the Youth Jobs PaTH measure announced in the 2016-17 budget as

Speaker: NA
Text: part of our youth employment package. Very proudly, our government announced this very

Speaker: NA
Text: significant package-an $840 million package to tackle youth unemployment in our country.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: That is in contrast to members opposite, from whom we saw no national initiatives to combat

Speaker: NA
Text: what we recognise is a very significant issue across our nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Youth Jobs PaTH program is aimed at maximising the chance of young jobseekers

Speaker: NA
Text: obtaining a job and moving off income support. It will do this in a number of ways, through a

Speaker: NA
Text: very significant investment of three-quarters of a billion dollars, and help some 120,000

Speaker: NA
Text: people over four years. It will do that by getting up to 30,000 eligible young jobseekers per

Speaker: NA
Text: year ready. It will prepare them and provide them with employability skills training from 1

Speaker: NA
Text: April 2017. It will give young people a go while trialling them by providing an internship

Speaker: NA
Text: supported by a youth bonus wage subsidy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later hour, following the

Speaker: NA
Text: statement by the Prime Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: Leave granted.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS

Speaker: NA
Text: National Security

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Wentworth-Prime Minister) (10:58): by leave-I returned yesterday

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation leaders summit in Peru. While APEC is a

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting where issues of trade and economic integration dominate, all of the leaders of

Speaker: NA
Text: economies great and small understand the threat that terrorism poses to our security and,

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed, to the relative peace in our region, which has itself been the foundation for the

Speaker: NA
Text: economic growth on which our futures and those of our children depend.

Speaker: NA
Text: In discussions with the leaders of the United States, China, Canada, Malaysia, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Philippines, Japan and others, cooperation on counterterrorism was a focus of attention.

Speaker: NA
Text: Few places in the world are unaffected by terrorism-whether it is returning foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: fighters or home-grown terrorists.

Speaker: NA
Text: Today I assure the House and the Australian people of my government's steadfast

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to ensuring Australians remain safe, secure and free.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's starting point is a stronger foundation than most other nations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our strengths are our freedom, our diversity, our security.

Speaker: NA
Text: These attributes are not mutually exclusive; rather they are mutually reinforcing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Security is a prerequisite to the trust and confidence that allows a diverse and free society

Speaker: NA
Text: to flourish.

Speaker: NA
Text: But we do face real challenges. And we must be open to them and learn lessons from

Speaker: NA
Text: events at home and abroad in order to deal with them.

Speaker: NA
Text: We must be clear-eyed and hard-headed as we assess the evolving threat.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no bliss in ignorance and no comfort in complacency.

Speaker: NA
Text: Recent terror attacks in Nice, Baghdad, Brussels, Quetta, Orlando, Kabul, Jakarta and

Speaker: NA
Text: elsewhere remind us that terrorism is a global challenge that affects us all.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is why a critical part of our strategy is to engage internationally and to contribute to

Speaker: NA
Text: global counterterrorism efforts.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Nowhere is this engagement more important than in South-East Asia.

Speaker: NA
Text: This region and its people are part of the fabric that shapes and defines the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: community and our national identity. But the rising influence in our region of terrorist

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations, such as ISIL or Daesh, demands the attention and the action of Australia and its

Speaker: NA
Text: neighbours.

Speaker: NA
Text: Daesh's insidious influence was demonstrated by terrorist attacks in Jakarta on 14 January,

Speaker: NA
Text: and again in the attack on Indonesian police on the outskirts of Jakarta on 20 October.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I told the House in my counterterrorism update on 1 September, the next mass-casualty

Speaker: NA
Text: attack on Australian victims could be somewhere in South-East Asia, where Daesh

Speaker: NA
Text: propaganda has galvanised existing networks of extremists, preyed on vulnerable young

Speaker: NA
Text: people and attracted new recruits.

Speaker: NA
Text: In response, my government, alongside key partners in our region, is at the forefront of

Speaker: NA
Text: regional efforts to combat terrorism and counter the destructive narratives of violent Islamic

Speaker: NA
Text: extremism.

Speaker: NA
Text: No one country can fight terrorism on its own.

Speaker: NA
Text: And over the past decade, we have built closer diplomatic and security relationships with

Speaker: NA
Text: our neighbours, including Indonesia, the Philippines, Malaysia, Thailand and Singapore.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is in this context that we continue to contribute to the global fight against Daesh and

Speaker: NA
Text: other terrorist organisations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Daesh's control of territory and resources in Iraq and Syria boost its ability to promote

Speaker: NA
Text: virulently anti-Western ideology and inspire terrorist attacks internationally.

Speaker: NA
Text: Only last week we saw Daesh's latest propaganda, which used footage of Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: locations and Australian icons in a call for further attacks against the West.

Speaker: NA
Text: Daesh will continue doing this in an attempt to intimidate us.

Speaker: NA
Text: But they will not succeed.

Speaker: NA
Text: My government and our agencies are committed to decisive action to combat and defeat

Speaker: NA
Text: Daesh through the United States-led coalition in the Middle East.

Speaker: NA
Text: In this fight, as with virtually every other significant security challenge facing our country,

Speaker: NA
Text: our alliance with the United States is the foundation of our national security architecture.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's trusted solidarity with the United States is based on mutual respect-we and we

Speaker: NA
Text: alone determine whether and how our forces are put in harm's way-but the closeness of our

Speaker: NA
Text: relationship ensures that no ally has more influence than we do.

Speaker: NA
Text: That influence is one which is highly valued now and in the future as President Obama

Speaker: NA
Text: reminded us in Lima on Sunday.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those who assert that our ties and our alliance with the United States should be

Speaker: NA
Text: reconsidered fail to recognise that a strong, trusted, forthright Australia is a powerful force for

Speaker: NA
Text: good whether it is on the fields of conflict or in the corridors of power in Washington.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact is that the United States remains our most important strategic and defence ally.

Speaker: NA
Text: This was on display only last week when I took part in the first Australian flight of the new

Speaker: NA
Text: P-8A Poseidon aircraft-developed between Australia and the United States Navy.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: And in relation to counterterrorism cooperation, our collaborative screening of refugees

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Syrian and Iraqi conflicts has identified 22 persons of national security concern.

Speaker: NA
Text: Right now, Iraqi defence forces, including units trained by the Australian Army, are

Speaker: NA
Text: making real progress in the liberation of Mosul from Daesh.

Speaker: NA
Text: The contribution of the ADF to the defence of Iraq, working with the United States and

Speaker: NA
Text: other coalition forces, has been critically important-as has been acknowledged by President

Speaker: NA
Text: Obama and indeed by the Prime Minister of Iraq itself.

Speaker: NA
Text: Daesh is under increasing pressure. It is losing territory, finance and fighters.

Speaker: NA
Text: Its so-called caliphate and its illusion of invincibility are being shattered.

Speaker: NA
Text: But as Daesh loses ground, many hundreds of foreign fighters in Syria and Iraq may seek

Speaker: NA
Text: to return to their countries of origin, including in our region-especially Indonesia, Malaysia,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Philippines as well as Australia itself.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our law enforcement and security agencies have long been prepared for this challenge and

Speaker: NA
Text: are constantly monitoring for any shift in the threat environment ahead.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indeed, we have seen in recent weeks three individuals charged with foreign incursion

Speaker: NA
Text: offences.

Speaker: NA
Text: These latest arrests bring to 55 the number of people charged from 24 counterterrorism

Speaker: NA
Text: operations around Australia since September 2014. The acts of terror we have witnessed

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrate that the international security environment has flow-on effects for Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: domestic threat environment.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Director-General of Security has informed me that he has reviewed the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Terrorism Threat Level and that it remains unchanged at probable.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have been at this elevated level of threat since September 2014, in which time we have

Speaker: NA
Text: experienced four attacks and 11 successful major disruptions.

Speaker: NA
Text: And despite Daesh's heavy territorial losses in Iraq and Syria, we do not expect this threat

Speaker: NA
Text: to diminish for some time. If anything, the threat has become more dispersed and new

Speaker: NA
Text: challenges are emerging.

Speaker: NA
Text: Increasingly widespread use of encrypted communication platforms makes the detection

Speaker: NA
Text: and interception of terrorist communications far more difficult.

Speaker: NA
Text: Human intelligence, and the strong relationships and trust on which it depends, are more

Speaker: NA
Text: important than ever.

Speaker: NA
Text: Around the world, the increase of attacks by lone actors, who are by their very nature so

Speaker: NA
Text: much harder to detect, presents new challenges for disruption and deterrence by our security

Speaker: NA
Text: and law enforcement agencies.

Speaker: NA
Text: The truck attack in Nice highlighted just how devastating an attack by a single perpetrator

Speaker: NA
Text: can be.

Speaker: NA
Text: To ensure Australia is best placed to respond to the evolving global threat environment,

Speaker: NA
Text: and immediately following the Nice attack, in July I requested the Commonwealth's Counter-

Speaker: NA
Text: Terrorism Coordinator to review the lessons from recent terrorist attacks overseas and

Speaker: NA
Text: specifically the threat from lone actors.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: While the full review will remain classified, I am pleased to be able to report it found

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia already has robust legislative, policy and operational arrangements in place to

Speaker: NA
Text: protect us from those threats. However, it also identified some areas requiring further work.

Speaker: NA
Text: A key finding was the need to continue working on how to best protect public places.

Speaker: NA
Text: I can confirm that in response to the review, we have committed, as a priority, to develop a

Speaker: NA
Text: national strategy for places of mass gathering, including a nationally consistent approach to

Speaker: NA
Text: risk assessment for such places.

Speaker: NA
Text: The review also confirmed there are a diverse range of factors that could make someone

Speaker: NA
Text: vulnerable to radicalisation, from mental health issues to a history of criminality.

Speaker: NA
Text: The review found that such factors might increase the vulnerability of lone actors to the

Speaker: NA
Text: propaganda of terrorist organisations offering them some perverse sense of inclusion.

Speaker: NA
Text: So we need to better support our frontline professionals including health professionals, to

Speaker: NA
Text: respond to Australians who may be at risk of radicalising towards violent extremism.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have therefore asked our agencies, the Attorney-General, the Minister for Health and

Speaker: NA
Text: Ageing and the minister assisting me on counterterrorism to work with the states and

Speaker: NA
Text: territories, peak bodies, international partners and the community to identify what more can

Speaker: NA
Text: be done in this area to help both carers and patients, taking great care we do not stigmatise

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the most vulnerable people in our communities.

Speaker: NA
Text: In relation to the nexus between criminality and terrorism, a pilot of the National Criminal

Speaker: NA
Text: Intelligence System now underway in the Australian Criminal Intelligence Commission will

Speaker: NA
Text: allow us to better understand this correlation and identify threats.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is clear from the review that our international partners face very similar challenges.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the key issues some international partners are addressing is the role played by their

Speaker: NA
Text: defence forces in domestic counterterrorism arrangements.

Speaker: NA
Text: In Australia, a review is already underway to examine the support Defence provides to

Speaker: NA
Text: domestic counterterrorism operations, looking at both the legislative framework and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Defence Force posture and capability in view of the current threat environment.

Speaker: NA
Text: The evolution of terrorism since 9/11, the adaptability of terrorist groups like Daesh and

Speaker: NA
Text: the insidious allure this group has held for too many often very young and vulnerable

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians, should put each and every one of us in this House in no doubt that to defeat them

Speaker: NA
Text: we also must adapt.

Speaker: NA
Text: And it has been the coalition government that has acted proactively to the challenge of the

Speaker: NA
Text: threat posed by Daesh.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have increased our counterterrorism funding by $1.5 billion since September 2014.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our counterterrorism laws are designed to be the most robust and proportionate response

Speaker: NA
Text: possible in the current threat environment.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government has shown it is willing and agile enough to amend these laws to

Speaker: NA
Text: sufficiently empower those agencies that are responsible for keeping us safe.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the past year alone we have introduced three vitally important bills.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: The amendments to the Commonwealth Criminal Code introduced in October will

Speaker: NA
Text: empower our military to target and kill a broader range of Daesh operatives, consistent with

Speaker: NA
Text: international law.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill applies to ADF operations to fight Daesh in theatre - including our airstrikes in

Speaker: NA
Text: support of the liberation of Mosul.

Speaker: NA
Text: Less well known, but of increasing importance, is that this fight against Daesh is also

Speaker: NA
Text: conducted through cyberspace.

Speaker: NA
Text: Now when I launched Australia's Cyber Security Strategy in April I acknowledged our

Speaker: NA
Text: nation's offensive cyber capabilities.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those capabilities are housed within the Australian Signals Directorate and they provide us

Speaker: NA
Text: with a capacity to deter and respond to cyber-attacks against Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: These same capabilities also have important military applications, including in support of

Speaker: NA
Text: Coalition operations against Daesh in Iraq and Syria.

Speaker: NA
Text: While I won't, for obvious reasons, go into the details of these operations, I can say that

Speaker: NA
Text: they are being used, that they are making a real difference in the military conflict, and that all

Speaker: NA
Text: offensive cyber activities in support of the ADF and our allies are subject to the same rules of

Speaker: NA
Text: engagement which govern the use of our other military capabilities in Iraq and Syria, such as

Speaker: NA
Text: our FA18 Hornets.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Signals Directorate's support for these operations is subject to stringent

Speaker: NA
Text: legal oversight and is consistent with our support for the international rules-based order and

Speaker: NA
Text: our obligations under international law.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is just another example of our partnership with the United States, and is of critical

Speaker: NA
Text: importance to global, regional and domestic security.

Speaker: NA
Text: We've also introduced the Counter-Terrorism Legislation Amendment Bill 2016 to allow,

Speaker: NA
Text: among other things, control orders to be placed on persons 14 years or older with appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: safeguards.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a sad reality that young people are being drawn to this violent ideology.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ideally we want to stop them getting to this point in the first place. And on most occasions,

Speaker: NA
Text: the work of families, communities, law enforcement and other agencies ensures people are

Speaker: NA
Text: turned away from radicalisation.

Speaker: NA
Text: But it is the government's, and the parliament's, responsibility, to do what we can to

Speaker: NA
Text: mitigate and manage these risks by ensuring the necessary measures are in place.

Speaker: NA
Text: The third bill is the Criminal Code Amendment (High Risk Terrorist Offenders) Bill 2016,

Speaker: NA
Text: which creates a new regime to allow for the ongoing detention of high risk terrorist offenders

Speaker: NA
Text: who are approaching the end of their custodial sentences but continue to pose an unacceptable

Speaker: NA
Text: risk of committing a serious terrorism offence if released.

Speaker: NA
Text: The third bill is the Criminal Code Amendment (High Risk Terrorist Offenders) Bill 2016,

Speaker: NA
Text: which creates a new regime to allow for the ongoing detention of high-risk terrorist offenders

Speaker: NA
Text: who are approaching the end of their custodial sentences but continue to pose an unacceptable

Speaker: NA
Text: risk of committing a serious terrorism offence if released.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to thank the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Intelligence and Security, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: leadership of its chair, the member for Deakin, for its careful consideration of these bills and

Speaker: NA
Text: its recommendation that they be passed.

Speaker: NA
Text: These laws are part of my government's ongoing reform to Australia's national security

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation. And this started in 2014 and continues to provide our agencies with the tools they

Speaker: NA
Text: need in an ever-changing security environment, and provides the public with the confidence

Speaker: NA
Text: that they can safely go about their daily lives.

Speaker: NA
Text: From the time we came into government in 2013, the coalition has understood the evolving

Speaker: NA
Text: nature of the threat that terrorism poses and has been as adaptive and as agile in its response

Speaker: NA
Text: as the people who seek to do us so much harm.

Speaker: NA
Text: Above all else, the most effective defence against terrorism is to prevent people from

Speaker: NA
Text: becoming terrorists in the first place. All levels of government and communities must

Speaker: NA
Text: continue working together to help prevent people from being drawn to violent extremism,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly to prevent the radicalisation of our young people-to stop terrorists stealing our

Speaker: NA
Text: children's futures.

Speaker: NA
Text: Continuing to build on our inclusive society where everyone has a place is vital.

Speaker: NA
Text: Countering violent extremism is a shared effort, of course, with the states and territories and it

Speaker: NA
Text: will be reported on and considered at the upcoming Council of Australian Governments

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting on 9 December.

Speaker: NA
Text: Terrorist groups seek to identify weakness and vulnerability and to drive and exploit fear

Speaker: NA
Text: and division. Actions and behaviours that target particular sections in society merely play into

Speaker: NA
Text: their hands. We are one of the most successful multicultural societies in the world-from the

Speaker: NA
Text: oldest human cultures of our First Australians, to the newborn baby in the arms of its

Speaker: NA
Text: immigrant mother. We are stronger because of our diversity.

Speaker: NA
Text: But this does not mean we should be blind to, or ignorant of, the challenges our society

Speaker: NA
Text: face. When we see extremist behaviour, it should be called out for what it is. And when we

Speaker: NA
Text: see vulnerability it should be addressed

Speaker: NA
Text: by all Australians; by government; by business; by community.

Speaker: NA
Text: We all have a stake in this. For it is the combination of our national attributes of security,

Speaker: NA
Text: diversity, freedom and the prosperity which they enable that make us best placed as a society

Speaker: NA
Text: to unite against terrorism and violent extremism.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I have said many times, the glue that holds us together is mutual respect-the

Speaker: NA
Text: recognition that each of us is entitled to the same respect, dignity, and opportunities.

Speaker: NA
Text: And as we look forward to this Christmas season, I can assure the House that my

Speaker: NA
Text: government is taking every action possible to keep Australians and their families safe, secure

Speaker: NA
Text: and free.

Speaker: Mr SHORTEN
Text: Maribyrnong-Leader of the Opposition) (11:18): I thank the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for updating the House. We welcome the fact that the Commonwealth Counter-

Speaker: NA
Text: Terrorism Coordinator has concluded his report on the recent dreadful overseas attacks and

Speaker: NA
Text: the lessons that we can learn. We hope that the government will brief us very soon on this

Speaker: NA
Text: report. Labor will support the review into the way defence and domestic counterterrorism

Speaker: NA
Text: operations work together. I think there is merit, in particular, in looking at whether the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: existing processes around the call-out of the Defence Force for domestic terrorist incidents is

Speaker: NA
Text: strong enough in the current threat environment.

Speaker: NA
Text: This parliament works best when leaders on both sides cooperate and communicate on

Speaker: NA
Text: important issues such as this. I would like to briefly acknowledge former Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: Abbott for consistently striving to keep me and Labor informed about national security. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Labor Party fully understands and appreciates the importance of cybersecurity to

Speaker: NA
Text: our national security. While there are many issues that can divide this parliament, often very

Speaker: NA
Text: deeply, all of us in this place, on all sides, share a common determination to keep Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: safe. We are all committed to ensuring our people, our institutions and, indeed, our

Speaker: NA
Text: commercial enterprises are protected by the most up-to-date technology. We are all

Speaker: NA
Text: committed to providing the best possible assistance to the men and women of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence Force, who have put themselves in harm's way in our country's name.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a century since Australians fought and fell on the Western Front, but there can be no

Speaker: NA
Text: question that the face of global conflict has dramatically changed, and changed exponentially,

Speaker: NA
Text: in recent years. But the courage of those who serve our nation endures. Our respect for their

Speaker: NA
Text: bravery, professionalism and skill is at the very heart of who we are as Australians and what

Speaker: NA
Text: we admire about Australians, as is the important regard in which we hold our security

Speaker: NA
Text: agencies and our intelligence community. When they seek our support, when they need our

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to modernisation, we should be prepared to do what it takes to keep people safe.

Speaker: NA
Text: The ultimate defeat of Daesh is a shared goal of all of those who believe in peace. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: years since this conflict began, we have learned not to underestimate their resilience or their

Speaker: NA
Text: adaptability. In fact, if we have learned anything about Daesh, it is that they will use every

Speaker: NA
Text: tool at their disposal-every weapon in their arsenal-to spread hatred, to encourage violence

Speaker: NA
Text: and to destroy innocent lives. Preventing this, combating terrorism and defeating extremism

Speaker: NA
Text: means meeting Daesh on every front, whether it is providing air support and training in Iraq

Speaker: NA
Text: or disrupting cyber operations-not just defensively, but offensively-ensuring we have, and

Speaker: NA
Text: use, the ability to silence the dreadful extremist propaganda and deprive them of resources

Speaker: NA
Text: and information.

Speaker: NA
Text: Improving our cybersecurity is equally important in protecting Australia's government and

Speaker: NA
Text: non-government agencies and institutions from digital attacks. In the past year alone, we have

Speaker: NA
Text: seen Austrade, the Bureau of Meteorology and the Department of Defence targeted. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: seen large-scale attacks and initiatives carried out around the world; perhaps, most noticeably,

Speaker: NA
Text: in the United States. Increased connectivity with the world through the internet for our

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses and communities is outstanding. It is one of the defining forces of our modern

Speaker: NA
Text: society and economy. But it does let others in. An increase in connections to the internet is

Speaker: NA
Text: matched by an increase in the number of points vulnerable to hacking and cybercrime. The

Speaker: NA
Text: number of potential targets increases, and millions of our small and medium-sized businesses

Speaker: NA
Text: need government to help them stay safe in the digital world. They need it in a way that is

Speaker: NA
Text: simple enough for them to incorporate into their business and that they can afford. This means

Speaker: NA
Text: having the resources to design cyber defences for our products, our processes and our

Speaker: NA
Text: people-Australian-developed cybersecurity capability and standards to protect all

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians. That is why, in government, Labor opened the Cyber Security Operations Centre

Speaker: NA
Text: and adopted Australia's first comprehensive Cyber Security Strategy.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: But we recognise that the scale and speed of change in this area mean that nothing can

Speaker: NA
Text: stand in stone. In the last two years, there has been more data created than in the entire

Speaker: NA
Text: previous history of the human race. We are living in a time when technology and invention

Speaker: NA
Text: are streaking ahead of traditional security and legal frameworks. Today, almost without

Speaker: NA
Text: thinking, Australians store and share vast amounts of private and personal information

Speaker: NA
Text: online-banking credit-debit records, medical history, tax and income data, intellectual

Speaker: NA
Text: property. It is why The Economist in 2014 estimated the global cost of cybercrime,

Speaker: NA
Text: intellectual property theft and espionage was around $445 billion a year. That is before we

Speaker: NA
Text: consider what we share on social media about ourselves. Like all parents in this place and

Speaker: NA
Text: around Australia, I am conscious that social media has fundamentally reshaped childhood for

Speaker: NA
Text: this generation of Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: For all of these reasons, we cannot afford to assume that cybersecurity is a niche issue for

Speaker: NA
Text: techxperts, the harmless hobby of a few dedicated followers. We must recognise that there is

Speaker: NA
Text: no such thing as an unhackable system, no such thing as a foolproof platform. Instead, the

Speaker: NA
Text: world's leading cybersecurity experts all say we should begin from the assumption that there

Speaker: NA
Text: are already people inside the system. Our focus should be on finding out what they are doing,

Speaker: NA
Text: tracing their activity and preventing others from using the same entry point.

Speaker: NA
Text: The key words in every cybersecurity conversation are trust and collaboration. No

Speaker: NA
Text: government has the reach or resources to act in this field alone. We must collaborate with the

Speaker: NA
Text: private sector, sharing information and strategies, learning from each other's successes and

Speaker: NA
Text: failures. That is true as well for cooperation with our international peers. We need to seek a

Speaker: NA
Text: new layer of engagement with our old allies and partners, recognising that frameworks and

Speaker: NA
Text: treaties written for a Cold War world need to be updated for an age where people can google

Speaker: NA
Text: bomb-making instructions and 3D-print guns. This is particularly important in our region. As

Speaker: NA
Text: Daesh is driven closer to defeat in the field, there is a very real risk of former extremists

Speaker: NA
Text: demobilising in our region-trained in the Middle East, better trained in combat, more

Speaker: NA
Text: radicalised than when they left. Managing this threat, keeping not only Australia but South-

Speaker: NA
Text: East Asia safe, will require our leadership and multilateral institutions and our example as a

Speaker: NA
Text: democratic, peaceful, prosperous and secure nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is vital we continue to enhance the reach and flexibility of our cybersecurity capabilities,

Speaker: NA
Text: but I also have to add that all of the good work, all of the unreplaceable investment in

Speaker: NA
Text: technological safety, can count for nothing unless we continue to invest in the very human

Speaker: NA
Text: element of countering extremism. There are not enough walls, weapons and technology to

Speaker: NA
Text: guarantee safety alone, unless we deploy our citizens in the pursuit of combating extremism.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, when I talk about our citizens, I am mindful that one of the most powerful assets in

Speaker: NA
Text: the fight against terrorism does not wear a uniform or wield a weapon; it is our united,

Speaker: NA
Text: harmonious, inclusive nation. As the Prime Minister said so well in parliament only last

Speaker: NA
Text: month:

Speaker: NA
Text: The terrorists want the wider Australian community to turn against Australian Muslims. Their message

Speaker: NA
Text: to Australian Muslims is, 'You're not wanted here. You will never be accepted here. You cannot be

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian.'

Speaker: NA
Text: So in this place we have a solemn responsibility to counter that argument of the extremists, of

Speaker: NA
Text: the extreme right and the extremists in the Middle East who say that being a Muslim citizen

Speaker: NA
Text: of this democracy is incompatible with their faith. We need to counter that argument, not

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: amplify it. It is our job, our duty, to foster a more inclusive, a more respectful, a more

Speaker: NA
Text: egalitarian Australia. We do not just tolerate diversity; we embrace diversity. We do not just

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledge multiculturalism; we embrace multiculturalism-as a bipartisan achievement

Speaker: NA
Text: and as a shared priority.

Speaker: NA
Text: And no individual in this place did more to shape the modern diverse nation that we

Speaker: NA
Text: cherish today than Malcolm Fraser. As the Prime Minister generously said in condolences

Speaker: NA
Text: about the former Liberal Prime Minister, he was so far ahead of his time. The Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: said:

Speaker: NA
Text: When you look at what he did in respect of shaping the nature of Australia today, it is really quite

Speaker: NA
Text: remarkable.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the Prime Minister reminded us in his most recent statement, just minutes ago, there is no

Speaker: NA
Text: bliss in ignorance. All of these are reasons why the Minister for Immigration and Border

Speaker: NA
Text: Protection's recent comments were so profoundly wrong. Suggesting it was a mistake to allow

Speaker: NA
Text: a generation of migrants to come to Australia more than three decades ago, because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: crimes of a tiny handful of their grandchildren, is not just ignorant and insulting; it is not just

Speaker: NA
Text: a denigration of people who have worked so hard and given so much to this country. The

Speaker: NA
Text: comments were not just a repudiation of the success of Australia, a nation made great by

Speaker: NA
Text: migration and multiculturalism. The minister's ignorant comments contradict, undermine and

Speaker: NA
Text: fly in the face of every briefing I have ever received from our security agencies who explain

Speaker: NA
Text: to us how best to counter radicalisation, about defeating extremism.

Speaker: NA
Text: Loud, lazy disrespect, wholesale labelling of entire communities for the actions of a tiny

Speaker: NA
Text: minority, aid and abet the isolation and resentment that the extremists prey upon. In this place

Speaker: NA
Text: we are leaders. We do not just cater for majorities; we respect minorities. We do expect

Speaker: NA
Text: anyone who comes here to adhere to our laws and our values, but we must take the

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility of leadership most seriously with how we act, with what we say. It is time for

Speaker: NA
Text: some leadership from the Prime Minister. It is time that the minister for immigration was

Speaker: NA
Text: brought into line. As the remarkable member for Cowan-who was involved in driving WA

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's Cyber Security Strategy seven years ago-said this morning, and I agree, 'I am fearful

Speaker: NA
Text: that the minister for immigration's comments will be used by an extreme few who would seek

Speaker: NA
Text: to harm the fabric of our society.' Second and third generation migrants are teachers. They are

Speaker: NA
Text: police officers. They are entrepreneurs. They are members of this parliament on both sides of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House. They serve in our hospitals and they serve in the uniform of our country. They

Speaker: NA
Text: raise children. They pay taxes. They build communities. They coach local sporting teams.

Speaker: NA
Text: They create small businesses. They volunteer. They do, as I say, sit on both sides of this

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber. And we, in the Labor Party, do not start by calling them 'second and third

Speaker: NA
Text: generation migrants'; we call them 'Australians'.

Speaker: NA
Text: And, in an age of rapidly evolving threats, of shifting battlegrounds and whole new forms

Speaker: NA
Text: of crime, we must continue to adapt our processes, our technologies and our capabilities. Our

Speaker: NA
Text: country requires it. The effort of our ADF personnel who put their lives on the line require us

Speaker: NA
Text: to do here the very best we can do. But we must also never lose sight of old truths in the

Speaker: NA
Text: search for new security. All of the machines and all of the walls and all of the guards are

Speaker: NA
Text: insufficient if we do not reach out and include all of those in our own society. We are always

Speaker: NA
Text: and every time a stronger nation and a safer place when we stand together. Now and always,

Speaker: NA
Text: let that guide us.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Ms LEY
Text: Farrer-Minister for Sport and Minister for Health and Aged Care) (11:31): I

Speaker: NA
Text: move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House take note of the document.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: Reference to Federation Chamber

Speaker: Ms LEY
Text: Farrer-Minister for Sport and Minister for Health and Aged Care) (11:31): by

Speaker: NA
Text: leave-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the order of the day be referred to the Federation Chamber for debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: BILLS

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Jobs Path: Prepare, Trial, Hire)

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill 2016

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Consideration resumed of the motion:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: to which the following amendment was moved:

Speaker: NA
Text: That all the words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

Speaker: NA
Text: "Whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House notes that the Turnbull Government

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot guarantee that, under Youth Jobs PaTH (Prepare, Trial, Hire):

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) jobs will not be displaced by cheaper labour;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) wages will not be undercut and some participants will be paid below minimum award wages;

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) participants' safety will not be compromised and that adequate insurance arrangements will be

Speaker: NA
Text: provided;

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) participants won't be used to help businesses sidestep unfair dismissal protections; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) it will prioritise using small to medium enterprises in PaTH because they have a demonstrated track

Speaker: NA
Text: record of employing more jobseekers through the jobactive programme".

Speaker: Ms HENDERSON
Text: Corangamite) (11:32): It is my pleasure to rise and speak on this bill,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Jobs Path: Prepare, Trial, Hire) Bill 2016,

Speaker: NA
Text: in continuation. I was talking about the three stages of the PaTH program, which will support

Speaker: NA
Text: up to 120,000 young people over four years. The first stage is getting them ready-preparing

Speaker: NA
Text: young people. The second stage is giving them a go-trialling them through an internship,

Speaker: NA
Text: supported by a youth bonus wage subsidy and voluntary internships of between four and 12

Speaker: NA
Text: weeks where employers will receive an incentive of $1,000 up-front and a young person, an

Speaker: NA
Text: intern, will receive a $200-a-fortnight payment to supplement their Newstart allowance-on

Speaker: NA
Text: top of their Newstart allowance. Then, of course, the third part of this program is hire-giving

Speaker: NA
Text: young people a job. In order to provide that incentive to employers, the government is

Speaker: NA
Text: proposing that businesses will be eligible for a youth bonus wage subsidy of between $6½

Speaker: NA
Text: thousand and $10,000 from 1 January next year.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill is needed because it is required to ensure jobseekers are not disadvantaged by

Speaker: NA
Text: taking part in the Youth Jobs PaTH measure announced in the budget to encourage eligible

Speaker: NA
Text: young jobseekers to take up a PaTH internship. Participants, as I have mentioned, will receive

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: $200 fortnightly in addition to their social security payments. The bill ensures that these

Speaker: NA
Text: payments are not considered as income for social security and veterans' entitlement purposes.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is obviously very important; we do not want to do anything that will impact on their

Speaker: NA
Text: social security entitlements. So it will amend the Social Security Act, the Veterans'

Speaker: NA
Text: Entitlements Act and the Social Security (Administration) Act to support the Youth Jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: PaTH measure.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do want to make some particular comments in relation to the member for Melbourne's

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution and more broadly in relation to some of the opposition that we have heard from

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite. This is an incredibly important program for young people. In contrast to

Speaker: NA
Text: those opposite and to the Greens, here we are, as a government, looking at every possible

Speaker: NA
Text: measure to drive young people into work. We are incredibly proud of what we are doing. And

Speaker: NA
Text: it is absolutely fallacious to suggest that this is a $4-an-hour program. What we are providing

Speaker: NA
Text: is a $200-a-fortnight bonus-that is in addition to Newstart; $200 extra per fortnight-which

Speaker: NA
Text: will put young people into the position of an internship for a limited period of time and, very

Speaker: NA
Text: importantly, will give employers the opportunity to trial someone and to train them. We all

Speaker: NA
Text: know that, when an employer brings anyone new into their business, there is a high degree of

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment by that employer to introduce a young person into the workplace, to train them

Speaker: NA
Text: and to get them job-ready, and the employer does not do that unless he or she, or the

Speaker: NA
Text: company, has a commitment to bringing someone into their organisation. It is also great

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity for young people: to learn new skills; to get a taste of that industry or to get an

Speaker: NA
Text: understanding of that business; to get a sense of self-worth; to be encouraged; to be inspired;

Speaker: NA
Text: and of course, in doing so, to receive this important bonus.

Speaker: NA
Text: So it is really regrettable that, while we have had this criticism both from the Greens and

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Labor Party, we have seen no ideas from members opposite. What are their ideas?

Speaker: NA
Text: We have seen no contrary ideas from the Labor Party.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a government, we are doing everything possible to drive jobs, to drive new programs

Speaker: NA
Text: and to look at new ways of getting young people into work. And its is not just through the

Speaker: NA
Text: PaTH program. We have our $96 million Try, Test and Learn Fund, introduced by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Social Services, asking all members of the community-volunteer groups,

Speaker: NA
Text: community organisations and members opposite-to come up with innovative employment

Speaker: NA
Text: ideas to drive employment. But what do we hear today from the member for Melbourne? No

Speaker: NA
Text: ideas. It is a zero ideas zone from the Greens and from members opposite. We recognise that

Speaker: NA
Text: government does not have all the ideas, and we are saying to Australians, 'Here is nearly $100

Speaker: NA
Text: million for an innovative scheme'-like a scheme that is being promoted and funded in my

Speaker: NA
Text: region, the GROW scheme, where G21 and Give Where You Live have done some wonderful

Speaker: NA
Text: work to try to address the very significant problems with youth unemployment, particularly in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Geelong region.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are making some very important inroads, despite some members opposite-particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Corio-trying to talk down our local economy at every opportunity. Last

Speaker: NA
Text: month's unemployment figures show that unemployment in the Geelong is currently sitting at

Speaker: NA
Text: four per cent, with a three-month rolling average of 5.8 per cent. Despite all the criticism from

Speaker: NA
Text: those opposite, we are doing so much better than the Labor Party have ever given us credit

Speaker: NA
Text: for. While we get criticism from those opposite, what is remarkable in this debate is that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have no ideas from those opposite.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Not only do we have our Try, Test and Learn scheme on top of our PaTH scheme; we have

Speaker: NA
Text: the Transition to Work scheme, which is an alternative for the jobactive providers. It supports

Speaker: NA
Text: young people aged 15 to 21 through intensive pre-employment support to improve work

Speaker: NA
Text: readiness and help them into work or education. We have the ParentsNext program, which

Speaker: NA
Text: helps eligible parents to identify their education and employment goals-again, to help them

Speaker: NA
Text: get into work. We have our Empowering YOUth Initiative, again to support innovative

Speaker: NA
Text: approaches to helping young unemployed people move into work. We are absolutely

Speaker: NA
Text: committed and doing everything we can to drive those jobs and to drive those opportunities,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it is really disappointing that we have not seen some bipartisanship on what is a very,

Speaker: NA
Text: very significant measure.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister for Employment, Senator Michaelia Cash, did an extraordinary job in leading

Speaker: NA
Text: our charge in passing the Fair Work (Registered Organisations) Amendment Bill 2014, which

Speaker: NA
Text: of course is a bill that is all about putting Australian workers first. In contrast to Labor, who

Speaker: NA
Text: wanted to back the union organisers, including those who had engaged in fraud and

Speaker: NA
Text: corruption, which is very disappointing, our government is focused on putting Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: workers first. It was wonderful to visit Kings Cars with the minister and to talk-

Speaker: Mr Champion
Text: Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The member is reflecting

Speaker: NA
Text: on members opposite and saying that they support fraud. That is not the case, and she should

Speaker: NA
Text: withdraw.

Speaker: Mr Irons
Text: That is not what she said.

Speaker: Mr Champion
Text: That is exactly what she said.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Goodenough): I call the member for Corangamite.

Speaker: Ms HENDERSON
Text: Mr Deputy Speaker, I will not withdraw. That is not what I said. I

Speaker: NA
Text: said that the Labor Party did not support a bill which combats union organisers engaging in

Speaker: NA
Text: fraud, engaging in corruption and engaging in dodgy union deals.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: There is no point of order. Please continue.

Speaker: Ms HENDERSON
Text: This is a great opportunity for me to say it again. What an absolute

Speaker: NA
Text: disgrace it is that the Labor Party did not support the Registered Organisations Bill, in

Speaker: NA
Text: contrast to the likes of the former Labor Attorney-General Rob MCClelland, in contrast to the

Speaker: NA
Text: likes of Martin Ferguson and in contrast to the likes of Bill Kelty, who all stood up and said,

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Yes, we do require this reform; we do need to put Australian workers first.' So thank you for

Speaker: NA
Text: the opportunity to make that point. It was a shameful day when the Labor Party would not

Speaker: NA
Text: support this vital industrial relations reform for our nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I was saying, in May, the Minister for Employment, Senator Michaelia Cash, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: visited Kings Cars, one of the many local employers in our region, and spoke very, very

Speaker: NA
Text: proudly about the Youth PaTH employment program. It is getting a lot of support and we are

Speaker: NA
Text: very enthusiastic as to how we can work locally with our local employers to make sure that as

Speaker: NA
Text: many employers as possible take up this opportunity and give young people a chance-

Speaker: NA
Text: because that is what it is all about.

Speaker: NA
Text: Everything our government is doing is about putting the Australian worker first and driving

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs, and we are so proud. I will take the opportunity to look at what we are doing locally.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is our massive investment in infrastructure, including, at long last, the $690 million that

Speaker: NA
Text: has been provided for rural and regional roads in Victoria. We had to drag the Labor Party

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: kicking and screaming in Victoria on that one. There is more investment in rail and our huge

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to Avalon Airport-all about driving jobs. There are our massive job creation

Speaker: NA
Text: programs, including a $20 million jobs and investment package for our region, which is very

Speaker: NA
Text: significant-looking at new investment, new opportunities, new industries and new jobs,

Speaker: NA
Text: including new jobs for young people. There is our Geelong Region Innovation and Investment

Speaker: NA
Text: Fund, which has created some 850 new jobs across our region. There is our $155 million

Speaker: NA
Text: Growth Fund. There is the Geelong Region Job Connections program, supporting lots of

Speaker: NA
Text: fantastic grassroots job creation programs, including supporting the Pivot Summit, which I

Speaker: NA
Text: will be very proudly opening on Friday-driving digital jobs, jobs for the future and jobs for

Speaker: NA
Text: young people.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is our focus on advanced manufacturing. What a reflection it was on Labor when

Speaker: NA
Text: they committed only around $7 million to our region, in contrast to our very significant

Speaker: NA
Text: investments in advanced manufacturing, including an industry growth centre in advanced

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturing and $4.7 million for Deakin University for the Future Fibres Research Hub.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is also our strong commitment to the National Stronger Regions Fund and our strong

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to small and medium business-delivering those tax cuts. Back in 2011, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party were very supportive of tax cuts for smalland medium-size businesses. Back

Speaker: NA
Text: then they were being quite open with the Australian people and acknowledging that that did

Speaker: NA
Text: drive new jobs, more investment and more opportunities. But now we see in another blatant,

Speaker: NA
Text: pathetic case of politicking, led by the Leader of the Opposition, an illogical opposition to tax

Speaker: NA
Text: cuts for small business. Then there are our free trade agreements-again, all about driving

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are getting the economy boosted again-as we did when we abolished the carbon tax

Speaker: NA
Text: and the mining tax and stripped red tape-and proudly doing all these important things to

Speaker: NA
Text: drive jobs and investment. This is a very important bill for young people and for our nation,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I commend this bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr CHAMPION
Text: Wakefield) (11:45): I wish I could say it was a pleasure to follow the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Corangamite in rising to speak on the Social Security Legislation Amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: (Youth Jobs Path: Prepare, Trial, Hire) Bill 2016. Such are the delusions of this government,

Speaker: NA
Text: where they think if they get up and say the word 'strong' and 'we are backing Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: workers first' enough times that it will somehow echo and ricochet from this parliament out

Speaker: NA
Text: there into the community. But the community, of course, know exactly what this government

Speaker: NA
Text: is up to in a whole range of areas because they see in this parliament every single day that we

Speaker: NA
Text: either have no positive agenda at all or we have these rampant reactionary measures. The

Speaker: NA
Text: member opposite wandered from this bill, which is all about internships, and into industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: relations-all sort of weaved into the ABCC. What I would like to let the House know is that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Building and Construction Commission does not deal with criminal behaviour

Speaker: NA
Text: at all.

Speaker: NA
Text: There was a fellow in my electorate named Ark Tribe. He lived out in Middle Beach and he

Speaker: NA
Text: worked on the Flinders hospital site. He was worried about the safety of himself and the

Speaker: NA
Text: workers at that site, so they held a safety meeting because they were worried about working in

Speaker: NA
Text: an unsafe environment. And do you know what happened? He got hauled before the courts by

Speaker: NA
Text: Gestapo style tactics for months and months and months of his life. He was not a corrupt

Speaker: NA
Text: union official; he was just a construction worker who wanted to work in a safe environment.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Those opposite want to criminalise that sort of behaviour and want to pretend that it is wrong.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact is, people like Ark Tribe are the real Australians who are really representing the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian tradition-that of a fair go, of a fair day's pay for a fair day's work, of working in a

Speaker: NA
Text: safe environment and of being able to come home to your family. Instead, we have this

Speaker: NA
Text: nonsense where those opposite talk about fraud. There is a place to deal with fraud whether it

Speaker: NA
Text: is in unions, the local footy club, a company or anywhere else in the community and it is

Speaker: NA
Text: called the courts. And guess what: they are doing it every single day. There is nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly special about it. That is the way we have set up our community for the

Speaker: NA
Text: administration of justice. That is the way we should pursue it because that is the best way to

Speaker: NA
Text: pursue it. We should leave industrial relations separate from criminal law.

Speaker: NA
Text: I guess we should talk about this bill. The other thing those opposite like to do is talk about

Speaker: NA
Text: real-life experience. I was a union official and, on occasion, I had stop-work meetings. These

Speaker: NA
Text: days, those opposite might have put me in jail for it. I might be in chains, like my forebear:

Speaker: NA
Text: my great-grandfather, Peter Roberts. He was on the docks at Geelong. He died in an unsafe

Speaker: NA
Text: work environment. He was a member of the Industrial Workers of the World. Those opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: would have banged him up because that is what they are about. They are about criminalising

Speaker: NA
Text: trade unions and trade union activity.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Falinski interjecting-

Speaker: Mr CHAMPION
Text: That is what was said. Let me tell you about what happened when I

Speaker: NA
Text: was a union official. Every so often I used to have to go out to some small retail

Speaker: NA
Text: establishment. I would be there and they would have somebody in to do 'work experience' or

Speaker: NA
Text: as an 'intern'. This would go on for weeks, sometimes months, and these people would be

Speaker: NA
Text: used to displace existing workers. Sometimes it was not such small institutions. We had one

Speaker: NA
Text: major retailer do it once. And I would have to patiently explain to those institutions, those

Speaker: NA
Text: commercial organisations that what they were doing was in fact illegal and that they should

Speaker: NA
Text: be paying these people.

Speaker: NA
Text: From time to time some manager, or sometimes it was an owner of a company, would get

Speaker: NA
Text: into his head that maybe, if he had people come in as interns or for work experience, that

Speaker: NA
Text: would be a great boon to his business and that somehow the individual committing this free

Speaker: NA
Text: work would also get a benefit. Now, from this article in The Sydney Morning Herald by Clara

Speaker: NA
Text: Jordan-Baird, who is the national policy director of Interns Australia, I have got some figures:

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Only 20 per cent of unpaid interns are offered employment with the same organisation.' What

Speaker: NA
Text: happens to the other 80 per cent? I can tell you from my real-life experience: they get

Speaker: NA
Text: exploited. Let us think about that.

Speaker: NA
Text: We roughly know what will happen under this bill and it will all come out in the Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry. The government is attempting to institute a program where we know the majority of

Speaker: NA
Text: people in the scheme are going to be exploited in some way.

Speaker: NA
Text: Government members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr CHAMPION
Text: I suppose I will be generous with those opposite after the interjections.

Speaker: NA
Text: I heard the member for Corangamite talk. I remember being on the backbench of a

Speaker: NA
Text: government that was in a death spiral. You know those dive-bombers? I had a constituent who

Speaker: NA
Text: was in a dive-bomber. He was a guy who had to sit in the rear seat and he was the gunner.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is who you guys opposite are: you are in the rear seat of a plane and you are assuming

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a pilot in the front, but they have bailed out and you are just sitting in the back and

Speaker: NA
Text: shooting away and you are taking out the rudder and the wings and you are hurtling towards

Speaker: NA
Text: the ground. And as you are hurtling towards the ground you are issuing orders to the rest of

Speaker: NA
Text: us. You are giving us your bon mots of wisdom as you hurtle towards the ground.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have been there, so I am not telling you how to suck eggs. But from these situations-and

Speaker: NA
Text: I have certainly seen enough of them in my time in parliament-we should know the sorts of

Speaker: NA
Text: rorts that go on and the sorts of people, the bottom feeders, who are attracted to programs just

Speaker: NA
Text: like this. To be fair to those opposite, we have seen it in all sorts of programs across

Speaker: NA
Text: administrations. The LPG subsidy was my favourite. It was started by Howard. There was

Speaker: NA
Text: $3,000 to subsidise LPG conversions. Australian taxpayers spent $750-odd million

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidising commercial activity that would have gone on anyway. All it did was drag demand

Speaker: NA
Text: forward. It doubled the price of LPG conversions. No-one was keeping an eye on that.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Goodenough): Member for Corangamite, do you have a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order?

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Henderson: Mr Deputy Speaker, I ask you to remind the member to confine his

Speaker: NA
Text: remarks to the bill. This is a speech on the bill that is before the House at the moment.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: On relevance, I call the member for Wakefield.

Speaker: Mr CHAMPION
Text: Was anybody here for her speech? Anyway, I am happy to relate it

Speaker: NA
Text: back to the bill because I am talking about the sorts of rorts that can go on under programs

Speaker: NA
Text: just like this. I will arrive at my point if you will allow me to just take this slightly circuitous

Speaker: NA
Text: route.

Speaker: NA
Text: We had a program that did not create a job, that subsidised commercial activity that was

Speaker: NA
Text: going to go on anyway, that dragged all this demand forward and that did not do the industry

Speaker: NA
Text: one lick of good, because I can tell you it cost jobs in the end. I saw LPG conversion

Speaker: NA
Text: companies go out of business because all the work had been done in this massive boom that

Speaker: NA
Text: did nothing but push prices up. And you can bet that there were a few bottom feeders who

Speaker: NA
Text: entered that industry just to get their hands on the subsidy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Here we have this program, which puts a $1,000 incentive into the business and then a

Speaker: NA
Text: wage subsidy after that, where we have a group of vulnerable potential interns. We know

Speaker: NA
Text: youth unemployment is at extraordinary levels and that it is often regionally based. I know

Speaker: NA
Text: exactly what the member for Corangamite is talking about when she talks about the

Speaker: NA
Text: challenges of this and the desire to do something, but it has actually got to be the right thing to

Speaker: NA
Text: do. Nobody on the government side of the program has gotten up and said, 'Well, this won't

Speaker: NA
Text: be rorted. Don't worry about it; we've got all these protections in there.' What you are setting

Speaker: NA
Text: up here is a program with no protections. For a start, in this bill there is no definition of 'an

Speaker: NA
Text: intern'. I could set up an intern pathway company where I partner with small business to take

Speaker: NA
Text: the interns from one place to another, and maybe I would get a fee and everybody would be a

Speaker: NA
Text: winner.

Speaker: Mr Coleman
Text: Think positively.

Speaker: Mr CHAMPION
Text: Think positively! The member opposite tells me to think positively. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have been here too long to be so naive about the sorts of people who would be attracted to this

Speaker: NA
Text: program, because we have just seen it in VET FEE-HELP. I remember being in the

Speaker: NA
Text: government party room when we were told about VET FEE-HELP.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Henderson interjecting-

Speaker: Mr CHAMPION
Text: Listen to this. It was supposed to be for TAFE. Then it was extended to

Speaker: NA
Text: private providers. Then, what happened? You came into government, and what did you try to

Speaker: NA
Text: do? You tried to fix it up-four or five times.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: The member for Wakefield will resume his seat. The member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Corangamite on a point of order?

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Henderson: Mr Deputy Speaker, I would ask that the member direct his comments

Speaker: NA
Text: through the chair.

Speaker: Mr CHAMPION
Text: I am happy to direct my comments through the chair. This government

Speaker: NA
Text: attempted to fix that program four or five times. Eventually Senator Birmingham from the

Speaker: NA
Text: other place did it. I know Senator Birmingham. He is a smart cookie. He has now fixed it,

Speaker: NA
Text: because he has come down on them like a ton of bricks. Previous ministers tried to say,

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Maybe we can negotiate with these people.' The truth is that whenever there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth dollar you can bet your bottom dollar-do not be naive about it-that there

Speaker: NA
Text: will be some bottom feeder out there who will set up a method of rorting the program.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Henderson interjecting-

Speaker: Mr CHAMPION
Text: Those opposite come in here with their rote-learning speeches where

Speaker: NA
Text: they recite the lines-and the member for Corangamite is a little bit better at disguising the

Speaker: NA
Text: lines. I heard some speeches last night. Honestly, they turn page 3 and then this is what page 4

Speaker: NA
Text: says. I have seen speeches like that before-on both sides of the House. But the learning from

Speaker: NA
Text: this is that you need to question the executive, because when they come up with a program

Speaker: NA
Text: like this, which, frankly, you could drive a truck through-there is no definition of 'an intern'

Speaker: NA
Text: and no real safeguards-it could be rorted by a middle man or by just your local company

Speaker: NA
Text: who thinks, 'Well, I'm going to get rid of all my existing workers and bring in all these

Speaker: NA
Text: interns.' And do not tell me it will not happen. I have seen whole companies where everybody

Speaker: NA
Text: is on a traineeship. There is nobody to train the trainees, because every single employee was

Speaker: NA
Text: on a traineeship. I remember one South Australian employer where even the owner of the

Speaker: NA
Text: company was on the traineeship. That was in the Howard years, so we are going back a few

Speaker: NA
Text: years.

Speaker: NA
Text: There has been completely shameless abuse of government programs across governments

Speaker: NA
Text: of various persuasions. So this is the thing: do not think that there is not someone out there

Speaker: NA
Text: right at this moment looking at this bill and thinking, 'How can I make some money out of

Speaker: NA
Text: this? How can I exploit this? How can I use this?' because you can bet they will. And you will

Speaker: NA
Text: have to come back here when the first scandal comes out and we will read all your speeches

Speaker: NA
