Text: back to you. When it appears on the ABC or when The Sydney Morning Herald does an

Speaker: NA
Text: investigation, guess what will happen? We will have to come back here and read all of your

Speaker: NA
Text: silly speeches about it where you recited the lines that were written by some 22-year-old in

Speaker: NA
Text: the minister's office-with all of that life experience there.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the problem with this bill. It is just sloppy. And whatever you say, we have got a

Speaker: NA
Text: second reading amendment with which the member for Chifley, he has learnt, is wisely going

Speaker: NA
Text: to push it off into a Senate inquiry. Hopefully, that will tighten this bill up. This is dangerous

Speaker: NA
Text: stuff, because it is full of exactly the sort of naive thinking, the wishful thinking, that is

Speaker: NA
Text: present on this government's back bench. As I said before, they are in a death spiral, so they

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: are grasping onto whatever they can. But this is the wrong thing to grasp onto. I would

Speaker: NA
Text: encourage those opposite to start doing your jobs on the back bench. Behind the scenes,

Speaker: NA
Text: actually start to put a bit of pressure on your executive-who are all shifting though their jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: so quickly that they are not really paying attention, let's be honest, with all the ministerial

Speaker: NA
Text: changes in this government. Start doing your jobs.

Speaker: Mr FALINSKI
Text: Mackellar) (12:00): We can now resume normal transmission, I think.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a critical piece of reform. For far too long too many people have languished, trapped,

Speaker: NA
Text: in the social security system, and the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: Path: Prepare, Trial, Hire) Bill 2016 is the beginning of a long and arduous journey to change

Speaker: NA
Text: the status quo.

Speaker: NA
Text: Having run my own business, I know the challenges that businesses face when employing

Speaker: NA
Text: people they do not know, particularly those who have never worked before. To a small

Speaker: NA
Text: business, the cost of not getting it right can be expensive in terms of time and money and,

Speaker: NA
Text: most importantly, in lost opportunities. Employers often attempt to contain that risk by

Speaker: NA
Text: choosing to employ people with work experience and a proven track record. Unfortunately,

Speaker: NA
Text: this traps those who are trying to get ahead, trying to break out of the welfare system.

Speaker: NA
Text: Over the last 24 hours I have borne witness to the Labor Party lecturing the rest of us on

Speaker: NA
Text: inequality in Australia. The member for Lilley was particularly illuminating on the issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: Never once did he mention microeconomic reform as a key platform to alleviating inequality.

Speaker: NA
Text: Never once did he talk about breaking the cycle of welfare dependency and unemployment.

Speaker: NA
Text: But we do. We talk about reform. We care about breaking the cycle of poverty and we care

Speaker: NA
Text: about employment, because the awful truth is this: that, after nearly seven decades of

Speaker: NA
Text: government-funded poverty programs, we have hardly moved the needle.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many social programs during this time have done nothing more than entrench poverty from

Speaker: NA
Text: one generation to the next. It is simply a fact that, if you are solely reliant on the welfare

Speaker: NA
Text: system in today's Australia, it is highly likely that your health and education outcomes will be

Speaker: NA
Text: substantially lower and you will have a shorter lifespan. At the same time, the chances of you

Speaker: NA
Text: forming a household are very low, while the likelihood of the system passing these outcomes

Speaker: NA
Text: onto your children is very high. This system costs $154 billion a year. In truth, the money is a

Speaker: NA
Text: second-order issue, because the Turnbull government is about saving lives, not money. When

Speaker: NA
Text: we on this side talk about reforming welfare-we are talking about saving lives, not money.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those opposite typically provide two solutions to alleviating inequality: the first is

Speaker: NA
Text: increased spending on welfare; the second is a more distributive tax system. Despite

Speaker: NA
Text: dedicating hundreds of billions of dollars to decreasing inequality, those opposite say things

Speaker: NA
Text: have got worse, and yet their only answer is to keep doing more of the same. Labor can talk

Speaker: NA
Text: ad nauseam about inequality, because they need people to feel like they are victims and

Speaker: NA
Text: supplicants of the state. Under no circumstances will they talk about the inequality of

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity that their own policies have created.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of Australians aged under 20 who are on income support, 67,000 have, or have had, a

Speaker: NA
Text: guardian who has been on welfare for the last 15 years. Our lifetime welfare bill has now

Speaker: NA
Text: reached an estimated $4.8 trillion dollars. That is not an amount we should try and grasp in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of dollars and cents, but rather as a sum total of human misery. But numbers do not

Speaker: NA
Text: paint pictures. This is the story of a never-ending cycle of poverty passed on from generation

Speaker: NA
Text: to generation.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: On this side of the House, we believe in standing up for hardworking Australians who

Speaker: NA
Text: aspire to a better future for their friends, their families and this great country-a modern and

Speaker: NA
Text: dynamic society that believes in helping people up, not dragging them down-with

Speaker: NA
Text: government as the great enabler, not the great enforcer. I am proud to be part of the Turnbull

Speaker: NA
Text: government that recognises that a new approach is urgently required. We cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: underestimate the urgency of the now. The Youth Jobs PaTH is part of our government's $840

Speaker: NA
Text: million project to improve people's chances of making a go of life, of getting and keeping

Speaker: NA
Text: them out of welfare and helping them to achieve their aspirations. The package, which is part

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Australian Priority Investment approach to welfare, provides a new, cutting-edge

Speaker: NA
Text: approach to youth employment. It will help 120,000 vulnerable young Australians over four

Speaker: NA
Text: years take advantage of job opportunities as our economy diversifies and transitions to

Speaker: NA
Text: broader based growth. It will help young people to get ready for meaningful work by giving

Speaker: NA
Text: them the tools they need to have a go and get a job.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Turnbull government is seeking to improve employment outcomes for Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: young people in a real, meaningful and tangible way by making it easier for them to enter the

Speaker: NA
Text: workforce. Young Australians should have the personal and financial opportunities that come

Speaker: NA
Text: with having a job-the independence, the experience, the self-esteem, the excitement and the

Speaker: NA
Text: chance to hone their skills. This aspect of employment is too often ignored by those on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Left of politics. The simple sense of achievement on someone's mentality has transformed

Speaker: NA
Text: lives and entire communities. Our future prosperity as a nation will suffer if we do not

Speaker: NA
Text: persistently tackle high levels of youth unemployment. Young people who cannot find a job

Speaker: NA
Text: are more susceptible to long-term unemployment and, from that place, it is a short trip to a

Speaker: NA
Text: cycle of welfare dependency.

Speaker: NA
Text: I welcome the reductions in the youth unemployment rate that this government has seen so

Speaker: NA
Text: far, but the numbers are still too high. We have identified that it is often a lack of experience

Speaker: NA
Text: that keeps young people out of the workforce, so we are implementing a measure that will

Speaker: NA
Text: facilitate young people getting exactly that experience so they might find it easier to gain

Speaker: NA
Text: meaningful employment. The Youth Jobs PaTH program will help and encourage young

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians to learn new skills, become job ready, get a job, and stay in a job.

Speaker: NA
Text: Having had open and frank conversations with the businesses of Australia, looking at the

Speaker: NA
Text: preliminary findings of the 'investment approach' actuarial analysis, and studying best

Speaker: NA
Text: practices both here and abroad, we have designed an innovative program that will make a real

Speaker: NA
Text: difference to young Australians. The prepare, trial, hire pathway will encourage employers to

Speaker: NA
Text: take a chance on young people by enhancing their employability, providing them real work

Speaker: NA
Text: experience, and increasing incentives for employers to take them on.

Speaker: NA
Text: Importantly, the program will give vulnerable young people that are trying to better their

Speaker: NA
Text: lives and create a future for themselves the confidence they need to transition to, find and

Speaker: NA
Text: retain work. We need to understand that what many of us in this place take for granted for

Speaker: NA
Text: some people is simply unknown. Vulnerable young Australians have no, or virtually no,

Speaker: NA
Text: experience of what work looks like, of what the expectations are in terms of practice,

Speaker: NA
Text: behaviour, what to wear, what is done and, more importantly, what is not done at work.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Youth Jobs PaTH is divided into three stages: prepare, trial and hire. To help young

Speaker: NA
Text: people gain a foothold in the labour market, young jobseekers will participate in intensive

Speaker: NA
Text: pre-employment skills training within five months of registering with jobactive. The first

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: three weeks of training will focus on skills such as working in a team, presentation, and

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate IT skills, like limiting your use of Facebook. A further three weeks of training

Speaker: NA
Text: will centre on advanced job preparation and job hunting skills.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government will introduce up to 120,000 internship placements over four years to help

Speaker: NA
Text: young jobseekers who have been in employment services for six months or more gain

Speaker: NA
Text: valuable work experience. Jobseekers and businesses, with the help of employment services

Speaker: NA
Text: providers, will work together to design internships of four to 12 weeks duration, during which

Speaker: NA
Text: the jobseeker will work 15 to 25 hours per week. Participation in an internship will be

Speaker: NA
Text: voluntary for both jobseekers and employers.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition to gaining valuable hands on experience in a workplace, young people will

Speaker: NA
Text: receive $200 per fortnight on top of their regular income support payment while participating

Speaker: NA
Text: in the internship. People that take on interns will receive an upfront payment of $1,000, and

Speaker: NA
Text: will benefit from the opportunity to see what a young worker can do and how they fit into the

Speaker: NA
Text: team before deciding whether to offer them a permanent job.

Speaker: NA
Text: Stage 3 of the new Youth Jobs PaTH provides increased and streamlined wage subsidies

Speaker: NA
Text: for young people. Australian employers will be eligible for a youth bonus wage subsidy if

Speaker: NA
Text: they hire a young jobseeker who has been in employment services for six months or more.

Speaker: NA
Text: Businesses will have the flexibility to employ young jobseekers either directly, through labour

Speaker: NA
Text: hire arrangements, or combined with an apprenticeship or traineeship. As part of these

Speaker: NA
Text: reforms, existing wage subsidies will be streamlined, making them easier for employers to

Speaker: NA
Text: access. In our modern and dynamic economy, highly entrepreneurial and flexible firms with

Speaker: NA
Text: dynamic mindsets will proliferate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yesterday I heard from Bernard Salt that five of America's top 10 companies were formed

Speaker: NA
Text: within the past 40 years. In Australia, our top 10 most valuable companies were founded

Speaker: NA
Text: before 1929. We need business leaders with new ideas. And, as much as it pains me to say it,

Speaker: NA
Text: young people are the source of most these bright new ideas. The Turnbull government will

Speaker: NA
Text: also encourage young people to start their own businesses by fostering their innovation and

Speaker: NA
Text: interest in self-employment.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is interesting that in the United States some of these innovative companies were formed

Speaker: NA
Text: by people still in their 20s-people like Mark Zuckerberg. Bill Gates was only 19 when he

Speaker: NA
Text: started Microsoft and created the DOS operating system that IBM bought. Even Warren

Speaker: NA
Text: Buffett started his funds management company when he was only 22. In Australia, this sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: entrepreneurship needs to be both encouraged and developed. This government will be part of

Speaker: NA
Text: enabling that to occur. It is this sort of stuff that not only helps young people find jobs that

Speaker: NA
Text: they love and that they want to be involved in but also builds our economy. It also helps

Speaker: NA
Text: create companies that pay taxes, that create jobs, that create wage growth, that create more

Speaker: NA
Text: competition in our marketplace and ensure that all of us, all consumers have the benefits of

Speaker: NA
Text: competition in the marketplace, so governments do not need to regulate as much, so that we

Speaker: NA
Text: can get out of the way of the market and allow people to enjoy the benefits thereof.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill, along with all the other reforms the Turnbull government is implementing, is

Speaker: NA
Text: about people's lives. It is about making a real difference to vulnerable members of our

Speaker: NA
Text: community. It shows that if you are willing to work hard, to put yourself out there, this

Speaker: NA
Text: government will support you no matter what your circumstances. This bill is not about the

Speaker: NA
Text: soft prejudice that says that people from tough backgrounds cannot aspire to something better,

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: that they are victims now and will forever-more be victims. This says that the human potential

Speaker: NA
Text: inherent in all of us will be supported and encouraged, that no person is not worth something,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that everyone can make a contribution. It is about saying that we believe that everyone

Speaker: NA
Text: can make a difference for themselves and for their families, and that if they are willing, this

Speaker: NA
Text: government, the Turnbull government, will support them. And we will break the cycle of

Speaker: NA
Text: poverty that has endured in this country for far too long.

Speaker: Ms SHARKIE
Text: Mayo) (12:14): I want our government to provide tangible opportunities

Speaker: NA
Text: for young people to gain relevant on-the-job training and experience. I worked for more than

Speaker: NA
Text: four years in executive roles in the youth space. When you know the challenges that face

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed young people like I do, you really do want ideas like the ones contained in this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation to work. However, I must put my concerns before the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I outlined in my first speech, many young people in our country, for a variety of

Speaker: NA
Text: complex reasons, are struggling to transition to employment. Contributing significantly to the

Speaker: NA
Text: youth unemployment rate is the reality that every year fewer and fewer entry-level jobs exist.

Speaker: NA
Text: Young people who are underemployed, early school leavers or those who fail to transition

Speaker: NA
Text: successfully from school to further education or employment are some of our most vulnerable

Speaker: NA
Text: members in our society. High youth unemployment rates and overrepresentation in

Speaker: NA
Text: underemployment mean that young people who are disengaged from education are not in

Speaker: NA
Text: training or employment and that they face a bleak financial future-a future with hardship,

Speaker: NA
Text: increased likelihood of health and mental health issues, and an increased probability of

Speaker: NA
Text: involvement in the criminal justice system.

Speaker: NA
Text: As our population ages, it is imperative for Australia's economic productivity and the well-

Speaker: NA
Text: being of society more generally that we equip all young people with the skills and support

Speaker: NA
Text: needed to become active, positive, contributing citizens. Young people who are unemployed

Speaker: NA
Text: for a prolonged period of time suffer wage scarring. The effect of wage scarring can be long-

Speaker: NA
Text: lasting and financially and emotionally detrimental. A recent international study from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Work Foundation in the United Kingdom indicated that long periods of unemployment when

Speaker: NA
Text: young can reduce an individual's wage-earning capacity between 13 and 23 percent by the age

Speaker: NA
Text: of 42. This phenomena negatively affects not only a person's individual financial ability but

Speaker: NA
Text: the nation's collective fiscal productivity. Therefore, I do commend the government for

Speaker: NA
Text: pressing ahead with the idea of systematically linking youth job seekers with work-trial

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities and paid employment. It is a fundamentally good idea. But, like any idea, it also

Speaker: NA
Text: needs to be implemented well to make it work. It is from this standpoint that I offer a

Speaker: NA
Text: constructive critique of this bill, the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: Path: Prepare, Trial, Hire) Bill 2016.

Speaker: NA
Text: My first observation when reading through the bill is that there is little detail on how the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prepare, Trial, Hire program-the PaTH program-will operate in practice. Much is left to

Speaker: NA
Text: regulation and administrative discretion. I understand the advantages of retaining flexibility

Speaker: NA
Text: when implementing a program like this. You want it to be able to adapt as conditions change

Speaker: NA
Text: and to leave room to incorporate improvements when lessons from its implementation are

Speaker: NA
Text: learned. However, too many fundamental questions remain unanswered in the bill and several

Speaker: NA
Text: important protections for young people are omitted.

Speaker: NA
Text: For a start, it is not sufficiently clear how young job seekers will be insured while they are

Speaker: NA
Text: on their placements. WorkCover-style entitlements that insure young people against accidents

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: in the workplace are a fundamental workplace right, and my Senate colleagues will find it

Speaker: NA
Text: hard to support any final version of the bill without such protections.

Speaker: NA
Text: The term 'internship', which is used in the bill, should be revisited. It conjures up images of

Speaker: NA
Text: making coffees for bosses in the offices of lawyers and accountants when most job seekers

Speaker: NA
Text: will be going down a very different, practical and vocational-skills-and-trades pathway. 'Work

Speaker: NA
Text: trial' would be a much more encompassing and meaningful expression to be used and would

Speaker: NA
Text: also highlight that the placements are intended to lead participants into work. Work health and

Speaker: NA
Text: safety requirements, including bullying and sexual harassment protections, must also exist to

Speaker: NA
Text: complement the WorkCover-style entitlements that are required.

Speaker: NA
Text: The amount of and timing of the subsidy received by business to take on a young person

Speaker: NA
Text: must also be clearer so as to understand exactly how the incentives will work for business. In

Speaker: NA
Text: particular, we need to know whether those incentives may become perverse if the churning of

Speaker: NA
Text: interns can work to a business advantage. Churning would be an unintended and perverse

Speaker: NA
Text: outcome, and would not be to the benefit of either the young participants or to existing

Speaker: NA
Text: employees who find their jobs being displaced by a readily available pool of subsidised

Speaker: NA
Text: labour.

Speaker: NA
Text: The lowest-skilled workplaces are particularly vulnerable to such churning, as young job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers are generally less skilled and would, therefore, compete directly with other employees

Speaker: NA
Text: in a low-skilled workplace. Similarly, we also need to know that young participants are not

Speaker: NA
Text: displacing their own jobs. We need to know that businesses that employ a lot of young

Speaker: NA
Text: people, like MCDonald's or a retail chain, cannot access young labour that simply replaces a

Speaker: NA
Text: significant chunk of their pre-existing workforce. It is for this reason that the Nick Xenophon

Speaker: NA
Text: team will seek to work with the government to ensure that appropriate industries are targeted

Speaker: NA
Text: for the PaTH program and that, where internship experiences are meaningful and do not

Speaker: NA
Text: displace existing labour, they genuinely facilitate a transition to ongoing employment. We

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot have a program that it is simply open slather and leaves young people open to

Speaker: NA
Text: exploitation. Between 2012 and 2015, NCVER recorded that the Australian economy lost

Speaker: NA
Text: almost 160,000 trainees and apprentices. We should, therefore, be targeting trades and the

Speaker: NA
Text: construction industry, and be, primarily, promoting this initiative to Australian small

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses. This will reduce the risk of churning by big business.

Speaker: NA
Text: The range of reasonable excuses for a young job seeker to end their internship early needs

Speaker: NA
Text: to be expanded. Currently, it does not appear that the legislation allows for a young person to

Speaker: NA
Text: terminate their internship for judicious reasons such as for sickness or for compassionate

Speaker: NA
Text: grounds, such as the death of a close family member. That, surely, must be amended.

Speaker: NA
Text: Furthermore, the definition of 'misconduct'-currently grounds for early termination of the

Speaker: NA
Text: internship-needs to be clarified in the legislation to avoid perverse incentives for business

Speaker: NA
Text: and to protect young people. For example, what level of proof is required for misconduct to

Speaker: NA
Text: be proven? Or is it just the word of the business owner versus the intern? Given the clear

Speaker: NA
Text: power imbalances between business and a young job seeker, there needs to be a clear and

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable standard of proof defined in the legislation. To complement this, a complaints

Speaker: NA
Text: system needs to be established so that young people can access it if they become exploited. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am concerned that without such legislative protections and oversight we risk the cultivation of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Dickensian master-servant relationships, echoed in the 19th century.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: There needs to be adequate resourcing for jobactive providers so that they can effectively

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiate placements with businesses and support internship participation. An additional

Speaker: NA
Text: question is whether jobactive or Transition to Work providers are better placed to house the

Speaker: NA
Text: PaTH program. I would argue that Transition to Work contract providers are a better fit as the

Speaker: NA
Text: government has a collective of organisations in Transition to Work that have proven specialist

Speaker: NA
Text: experience in delivering employment and transition support to young people.

Speaker: NA
Text: The proposed bill currently excludes related entities from being able to deliver the 'prepare'

Speaker: NA
Text: phase of the PaTH program. In practical terms, this means that a provider that is both an RTO,

Speaker: NA
Text: a registered training organisation, and a jobactive provider will not be able to refer jobseekers

Speaker: NA
Text: from its own caseload to its own RTO to complete employability skills training. This runs

Speaker: NA
Text: counter to the notion of creating integrated services to prevent service gaps and will create

Speaker: NA
Text: particular problems in regional areas, where few providers are readily accessible. One

Speaker: NA
Text: possible remedy might be to exempt not-for-profit providers from the related entities rule.

Speaker: NA
Text: One hundred dollars a week is very little to be paying an intern when their prospective

Speaker: NA
Text: employer is being paid a multithousand dollar subsidy to take them on and help them into

Speaker: NA
Text: employment. The balance of incentives needs to be much more fairly weighted. Furthermore,

Speaker: NA
Text: in rural communities, $100 may be barely sufficient to cover the cost of running a car-

Speaker: NA
Text: remember that in communities such as mine there are few buses. The dollars offered would

Speaker: NA
Text: not cover the long drives that are required to even attend a program.

Speaker: NA
Text: A work-trial style program like PaTH is only the beginning of the work the government

Speaker: NA
Text: needs to do in the young jobseeker space. The economic burden for Australian society and

Speaker: NA
Text: government as a result of youth inactivity and poor transitions is substantial. A national youth

Speaker: NA
Text: activation and transition service targeted towards young people who are not engaged in

Speaker: NA
Text: education, employment or training and who have multiple barriers would contribute to

Speaker: NA
Text: reducing this burden and increasing the productivity of the nation as a whole. For many young

Speaker: NA
Text: people who have had experiences of employment, those experiences have been temporary in

Speaker: NA
Text: nature. The Australian government Productivity Commission working paper Prevalence of

Speaker: NA
Text: transition pathways in Australia recognised that many young people frequently 'churn' in and

Speaker: NA
Text: out of the labour force. One of the main reasons for this is the casual or temporary nature of

Speaker: NA
Text: the majority of their employment opportunities. There is an urgent and compelling need for a

Speaker: NA
Text: youth activation and transition service to exist for disengaged young people to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: they successfully transition into stable employment or further training. The current jobactive

Speaker: NA
Text: service does not provide the specialist support needed for young people to successfully

Speaker: NA
Text: transition to sustainable employment, particularly young people who face complex non-

Speaker: NA
Text: vocational barriers, and yet those young people, who are the most vulnerable with the highest

Speaker: NA
Text: barriers to overcome-the stream C young people-are not in the youth transition service but

Speaker: NA
Text: in the adult transitional employment service, jobactive. It does not make sense. Of those

Speaker: NA
Text: young people, we know that many are not 'employment ready' after they leave school,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly young people who did not experience a solid secondary education. For those

Speaker: NA
Text: young people, the opportunity to connect with vocational or pre-employment education and

Speaker: NA
Text: training needs to coincide with intensive support to address non-vocational barriers through

Speaker: NA
Text: the development of an individual plan with mutually agreed specific steps to address barriers,

Speaker: NA
Text: to identify and develop personal strengths and to reach goals. This level of support is the best

Speaker: NA
Text: way to create a foundation for future employability. International experience suggests that

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: such rapid activation of young people who are not in education or employment provides the

Speaker: NA
Text: greatest opportunity for a positive outcome. Such a national plan should be delivered as a

Speaker: NA
Text: specialised youth service, it should adopt a place based approach and it should be delivered by

Speaker: NA
Text: local community services. This is especially the case in regional and remote communities,

Speaker: NA
Text: where local delivery by providers allows for the flexibility to tailor the service to specific

Speaker: NA
Text: community needs and is integral to successful delivery.

Speaker: NA
Text: Addressing the needs of young people who are unemployed, underemployed or inactive is

Speaker: NA
Text: equitably responsible and would be fiscally advantageous to the Australian government

Speaker: NA
Text: through the implementation of cost-effective, preventative activation programs that will

Speaker: NA
Text: ultimately reduce long-term dependence on welfare and increase Australia's productivity.

Speaker: NA
Text: I and my colleagues do commend the idea behind the bill before us, but adequate

Speaker: NA
Text: safeguards would also need to be legislated in order to make it work in practice. It also must

Speaker: NA
Text: be understood that a workable program for young jobseekers is but a first step in engaging

Speaker: NA
Text: young people transitioning towards employment. I will support the bill in this House, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledge that my colleagues in the Senate reserve the right to propose amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: relating to what I have spoken on today.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to finish by telling you a story of a young person from my electorate, who served me

Speaker: NA
Text: at a checkout in the supermarket just a couple of weeks ago. This young man graduated with a

Speaker: NA
Text: bachelor's degree in science majoring in geology and ecology, and went on to study honours

Speaker: NA
Text: in environmental biology at the University of Adelaide. He is now in his first year out of

Speaker: NA
Text: university and has struggled to obtain even an interview for an environmental job, not just in

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australia but also interstate. He has also emailed a lot of companies explaining his

Speaker: NA
Text: interest in doing work experience or vacation work, but most employers will not take on work

Speaker: NA
Text: experience students. For every graduate or entry-level job he has applied for, the employer

Speaker: NA
Text: requires years of experience. As the young man described it to me: 'It's a never-ending cycle.

Speaker: NA
Text: If employers don't want work experience students, how are we supposed to get the experience

Speaker: NA
Text: in the first place? It's an issue of not just experience but also the sheer number of applicants

Speaker: NA
Text: for the jobs.' One job he went for, a graduate-level environmental officer position, had over

Speaker: NA
Text: 200 applicants, and this level of competition was not unusual. Of the group of about 20 to 30

Speaker: NA
Text: talented students who graduated with honours with this young man last year, only 10 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: have obtained full-time work in their area of specialisation and most have resorted to working

Speaker: NA
Text: in a supermarket and the like.

Speaker: NA
Text: Young people, just like the rest of the population, want to build a good life for themselves.

Speaker: NA
Text: Currently, our society is failing to provide the jobs for our next generation of workers to get

Speaker: NA
Text: their start. As we do that, we will continue to fail our young people and we will fail Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr BRENDAN OCONNOR (Gorton) (12:29): I rise to contribute to this debate on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Jobs Path: Prepare, Trial, Hire) Bill 2016

Speaker: NA
Text: because it is an essential debate to be had in this place insofar as providing opportunities for

Speaker: NA
Text: young people in this country to find work is concerned. I start by commending the

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution by the member for Mayo. I think her concerns about the bill are absolutely

Speaker: NA
Text: correct. The intent of the bill-at least if it is to ensure the opportunity of young people to get

Speaker: NA
Text: work-is noble and good, but, as always, we need to look at the impact of the legislation and

Speaker: NA
Text: whether in fact there are sufficient safeguards in place for the most vulnerable workers in the

Speaker: NA
Text: labour market, namely young people.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: I also think it is true to say that there is no point providing a subsidised program, if you do

Speaker: NA
Text: not understand the challenges confronting young people. The member for Mayo went to the

Speaker: NA
Text: issue of non-vocational barriers to employment-the fact that there are so many young people

Speaker: NA
Text: who are not only not equipped with skills to deal with the labour market and find a job but

Speaker: NA
Text: also dealing with so many other barriers, including homelessness, intergenerational

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment, drug dependency and all sorts of other difficulties. Whatever we do in

Speaker: NA
Text: supporting those on the margins-young people struggling-we need to ensure that we attend

Speaker: NA
Text: to them in a holistic manner; not only providing a job, in the case of people who might be

Speaker: NA
Text: struggling, but also attending to their other concerns so we can make sure that their

Speaker: NA
Text: attachment to the labour market is not a precarious one.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor supports opportunities for young people. We are concerned that there are in excess

Speaker: NA
Text: of 260,000 young people unemployed in Australia, and that is a very significant proportion of

Speaker: NA
Text: the unemployment numbers in this country. We know, as the result of automation and other

Speaker: NA
Text: changes in the labour market, there are fewer entry-level jobs for younger people. Therefore

Speaker: NA
Text: the government does have a role to partner businesses and partner companies to ensure we

Speaker: NA
Text: provide greater opportunities. We also know, because of the disruption to other sectors of the

Speaker: NA
Text: labour market, we have a situation where young people now are competing against older

Speaker: NA
Text: workers for the same jobs. There was a time when fast-food chains probably employed

Speaker: NA
Text: predominantly young people. That still may be the case but, increasingly, we are seeing older

Speaker: NA
Text: workers having to take on fast-food work because they have been displaced from other sectors

Speaker: NA
Text: of the labour market. This adds to the difficulty young people are having finding work at the

Speaker: NA
Text: moment.

Speaker: NA
Text: We support the tenor of the bill, but we have some grave reservations. The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Chifley has moved a very significant amendment that goes to the concerns that Labor has in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to this bill. The night of the budget, when it was introduced by the Treasurer and later

Speaker: NA
Text: advocated by the Minister for Employment, was the first indication we had in relation to this

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed initiative that it would only apply to existing jobs. In fact, when asked whether it

Speaker: NA
Text: would apply to additional jobs or existing jobs, the Minister for Employment advised that it

Speaker: NA
Text: would only apply to existing jobs and then, of course, subsequently had to correct the record

Speaker: NA
Text: and say, 'No, it could include additional jobs as well.' That is a fundamental concern we have

Speaker: NA
Text: with respect to this initiative.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a concern that we are using tax payers' dollars to subsidise jobs that were going to

Speaker: NA
Text: be provided to young people anyway. If the minister needs to get a lesson on deadweight loss,

Speaker: NA
Text: she only need look at the weakness of this scheme. The way that the scheme has been set up

Speaker: NA
Text: will allow employers to use it to ensure there is no additionality to the labour market and,

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed, allow them to employ young people in existing positions, thereby avoiding having to

Speaker: NA
Text: fully pay for their own workers and, of course, not having to pay them pursuant to industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: instruments. There is a twofold problem here: firstly, the taxpayer will be paying for these so-

Speaker: NA
Text: called interns for work they were going to employ someone for anyway, but now they are

Speaker: NA
Text: getting a subsidy from the taxpayer; and, secondly, they do not have to ensure it is additional

Speaker: NA
Text: to the workforce. That is a concern, and it has been catered for in the amendment moved by

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Chifley, where we want to get some guarantees as to this initiative.

Speaker: NA
Text: We do not have to go too far back to remember what this government was considering

Speaker: NA
Text: doing to young jobseekers. It was not when long ago that the government was looking at

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: cutting any benefit whatsoever for all jobseekers up to the age of 30 from any support for six

Speaker: NA
Text: months. This government advocated that young people up until the age of 30 would receive

Speaker: NA
Text: no support for six months even when they were looking each and every day for work.

Speaker: NA
Text: Because of the pressure from Labor and others, that has now been reduced to one month, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: can tell you that for young people who are independent people looking for work, if they are

Speaker: NA
Text: not to receive any support for the first month they are unemployed and they are not living at

Speaker: NA
Text: home, it is an enormous burden and it is counterproductive. It will be more difficult where

Speaker: NA
Text: there is no support whatsoever for young people to look for work.

Speaker: NA
Text: We ask the government, as they ended up backflipping on the six-month suspension of any

Speaker: NA
Text: support, to also change their position on the one-month suspension and provide some level of

Speaker: NA
Text: support, provided the young jobseeker is looking for work. That is what mutual obligation

Speaker: NA
Text: means. You cannot have the principle of mutual obligation when you say, 'There's an

Speaker: NA
Text: obligation on the young jobseeker to look for work, but there is no obligation on us to help

Speaker: NA
Text: them.' That is not mutual obligation. That is just putting the onus on them with no support

Speaker: NA
Text: from the government, and that is completely undermining the principle of mutual obligation

Speaker: NA
Text: that I thought both major parties shared in that regard. I ask the government to reconsider

Speaker: NA
Text: their position on the absence of support for one month so that they are not being unduly

Speaker: NA
Text: unfair.

Speaker: NA
Text: While I am on my feet, in relation to support from government, they also extended the

Speaker: NA
Text: youth allowance to cover 22and 23-year-olds so there would be, in effect, a 20 per cent cut,

Speaker: NA
Text: in real terms, to income support for unemployed young people at the age of 22 and 23. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: still something the government is seeking to pass through the Senate. It is a massive cut. If

Speaker: NA
Text: you are on Newstart, on the lowest support-we know Newstart is not a very significant

Speaker: NA
Text: income-you are going to be subject to a 20 per cent cut to that income, if you are 22 or 23,

Speaker: NA
Text: Again, that is a pretty harsh thing to do to that age cohort, and we would ask the government

Speaker: NA
Text: to reconsider its position there. It is pretty harsh stuff. It is not going to help them find work.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is going to make it more difficult. It is just gratuitously punitive and, quite frankly, quite

Speaker: NA
Text: nasty, but in keeping with this sort of government.

Speaker: NA
Text: This government wants to have a society that is easy to hire and easy to fire. That is liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: philosophy, quite frankly-let the market rip, undermine the safety net, go after penalty rates,

Speaker: NA
Text: find ways to displace workers in the labour market, undermine employment security, diminish

Speaker: NA
Text: the conditions of employment, and smash unions so that there is little collective bargaining

Speaker: NA
Text: happening in the labour market. That is pretty much the modus operandi of the Liberal Party.

Speaker: NA
Text: Given that the aspiration of Prime Minister Turnbull and this government is to have an easy-

Speaker: NA
Text: to-hire, easy-to-fire, low-wage society, we are concerned that this initiative, even if it is well-

Speaker: NA
Text: intended, could actually lead to that result. Therefore, I think the government should seriously

Speaker: NA
Text: contemplate the amendment moved by the member for Chifley. I will just go to some of those

Speaker: NA
Text: points.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Chifley has made clear that the opposition is not declining to agree to the

Speaker: NA
Text: second reading of this bill, but we are concerned about a number of key areas. Firstly, we are

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned that the jobs will not be displaced by cheaper labour. I have mentioned the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: with this scheme, by being able to replace existing workers, rather than it involving additional

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs and an increase in the number of jobs available for young people in the labour market,

Speaker: NA
Text: we are concerned that if you have these so-called interns coming into workplaces on income

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: that is less than the award that applies to that workplace you are effectively undermining the

Speaker: NA
Text: existing arrangements in that workplace. It is the classic race to the bottom method used by

Speaker: NA
Text: reactionary right-wing governments, and we would be concerned that this initiative will

Speaker: NA
Text: actually apply in that way. So, quite rightly, the member for Chifley has said that we need to

Speaker: NA
Text: be given some assurance that that would not take place as a result of the efforts of this

Speaker: NA
Text: initiative.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our further concern is that wages will not be undercut and some participants will be paid

Speaker: NA
Text: below award minimum wages. That is specifically referring to the failure to recognise awards

Speaker: NA
Text: in the workplace. Further, that participants' safety will not be compromised and that adequate

Speaker: NA
Text: insurance arrangements will be provided. Again, because this class of jobseekers will not be

Speaker: NA
Text: strictly identified as employees, they will not be covered by the workers compensation

Speaker: NA
Text: schemes that apply to actual workers. It would be very concerning to Labor if there were not

Speaker: NA
Text: sufficient support to provide some other means to ensure not only their safety but, indeed,

Speaker: NA
Text: provide compensation if they are injured at work.

Speaker: NA
Text: Given that this scheme is effectively going right across the labour market, dealing with

Speaker: NA
Text: private sector companies, we are concerned that there is a possibility that these young people

Speaker: NA
Text: will be in unsafe situations where they will be at risk of injury, or worse. The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Chifley may have already mentioned that we recently saw the tragic death of a very young

Speaker: NA
Text: participant on a Work for the Dole scheme in Toowoomba. It was an absolute tragedy and I

Speaker: NA
Text: know everyone in this place has that view. We say that when it, in particular, comes to young

Speaker: NA
Text: people in workplaces who do not have a great deal of experience, and given that this can go

Speaker: NA
Text: across so many sectors of the labour market, we do really need to ensure that we go above and

Speaker: NA
Text: beyond in providing safety and that in the induction of young people into these workplaces

Speaker: NA
Text: there is sufficient training for them to understand the potential risks. I am not aware that that

Speaker: NA
Text: will not happen, but there is no clarity from the bill suggesting that it will happen. Labor is

Speaker: NA
Text: insisting that we get some undertaking from the government that the safety of these young

Speaker: NA
Text: people has been taken into consideration.

Speaker: NA
Text: Too many deaths are occurring in workplaces in this country. Three weeks ago a German

Speaker: NA
Text: backpacker was on the 14th floor of a building site in Perth and fell to her death, tragically.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is just one of many examples that can happen if young people, or workers generally, are

Speaker: NA
Text: not given sufficient safety training. We need to make sure that happens.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another concern is that participants will not be used to help businesses sidestep unfair

Speaker: NA
Text: dismissal protections. That goes to our concern that, increasingly, people feel so little security

Speaker: NA
Text: of work. We would be worried about the vulnerability of workers if employers were able to

Speaker: NA
Text: obviate their responsibilities and not provide sufficient protection for those participants.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have talked about prioritising small and medium enterprises. We do not want to see

Speaker: NA
Text: wholesale use of this scheme by large employers just as a mechanism to displace workers

Speaker: NA
Text: who are being paid under an award. Any scheme that involves taxpayers' dollars to subsidise

Speaker: NA
Text: wages should be about adding to the labour market, not taxpayers subsidising under-award-

Speaker: NA
Text: wage jobs. That is not what this bill should be about. Yet, when you read the bill, there is no

Speaker: NA
Text: clarity-none on security of employment, none on safety and not sufficiently on insurance, if

Speaker: NA
Text: compensation is required when there is an injury. There are so many questions requiring

Speaker: NA
Text: answers from the government, which I think are very appropriately determined through our

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment. Until we get some clarity we have not made our position fully known on this. We

Speaker: NA
Text: ask the government to take these issues very seriously.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms MADELEINE KING (Brand) (12:44): I rise today to speak about the Social Security

Speaker: NA
Text: Legislation Amendment (Youth Jobs Path: Prepare, Trial, Hire) Bill 2016. The Turnbull

Speaker: NA
Text: government's prepare, trial, hire program, or PaTH as it is known, is a program that is

Speaker: NA
Text: supposed to prepare young people for work by placing them in voluntary internships for

Speaker: NA
Text: between four and 12 weeks. This bill is designed in part to support the introduction of PaTH.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am particularly interested in the issues surrounding getting young people to work. I

Speaker: NA
Text: represent the electorate of Brand where pockets of the community are struggling with youth

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment figures that stand at a staggering 13.6 per cent. This is more than double the

Speaker: NA
Text: national unemployment rate average. This is despite the electorate being home to Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's major industrial strip in Kwinana-home to big and small businesses, from Co-

Speaker: NA
Text: operative Bulk Handling, Alcoa and BP to smaller fabricators and contractors. Supporting this

Speaker: NA
Text: state and the nation during the construction phase of the mining boom, job seekers in WA and

Speaker: NA
Text: Brand are now having to look elsewhere, beyond the Kwinana strip, to find work now the

Speaker: NA
Text: mining industry has moved into its foreseeable production phase. The move into this phase

Speaker: NA
Text: was always foreseeable. There was no surprise with this movement of phases. It was plain to

Speaker: NA
Text: see for all. The construction boom in the mining industry of Western Australia could not last

Speaker: NA
Text: forever.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government-I might say the state government of Western Australia as well as the

Speaker: NA
Text: federal government here-has had a long time to consider the impact of this economic change

Speaker: NA
Text: on communities in Brand, in Western Australia and across the whole country. This

Speaker: NA
Text: government has used its time to come up with, and endlessly repeat, a slogan to address the

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment rate-'jobs and growth', they say. It seems to be a big useless loop. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned that PaTH is a cobbled together program that will not provide realistic

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities for young unemployed people. I am concerned that it will not address the lack

Speaker: NA
Text: of jobs available to young people and will instead fail young job seekers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us have a look at what PaTH is. It is supposedly designed to prepare young people for

Speaker: NA
Text: work by providing job seekers aged 17 to 24 with pre-employment training and placement in

Speaker: NA
Text: voluntary internships over four to 12 weeks. Businesses will be paid $1,000 to take on an

Speaker: NA
Text: intern and then receive a wage subsidy of between $6½ thousand and $10,000 if they hire

Speaker: NA
Text: them at the conclusion of the internship. During that time interns may work 15 to 25 hours a

Speaker: NA
Text: week. In return, job seekers will receive payments of $200 per fortnight on top of their current

Speaker: NA
Text: income support payments while they are participating in the PaTH program. The program is

Speaker: NA
Text: being introduced at the same time the other government job programs, such as the Work for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Dole scheme, are hopelessly failing our young unemployed.

Speaker: NA
Text: I see and hear regularly from my constituents who are worried about their children that are

Speaker: NA
Text: unable to find meaningful work and with little prospect of meaningful work in the near future.

Speaker: NA
Text: I hear concerns from young people themselves who want to work but have no job, and this is

Speaker: NA
Text: not from lack of trying. Of course, the reality is that when there are less jobs than there are job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers people will remain unemployed. This is a sentiment that has been shared with me by

Speaker: NA
Text: people in the jobs service industry, who have expressed their frustrations at a lack of jobs for

Speaker: NA
Text: people to apply for.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: The Kwinana strip has been a major source of jobs for people living in Rockingham and

Speaker: NA
Text: Kwinana-the two cities within Brand-for many decades. Recently, on a visit to a local job

Speaker: NA
Text: service provider in Kwinana, with the member for Chifley, I was told by these people

Speaker: NA
Text: working on the frontline trying to help people find work that the jobs that were once so

Speaker: NA
Text: plentiful on the strip, as it is known, have now dried up. The jobs for those people who want

Speaker: NA
Text: to work are just not there.

Speaker: NA
Text: Youth unemployment in parts of Brand stands at more than double the national

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment average, as I have mentioned before. I repeat it because the figures are

Speaker: NA
Text: astounding. What happened to the jobs and growth mantra espoused by the government

Speaker: NA
Text: during the election? Where are these jobs? Where is the investment needed to get people back

Speaker: NA
Text: into meaningful employment? The sad truth is that Australia's youth are counting the cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Turnbull government's failure to develop a real jobs plan for the future and a real

Speaker: NA
Text: sustainable jobs plan for our nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: In Brand and across the country we are seeing a government that is not willing to invest in

Speaker: NA
Text: their future by investing in the productive infrastructure that can deliver real opportunities and

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits to the community. One glaring example of this failure in my electorate comes to

Speaker: NA
Text: mind as I consider this bill: the Kwinana outer harbour. I know members of this place will

Speaker: NA
Text: have heard me mention the Kwinana outer project often. It is one of those nation-changing

Speaker: NA
Text: and certainly electorate-changing-not to mention state-changing-infrastructure projects.

Speaker: NA
Text: Instead of progressing the construction of the Kwinana outer harbour project, the Turnbull

Speaker: NA
Text: government is pursuing a $2 billion investment in the Perth Freight Link, a road to a port

Speaker: NA
Text: which is fast approaching the day when it will reach full capacity and even then the road

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed does not even make it to the port. In fact, it stops about two kilometres south of the

Speaker: NA
Text: port. An alternative investment by the government, an investment in the Kwinana outer

Speaker: NA
Text: harbour project-a long-term investment in a long-term future-would instead unlock latent

Speaker: NA
Text: potential across existing industries and attract new industries into the area.

Speaker: NA
Text: Support for the new outer harbour makes sense. It would help grow the local, state and

Speaker: NA
Text: national economies. It is estimated it would create 25,000 new jobs. That is a lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: employment opportunities for our young people. It would provide real paid jobs and training;

Speaker: NA
Text: not short-term internships off the back of a hastily put together program. The Kwinana outer

Speaker: NA
Text: harbour project would encourage innovation through the application of modern technology to

Speaker: NA
Text: port operations, and it puts people first by supporting a sustainable industrial base to underpin

Speaker: NA
Text: the flourishing communities in Brand. Such investment would create job opportunities that

Speaker: NA
Text: would give young people an employment future, and a long-term employment future. It

Speaker: NA
Text: would open up opportunities for new and developing industry to move into Kwinana to

Speaker: NA
Text: expand the large industrial estate that has been planned for there for many years. These new

Speaker: NA
Text: industries would be located next to a state-of-the-art export port.

Speaker: NA
Text: Despite promising that it would tackle youth unemployment, the coalition has failed to

Speaker: NA
Text: deliver on the means and ends of actually doing so. According to the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Employment, youth unemployment nationally is at 12.8 per cent with nearly 300,000

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed young people between the ages of 15 and 24 unable to have productive work

Speaker: NA
Text: lives. On top of this, the department acknowledges there are another 170,000 people who

Speaker: NA
Text: have been unemployed for more than a year. We have a generation of young people who are

Speaker: NA
Text: disillusioned by the act of looking for jobs that simply are not there. It is a national disgrace.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Against the backdrop of this woeful performance, the Turnbull government has pulled

Speaker: NA
Text: together the PaTH program. I am concerned, as are many of my colleagues, that PaTH will

Speaker: NA
Text: not be a pathway to meaningful employment opportunities and will simply result in young

Speaker: NA
Text: people being exploited. We already know that the Work for the Dole program is not providing

Speaker: NA
Text: long-term solutions for young people. It is failing our young unemployed. In the case of Work

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Dole, even the government's own figures show nearly 90 per cent of its participants are

Speaker: NA
Text: not in full-time work three months after finishing the program. You would think that these

Speaker: NA
Text: results would cause a re-think on performance of this program, but, no, as we have heard from

Speaker: NA
Text: my colleague the member for Chifley, the response from the government was astounding.

Speaker: NA
Text: And I will repeat the response which was heard at last month's Senate estimates, 'The purpose

Speaker: NA
Text: of Work for the Dole is not necessarily to lead directly to a full-time job.'

Speaker: NA
Text: It is no wonder that the failure of this program and the attitude towards young people trying

Speaker: NA
Text: to find work causes me to have concerns about this new plan proposed by the government. As

Speaker: NA
Text: you have heard from my colleagues who have spoken already on this bill, they and many

Speaker: NA
Text: others in the community are worried about whether the program represents a fair deal for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's young jobseekers. Under the PaTH program, we are concerned that young people

Speaker: NA
Text: will be forced to pay an even heavier price through the program's apparent flaws.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill is designed to provide support to participants' social security entitlements while in

Speaker: NA
Text: the program. It does this via two measures. Firstly, a provision will be inserted into the Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Security Act and the Veterans' Entitlements Act so that the $200 payment interns receive is

Speaker: NA
Text: not counted as income for social security or veterans' entitlements purposes. And, secondly, it

Speaker: NA
Text: amends the Social Security Act to allow young people to suspend their payments if they are

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed employed-against all odds. They can then restart them without re-applying if they

Speaker: NA
Text: lose their job through no fault of their own within 26 weeks.

Speaker: NA
Text: Now, if taken in isolation the government will claim the measures in the bill are

Speaker: NA
Text: noncontroversial and should be accepted. However, a closer look shows us that the reality is

Speaker: NA
Text: very different and that our concerns are justified. We are concerned at what the future might

Speaker: NA
Text: hold for young people who are at a most important stage in life as they look to enter the

Speaker: NA
Text: workforce and as they look to prepare for the rest of their lives. The reality is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: measures proposed by the government form part of a broader new program design which

Speaker: NA
Text: could see young jobseekers exploited. I agree with the proposition that there is dignity in

Speaker: NA
Text: work, but there is not much dignity if you are the victim of exploitation. The measures could

Speaker: NA
Text: undermine workforce standards, which would have an even broader impact on the wider

Speaker: NA
Text: community and those already in employment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Perhaps most alarming is the fact that, unlike with Work for the Dole, for the first time

Speaker: NA
Text: participants would be placed in the private sector and would be paid below award wages. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Work for the Dole program is not-for-profitand government-organisation based. PaTH

Speaker: NA
Text: places young people into businesses. This means private businesses will be given access to

Speaker: NA
Text: thousands of young Australians who will work for the benefit of business for less than the

Speaker: NA
Text: minimum wage. The implications of this are obviously concerning and again, impacts on

Speaker: NA
Text: more people than those participating in the PaTH program itself. PaTH has the potential to be

Speaker: NA
Text: used to displace jobs with cheap labour. Families do not want to see their children used in this

Speaker: NA
Text: way. Young people do not want to be used in this way and workers do not want to be usurped

Speaker: NA
Text: out of their jobs by a cheaper and potentially untrained labour source.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: In this country we have a minimum wage overseen by the Fair Work Commission. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: something to be proud of. However, with PaTH there are very real concerns raised that

Speaker: NA
Text: participants may be entering a program where they are 'working' for below minimum award

Speaker: NA
Text: wages. The program could very well see young Australians doing the same job as others,

Speaker: NA
Text: except being paid less than the minimum wage. It is a dangerous path to take and, as the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Burt said, it is a dangerous race to the bottom.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reality is that we are experiencing a time in this country where wages growth is at the

Speaker: NA
Text: lowest rate on record. My colleagues' concern, and my concern, is that PaTH could be used to

Speaker: NA
Text: undermine wages across industries, and this concern is very real. Not only is it worrying to

Speaker: NA
Text: young people who potentially will be paid below award wages, and not only is it worrying to

Speaker: NA
Text: their families and loved ones who will potentially watch them work for less than they deserve

Speaker: NA
Text: and for less than an award wage, but it will also be worrying to workers and employees who

Speaker: NA
Text: could see underpaid PaTH interns doing their work and taking their jobs. In such cases there

Speaker: NA
Text: would be two victims: the underpaid intern and the person who, sadly, loses their job to them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Large numbers of interns could completely remove the need for existing employees to work at

Speaker: NA
Text: certain times in certain sectors, including hospitality and tourism. Who is to say that large

Speaker: NA
Text: numbers of PaTH participants would not be used over weekends, removing the need for

Speaker: NA
Text: regular employees at those times and also removing the need to pay penalty rates for those

Speaker: NA
Text: employees?

Speaker: NA
Text: This is counterproductive, and could potentially add to the problem of underemployment in

Speaker: NA
Text: the community. Underemployment, as we all know, is a massive concern, with people

Speaker: NA
Text: struggling to find enough work to pay the bills and to keep their heads above water. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: time where they are seeking more hours and greater employment. There are 1.1 million

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians wanting more work, but unable to find it, and underemployment in the August

Speaker: NA
Text: quarter was at 8.7 per cent, the highest level since this data began in 1978. In these

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances it would be irresponsible to support a program that has the very real potential

Speaker: NA
Text: of adding to this problem and to people's hardships.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another concern is that despite repeated questioning there are few assurances that interns

Speaker: NA
Text: will be covered by appropriate workers compensation schemes should there be an accident.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is because PaTH participants will be considered as 'volunteers', not as employees. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: despite the fact they will be doing jobs and will get paid, albeit a below award amount. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: farcical and it is a clear demonstration of exploitation. It is damaging, because in some

Speaker: NA
Text: jurisdictions this could affect the way workers compensation systems would treat participants

Speaker: NA
Text: in the event of an accident-which may well be a life-changing accident.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are no specifics about the program: there is no detail on areas where jobseekers will

Speaker: NA
Text: acquire skills. The program has been touted as a means to prepare young people for work

Speaker: NA
Text: during these times of high youth unemployment, but there is very little in the way of detail in

Speaker: NA
Text: the way it will be implemented. In fact, while the program was announced in May and is

Speaker: NA
Text: scheduled to start next April the government cannot even tell us what an 'intern' is. In Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: estimates back in May the clearest outline of training and skills outcomes Minister Cash

Speaker: NA
Text: offered us was, 'We will give you the skills that employers tell us you just do not have.'

Speaker: NA
Text: The government has also had trouble explaining what jobseekers will be doing in the

Speaker: NA
Text: internship phase of the program-whether they would be working or just observing. To say

Speaker: NA
Text: that this is a vague outcome for participants would be an understatement. It leaves them with

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: little scope to plan, to achieve or to develop in their work experiences. I and my colleagues

Speaker: NA
Text: are also concerned that large numbers of participants could be used within companies at any

Speaker: NA
Text: given time, with little sanction applied to employers that might 'churn' through participants as

Speaker: NA
Text: their engagement concludes. We do not know if this will happen.

Speaker: NA
Text: The lack of information around this program and the problems not only for participants but

Speaker: NA
Text: for the wider community mean we cannot agree to this legislation at the moment, without

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment. The government needs to show how these issues will be fixed and addressed. We

Speaker: NA
Text: call-Labor is calling-for this legislation to be considered by a Senate inquiry. We would be

Speaker: NA
Text: doing a disservice to young jobseekers if we just agreed to PaTH and to this legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: without amendment. We would be doing a disservice to those workers who potentially would

Speaker: NA
Text: have their jobs undermined by this program.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government's failure to invest in jobs and in infrastructure that will provide jobs,

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot be hidden behind a poorly-put-together program such as the PaTH program. The

Speaker: NA
Text: government must address the concerns raised against this hastily-put-together internship

Speaker: NA
Text: program, and Labor demands a better deal than this for young jobseekers.

Speaker: Ms RYAN
Text: Lalor-Opposition Whip) (12:59): I rise to support the amendment by the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Chifley and to discuss this program that has been put forward by the government

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Jobs Path: Prepare, Trial, Hire) Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 2016. It seems to me that this is a creative concoction. They have come up with the word

Speaker: NA
Text: 'PaTH' for a path, supposedly, to somewhere, and then they have thought, 'Prepare, Trial,

Speaker: NA
Text: Hire'. It is a clever little idea. There is only one problem: we have all seen The Pursuit of

Speaker: NA
Text: Happyness. We saw the film. We saw Will Smith being homeless while he worked for

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing with his young child with him. We have seen the film. We know that the glorified

Speaker: NA
Text: internship is a very, very sexy word that people use for unpaid work, unless there is a quid pro

Speaker: NA
Text: quo in terms of some kind of an accreditation.

Speaker: NA
Text: An internship in this country is not tightly defined. We do, however, use the word to

Speaker: NA
Text: describe what RMIT students might do as part of their practical placement for which they are

Speaker: NA
Text: given accreditation in their postgrad study. ANU runs similar programs. There is a quid pro

Speaker: NA
Text: quo here. The young person attends a workplace in a learning environment to do a work

Speaker: NA
Text: placement. We even use that language of 'work placement' in high school with VET

Speaker: NA
Text: programs. There is always a quid pro quo.

Speaker: NA
Text: The problem with this plan is that it is called an internship, but there is no quid pro quo.

Speaker: NA
Text: The notion here is that we are just going to roll out a policy so that we can pay kids $100 a

Speaker: NA
Text: week on top of what they get for Newstart and they will actually be working. Or are they

Speaker: NA
Text: working? This is the least thought-out piece of legislation from those opposite to come into

Speaker: NA
Text: this place in 3½ years, and it is the worst. Worse than that, it is packaged like it is some kind

Speaker: NA
Text: of panacea for youth unemployment. There is no panacea for youth unemployment. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: no quick fix and there is no easy fix. We have tried these things before and they have been

Speaker: NA
Text: dropped. Why? Because they were not successful.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a young person, when I first left school at 16 I was part of a program that came out of

Speaker: NA
Text: what we now call Centrelink, which used to be something very different. We were put into

Speaker: NA
Text: positions that were three-month trials where the government subsidised the employer to put

Speaker: NA
Text: those young people into those jobs. I was in a job for 12 months and I watched four other

Speaker: NA
Text: young people come and go in three-month blocks and get no ongoing employment. In our era,

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: I talked to lots of young people who were just going from three-month position to three-

Speaker: NA
Text: month position to three-month position. What we did was subsidise business. What we did not

Speaker: NA
Text: do was find long-term jobs for young people.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is just another iteration of that, although this time it is dressed up as if it is more

Speaker: NA
Text: important. This is not about putting someone into a low-paid entry-level job where they may

Speaker: NA
Text: not even require a school finishing certificate or year 12 qualification. This is being dressed

Speaker: NA
Text: up like it is some kind of postgrad experience. It is not. This is about exploiting young people

Speaker: NA
Text: and finding yet another way to subsidise business. If they cannot get their $50 billion tax cuts

Speaker: NA
Text: through, I suppose this was the next best thing. They are going to subsidise business and wrap

Speaker: NA
Text: it up like it is going to address youth unemployment. It is not.

Speaker: NA
Text: As we saw in The Pursuit of Happyness, the American version of an internship is unpaid

Speaker: NA
Text: postgrad work. That movie blew apart any notion that internships are necessarily a way to get

Speaker: NA
Text: to work. Mr Deputy Speaker, if you remember Will Smith in that movie-I certainly do-you

Speaker: NA
Text: will remember him sleeping in a public toilet with his son. If you remember, that model that

Speaker: NA
Text: the movie exposed was where American companies-I think it was a law firm or an

Speaker: NA
Text: accountancy firm-would put on 10 interns who would do unpaid work and would ultimately

Speaker: NA
Text: vie for one paid position. It was not funny. The movie was incredibly sad, and so is this

Speaker: NA
Text: proposal which came down on budget night. The minister responsible, when asked, 'Is this

Speaker: NA
Text: about new jobs or existing jobs?' said, 'It's about existing jobs.' It is about existing jobs, so it is

Speaker: NA
Text: about reducing the wages of young people as they enter employment-well, quasi-

Speaker: NA
Text: employment or possible employment. Perhaps one in 1,000 will get a job out of this program.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have found this entire idea to be completely and utterly fanciful. It is absolutely fanciful.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are so many other questions that come from it. Will they get a payslip? It is illegal in

Speaker: NA
Text: this country not to give a worker a payslip. Where in the provisions in here does it explain

Speaker: NA
Text: exactly what role these kids are going to play in these jobs? Are they going to be paid by the

Speaker: NA
Text: hour? Is that the plan for this loose $100 on top of their Newstart? Is the $100 if you show up

Speaker: NA
Text: or is it $100 if you work 15 hours? Does anyone want to quickly do the maths on how much

Speaker: NA
Text: an hour this worker is going to cost the company? It is not like we pay young people an

Speaker: NA
Text: extraordinary amount now.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are real risks in this. As someone who spent her life working with young people, I

Speaker: NA
Text: know what those risks are. As someone who spent her life with young people who went and

Speaker: NA
Text: got that part-time job after school, we applaud them and we love it. At 14 and nine months in

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria, off they go out the door to get that part-time job. But when they are doing year 12

Speaker: NA
Text: and they turn 18, halfway through the year they come to see you, heartbroken because they

Speaker: NA
Text: are no longer in that part-time job. They are too old and they cost too much on an 18-year-

Speaker: NA
Text: old's salary, so they have been replaced by a year 9 student. This will be open to absolute

Speaker: NA
Text: exploitation and abuse, and this government should be ashamed to put it forward as a serious

Speaker: NA
Text: idea.

Speaker: NA
Text: This government wants to address youth unemployment. If they actually want to do

Speaker: NA
Text: something serious for the 260,000 young people in this country that are currently looking for

Speaker: NA
Text: work then perhaps they need to address the way we build infrastructure. Perhaps we could

Speaker: NA
Text: take the advice of the economists around the country and get started on some of those things.

Speaker: NA
Text: I note, too, today that we are talking about a situation where the ABCC bill, which is being

Speaker: NA
Text: put to the Senate, actively discourages large companies from putting on apprentices. So, we

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: will discourage apprenticeships and we will introduce internships-vaguely wrapped

Speaker: NA
Text: internships-in this path-to-nowhere program. Let's look at the notion of internships in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country. We have people doing internships and, as I said, the general view of those

Speaker: NA
Text: internships is that they are part of some kind of university qualification as a workplace

Speaker: NA
Text: placement and, in that sense, they are not necessarily a bad thing. But this legislation is a case

Speaker: NA
Text: of extrapolating from what the community perceives to be a good thing: you are going to a

Speaker: NA
Text: university that is going to give you not just an academic training but also the practical work

Speaker: NA
Text: component that is going to help you become more career ready. Note: we are talking about

Speaker: NA
Text: internships in this country that are generally about building a career; it is an entry level into a

Speaker: NA
Text: career. However, we have now got this down to youth unemployment-youths of 17 to 24

Speaker: NA
Text: years of age. I do not think they are going to build a career from working for 12 weeks for

Speaker: NA
Text: what is ostensibly $100 a week, on top of the government's Newstart allowance. So it is a

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidy for business. It is not about youth unemployment and it is not about preparing kids for

Speaker: NA
Text: work.

Speaker: NA
Text: While I am here, I cannot ignore this notion-and I hear it in this place all the time-of

Speaker: NA
Text: how young people need to be in a program to develop soft work skills. What on earth are soft

Speaker: NA
Text: work skills? Tying your tie? Getting out of bed on time? As someone who has raised three

Speaker: NA
Text: sons, I have watched them all go out to work at very early hours of the morning at young

Speaker: NA
Text: ages. Every young person has to go through that process. We do not spit them out of school,

Speaker: NA
Text: put them in a truck, take them to a job site and say, 'They're ready.' Part of that development is

Speaker: NA
Text: about the relationship between the employer and the young person. When young people go

Speaker: NA
Text: through those first months of getting up and getting ready for work they sometimes stumble.

Speaker: NA
Text: It takes them a little while sometimes to figure out that they actually need to go to bed before

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 pm if they have to be up at 5.30 am. You cannot teach that as part of a program on soft

Speaker: NA
Text: skills. Our employers are not screaming out for young people to have soft skills. Our

Speaker: NA
Text: employers are asking for students who have the skills to work in a collaborative team. They

Speaker: NA
Text: are asking for literacy and numeracy. Most employers know that the soft skills of being polite

Speaker: NA
Text: to people and saying good morning when you get to work will have been learnt at home and

Speaker: NA
Text: that most of those things are about work culture. Work will teach them. They will develop

Speaker: NA
Text: those skills when they are at work.

Speaker: NA
Text: So we have this notion that we are going to subsidise companies to teach soft skills in an

Speaker: NA
Text: internship that is about entry level work for young people. Let's face it, if this legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: comes into being then this internship is going to be about supermarkets. This is going to be

Speaker: NA
Text: about fast food outlets. This is going to be about 7-Eleven not having to break the law

Speaker: NA
Text: anymore, because it will be legal for them to do what they have already been doing. In fact,

Speaker: NA
Text: they will be further subsidised to do exactly what they have been doing, and they will be able

Speaker: NA
Text: to do it without having breached a visa regulation in the process because they will be doing it

Speaker: NA
Text: to young Australian people. This is a road to nowhere. It is a path to nowhere. In fact, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: nowhere for a young person. We know where this path will lead to in terms of work

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions and wages in this country. It will drive down wages. It will drive down conditions.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are my other questions: does this young person get a pay slip? Is this young person

Speaker: NA
Text: going to be on work experience, or are they considered to be an employee? Are they going to

Speaker: NA
Text: be covered by WorkCover? Are they going to be covered by the Fair Work Act? Will they

Speaker: NA
