Text: have to provide their own equipment? Will they be expected to show up with hard shoes on

Speaker: NA
Text: on the first day of job? Will they have to pay for their uniform?

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: This legislation is an absolute thought-bubble from this government. They have not given

Speaker: NA
Text: any consideration to how they might tackle youth unemployment, except to find a way to

Speaker: NA
Text: drive down young people's wages and to drive down work conditions in this country. My last

Speaker: NA
Text: big question is: does the bill specify when these hours of work will occur? Will they be from

Speaker: NA
Text: 8 pm until three in the morning for a job of picking up glasses at a nightclub? Is that the job

Speaker: NA
Text: young people are going to be doing for their Newstart allowance, plus $100? Are there going

Speaker: NA
Text: to be limits on how far from home they can be asked to travel before they are cut off

Speaker: NA
Text: Newstart, because they did not attend the nonworkplace for the noninternship to get their

Speaker: NA
Text: nontraining?

Speaker: NA
Text: This government should come into this place and treat it with some respect. They should

Speaker: NA
Text: approach the creation of legislation that is supposedly about getting young people into work

Speaker: NA
Text: seriously. If they cannot approach it seriously then they should sit down and watch some

Speaker: NA
Text: American films, because I am sure that if they had seen The Pursuit of Happyness this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: would never have come into this chamber. Will Smith did a terrific job in that film, showing

Speaker: NA
Text: us all what Americanisation looks like. If we want to have internships in this country then can

Speaker: NA
Text: we have it so that there is a clear advantage for young people to be engaged in them and it not

Speaker: NA
Text: be an opportunity for potential exploitation?

Speaker: NA
Text: I am going to finish with a quote from Clara Ivy Baird-a good friend of mine. She has

Speaker: NA
Text: worked in this building and now works for Interns Australia. She says:

Speaker: NA
Text: There are countless interns who have gained real life benefits from their internships. Unfortunately,

Speaker: NA
Text: however, the opposite is also true: desperate to pick up work, too many young Australians are being

Speaker: NA
Text: lured in by an 'internship', and then used to pick up dry cleaning, make coffee and fill out data entry,

Speaker: NA
Text: often without being paid at all.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the real experience of a young person who is dealing with other young people. The

Speaker: NA
Text: people she is mostly talking about have a university degree. They are not 17-year-olds straight

Speaker: NA
Text: out of school, ripe for exploitation by this government and its cronies.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Jobs Path: Prepare, Trial, Hire) Bill 2016. Can I say

Speaker: NA
Text: up-front, I commend the member for Lalor on her contribution. She is always worth listening

Speaker: NA
Text: to, and she certainly seemed to cover the perils of this legislation very well.

Speaker: NA
Text: In another life, before I was in parliament, I had a couple of jobs that were less well

Speaker: NA
Text: remunerated than being a politician. I started off my time at high school spending every

Speaker: NA
Text: summer cotton chipping in the cotton fields around St George and then spent time, when I

Speaker: NA
Text: was at teachers college, working in an abattoir and at Hungry Jack's before moving into better

Speaker: NA
Text: paid jobs. I do say, Member for Lalor, that elements of my time as an articled clerk were not

Speaker: NA
Text: unlike what you described, except they did pay me as an articled clerk. I think 'paid slavery'

Speaker: NA
Text: would be the official description.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 2016, we have heard an awful lot about jobs-all that talk of jobs and growth. I think I

Speaker: NA
Text: will need to get a therapist at some stage to get 'jobs and growth' out of my head. The

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition was all about the jobs and growth that they would be creating. But, sadly, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Turnbull government has failed at the very task that they set themselves-to create jobs and

Speaker: NA
Text: to create growth. They set the standard, and they failed. They have not met their own

Speaker: NA
Text: fundamental KPI which was-as written on the side of buses, basically-that they would

Speaker: NA
Text: deliver jobs and deliver growth.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Employment conditions have deteriorated so much that they are now, arguably, worse than

Speaker: NA
Text: at any time since the peak of the global financial crisis. I remind you of that, Deputy Speaker

Speaker: NA
Text: Broadbent, because the global financial crisis was the worst set of economic conditions since

Speaker: NA
Text: the Depression. But that is what we are looking at now. The problem is not just the

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed; there is actually a huge problem in Australia of underemployment. The figure

Speaker: NA
Text: for underemployment for the August quarter was 8.7 per cent. Youth unemployment is at 12.8

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent. There are more than 270,000 unemployed youth between 15 and 24 years of age. A

Speaker: NA
Text: recent report from Anglicare stated that there is only one job advertised for every six low-

Speaker: NA
Text: skilled jobseekers in Australia. The report said that in May this year alone nearly 140,000

Speaker: NA
Text: people competed for roughly 22,000 entry-level jobs advertised across Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a huge problem, and one that will not be solved by the government's PaTH program

Speaker: NA
Text: that is before the chamber. This bill is designed to support the government's prepare, trial, hire

Speaker: NA
Text: program-or PaTH. It provides that payments made to interns under the PaTH program will

Speaker: NA
Text: be excluded from the income test for social security payments, and thus not affect recipients'

Speaker: NA
Text: payments and entitlements. It allows for the suspension for up to 26 weeks of a person's social

Speaker: NA
Text: security payment, where they are employed by a business that is eligible to receive a youth

Speaker: NA
Text: bonus wage subsidy in relation to them under the PaTH program.

Speaker: NA
Text: The problem lies not so much with the provisions in this bill as with the PaTH program

Speaker: NA
Text: itself, as detailed by the member for Lalor. The PaTH program is, appropriately, set to

Speaker: NA
Text: commence on 1 April 2017-because, surely, this is an April Fools Day joke on the young

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Australia. The program claims to provide job seekers aged 17 to 24 with work

Speaker: NA
Text: experience to maximise their prospects of subsequently gaining employment. These are,

Speaker: NA
Text: perhaps, noble intentions. But, although the objectives of the program might have some merit,

Speaker: NA
Text: there are huge problems with the architecture of the scheme. Australia's young unemployed

Speaker: NA
Text: are a very vulnerable group open to exploitation, and good government's job is to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: they are not being unfairly treated.

Speaker: NA
Text: Existing programs, such as the Work for the Dole scheme, do have problems, and you

Speaker: NA
Text: could argue that they are failing. On the government's own figures, nearly 90 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: participants in the Work for the Dole scheme are not in full-time work three months after

Speaker: NA
Text: completing the program. We do not want to see our young unemployed given false hope and

Speaker: NA
Text: working for under award wages in a scheme that is destined to fail them.

Speaker: NA
Text: This scheme, unlike the Work for the Dole scheme, will place young unemployed people in

Speaker: NA
Text: the private sector. Private sector employers will be paid $1,000 as an up-front payment for

Speaker: NA
Text: each jobseeker that they take on through the PaTH scheme. There are concerns that employers

Speaker: NA
Text: could take on large numbers of PaTH participants at any one time. Employers could churn

Speaker: NA
Text: through the participants without ever offering a job to any of them-repeatedly saying, 'This

Speaker: NA
Text: person was unsuitable.' This could result in employers not having to employ workers in

Speaker: NA
Text: particular areas at certain times. For example, an employer in the hospitality industry could

Speaker: NA
Text: use PaTH participants at a time when they would otherwise have to pay their staff penalty

Speaker: NA
Text: rates.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a real concern that the PaTH program will result in jobs being replaced with

Speaker: NA
Text: cheaper labour because of this program. Participants will be 'working' for below minimum

Speaker: NA
Text: award wages. A PaTH participant will receive their Newstart payment plus the $200 incentive

Speaker: NA
Text: payment while they are working for an employer in the program. If the participant is working

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: for 25 hours a week, their hourly rate will be only $14.50. To put that in context, the national

Speaker: NA
Text: minimum wage is $17.70 an hour.

Speaker: NA
Text: The 7-Eleven wage scandal is fresh in our minds-we saw that footage. Here in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: in 2016 people are, effectively, paying their employer for the job that they have. I have not

Speaker: NA
Text: seen a lot of condemnation about that come from those opposite. In light of the 7-Eleven

Speaker: NA
Text: scandal and some of the concerns in the fruit picking area, why should we consider

Speaker: NA
Text: sanctioning the underpayment of our unemployed youth? That problem with the scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: would be very easy to fix. The government would just need to set the bonus payment and the

Speaker: NA
Text: hours to be worked at a rate that equates with the national minimum wage. The fact that the

Speaker: NA
Text: government has not fixed this just shows where their priorities lie-despite their protestations

Speaker: NA
Text: about unions, their priority is never to uphold workers' rights. Wages growth, sadly, is at its

Speaker: NA
Text: lowest on record. The PaTH program could further undermine wages across a variety of

Speaker: NA
Text: industries.

Speaker: NA
Text: A further, very basic, problem with the scheme lies in the government's failure to actually

Speaker: NA
Text: define what they consider an 'intern' will be under the scheme. It is six months since the

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme was announced, and we still have no definition. Can an intern be a waiter, for

Speaker: NA
Text: instance? Can an intern be a shop assistant or a retail assistant? Is there any threshold

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary for the intern to learn new skills? We just do not know. Most people consider

Speaker: NA
Text: interns to be learning something additional to that which they learn in educational institutions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Traditional roles as interns have been found in publishing houses, law firms and other

Speaker: NA
Text: professional services, where you will enhance what is delivered by academics. But it does not

Speaker: NA
Text: seem that the government's definition of an intern will marry with my traditional view of an

Speaker: NA
Text: intern that we are perhaps more familiar with. I should say up-front that I do not have a

Speaker: NA
Text: problem with industries having interns-it is this program that I have significant concerns

Speaker: NA
Text: about.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is another question that the government has not addressed yet-whether the

Speaker: NA
Text: participants in this scheme will be covered by appropriate workers compensation schemes in

Speaker: NA
Text: the event of an accident while they are 'working'. The participants will actually be considered

Speaker: NA
Text: volunteers in the workplace and not employees. This can affect how they will be treated by

Speaker: NA
Text: workers compensation schemes in the event of an accident. So there are many problems that

Speaker: NA
Text: have not been addressed in this scheme, which was way too hurriedly announced by a

Speaker: NA
Text: desperate coalition in their May budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister promised us the end of three-word slogans-but what did we see

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout the election campaign? Jobs and growth. I think I have even heard it this week.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sadly, the Prime Minister has not delivered-on his watch youth unemployment has climbed

Speaker: NA
Text: to nearly 13 per cent, double the national average. The Turnbull government talks the talk but

Speaker: NA
Text: does not walk the walk when it comes to job creation. Representing a marginal seat, I should

Speaker: NA
Text: point out that the Prime Minister decided to start his election campaign in my electorate, in

Speaker: NA
Text: Moreton. It is a marginal seat, so I can understand that. He kicked that off at the Brisbane

Speaker: NA
Text: markets, probably knowing that employment is always an important issue in the electorate of

Speaker: NA
Text: Moreton. In the lead-up to the 2013 election the Liberal-National Party candidate, Malcolm

Speaker: NA
Text: Cole-a good bloke-made a commitment that the coalition would stage a Moreton jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: summit within 100 days of the election. The Abbott government was elected, so the deadline

Speaker: NA
Text: for the coalition government to hold this employment summit, important for Moreton, was

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Monday 16 December 2013. But nothing occurred-not a thing. On 27 September 2013 I

Speaker: NA
Text: wrote to the relevant minister, Senator the Hon. Eric Abetz, a Tasmanian representative,

Speaker: NA
Text: regarding the implementation of the promised summit but to date this coalition 2013 election

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment has not been honoured.

Speaker: NA
Text: This year we had a new election and a new parliament, the Prime Minister was elected by

Speaker: NA
Text: the people of Australia-with a majority of one-so I wrote to Prime Minister Turnbull after

Speaker: NA
Text: the election asking for the commitments made by the LNP during the 2016 election campaign

Speaker: NA
Text: to be honoured and I again asked that the commitment made during the 2013 campaign to

Speaker: NA
Text: hold a Moreton jobs summit also be honoured. You would think, with all the rhetoric coming

Speaker: NA
Text: from this government on jobs and growth, that the Prime Minister would be a man of his

Speaker: NA
Text: word, that he would honour their commitment. Sadly, to this day there is still no jobs summit

Speaker: NA
Text: on the horizon for Moreton- in fact, I have not even had a response from the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: to my letter to him. I call out the coalition government and ask that they honour their

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment-it is so important for the unemployed people in Moreton.

Speaker: NA
Text: In contrast, the Labor Party has always had as its first priority the creation of jobs, and

Speaker: NA
Text: especially preparing youth for jobs. The member for Lalor and I in our previous lives were

Speaker: NA
Text: educators. We know how the important role education plays in giving people opportunities. In

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, Labor announced as a 2007 election commitment the Trade Training Centres in Schools

Speaker: NA
Text: Program. The Labor government's 2008-09 budget subsequently provided $2.5 billion over 10

Speaker: NA
Text: years to implement that program. Four rounds of phase 1 of the program were completed

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Labor government. Sadly, the coalition government announced in 2013 that the

Speaker: NA
Text: funding for the trade training centres would cease following round five of phase 1, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: projects would thereafter be known as trade skills centres. The objectives of the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: program included addressing skills shortages in traditional trades and other eligible

Speaker: NA
Text: occupations by improving student access to trade training facilities that meet industry

Speaker: NA
Text: standards and improving the quality of schooling offered to secondary students undertaking

Speaker: NA
Text: trade related pathways. As this is the graduation season, we know how many students end up

Speaker: NA
Text: working through a variety of courses. People end up at university through a variety of

Speaker: NA
Text: courses, including those trade training courses. The program was also assisting young people

Speaker: NA
Text: to make a successful transition from school to work or further education or training.

Speaker: NA
Text: This program is reaping benefits for the youth in my electorate of Moreton. I recently

Speaker: NA
Text: attended the opening of the trade skills centre at the Runcorn State High School with the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for MCPherson in her ministerial portfolio. Runcorn State High will now be offering

Speaker: NA
Text: their students the incredible benefits of having trade training facilities on site at their school.

Speaker: NA
Text: This facility will make an enormous difference to the future of these students. There will be

Speaker: NA
Text: two more trade skills centres opening in the future at nearby schools. The principals of those

Speaker: NA
Text: schools, Terry Heath from Yeronga State High, also in my electorate, and Linda Galloway of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Balmoral State High, in Griffith, were there to witness the opening of the Runcorn centre.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the opening, I met Michael, who is a grade 10 student at Runcorn State High. He was

Speaker: NA
Text: proud to show me around the facilities. He said he was looking forward to the workshops

Speaker: NA
Text: starting so that he could build a Formula One car-one of the things they do. The Formula

Speaker: NA
Text: High School Program is one of the programs to be offered at the Runcorn State High School.

Speaker: NA
Text: It will teach students engineering skills and practices while building a race car-not quite the

Speaker: NA
Text: same as making a tea cosy for my mum when I was in shop. But this is not just fun; it

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: obviously prepares them for work. Students who undertake the Formula High School Program

Speaker: NA
Text: will be completing a certificate II in Engineering Pathways, an engineering qualification that

Speaker: NA
Text: will equip them to enter a range of occupations. The student participants will learn practical,

Speaker: NA
Text: general, work-ready knowledge and teambuilding skills-real preparation for jobs where

Speaker: NA
Text: students learn a skill that is useful for employers, who will then give them a real job.

Speaker: NA
Text: I fear that this PaTH scheme is not going to result in any more young people obtaining full-

Speaker: NA
Text: time work, but it may put the young unemployed, who are already vulnerable, in situations

Speaker: NA
Text: where they will be exploited. Young people deserve better than to be used and abused by an

Speaker: NA
Text: unscrupulous employer wanting cheap labour. That is my fear. Labor is calling for this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation and the PaTH program itself to be considered by a Senate inquiry to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: these concerns are addressed. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr CRAIG KELLY (Hughes) (13:29): I was not actually going to speak on this bill, but

Speaker: NA
Text: I heard the member for Lalor talking about the movie The Pursuit of Happyness, saying how

Speaker: NA
Text: this is an example of why intern programs are not very good. The member for Lalor may not

Speaker: NA
Text: be aware, but the movie The Pursuit of Happyness was based on a true story of an American

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman called Chris Gardner. He left jail with no experience, no college education, no

Speaker: NA
Text: connections and obtained-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Coulton): Order. The debate is interrupted in accordance

Speaker: NA
Text: with standing order 43. The debate may be resumed at a later hour.

Speaker: NA
Text: STATEMENTS BY MEMBERS

Speaker: NA
Text: Indi Electorate: Jobs and Investment Fund

Speaker: Ms MCGOWAN
Text: Indi) (13:30): I call on the coalition to walk the talk of listening to

Speaker: NA
Text: communities, avoiding duplication and respecting the local knowledge and experience of the

Speaker: NA
Text: leaders in rural and regional Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The case in point: on Monday, in the Federation Chamber, the member for Murray referred

Speaker: NA
Text: to the $20 million promised during the election campaign to the Hume region under the jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: and investment fund. He told us how he called a special meeting of 13 LGAs, who all came

Speaker: NA
Text: together to add their advice to the $20 million jobs and investment fund that has been put

Speaker: NA
Text: forward by the minister, Senator Fiona Nash.

Speaker: NA
Text: What I want to say to the coalition is that the member for Murray did not say that there is

Speaker: NA
Text: already a Commonwealth government advisory body that is commissioned to provide advice

Speaker: NA
Text: on jobs and investment. This is the Hume RDA, which has representatives from LGAs,

Speaker: NA
Text: government, business, industry and community. The chair of the Hume RDA has specifically

Speaker: NA
Text: communicated with the government, and me, to say that the RDA is the ideal body, already

Speaker: NA
Text: set up and already operating, to provide advice on this program. But, sadly, it has been

Speaker: NA
Text: ignored. Another meeting was held and more community people's time was wasted.

Speaker: NA
Text: Recently, in a speech to the Press Club, the Minister for Regional Development lauded our

Speaker: NA
Text: rural leaders and said how pragmatic they are. My message to the coalition is this: do not

Speaker: NA
Text: ignore local advice and experience. Listen to these very pragmatic rural communities,

Speaker: NA
Text: reconsider the wasteful duplication of advisory bodies, and start acting on local priorities.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Crime

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr CRAIG KELLY (Hughes) (13:31): On behalf of the constituents of Hughes, I would

Speaker: NA
Text: like to congratulate our local police forces serving under the command of local area

Speaker: NA
Text: commander Superintendent Julian Griffiths at Sutherland and Superintendent Peter Gillam at

Speaker: NA
Text: Liverpool. You can look at the fine job that they are doing in my local area, and in New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales, by comparing some of the crime statistics in New South Wales with those of Victoria.

Speaker: NA
Text: For motor vehicle theft in New South Wales over the last 12 months, we have seen a 12.6 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent decrease. In Victoria over the same period of time, we have seen a 33 per cent increase in

Speaker: NA
Text: motor vehicle theft. In fact, today, if someone in New South Wales drove across the border

Speaker: NA
Text: into Victoria, they would be 66 per cent more likely to have their car stolen.

Speaker: NA
Text: Also, in robbery, we see that offences in New South Wales are down between 22 and 42

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent. In comparison, we see that offences in Victoria are up 14 per cent. The same goes

Speaker: NA
Text: for break and enter of a dwelling. In New South Wales, the numbers, thankfully, are down 7.2

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent, but in Victoria, they are up 12.6 per cent. For stealing, we are seeing that New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales is down between seven and 10 per cent, whereas theft in Victoria is up 19 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: Congratulations to the NSW Police and congratulations to the New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: government. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Migration

Speaker: Mr KHALIL
Text: Wills) (13:33): The Minister for Immigration and Border Protection

Speaker: NA
Text: confirmed yesterday that he believed that tens of thousands of Lebanese who migrated to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia were a mistake, because 22 of their grandchildren had been charged with terrorist

Speaker: NA
Text: offences. By this twisted logic, all migration from the UK would be a mistake, because David

Speaker: NA
Text: Hicks was charged with terror offences.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister has displayed a breathtaking ignorance of the success of generations of

Speaker: NA
Text: Lebanese Australians, the success of people like former Victorian Premier Steve Bracks,

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia Post CEO Ahmed Fahour Richmond footballer Bachar Houliorr and my mate David

Speaker: NA
Text: Basheer at SBS.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was during the early 1970s that my parents also were able to escape a war-torn Middle

Speaker: NA
Text: East for a life of peace and security in Australia. Like millions of migrants, including the

Speaker: NA
Text: Lebanese, they worked hard and made a contribution to their adopted country, instilling in us,

Speaker: NA
Text: the next generation of Australians, the importance of giving something back to the country

Speaker: NA
Text: that gave us such an opportunity.

Speaker: NA
Text: The minister refused to apologise for his offensive comments; he doubled down. It was a

Speaker: NA
Text: pathetic, sad attempt at divisive politics. He may seek to distract from the myriad failings

Speaker: NA
Text: occurring under this government, but, in doing so, he causes enormous damage to our social

Speaker: NA
Text: cohesion. Worse, he has abrogated his responsibility as Minister for Immigration to bring

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians together. Rather, he has chosen to divide us through fearmongering.

Speaker: NA
Text: And I ask the Minister for Immigration: does he believe, as he does for the hundreds of

Speaker: NA
Text: thousands of Lebanese Australians, that letting my family migrate from Egypt to this country

Speaker: NA
Text: was a mistake?

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Migration

Speaker: Mr LAMING
Text: Bowman) (13:34): On that same topic, the ministerial statement this

Speaker: NA
Text: week-the truthful statement-that 22 of 33, or two-thirds of all terror-related offences, are

Speaker: NA
Text: directly related to one ethno-religious group is just that-truth. We are in a nation that, no

Speaker: NA
Text: matter uncomfortable, has to be able to express the truth. It is prima facie correct, and we, as a

Speaker: NA
Text: nation, need the public interest to decide how important that information is. The minister does

Speaker: NA
Text: not deserve to be criticised by those who do not agree with him.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Ryan interjecting-

Speaker: Mr LAMING
Text: I listened politely to you and I ask Labor to listen politely to me, instead of

Speaker: NA
Text: shutting me down with a gobful. In this dialectic, our failure to engage this reality makes our

Speaker: NA
Text: nation weaker-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Ryan interjecting-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: The member for Lalor.

Speaker: Mr LAMING
Text: Again, I ask Labor to listen as I did to them. If any religious and ethnic

Speaker: NA
Text: group that represents less than half a per cent of our population gets twice the number of carer

Speaker: NA
Text: payments, three times the number of disability payments, twice the amount of Newstart

Speaker: NA
Text: payments, are 94 per cent unemployed when they arrive and remain at 80 per cent two to nine

Speaker: NA
Text: years later, we need to talk about that. It is a failure as much by our system as it is of that

Speaker: NA
Text: group. This is a major PR disaster for this ethnic group. We need to work towards giving their

Speaker: NA
Text: children the education they need, the youth the training they need and the young adults the

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs they need so that can share in the Australian dream. Until we do that, we continue to reap

Speaker: NA
Text: the seeds of terrorism related offences. We can do better. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Dobell Electorate: Veterans

Speaker: Ms MCBRIDE
Text: Dobell) (13:36): The Toukley RSL Sub-Branch will hold a dedication

Speaker: NA
Text: service for their restored cenotaph memorial this Friday. The original cenotaph was erected in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1971 and marks the final resting place of 397 deceased sub-branch members, whose ashes are

Speaker: NA
Text: interred in the cenotaph memorial gardens. With the passing of time, the condition of the

Speaker: NA
Text: names on the plaques has, sadly, deteriorated. The sub-branch members got to work and

Speaker: NA
Text: significantly upgraded the memorial. The plaques have been restored and, once again, names

Speaker: NA
Text: can be read and remembered. The concrete plinths are now beautiful granite borders, and a

Speaker: NA
Text: new rosemary garden creates a fitting place for members, families and the community to

Speaker: NA
Text: remember our departed veterans.

Speaker: NA
Text: The service this week will be marked by the planting of a lone pine, struck from a seed that

Speaker: NA
Text: originated in Gallipoli. This memorial, which pays tribute to those who made the ultimate

Speaker: NA
Text: sacrifice in the First World War, is part of the sub-branch's broader Centenary of Anzac

Speaker: NA
Text: commemorations. A plaque remembering those who participated in the Vietnam conflict will

Speaker: NA
Text: also be unveiled. I congratulate Toukley RSL Sub-branch President Bob Wilson; his vice-

Speaker: NA
Text: presidents, Tom Hobbs and Keith Bailey; and sub-branch secretary, Graham Tredinnick, on

Speaker: NA
Text: their work in returning dignity to the memorial. Thank you to all members of the Toukley

Speaker: NA
Text: sub-branch and the women's auxiliary for your ongoing work supporting returned servicemen

Speaker: NA
Text: and their families. The Dobell community pays tribute to the service and sacrifice of those

Speaker: NA
Text: who endured the horrors of war in defence of our nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Capricornia Electorate: Adani Solar Farm

Speaker: Ms LANDRY
Text: Capricornia-Deputy Nationals Whip) (13:38): With many job losses in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Queensland coal sector in the past few years, I rise today to inform the House of some

Speaker: NA
Text: good news. Indian based energy company Adani will construct a $200 million solar farm near

Speaker: NA
Text: Moranbah, in the inland coalfields of my electorate of Capricornia. The project is touted to

Speaker: NA
Text: create hundreds of new jobs over various stages of the work. This will provide a welcome

Speaker: NA
Text: shot in the arm for the mining town, normally reliant on coal. The Adani energy company will

Speaker: NA
Text: build the solar plant on 600 hectares of land on a local cattle property about 20 kilometres

Speaker: NA
Text: from Moranbah. The 100 megawatts of power to be generated will be significant, and this

Speaker: NA
Text: project, along with the Adani Carmichael coal project, demonstrates the company is

Speaker: NA
Text: committed to Queensland and job creation. The company expects construction to begin on the

Speaker: NA
Text: solar farm in mid-2017. The federal government has a policy of transitioning the economy

Speaker: NA
Text: from being resources-heavy to a future of innovation and technology, and this is one type of

Speaker: NA
Text: project that meets this goal. It also adds to our bipartisan, fully legislated renewable energy

Speaker: NA
Text: target of 23.5 per cent by 2020. For the record, Adani coal will not be used in Australia but

Speaker: NA
Text: will be exported to India.

Speaker: NA
Text: Werriwa Electorate: Amity College

Speaker: Ms STANLEY
Text: Werriwa) (13:39): This year, Amity College in Prestons celebrates its

Speaker: NA
Text: 20th anniversary. I was very privileged to be present for the celebration of this milestone in

Speaker: NA
Text: September and again at the college last weekend for the year 12 graduation. The school was

Speaker: NA
Text: originally established by volunteers, with 33 students. It now has enrolments exceeding 1,800,

Speaker: NA
Text: with other campuses at Auburn and Shellharbour. As a local, I have been able to watch the

Speaker: NA
Text: school grow to the excellent teaching facility that it is today. I am always inspired by the

Speaker: NA
Text: achievements of its students, not only academically but also in the extra activities and

Speaker: NA
Text: volunteer pursuits that the students are encouraged to pursue.

Speaker: NA
Text: South-west Sydney has a highly diverse population. Many people move to my area looking

Speaker: NA
Text: to raise their children. Our schools serve as community focal points and are a key part in

Speaker: NA
Text: helping shape these communities. Amity lives up to its name. It is a proud embodiment of the

Speaker: NA
Text: multicultural tradition of Western Sydney and of Werriwa and is an asset to my community.

Speaker: NA
Text: Twenty years is a long time, and the college is now beginning to span generations. Students

Speaker: NA
Text: who attended here in the 1990s are now sending their own children to the school, and former

Speaker: NA
Text: students are teachers. I congratulate the executive principal, Denis Erdogan; girls principal,

Speaker: NA
Text: Alpaslan Cem Sancili; boys principal, Atilla Sinik; and chair of the school's board, Abdullah

Speaker: NA
Text: Aksu; as well as teachers and students, for the great- (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: South Burnett CTC

Speaker: Mr LITTLEPROUD
Text: Maranoa) (13:41): Today I would like to acknowledge the

Speaker: NA
Text: crucially important contribution of South Burnett CTC, who work with those with disabilities

Speaker: NA
Text: in the South Burnett region. The humble beginnings of South Burnett CTC were as a

Speaker: NA
Text: grassroots community response to youth unemployment back in 1983. The dedicated,

Speaker: NA
Text: compassionate and community-minded people at South Burnett CTC have ensured that this

Speaker: NA
Text: not-for-profit organisation has grown into a multifaceted community-owned service for

Speaker: NA
Text: people across South Burnett, including Gumnut, which provides supported employment

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities for up to 20 people with disabilities.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Last week I was fortunate enough to attend the opening of Heritage Lodge in Nanango, an

Speaker: NA
Text: accommodation precinct of duplexes designed and managed by South Burnett CTC, to allow

Speaker: NA
Text: people with disabilities to live independently. As I sat there at the opening ceremony,

Speaker: NA
Text: listening to Nina Temperton, the CEO of South Burnett CTC, I was reminded of the value of

Speaker: NA
Text: the sheer dedication and commitment of passionate and community-minded people like Nina,

Speaker: NA
Text: people on the ground who see a need and pursue the solution relentlessly. I would also like to

Speaker: NA
Text: note Heritage Nanango Community Funding Ltd, South Burnett Regional Council and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland state government for their contributions to this project.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is the community spirit I have been witnessing all over my electorate that I will be

Speaker: NA
Text: highlighting this Christmas. These amazing people, whether they are paid or whether they are

Speaker: NA
Text: volunteers, contribute so much to our social fabric and serve as a timely reminder of the

Speaker: NA
Text: importance of our roles in being advocates for our respective communities.

Speaker: NA
Text: Burt Electorate: Mosque Attacks

Speaker: Mr KEOGH
Text: Burt) (13:42): There are some experiences during campaigns that shake and

Speaker: NA
Text: disturb you to the core. I am referring to the disgusting and cowardly attacks on two mosques

Speaker: NA
Text: in the electorate of Burt during the recent election campaign: the leaving of insulting and

Speaker: NA
Text: disgusting objects at the Southern River mosque, and the fire-bombing of a car and graffiti at

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Islamic College and mosque in Thornlie. The new electorate of Burt is one of

Speaker: NA
Text: the most multicultural in Western Australia-a diversity that should be celebrated. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: moved on from the Christian sectarianism so commonplace in Australia until merely a

Speaker: NA
Text: generation ago, so must we as a nation move on from religious vilification and attacks of all

Speaker: NA
Text: forms.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet some members of different religious traditions face religious persecution every day in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. As retired Chief of Army Lieutenant General David Morrison AO so elegantly

Speaker: NA
Text: expressed it, the standard you walk past is the standard you accept. As a multicultural society,

Speaker: NA
Text: we must accept and protect each and every person's right to practise their faith freely and

Speaker: NA
Text: without any form of intimidation or violence, just as we ask them to do the same and as we all

Speaker: NA
Text: stand for the Australian fair go.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to acknowledge the good work of the WA Police in their investigations and

Speaker: NA
Text: support of the local community; the state member for Gosnells and Thornlie, Chris Tallentire;

Speaker: NA
Text: and City of Gosnells councillor Terry Healy, for responding so quickly to help the local

Speaker: NA
Text: community clean up before the children arrived for school the next morning, as well as Salim

Speaker: NA
Text: and Raif Youssef, the current and former presidents of the Australian Arab Association and

Speaker: NA
Text: proud Lebanese Australians in my electorate, who are in the gallery here today.

Speaker: NA
Text: Maddinson, Mr Nic

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs SUDMALIS (Gilmore) (13:44): As anyone will tell you-particularly my family-I

Speaker: NA
Text: am usually not much of a cricket watcher. However, when parliament closes on Thursday, I

Speaker: NA
Text: will be searching for the cricket highlights, because Nic Maddinson will make his debut for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia in the third test against South Africa. Nic will play on the Adelaide Oval. While this

Speaker: NA
Text: is one of cricket's greatest honours, more importantly Nic is a resident of the Shoalhaven area,

Speaker: NA
Text: in my electorate of Gilmore. Alongside fellow Shoalhaven resident Ian Davis, Nic will be the

Speaker: NA
Text: Shoalhaven's second test cricketer.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Nic has had close to 60 first-class games and has previously played for Australia in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Twenty20 and an Australian A team. On the local scene, Nic has competed in the Bradman

Speaker: NA
Text: Cup, Southern Zone and country teams. He began playing representative cricket for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Shoalhaven in the under-12s, competed in state teams and national junior teams and was a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the Australian under-19s who successfully competed in and won the World Cup in

Speaker: NA
Text: Locally, Nic has been awarded the Shoalhaven Sportstar of the Year award for three years

Speaker: NA
Text: and was also the recipient of the very famous Bernie Regan Memorial Sporting Trust Grant.

Speaker: NA
Text: More than five years ago, at the age of 18 years, Nic made his Sheffield Shield debut in

Speaker: NA
Text: Adelaide and posted 113, which broke a 70-year-old state record as the youngest century-

Speaker: NA
Text: maker on debut. Everyone in our region will be sending their best wishes to Nic in his first

Speaker: NA
Text: test cricket match because he makes us all so proud. Go, Nic!

Speaker: NA
Text: Geelong: Digital Billboard

Speaker: Mr MARLES
Text: Corio) (13:45): Back in April, VCAT approved a giant digital billboard on

Speaker: NA
Text: the corner of Yarra and Malop Streets. It is twice the size of a similar digital billboard

Speaker: NA
Text: installed on the corner of Moorabool and Ryrie Streets. The City of Greater Geelong had

Speaker: NA
Text: refused to grant a permit for the 'sky sign', citing that it did not suit the location, was

Speaker: NA
Text: oversized and shared no objective with the Central Geelong Urban Design Guidelines.

Speaker: NA
Text: The council was right. This sort of large electronic advertising sign in the heart of our CBD

Speaker: NA
Text: distracts from the very things that Geelong should be emphasising: our history, our

Speaker: NA
Text: architecture and our heritage. Geelong is one of the most historic towns in Australia, although

Speaker: NA
Text: we do not often think of ourselves in this way. Indeed, the Geelong CBD has one of the best

Speaker: NA
Text: collections of heritage buildings adjacent to water anywhere in the country. The woolsheds,

Speaker: NA
Text: the factories, the shopfronts and the Customs House-these are what make Geelong special,

Speaker: NA
Text: not electronic billboards, and we will never compete on the basis of neon signs with our large

Speaker: NA
Text: neighbour up the road.

Speaker: NA
Text: I firmly believe that the secret to reinvigorating our CBD does not lie in flashy lights. Just

Speaker: NA
Text: like Ballarat and Bendigo, but potentially on a much bigger scale, it lies in developing our

Speaker: NA
Text: heritage. It is important we show off who we are as a city and do not allow our beautiful

Speaker: NA
Text: architecture and streets to fall into the background. Let us show off the art gallery, the

Speaker: NA
Text: telegraph station, the Gordon, the boardwalk and the old Geelong post office, because they

Speaker: NA
Text: tell our story; they tell Geelong's deeply historic story.

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade with Hong Kong

Speaker: Dr MCVEIGH
Text: Groom) (13:47): The first consignment of international air freight from

Speaker: NA
Text: the nation's largest privately-owned airport touched down in Hong Kong this morning. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: a remarkable case of endeavour and initiative from the Darling Downs. Many said it was a

Speaker: NA
Text: pipe dream. But those naysayers have learnt that Toowoomba's Wagner family should never

Speaker: NA
Text: be underestimated. Due to their foresight and the commitment of local families and

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses, the potential for our electorate of Groom is only limited by the constraints we

Speaker: NA
Text: place on ourselves.

Speaker: NA
Text: Not so long ago, people would have thought that air-freighting fresh produce to Asian

Speaker: NA
Text: markets from the Downs was a good idea but one fraught with challenges. Well, last night, a

Speaker: NA
Text: Cathay Pacific Airways 747 cargo flight did just that. It was loaded with chilled beef and

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: other produce to be taken to market. This regular service will see Australian clean, green and

Speaker: NA
Text: safe produce from the Darling Downs flown directly into Asia-including, for example,

Speaker: NA
Text: premium beef loin cuts from Oakey Beef Exports destined for high-end restaurants in Hong

Speaker: NA
Text: Kong.

Speaker: NA
Text: Groom is truly a world-class example of industry leading business and job creation and

Speaker: NA
Text: growth, and of all levels of government supporting and facilitating where appropriate. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: proud to say: that is exactly what the Turnbull government has been doing in securing

Speaker: NA
Text: approvals for this airport, investing heavily in our roads, and getting on with the job of inland

Speaker: NA
Text: rail.

Speaker: NA
Text: Smith, Mr Michael

Speaker: Ms CHESTERS
Text: Bendigo) (13:48): Today I rise to welcome to the Speaker's gallery

Speaker: NA
Text: Michael Smith. Michael Smith has been on a journey. He has walked 600 kilometres from

Speaker: NA
Text: Chewton in the Bendigo electorate in central Victoria to this place, to raise and highlight one

Speaker: NA
Text: of his great concerns. Michael has actually drafted a bill. He believes that it is this place and

Speaker: NA
Text: this parliament that should make the decision about whether this country enters into armed

Speaker: NA
Text: conflict and whether we deploy to war; he does not believe that it should be made by one

Speaker: NA
Text: person. In a recent interview with the ABC, Michael said:

Speaker: NA
Text: I don't think these decisions should be with one person. I think that the more people that are involved

Speaker: NA
Text: in the decision, the better decision we'll get.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are Michael's views.

Speaker: NA
Text: We should congratulate and acknowledge anybody with this passion and commitment. To

Speaker: NA
Text: walk 600 kays to come here to raise this issue is a fantastic effort. And I know that the people

Speaker: NA
Text: of Chewton-the people's republic of Chewton-are very proud of Michael's efforts.

Speaker: NA
Text: What this does is to remind all of us that we have great responsibility in this place, and,

Speaker: NA
Text: when one of our constituents makes this kind of effort, we should take time to discuss this in

Speaker: NA
Text: our party room and in our caucuses to see what more we can do in this area. Congratulations,

Speaker: NA
Text: Michael, on your efforts.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tangney Electorate: Willetton Bowling Club

Speaker: Mr MORTON
Text: Tangney) (13:50): It was great news for the Willetton Bowling Club in

Speaker: NA
Text: Tangney when I was able to telephone Club President Max Strange to let him know that a

Speaker: NA
Text: $250,000 grant from the federal government would be on its way to their club very soon. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Regional Development, Fiona Nash, has approved a Community Development

Speaker: NA
Text: Grant for a new synthetic green at this club that delivers on our election commitment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Willetton Bowling Club will also install new lighting to complete the project, with an

Speaker: NA
Text: additional $20,000 from a Stronger Communities grant. Importantly, Willetton Bowling Club

Speaker: NA
Text: will contribute their own fundraising towards these projects.

Speaker: NA
Text: The new Ultra Dry Max Pro synthetic grass green is great news for pennants players. And

Speaker: NA
Text: the new lights will mean both social and competition bowlers can play later into the evening

Speaker: NA
Text: and on more days of the year. Wet weather will no longer stop the members and friends at

Speaker: NA
Text: Willetton Bowling Club from getting out on the green and enjoying a game. The fantastic

Speaker: NA
Text: club rooms built in recent years by the City of Canning and the new synthetic green and new

Speaker: NA
Text: lighting will make Willetton Bowling Club's facilities second to none.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: I cannot wait to see the project completed before next winter, and I look forward to getting

Speaker: NA
Text: down to the club to catch up with members very soon.

Speaker: NA
Text: Jagajaga Electorate: Pasinis, Mr Jim

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Text: Jagajaga) (13:52): I am very pleased today to acknowledge the enormous

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution of Jim Pasinis as chief executive of Banyule Community Health. This month Jim

Speaker: NA
Text: has stepped down from his role as chief executive officer, a position he has held for the last

Speaker: NA
Text: 26 years. Jim has led the extraordinary growth of Banyule Community Health, an incredible

Speaker: NA
Text: community health organisation that has been at the heart of West Heidelberg for more than 40

Speaker: NA
Text: years. It is one of the original Whitlam community health centres. It is a very lively

Speaker: NA
Text: community centre, where everyone knows that they can get the health and social services that

Speaker: NA
Text: they need.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under Jim's leadership, Banyule Community Health has been completely rebuilt into its

Speaker: NA
Text: fantastic modern home in Alamein Road. This simply would not have been possible without

Speaker: NA
Text: Jim's commitment, dedication and hard work. In 2016, Jim was awarded Banyule Citizen of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Year in recognition of his commitment to social justice. West Heidelberg will miss him. I

Speaker: NA
Text: will miss him. Yes, we will miss his quirky sense of humour but, above all, we will miss his

Speaker: NA
Text: compassion, his commitment to social justice and his strong leadership. Thank you, Jim.

Speaker: NA
Text: Flynn Electorate: Drought

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr O'DOWD (Flynn) (13:53): I wish to speak today about the most widespread drought

Speaker: NA
Text: in Queensland's history. Despite fantastic winter rains across most of Queensland and record

Speaker: NA
Text: high prices for beef cattle, many producers are still doing it tough and know the drought is not

Speaker: NA
Text: over yet. Rainfall over the last two months is down by 80 per cent on average. More than 80

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of Queensland is still drought-declared, including almost the entire electorate of

Speaker: NA
Text: Flynn. North Burnett, South Burnett, Banana Shire, the Gladstone region and the Bundaberg

Speaker: NA
Text: region are completely declared. Only the Rockhampton area and the northern reaches of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Central Highlands are no longer declared.

Speaker: NA
Text: June and July, which are normally very dry months, provided welcome relief for many

Speaker: NA
Text: landholders across the state, with record rainfall in these parts-but, unfortunately, it does not

Speaker: NA
Text: rain money. While the dust was settled and grass grew, livestock prices remained incredibly

Speaker: NA
Text: high, making restocking a high-risk venture, especially when there is no guarantee of much-

Speaker: NA
Text: needed follow-up rain. As we wind up for the year, I hope that those in this place will spare a

Speaker: NA
Text: thought and a prayer for our farmers, as they need the rain to provide you with Christmas

Speaker: NA
Text: dinner.

Speaker: NA
Text: Multiculturalism

Speaker: Ms RYAN
Text: Lalor-Opposition Whip) (13:54): I stand here as a proud Australian. There

Speaker: NA
Text: are lots of things about Australia that I am proud of. One of the things I am proudest of is that

Speaker: NA
Text: a country that was built as a supposed prison built a great democracy and embedded the rule

Speaker: NA
Text: of law in our great egalitarian society. I am incredibly proud to call myself an Australian, and

Speaker: NA
Text: I am incredibly proud of our multiculturalism. But I am saddened that this week a minister of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Crown has come into this place and sought to divide this country-sought to smear a

Speaker: NA
Text: whole community on the actions of so few.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the things about the rule of law in this country that I am so proud of is that we hold

Speaker: NA
Text: individuals accountable for their actions. We do not hold the entire Catholic community

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible for the sexual assault against children that happened in our history. If that were

Speaker: NA
Text: the case, all of us in this chamber would be ashamed. We do not smear a whole community on

Speaker: NA
Text: the back of the actions of a few. We have rule of law in this country. I am ashamed that a

Speaker: NA
Text: minister of the Crown would come into this place and try to divide and smear communities.

Speaker: NA
Text: But he has had practice. In the last week they have also been trying to smear every unionist in

Speaker: NA
Text: the country for the actions of a few.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sunshine Coast: Infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr TED O'BRIEN (Fairfax) (13:55): I am delighted to say something positive on the

Speaker: NA
Text: back of such negativity coming from the opposition. When it comes to strong representation,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Sunshine Coast is back. Admittedly, we actually had a few tough years, because my

Speaker: NA
Text: predecessor, the former member for Fairfax, was a serial absentee. I think he attended less

Speaker: NA
Text: than eight per cent of divisions. But, boy, has the world changed now. It has changed because

Speaker: NA
Text: we have a united force, with the member for Fisher, with the member for Wide Bay and with

Speaker: NA
Text: me as the member for Fairfax, working exactly how the Turnbull government works:

Speaker: NA
Text: delivering as a united team.

Speaker: NA
Text: Look at the big ticket items on the Sunshine Coast. Take the Bruce Highway, with over a

Speaker: NA
Text: billion dollars on local stretches of the Bruce Highway. Then there is the Sunshine Coast

Speaker: NA
Text: Airport. Within four months alone, what have we seen? We have seen an environmental green

Speaker: NA
Text: light-tick, done, delivered. We have also seen the designation of the airport as an

Speaker: NA
Text: international airport-done, tick, delivered. As of last week, the Turnbull government

Speaker: NA
Text: announced a $181 million concessional loan to that airport-done, tick, delivered. We will

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to work as a united team to deliver for the Sunshine Coast.

Speaker: NA
Text: Multiculturalism

Speaker: Mr HAMMOND
Text: Perth) (13:57): I rise to speak on behalf of those very good people in

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate of Perth, who the Minister for Immigration and others on the government side

Speaker: NA
Text: might like to describe as 'the children of second and third generation immigrants'. Those

Speaker: NA
Text: electors who I am privileged to speak on behalf of are so much more than that and so much

Speaker: NA
Text: more than the unfair and untrue slur that the Minister for Immigration and those on that side

Speaker: NA
Text: would like to paint them as. They are doctors, they are nurses, they are teachers, they are hard

Speaker: NA
Text: workers and their mums and dads contribute to P&Cs. They are Australians, and they are the

Speaker: NA
Text: people who make this country what it is.

Speaker: NA
Text: They do not deserve to be painted, as the members of the other side would like to have

Speaker: NA
Text: them painted, as those who are responsible for the security of this country being at risk. They

Speaker: NA
Text: are Australians. There is a culture on the other side where the member for Bowman, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Immigration and the Prime Minister hide behind a number of facts without

Speaker: NA
Text: displaying the truth. The truth is that these are not immigrants; these are Australians. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister is held captive to his conservative right. This Prime Minister is now just

Speaker: NA
Text: somebody that we used to know.

Speaker: NA
Text: Wide Bay Electorate: Bruce Highway Upgrade

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr LLEW O'BRIEN (Wide Bay) (13:59): It was a pleasure to welcome the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Infrastructure and Transport to Wide Bay last week to inspect progress on the Bruce

Speaker: NA
Text: Highway, Cooroy to Curra, four-lane Section C project. Section C is a 10.5 kilometre stretch

Speaker: NA
Text: of highway from Traveston to Woondum and is scheduled to finish in mid-2018. The

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: construction phase is supporting around 600 jobs and, when completed, will boost the local

Speaker: NA
Text: economy. At the 2013 election, the coalition government committed to $2 billion to upgrade

Speaker: NA
Text: the Bruce Highway through Wide Bay. The Cooroy to Curra four-lane upgrade will make that

Speaker: NA
Text: section safer, faster and less congested, and it will improve flood immunity to prevent

Speaker: NA
Text: Gympie being cut off when the Mary River floods. It will also improve the capacity to move

Speaker: NA
Text: freight more efficiently along the coast. This will support major industry in the region,

Speaker: NA
Text: including the timber industry, manufacturing, dairying and local agriculture.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Cooroy to Curra section was rated as one of the most dangerous sections of highway.

Speaker: NA
Text: Between 2002 and 2014 more than 50 people lost their lives along this deadly stretch.

Speaker: NA
Text: Regrettably, there are still too many lives being touched by the horror of serious accidents

Speaker: NA
Text: along this section yet to be upgraded. We need to continue to invest in the highway to make it

Speaker: NA
Text: safer and complete the full Cooroy to Curra project, including the 26 kilometre section D

Speaker: NA
Text: project to bypass Gympie.

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament House: Christmas Carols

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Tonight in the Members Hall, the Canberra Choral Society will be singing Christmas carols

Speaker: NA
Text: for the benefit of the members, staff and others who inhabit the building, including Laura

Speaker: NA
Text: Tingle. I am sure we would much prefer to hear Laura Tingle singing than her husband, Alan

Speaker: NA
Text: Ramsey, who probably does not have nearly as nice a voice!

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: In accordance with standing order 43, the time for members' statements

Speaker: NA
Text: has concluded.

Speaker: NA
Text: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Speaker: NA
Text: Domestic and Family Violence

Speaker: Mr SHORTEN
Text: Maribyrnong-Leader of the Opposition) (14:01): My question is to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister. Congratulations on your words at White Ribbon this morning. All of us agree

Speaker: NA
Text: that family violence is a national crisis. Rosie Batty, the Productivity Commission and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Victorian Royal Commission into Family Violence have all recommended that family

Speaker: NA
Text: violence survivors should not be cross-examined in court by their abusers. Will the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister join with Labor to amend the Family Law Act to ensure that vulnerable witnesses are

Speaker: NA
Text: protected during court proceedings?

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Wentworth-Prime Minister) (14:01): I want to thank the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition for his question, and thank him, his colleagues and all members for their support

Speaker: NA
Text: for White Ribbon. Addressing domestic violence is a priority for all of us. We have to stop it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Violence against women and children is utterly unacceptable. The truth is that not all

Speaker: NA
Text: disrespect of women ends up with violence against women, but that is where all violence

Speaker: NA
Text: against women begins. We have to lead with legislation, investments and government actions.

Speaker: NA
Text: But one of the most important things we have to do, as parents or grandparents, is say that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: our responsibility to make sure our sons and our grandsons grow up to respect the women in

Speaker: NA
Text: their lives, beginning with their mothers and their sisters-those most close to them. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: critically important. It is a point my wife, Lucy, has often made-it is a powerful one. That

Speaker: NA
Text: role of leadership is driving cultural change. The advertising campaign that I know all of us

Speaker: NA
Text: have admired, Stop it at the Start, that Senator Cash oversaw, has been particularly effective.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me address the issue of cross examination. We all understand that the cross-

Speaker: NA
Text: examination of a victim by the alleged perpetrator is a very traumatic experience. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: working very closely with the stakeholders in this area, in particular the judges and

Speaker: NA
Text: magistrates of the family courts, to progress measures to support vulnerable witnesses. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: establishing integrated duty lawyer and domestic violence support services in the family law

Speaker: NA
Text: courts to improve the support available to victims, and that includes assisting them to draft

Speaker: NA
Text: notices of risk and access alternative ways to give evidence. We have also commissioned a

Speaker: NA
Text: bench book which provides guidance for all judicial officers dealing with domestic and family

Speaker: NA
Text: violence, including guidelines for courtroom management to minimise secondary abuse

Speaker: NA
Text: through court processes of those that have experienced family violence. Judges and judicial

Speaker: NA
Text: officers always have a discretion, of course, in this area, and we are encouraging them to use

Speaker: NA
Text: this very actively to ensure that these distressing circumstances do not occur.

Speaker: NA
Text: I noted what the honourable member opposite proposed this morning and the funding that

Speaker: NA
Text: he recommended, which, at first examination, would not appear to us to be adequate for the

Speaker: NA
Text: task that he has proposed. But I can assure honourable members opposite we are very well

Speaker: NA
Text: aware of the trauma that victims suffer if they are cross-examined by a perpetrator, and we

Speaker: NA
Text: have put in place the measures to ensure that that does not occur where it would create that

Speaker: NA
Text: type of trauma.

Speaker: NA
Text: Turnbull Government

Speaker: Mr HOWARTH
Text: Petrie) (14:05): My question is to the Prime Minister. Will the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister please update the House on the government's record of delivering on its election

Speaker: NA
Text: commitments, including tackling union corruption and ensuring that employer organisations

Speaker: NA
Text: are more accountable to their members as well?

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Members on both sides: the Prime Minister has the call.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Wentworth-Prime Minister) (14:05): I thank the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for his question. The government is getting on with the job. We are delivering for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian people. We are providing the strong and stable economic leadership Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: needs in this time of great change and even greater opportunity. To secure our future

Speaker: NA
Text: prosperity, to ensure that our children and grandchildren can enjoy the same and better

Speaker: NA
Text: standards of living than that which we enjoy we must live within our means and we must

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to pursue sound economic reforms, and that is exactly what we are doing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Just this morning, the parliament passed our superannuation reforms, ensuring that the

Speaker: NA
Text: superannuation system is fair and sustainable for all Australians. We are making the 45th

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament work-an obligation that falls to all of us-delivering important economic

Speaker: NA
Text: reforms, including around $20 billion in gross budget repair; tax cuts to stop half a million

Speaker: NA
Text: middle-income Australians from entering the second-highest tax bracket; building on our big

Speaker: NA
Text: export trade deals by enhancing our free trade and strategic agreement with Singapore; and,

Speaker: NA
Text: for the first time, the parliament has passed the Fair Work (Registered Organisations)

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment Bill 2014. The 44th Parliament rejected the bill three times; now it has been

Speaker: NA
Text: passed.

Speaker: NA
Text: This will ensure that union officials are as accountable to their members as company

Speaker: NA
Text: directors are to their shareholders. We are cracking down on the dishonesty and the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: malfeasance, the misuse and the abuse that has become all too common with union bosses.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are standing up for the workers. We are standing up for the members of trade unions.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are entitled to see that their money is well spent. They are entitled to know how it is

Speaker: NA
Text: spent. They are entitled to know where there are conflicts of interest. They are entitled to

Speaker: NA
Text: know whether their hard-earned union dues are being frittered away by union officials on

Speaker: NA
Text: personal extravagances.

Speaker: NA
Text: You would think that the Leader of the Opposition, a former union boss himself and a

Speaker: NA
Text: former senior union leader, would support this. After all, given the scandals that we saw with

Speaker: NA
Text: Craig Thompson and others-so many of them have been exposed in the Heydon royal

Speaker: NA
Text: commission that there have been two arrests just over the last few days-and the $870,000

Speaker: NA
Text: misappropriated from the National Union of Workers, who are some of the lowest-paid

Speaker: NA
Text: workers in Australia, you would think that the Labor Party, composed as it is of so many

Speaker: NA
Text: former union officials, would say, 'Here is a chance to clean up the act. Here is a chance to

Speaker: NA
Text: make unions more attractive than they are today and make people more confident about

Speaker: NA
Text: joining them.' Labor did not do that. Labor backed the bosses. We backed the members.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget

Speaker: Mr BOWEN
Text: MCMahon) (14:08): My question is to the Treasurer. Ratings agency

Speaker: NA
Text: Standard & Poor's has today warned that Australia's AAA credit rating will be at risk unless

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer stands by his commitment to a surplus in 2021, a commitment which is in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer's own budget papers that bear his name. With his chaotic management of the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget, does the Treasurer take any responsibility for placing Australia's AAA rating at risk?

Speaker: Mr MORRISON
Text: Cook-Treasurer) (14:09): I thank the member opposite for his

Speaker: NA
Text: question. The budget is projected to return to balance in 2021. That balance is contingent

Speaker: NA
Text: upon the $40 billion worth of budget improvement measures that are contained in the budget

Speaker: NA
Text: and the forward estimates being passed by this parliament. I am pleased that the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister has just reminded the House that some $20 billion of that $40 billion has already

Speaker: NA
Text: been passed through this parliament in just these few sitting weeks since the last election.

Speaker: NA
Text: That demonstrates that this government is getting on with the job of implementing our budget

Speaker: NA
Text: measures. But there remains a further $20 billion, which those opposite remain substantively

Speaker: NA
Text: opposed to. The greatest guarantee for the AAA credit rating that those opposite could give

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian people is to say that they will support the government's budget savings

Speaker: NA
Text: measures.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government has laid out our plan in the budget. What stands in our way is the refusal

Speaker: NA
Text: of those opposite to stand up to their economic responsibility, heed the warnings from the

Speaker: NA
Text: ratings agencies and pass the government's budget. But they have an alternative plan! Their

Speaker: NA
Text: view is that the ratings agencies would rush to reaffirm Australia's AAA credit rating if the

Speaker: NA
Text: deficit were to be increased by $16.8 billion. So confident were they that that would be the

Speaker: NA
Text: case that they took a $16½ billion increased deficit to the last election. And what happened at

Speaker: NA
Text: the last election? You took a $16½ billion deficit increase to the last election and it was no

Speaker: NA
Text: surprise that the Australian people rejected you.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Macklin interjecting-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Moreton and, again, the member for Jagajaga will cease

Speaker: NA
Text: interjecting. We are heading down a certain track, I fear, with the member for Jagajaga.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs SUDMALIS (Gilmore) (14:11): My question also is to the Treasurer. Will the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer update the House on how the government is strengthening Australia's economy by

Speaker: NA
Text: reducing the deficit and arresting debt? Will the Treasurer again explain how important it is

Speaker: NA
Text: that the budget measures currently before parliament are passed to protect Australia's AAA

Speaker: NA
Text: credit rating?

Speaker: Mr MORRISON
Text: Cook-Treasurer) (14:12): I thank the member for her question and

Speaker: NA
Text: her keen interest. More importantly, I thank her and those who sit on this side of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: for their support for the government's budget, which is projected to return to balance in 2021.

Speaker: NA
Text: But, as I just remarked to the House, there are some impediments that stand in the way of that,

Speaker: NA
Text: and they sit opposite. I turn to none other than the support given by the former Treasurer and

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister, Paul Keating, who said this earlier this year: 'When Commonwealth revenue

Speaker: NA
Text: has been so affected, the penny ought to drop; that what we should be doing is cutting

Speaker: NA
Text: spending. That is what the Treasurer'-referring to myself-'has said for some weeks now,

Speaker: NA
Text: and on this point he is actually right.' So we have the former Treasurer and Prime Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: whom the shadow Treasurer claims is his great mentor, telling him direct, just as the ratings

Speaker: NA
Text: agencies are telling him direct: pass the budget savings measures to ensure the security of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's AAA credit rating.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since 2013, as a government, under both Prime Minister Abbott and Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: Turnbull, we have already cut the rate of spending growth from 4.2 per cent, as it was under

Speaker: NA
Text: the budgets of those opposite, to around 1½ per cent under the budgets of the coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: government. That is what we have achieved, and that is how we are arresting the debt. But we

Speaker: NA
Text: are faced with the impediment of those opposite, who would rather spend more and tax more

Speaker: NA
Text: and raise debt to even higher levels than actually face up to their economic responsibility and

Speaker: NA
Text: come into this place and support the government's comprehensive plan to achieve budget

Speaker: NA
Text: repair. Of the measures that I refer to, we have already been able to pass some $20 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: worth through this parliament. They include the superannuation measures, which included

Speaker: NA
Text: some $6 billion in additional revenue. That also included $3 billion of investment back into

Speaker: NA
Text: the superannuation system-a world-leading superannuation system-to ensure that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: fairer, more flexible and sustainable.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those opposite spoke an untruth to the Australian people at the last election. On

Speaker: NA
Text: superannuation, they said in their own estimates that they would do the same thing as the

Speaker: NA
Text: government when it came to the revenue net position. They did not tell the Australian people

Speaker: NA
Text: that they wanted to tax contributions more. They did not tell those who run home based

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses, those who are contractors and those who are seeking to catch up on their

Speaker: NA
Text: concessional contributions because they have been carers or they have been having children.

Speaker: NA
Text: They did not tell them they were going to strip those flexibility measures away. They did not

Speaker: NA
Text: tell them that at all. They went to the Australian people and misled them on superannuation

Speaker: NA
Text: and now, in this parliament, they have made a promise that, at the next election, the only party

Speaker: NA
Text: that is going to be taxing superannuation more is led by the Leader of the Opposition. (Time

Speaker: NA
Text: expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Economy

Speaker: Dr CHALMERS
Text: Rankin) (14:15): My question is also to the Treasurer. Ratings agency

Speaker: NA
Text: Standard & Poor's has today warned that Australia's AAA rating will be at risk unless revenue

Speaker: NA
Text: is increased in a sustained way. Why is the Treasurer refusing to support sensible reforms on

Speaker: NA
Text: negative gearing and capital gains tax?

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The Leader of the House will cease interjecting!

Speaker: Mr MORRISON
Text: Cook-Treasurer) (14:15): Of the $40 billion in budget improvement

Speaker: NA
Text: measures that we set out in our budget-he is a little excited, though, Mr SPEAKER -that we

Speaker: NA
Text: took to the Australian people, $25 billion of those measures related to payment savings and

Speaker: NA
Text: $15 billion of those measures related to revenue. There was a balance of the two to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: we bring the budget back to balance. We think we got the balance right when it comes to the

Speaker: NA
Text: balance between taxes and expenditures. As a government we have always ensured that,

Speaker: NA
Text: where our expenditure has increased, we have offset that with payment savings-not revenue

Speaker: NA
Text: increases, but payment savings. When we have gone to the Australian people and we have

Speaker: NA
Text: said that we are going to cut taxes-as we have done for personal income tax and legislated

Speaker: NA
Text: through this place-or when we have gone to the Australian people, as we have said, and we

Speaker: NA
Text: have said we want businesses, particularly small businesses with a turnover of up to $10

Speaker: NA
Text: million, to be able to access a lower rate of tax and to access the instant asset write-off and the

Speaker: NA
Text: pool depreciation provisions, we have offset the cost of revenue-

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Chalmers interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Rankin will cease interjecting. He has asked his

Speaker: NA
Text: question.

Speaker: Mr MORRISON
Text: with other revenue measures. That is how you actually drive yourself

Speaker: NA
Text: towards a budget balance. But those opposite are a one-trick pony when it comes to the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget, and the only thing that they are able to come up with is to tax people more. They are

Speaker: NA
Text: addicted to tax and, rather than try and ease the burden on Australian businesses so they can

Speaker: NA
Text: give Australians more opportunity for more hours, they just want to keep squeezing that tax

Speaker: NA
Text: lemon as hard as they possibly can. That presents a great threat to our economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The United Kingdom will bring down their autumn statement tonight, and we already

Speaker: NA
Text: know that they have put the UK on a trajectory to one of the lowest tax rates in the advanced

Speaker: NA
Text: world. We know that the Trump administration will be seeking to do exactly the same thing,

Speaker: NA
Text: and we have already moved in our budget to take Australia down a similar path. Those

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite plan to strand Australian businesses in a high-tax environment where they cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: invest, where they cannot attract capital and where they cannot provide additional working

Speaker: NA
Text: hours and additional wages to working Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a leader of the opposition who, rather than following the economic policy advice of

Speaker: NA
Text: Bob Hawke, has become an acolyte of Bob Brown when it comes to economic policy. He is

Speaker: NA
Text: the Jeremy Corbyn of Australian politics, appealing to the Bernie Sanders and all the rest of

Speaker: NA
Text: them. This is a leader of the opposition who is so indulgent in cynical politics that he cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: find his way to the surface again.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Water

Speaker: Mr KATTER
Text: Kennedy) (14:19): My question is to the Deputy Prime Minister. Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister, you are aware of the notorious Flinders River water allocations. Almost all of

Speaker: NA
Text: these waters, worth over $180 million, have been granted to just two absentee landlord

Speaker: NA
Text: corporations. This was in contrast to refusal to even consider submissions from the people of

Speaker: NA
Text: the area itself that were based upon economic development, industry and community benefit.

Speaker: NA
Text: The most serious questions of ministerial and departmental impropriety are raised here. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: light of this impoverishment of the hands on to provide for the enrichment of the rich, would

Speaker: NA
Text: the minister consider right to sustenance legislation-rights enshrined in and from the time of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Magna Carta itself?

Speaker: Mr JOYCE
Text: New England-Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Agriculture and

Speaker: NA
Text: Water Resources) (14:19): I thank the honourable member for his question. At times I stay up

Speaker: NA
Text: late at night deliberating on the issues of Runnymede in 1215 and exactly what was going on

Speaker: NA
Text: between King John and those feudal lords. I do acknowledge that, after a few months, they

Speaker: NA
Text: broke out into a war in any case, so it was not of much use. But he does speak to a rather more

Speaker: NA
Text: substantial issue-the issue of water. Predominantly-

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Members on my left, and right. The Minister for Immigration and the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Grayndler are interrupting the minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: An honourable member: He wrote it!

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The Leader of the House will cease interjecting. The Deputy Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister has the call.

Speaker: Mr JOYCE
Text: I take the interjection from the member for Grayndler, who is claiming that

Speaker: NA
Text: he built the Magna Carta. But the issue, of course, is one of water. The water licences for the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Kennedy are overwhelmingly a state issue, especially on the Flinders. I note the

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns you have. We too are wanting to develop the north and to build more water

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure. It is vitally important, and that is why we have put up money for feasibility on

Speaker: NA
Text: 14 sites in Queensland and $130 million on the table for Rookwood Weir. Unfortunately, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland Labor government has been either tardy or unwilling to participate in it-we are

Speaker: NA
Text: still waiting for their support so we can get these things moving. Also in the member's

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate is one of those feasibility studies, at Cloncurry. We have to try and drive these

Speaker: NA
Text: agendas forward, because we know that water is wealth and, if we are driving jobs and

Speaker: NA
Text: creating jobs, we have to create the water infrastructure.

Speaker: NA
