Text: The member for Kennedy can take some solace in the fact that we are hard at work in

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania building that same water infrastructure. We have completed Chaffey Dam. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: also put money on the table for the South-West Loddon Pipeline and for the Macalister

Speaker: NA
Text: Irrigation District. These programs are up and running and we want to start more. We want to

Speaker: NA
Text: go further. We want to be the government that has the vision to build the water infrastructure.

Speaker: NA
Text: I appreciate the trip that I took with the member for Kennedy to Hell's Gates, where we

Speaker: NA
Text: also have put money on the table for the feasibility study on that. That would be a tremendous

Speaker: NA
Text: project. But we need the same sense of fervour, the same sense of excitement as we have seen

Speaker: NA
Text: from the people who built the Snowy Mountains scheme. That is the sort of vision that our

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: nation is looking for. That is the sort of vision that people want from a government, a

Speaker: NA
Text: government that actually believes in the delivery of the tactile, in the things that you can see,

Speaker: NA
Text: rather than standing on their philosophical log and procrastinating and just waiting and

Speaker: NA
Text: waiting and waiting until nothing happens.

Speaker: NA
Text: So, if it is the vision that you had on 15 June 1215 at Runnymede, where not-so-good King

Speaker: NA
Text: John was taken on by the not-so-good feudal lords, then that is the sort of vision. But,

Speaker: NA
Text: ultimately, the document was sustainable through time, and we want to build the water

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure that is sustainable through time for the Australian people.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Building and Construction Commission

Speaker: Mr HOGAN
Text: Page) (14:23): My question is the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Agriculture and Water Resources. Will the Deputy Prime Minister explain to the House how

Speaker: NA
Text: forcing the rule of law on construction sites through the reintroduction of the ABCC will

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit the hardworking Australians I represent in the agricultural industry?

Speaker: Mr JOYCE
Text: New England-Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Agriculture and

Speaker: NA
Text: Water Resources) (14:23): I thank the honourable member for Page for his question. He is a

Speaker: NA
Text: person who understands the benefit to the Australian working man and woman from the

Speaker: NA
Text: production of food and from the delivery and processing of food. We note-in areas such as

Speaker: NA
Text: macadamia production that he has in his electorate-the great jobs that are produced not only

Speaker: NA
Text: by the farmers but also by the people who are processing the macadamias. That is also the

Speaker: NA
Text: case in the Casino cooperative meatworks. I commend the work he has been doing with

Speaker: NA
Text: cooperatives-those meatworks employing working men and women and making sure that

Speaker: NA
Text: they have the capacity to go home with a fair day's pay after a fair day's work.

Speaker: NA
Text: But, unfortunately, from time to time we have an impediment in trying to bring forth these

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs that are so essential to the Australian economy. We note, for instance, the $280-or-so

Speaker: NA
Text: million that was put aside to build the Melbourne wholesale fruit and vegetable markets.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unfortunately, when they went to build it, there was a bit of fight. You would think it would

Speaker: NA
Text: be about the farmers wanting it bigger. No, it was between the member for Griffith's crowd,

Speaker: NA
Text: the CFMEU, and the member for Maribyrnong crowd, the AWU. They went to fight and just

Speaker: NA
Text: kept fighting and fighting and fighting, until in the end the ABCC took them to the Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Court and ordered that they remove the blockades, which were costing millions of dollars, and

Speaker: NA
Text: that they get back to work.

Speaker: NA
Text: So what do they do when the court of the land says to go back to work? You would think

Speaker: NA
Text: they would obey that order. No, they did not. The CFMEU was obviously above the law.

Speaker: NA
Text: They do not have to comply with the law. That is for the regular men and women of Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: not the CFMEU. They can just make their own arrangements. We saw it again with the desal

Speaker: NA
Text: plant, where the CFMEU went on strike, costing $5 million a day.

Speaker: NA
Text: The issue for the member for Page and for everybody here is that we must believe in the

Speaker: NA
Text: rule of law. We cannot have mum-and-dad operators going onto worksites, being bullied by

Speaker: NA
Text: thugs who stand over them, thugs whose belief is not in a fair day's work and a fair day's pay,

Speaker: NA
Text: but just in extorting money and extorting ridiculous conditions out of it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Labor Party would be the champion of the CFMEU, with the member for Griffiths

Speaker: NA
Text: involved in the CFMEU, the member for Shortland involved in the CFMEU, and the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Calwell involved in the CFMEU. These are part of the process, and they are paying their

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: dues here at the moment. They are paying their dues to make sure that they deliver back to the

Speaker: NA
Text: CFMEU, who has also delivered millions of dollars to the Australian Labor Party. The

Speaker: NA
Text: problem with the Labor Party these days is there are not many labourers in it. There are an

Speaker: NA
Text: awful lot of union officials but not many labourers. But we will make sure that we give our

Speaker: NA
Text: very best endeavours to get the cop back on the beat.

Speaker: NA
Text: Taxation

Speaker: Mr SHORTEN
Text: Maribyrnong-Leader of the Opposition) (14:26): My question is to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister. Today ratings agency Standard & Poor's warned that Australia's AAA credit

Speaker: NA
Text: rating will be at risk unless the government stands by its commitment to a surplus in 2021. On

Speaker: NA
Text: this basis, why is the Prime Minister still persisting with his $50 billion tax handout to big

Speaker: NA
Text: business, when a ratings downgrade will push up the mortgage repayments for Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: homeowners?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs Sudmalis interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Members on my right. The member for Gilmore.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Wentworth-Prime Minister) (14:27): There was a time when the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party understood-indeed, a prominent figure on the opposition benches wrote a book

Speaker: NA
Text: about it-that reducing company tax, reducing businesses taxes, would, because it increased

Speaker: NA
Text: the return on investment, deliver more investment. And, if you get more investment-do you

Speaker: NA
Text: know what?-you get more jobs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Around the world companies are reducing business taxes. We pointed to the policies of the

Speaker: NA
Text: incoming administration in the United States. You can look at what the UK government has

Speaker: NA
Text: done. That has been a policy followed by Labor governments in this place as well for the

Speaker: NA
Text: obvious reason: if you increase the return on investment, you get more investment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Turning to the ratings agencies: the ratings agencies have been absolutely crystal clear.

Speaker: NA
Text: Their concern is that the government's budget will not be passed through the parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the reckless opposition of the Labor Party. That is what their concern is. They

Speaker: NA
Text: recognise that we have an economic plan that sets out a path towards a budget surplus. They

Speaker: NA
Text: recognise that and they accept it. Their concern is the political risk, and that is why they

Speaker: NA
Text: welcomed the omnibus savings bill, that is why they welcomed the passage of the

Speaker: NA
Text: superannuation reforms, and that is why they have welcomed our ability, when it is there, to

Speaker: NA
Text: secure our budget policies through the Senate.

Speaker: NA
Text: But we work very hard and respectfully and constructively with the crossbench, and we

Speaker: NA
Text: will continue to do so. But the Labor Party know very well that any and every measure in that

Speaker: NA
Text: budget can be passed if they support it, and it is their opposition which puts the AA rating at

Speaker: NA
Text: risk. It is the political risk-

Speaker: NA
Text: An honourable member: You're the government!

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: The honourable member says, 'You're the government.' You're quite

Speaker: NA
Text: right. That is something you have not quite twigged to yet. We are the government; we won

Speaker: NA
Text: the election. The reality is: you cannot turn around and say to us, 'You're at risk of the AAA

Speaker: NA
Text: rating being pulled because of the rating agencies,' when the risk that the rating agencies

Speaker: NA
Text: identified is that the government's plan will not get through the Senate because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: trenchant political opposition of the Labor Party. So, if the Labor Party are concerned about

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the AAA rating and if they want to support the AAA rating-and we would be grateful for

Speaker: NA
Text: it-then they should support the budget measures, because their passage will secure it.

Speaker: NA
Text: DISTINGUISHED VISITORS

Speaker: NA
Text: The SPEAKER (14:30): I would like to inform the House that we have present in the

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber this afternoon a delegation from Cambodia led by his excellency Mr Kimyeat. On

Speaker: NA
Text: behalf of the House I extend a very warm welcome to you.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members: Hear, hear!

Speaker: NA
Text: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Speaker: NA
Text: Economy

Speaker: Mr CREWTHER
Text: Dunkley) (14:30): My question is to the Treasurer. Will the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: advise the House on the importance of strong economic growth to employment security, job

Speaker: NA
Text: creation and wage growth for hardworking Australians? How important is it that the

Speaker: NA
Text: government continues to promote productivity and reduce inefficiencies that drag on our

Speaker: NA
Text: economy?

Speaker: Mr MORRISON
Text: Cook-Treasurer) (14:31): I thank the member for Dunkley for his

Speaker: NA
Text: question and for his support for the measures that this government is seeking and introducing

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensure greater productivity in the Australia economy, because from that comes the growth,

Speaker: NA
Text: the investment, the jobs and the wages. The way you lift revenue in this country, if you want

Speaker: NA
Text: to budget balance, is: you need to ensure that businesses are earning more, that employees are

Speaker: NA
Text: earning more and that they are getting extra hours. To do that you need a tax environment

Speaker: NA
Text: which supports business, particularly small business, to achieve that. But you also need an

Speaker: NA
Text: environment in the building and construction industry that when businesses and others go and

Speaker: NA
Text: invest they are not hit with a 30 percent premium as a result of the lawlessness in the building

Speaker: NA
Text: and construction industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: I notice that the member for Grayndler has said very recently-I understand it was last

Speaker: NA
Text: night-that now was the time for the Commonwealth to lift investment right across the

Speaker: NA
Text: nation. It might be news to the member for Grayndler that, under the Labor Party,

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth investment as a share of public investment was an average of 24 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under this government, it is an average of 30½ per cent. So this government has been lifting

Speaker: NA
Text: investment in Commonwealth investment, but investment particularly in public infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: is hampered by those opposite who continue to frustrate and work against the restoration of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Building and Construction Commission.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yesterday, I asked a very polite question to those opposite of those who happen to be

Speaker: NA
Text: members of registered trade unions. And none of them put their hands up. I asked them: 'Who

Speaker: NA
Text: are members of the CFMEU?' So, Mr Speaker, I thought this may be a reason as to why in

Speaker: NA
Text: unions' interests they may be seeking to protect the lawlessness in the building and

Speaker: NA
Text: construction industry on behalf of militant unions. So I did a bit of homework. It turns out that

Speaker: NA
Text: when you look at the Register of Members' Interests of the 68 members of parliament who sit

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite only 32 have not listed any union membership at all on their register of interests.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is interesting because when I look at the membership form of the ALP, which is a

Speaker: NA
Text: requirement, it says 'member of affiliated union'. So why is it that the member for Batman

Speaker: NA
Text: thinks it is important to declare a 1/400 scale model of a Shortfin Barracuda submarine but he

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: does not think it is relevant to disclose the fact of his membership, as others have on that side,

Speaker: NA
Text: of a trade union?

Speaker: NA
Text: If we go to the actual register of interests question-and I happen have the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: MCMahon's here. Strangely enough, he has not mentioned what union he is a member of. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: glad to know that he is a member of the Marconi club and the Guildford West leagues-they

Speaker: NA
Text: are fine institutions; great clubs-but he has not mentioned what union he is a member of.

Speaker: NA
Text: And question 13 says 'membership of any organisation'-(Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Superannuation

Speaker: Ms PLIBERSEK
Text: Sydney-Deputy Leader of the Opposition) (14:34): My question is to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Revenue and Financial Services. It has been revealed that Australia's biggest

Speaker: NA
Text: banks will have to pay almost $180 million in compensation because they spent years

Speaker: NA
Text: charging over 200,000 customers fees for services that they did not actually receive. Is this

Speaker: NA
Text: what the minister meant when she said she wanted to lift superannuation funds to the same

Speaker: NA
Text: standards as banks? Does the minister really want superannuation account holders to be

Speaker: NA
Text: treated the way banks treat their customers?

Speaker: Ms ODWYER
Text: Higgins-Minister for Revenue and Financial Services) (14:35): I thank

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for her question. I note that she believes, along with those opposite, that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: incredibly important that the mandated superannuation system, in which we force people to

Speaker: NA
Text: defer their wages that they earn today to save for their retirement income into the future-

Speaker: NA
Text: they think it is acceptable that it has lower governance standards than that that currently apply

Speaker: NA
Text: to banks and life insurance companies. It is ridiculous to think that millions of Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: who have their money in superannuation funds would have funds that have lower governance

Speaker: NA
Text: standards than what currently applies to banks and to life insurance companies.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Brendan O'Connor interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Gorton!

Speaker: Ms ODWYER
Text: It is not actually something that we have dreamt up on this side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House. In fact, there was a review that was undertaken under Labor's watch by Jeremy

Speaker: NA
Text: Cooper-a handpicked person from Labor for the job-who concluded that the governance

Speaker: NA
Text: standards for superannuation funds was not up to the mark. He said that there needed to be at

Speaker: NA
Text: least one-third of independent directors on these boards.

Speaker: NA
Text: A second review conducted by David Murray said that there needed to be a majority of

Speaker: NA
Text: independent directors and an independent chair on these boards. It is so unacceptable to think

Speaker: NA
Text: that all of the problems that could occur within these funds can continue without there being

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate oversight.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me just quote a couple of other people who think that this might be a good idea. Ken

Speaker: NA
Text: Henry, who was the former adviser to Paul Keating and former Treasury secretary, has been

Speaker: NA
Text: reported as saying it was time that industry funds accepted the need for new governance

Speaker: NA
Text: standards as advocated by the government. He said that the trade union movement should be

Speaker: NA
Text: proud of the system it created, but that the argument that, 'The system isn't broken, so why fix

Speaker: NA
Text: it?' was a bit like saying that a house that had not been torched should not have insurance.

Speaker: NA
Text: Paul Howes, the former Australian Workers' Union boss, has said:

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: It has been disappointing to see a knee-jerk reaction against the call for a more independent governance

Speaker: NA
Text: model … Equal representation has been a success but the evolution of the super industry is important

Speaker: NA
Text: and I can't see anything negative in having more independents on boards.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those on that side of the House want to protect their union mates and union bosses in

Speaker: NA
Text: maintaining access to slush funds. We think it is completely and utterly inappropriate, and we

Speaker: NA
Text: will stand up for members, we will stand up for what is right for them and we will stand up

Speaker: NA
Text: for their interests.

Speaker: NA
Text: Workplace Health and Safety

Speaker: Mr COLEMAN
Text: Banks) (14:38): My question is to the Minister for Defence Industry,

Speaker: NA
Text: representing the Minister for Employment. Will the minister explain why it is critical to

Speaker: NA
Text: maintain a consistent approach to occupational health and safety in the workplace and how

Speaker: NA
Text: that will be assisted by the establishment of the Registered Organisations Commission and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Building and Construction Commission?

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: thank the member for Banks for his question. It is a very important question because

Speaker: NA
Text: occupational health and safety-a safe workplace-is the most important priority in every

Speaker: NA
Text: single workplace in Australia for employers and, equally, employees. The first task of every

Speaker: NA
Text: business is to ensure that their employees are in a safe workplace, and it is one of the most

Speaker: NA
Text: important requirements of unions, of course, to represent their members to ensure that they

Speaker: NA
Text: are in safe workplaces. That, of course, is the reason why the Labor Party should support the

Speaker: NA
Text: Registered Organisations Commission being established, which they have tried to oppose and

Speaker: NA
Text: failed this week, which is why it is an important signature reform. It is why they should

Speaker: NA
Text: support the Australian Building and Construction Commission-because healthy unions are

Speaker: NA
Text: good for their members. Honest union leaders looking after their members rather than lining

Speaker: NA
Text: their pockets should be the outcome that every member in this House should be seeking.

Speaker: NA
Text: So I find very strange indeed the hypocrisy-the hideous hypocrisy-that members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party, and particularly this Leader of the Opposition, show in their feigned concern

Speaker: NA
Text: about safety in the workplace for workers, when in fact the Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: deliberately parachuted into the Senate Kimberley Kitching to become Senator Kitching, who

Speaker: NA
Text: is alleged to have fraudulently filled out the safety tests for six union leaders in the Health

Speaker: NA
Text: Services Union. So they had a captain's pick where the Leader of the Opposition put

Speaker: NA
Text: Kimberley Kitching, Senator Kitching, into the Senate when the trade union royal

Speaker: NA
Text: commission has referred her to the Commonwealth DPP for fraudulently, it is alleged, filling

Speaker: NA
Text: out the safety tests for six union leaders from the Health Services Union and bragging about

Speaker: NA
Text: it. That put union leaders into workplaces, pretending that they had done the safety tests and

Speaker: NA
Text: safety standards that were necessary to go into those worksites but knowing that they did not

Speaker: NA
Text: have those safety standards that are required.

Speaker: NA
Text: That reckless decision by the Leader of the Opposition was made over the complaints and

Speaker: NA
Text: the outrage of many members of his frontbench, particularly the member for Isaacs. The

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Isaacs, as I understand it, threatened to resign if Kimberley Kitching was

Speaker: NA
Text: appointed to the Senate. If that is not true, he is quite welcome to say that he was

Speaker: NA
Text: misrepresented and explain the facts, because that is the very strong story that is circulating.

Speaker: NA
Text: Over the objections of former Senator Conroy and the objections of members of the right-

Speaker: NA
Text: wing faction from his own state, he put into the Senate a person who had fraudulently filled

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: out the tests, it is alleged, of union leaders, putting workers in danger in the workplace. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is the real respect they have for workers' safety. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Superannuation

Speaker: Mr BOWEN
Text: MCMahon) (14:41): My question is to the Prime Minister. Yesterday, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Revenue and Financial Services said she wanted to lift superannuation funds to

Speaker: NA
Text: the same standards as the banks. So is the former New South Wales Liberal leader and

Speaker: NA
Text: chairman of Industry Super Australia, Peter Collins, accurately describing government policy

Speaker: NA
Text: when he says:

Speaker: NA
Text: If super funds had been responsible for systemic failures in financial advice, failure to pass on interest

Speaker: NA
Text: rate cuts, excessive executive remuneration and other forms of profit gouging by banks, there would

Speaker: NA
Text: have been a royal commission into super funds in a flash.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Wentworth-Prime Minister) (14:42): The honourable member knows

Speaker: NA
Text: very well that the government has sought to ensure that there are independent directors on

Speaker: NA
Text: industry super funds. That is hardly a radical proposal. This has been resisted by a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: the vested interests associated with the industry super funds, where, in many cases, as the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member knows, the directors are drawn solely from the employers and the unions.

Speaker: NA
Text: All we are seeking to do is to install what is regarded as corporate governance 101 in the rest

Speaker: NA
Text: of the corporate world. The honourable member should take care to represent the interests of

Speaker: NA
Text: the members as opposed to, once again, representing the interests of union bosses, who are

Speaker: NA
Text: very happy to sit in those well-paid directorships.

Speaker: NA
Text: Aged Care

Speaker: Mr ALEXANDER
Text: Bennelong) (14:43): My question is to the Minister for Health and

Speaker: NA
Text: Aged Care. Will the minister explain to the House how a re-established Australian Building

Speaker: NA
Text: and Construction Commission will ensure hardworking Australians receive the aged-care

Speaker: NA
Text: services they deserve? What is standing in the way of this progress?

Speaker: Ms LEY
Text: Farrer-Minister for Sport and Minister for Health and Aged Care) (14:43):

Speaker: NA
Text: Thank you to the member for Bennelong for his question about the important subject of aged

Speaker: NA
Text: care-in particular, aged-care residential facilities. I would just like to provide the House with

Speaker: NA
Text: a demonstration of our investment in this important policy area. This year, it is estimated that

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth funding in residential aged care will be about $65,000 per resident. This year,

Speaker: NA
Text: aged-care spending is estimated at $17½ billion-that is actually 20 per cent higher than it

Speaker: NA
Text: was in Labor's last budget, at least. Since June 2015, there has been an increase of about 3½

Speaker: NA
Text: thousand operational residential aged-care places. Aged-care spending is increasing by an

Speaker: NA
Text: average of 6.7 per cent a year. With this ageing population and a figure that is only going to

Speaker: NA
Text: grow, it is important that we have adequate facilities to support Australians who need

Speaker: NA
Text: residential care and the ability for those Australians to access that care as soon as possible.

Speaker: NA
Text: New facilities are being built around the country. In many cases it is a partnership with

Speaker: NA
Text: government capital investment and investment from the private sector. Unfortunately, the

Speaker: NA
Text: sites for these much-needed facilities are not immune to union thuggery that all construction

Speaker: NA
Text: sites face. I have an example which was reported in The Age in April this year: The Age

Speaker: NA
Text: reported that, on an aged-care construction site in Templestowe, Victoria, up to 30 workers

Speaker: NA
Text: simply walked off the job, just like that. The company allegedly told the CFMEU officer

Speaker: NA
Text: present, 'What you have done is illegal, and I am going to have to report you,' to which the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: CFMEU officer allegedly responded, 'I know it's illegal, but I had to do it.' This is so wrong

Speaker: NA
Text: on so many levels. It just goes to show that the unions that are holding our construction sites

Speaker: NA
Text: to ransom can do these things just because they feel like it. We are committed to restoring law

Speaker: NA
Text: and order-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Collins interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Franklin will cease interjecting.

Speaker: Ms LEY
Text: on construction sites. Whenever I hear about elderly Australians unable to get a

Speaker: NA
Text: residential aged-care place or that place costing more in terms of the capital to build because

Speaker: NA
Text: of the union thuggeries, I know that not enough is being done by this Labor Party to sort out

Speaker: NA
Text: the union bosses who are running the show. We only have to reflect on the words of the trade

Speaker: NA
Text: union royal commission-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Plibersek interjecting-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Collins interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Sydney and the member for Franklin.

Speaker: Ms LEY
Text: about the systemic world of louts, thugs, bullies, thieves and perjurers. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: across the board. It is operating in a construction site near each one of these Labor Party

Speaker: NA
Text: members. None of them are doing anything about it, but what it is doing is affecting the aged-

Speaker: NA
Text: care places, the residential funding and the cost for those everyday Australians. (Time

Speaker: NA
Text: expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Murray-Darling Basin

Speaker: Mr GEORGANAS
Text: Hindmarsh) (14:46): My question is to the Prime Minister. The

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Mallee said the Deputy Prime Minister was right to abandon the bipartisan

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment for an additional 450 gigalitres in the Murray-Darling Basin Plan saying, 'South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia will get more water than it can actually handle.' Is it the position of the government

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Basin Plan delivers more water than South Australia can actually handle?

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Wentworth-Prime Minister) (14:47): I thank the honourable member.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have the Basin Plan here which I will refer to in a moment. The Australian government is

Speaker: NA
Text: committed to delivering the Murray-Darling Basin Plan in full and on time. Our policy has

Speaker: NA
Text: not changed. The Basin Plan is based on an approach to water management that delivers a

Speaker: NA
Text: healthy basin and supports productive industries, confident communities and a resilient

Speaker: NA
Text: environment.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are challenges in delivering anything as complex as the Basin Plan. What we need to

Speaker: NA
Text: remember is that, in delivering additional water for the environment, the sustainability of

Speaker: NA
Text: communities in economic and social terms must be preserved. I will refer the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member to section 7.17 of the Basin Plan. What it makes very clear is that it must be neutral

Speaker: NA
Text: or improved socioeconomic outcomes associated with the conversion of water from

Speaker: NA
Text: consumptive to environmental uses. That is what is in the plan; that is what the plan says.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nobody is saying it is easy. I think it was Mark Twain that said, 'Whiskey is for drinking;

Speaker: NA
Text: water is for fighting over'-I remember it very well; I was the water minister. I understand

Speaker: NA
Text: because the Murray-Darling Basin Plan was put in place when I was the water minister under

Speaker: NA
Text: John Howard.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Rishworth interjecting-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Kingston.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: It is always contentious, but the reality is that what we have to do is to

Speaker: NA
Text: find the solutions and the mechanisms that enable us to return water to the environment in a

Speaker: NA
Text: way that does not disadvantage basin communities in social or economic forms. There will

Speaker: NA
Text: always be arguments about water. There will always be disputes about water, but where there

Speaker: NA
Text: is goodwill and a dynamic, constructive approach then we will be able-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Rishworth interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Kingston will cease interjecting.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: to deliver the plan in full as we are committed to. What I would invite

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member to do is to work with us and to encourage his colleagues in the South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian government to work with us. Some of the language that was used by the South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian water minister, I have to say, was not constructive and not calculated to assist in

Speaker: NA
Text: resolution.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bottom line is this: we are committed to the plan, but the plan has provisions. The

Speaker: NA
Text: provision I just read out to the honourable member is very clear. The honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Watson opposite knows this very well-he was the water minister; he knows it very well. For

Speaker: NA
Text: example, in 2012 he set up a review of the northern basin plan to look at precisely this point,

Speaker: NA
Text: so we know it is challenging but we are up to it, and we are going to deliver it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Employment

Speaker: Ms BANKS
Text: Chisholm) (14:50): My question is to the Minister for Industry, Innovation

Speaker: NA
Text: and Science. Will the minister update the House on what the government is doing to promote

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian industry, business and jobs for hardworking Australians? Is the minister aware of

Speaker: NA
Text: any alternative approaches that would hurt Australian industry, business and jobs?

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: Flinders-Minister for Industry, Innovation and Science) (14:50): I want to

Speaker: NA
Text: thank the member and acknowledge that she comes to this place not just as the victor of

Speaker: NA
Text: Chisholm but also as somebody who has had a distinguished career in businesses that are

Speaker: NA
Text: providing jobs for numerous Australians. As part of that work she has been passionate about

Speaker: NA
Text: creating job opportunities for Australians. In that light, I am pleased to inform the House that

Speaker: NA
Text: last Thursday the member for Reid, in his capacity as assistant minister, and I met with all of

Speaker: NA
Text: the states and territories and achieved exactly what the Prime Minister was talking about: a

Speaker: NA
Text: good working relationship and an outcome where all of the Labor states and territories, as

Speaker: NA
Text: well as the coalition states and territories, agreed on a national business simplification

Speaker: NA
Text: initiative aimed at creating jobs, so unanimity across the jurisdictions with the federal

Speaker: NA
Text: government. Examples of what we are proposing to do to create jobs include: working with

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales on bringing down the time for formation of a cafe from 18 months to 3

Speaker: NA
Text: months; working with South Australia on food-handling standards and simplifying those;

Speaker: NA
Text: working with Victoria on creating faster approaches to registering and starting retail

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses; working with Tasmania on ecotourism being expedited; and, working with

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland on faster approaches to registering and creating agricultural and manufacturing

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses. Real action that will create jobs.

Speaker: NA
Text: That has been twinned this week with the work of the parliament in passing the Registered

Speaker: NA
Text: Organisations Commission bill and the progress that is being made on the ABCC-two things

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: that will assist in not just establishing businesses but in allowing the construction to go ahead

Speaker: NA
Text: that is necessary to house these businesses.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am asked if there are alternatives to this approach of actually creating job and actually

Speaker: NA
Text: allowing businesses to be created. And, yes, there are. Our friends on the other side are

Speaker: NA
Text: resolutely opposed to any action that will rein in union tyranny and thuggery in the

Speaker: NA
Text: workplace. Let me give you an example. Moose Toys, the Australian based maker of Betty

Speaker: NA
Text: Spaghetty and Little Live Pets, which, of course, the CFMEU uses as a way of referring to

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill and Burkie.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The Minister for the Environment will refer to members by their correct

Speaker: NA
Text: titles.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: I apologise. I withdraw. Moose Toys was accused and threatened on site with

Speaker: NA
Text: the phrase by a CFMEU official, 'You do not want to be the dog who calls the cop on a union

Speaker: NA
Text: official.' Why would they tolerate that sort of intimidation of an Australian business. The

Speaker: NA
Text: reason is that they stand for the thugs. They do not stand for the businesses. We are creating

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs to make it simpler to do business. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr BRENDAN OCONNOR (Gorton) (14:54): My question is to the Prime Minister. I

Speaker: NA
Text: refer to the video of a Brisbane 7-Eleven employee being forced to return half her wages to

Speaker: NA
Text: her employer in cash. As a result of this cashback scam, staff are paid $11 an hour below the

Speaker: NA
Text: minimum wage. Given the Prime Minister's own ministerial standards requires ministers to

Speaker: NA
Text: act with the highest standards of integrity, how can the Prime Minister possibly justify his

Speaker: NA
Text: ongoing holdings in managed funds that invest in 7-Eleven?

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Members on my right. The member for Wakefield will cease

Speaker: NA
Text: interjecting.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Wentworth-Prime Minister) (14:54): As honourable members are

Speaker: NA
Text: aware, my and my wife's investments are managed for us by an external adviser. They are

Speaker: NA
Text: invested almost entirely-for the most part in any event-in large managed funds, typically

Speaker: NA
Text: index funds, exchange traded funds, that have a wide range of investments. Typically, very

Speaker: NA
Text: similar to the large superannuation funds that many other members, including members

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite, have their funds invested in.

Speaker: NA
Text: What I would suggest to the honourable member is that he now scour through the large

Speaker: NA
Text: portfolios of all the managed funds that are opposite. But the point of the matter is that I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not choose the stocks those funds invest in. I am completely transparent. They are there, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the allocation of the funds is a matter for my adviser. So it is kept very much at arms-length

Speaker: NA
Text: from me. It is thoroughly transparent and at arm's length.

Speaker: NA
Text: National Security

Speaker: Ms MARINO
Text: Forrest-Chief Government Whip) (14:56): My question is the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Immigration and Border Protection. Will the minister update the house on steps the

Speaker: NA
Text: government has taken to secure our borders and achieve third-country resettlement pathways?

Speaker: NA
Text: Is the minister aware of any alternative approach?

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Mr DUTTON
Text: Dickson-Minister for Immigration and Border Protection) (14:56): I

Speaker: NA
Text: thank the honourable member for her question. It is a particularly import question, because, as

Speaker: NA
Text: we all know, people smugglers have not gone out of business. Right now, people smugglers

Speaker: NA
Text: are trying to get people to pay money to hop onto boats. Tragically, we know the outcome if

Speaker: NA
Text: we lose control of our borders, because it was evidenced over the six years of the Rudd-

Speaker: NA
Text: Gillard-Rudd years, when the Leader of the Opposition was a senior member within that

Speaker: NA
Text: cabinet. There were 1,200 people, including women and children, who drowned at sea. There

Speaker: NA
Text: were thousands and thousands of children put into detention. It was the case that 50,000

Speaker: NA
Text: people arrived on 800 boats, and we are still cleaning up Labor's mess.

Speaker: NA
Text: Having got the children out of detention, having closed the 17 detention centres, having not

Speaker: NA
Text: had a successful people smuggling venture arrive in over 800 days now, and having fixed up

Speaker: NA
Text: this mess and this sad chapter in Labor history-

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Member for Wakefield, this is your final warning.

Speaker: Mr DUTTON
Text: -our determination is to get women and children and all those people on

Speaker: NA
Text: Nauru and Manus off those two islands, but to do it in such a way that we do not recommence

Speaker: NA
Text: boat arrivals. I do not want new arrivals to fill the vacancies we create, which is the policy

Speaker: NA
Text: prescription that Labor is putting forward. We have had Homeland Security and State

Speaker: NA
Text: Department representatives from the United States in Australia over the course of the last

Speaker: NA
Text: week or so talking through with officials from my department ways in which we can screen

Speaker: NA
Text: people very quickly and facilitate their removal. I do not want the people smugglers to hear

Speaker: NA
Text: the weak message being conveyed by the Leader of the Opposition, as we have seen over the

Speaker: NA
Text: course of the last couple of weeks.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the Opposition is intent on creating whatever distraction he can. But the

Speaker: NA
Text: reality remains that this Leader of the Opposition presides over a weak and divided party.

Speaker: NA
Text: They were weak and divided when they were in government and they are weak and divided

Speaker: NA
Text: now. The people smugglers saw a weak leader in Kevin Rudd, they saw a weak leader in Julia

Speaker: NA
Text: Gillard and they know this Leader of the Opposition is at least as weak as they are.

Speaker: NA
Text: I see notification today that the policy unit of the Labor Party has been taken over by the

Speaker: NA
Text: left of this party. That is a terrible development, because the people smugglers were rubbing

Speaker: NA
Text: their hands together when Labor was last in power, because the fact is that the left of the party

Speaker: NA
Text: completely dominate this border protection policy. That is why 26 people in the Labor Party

Speaker: NA
Text: came out against the legislation the government has passed through the Lower House. At

Speaker: NA
Text: every opportunity, this Leader of the Opposition shows that he is unfit to be Prime Minister of

Speaker: NA
Text: this country and, if he were to be elected at the next election, as sure as night follows day, the

Speaker: NA
Text: boats would restart.

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The members on my left will cease interjecting. I gave the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Wakefield his final warning. He kept interjecting; he can leave under standing order 94(a).

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Wakefield then left the chamber.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Intellectual Property

Speaker: Mr BURKE
Text: Watson-Manager of Opposition Business) (14:59): My question is directed

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister confirm that his government has threatened to

Speaker: NA
Text: sue Mark Rogers, a Sydney grandfather, over his use of the Medicare logo on his Save

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare website. Will the government also be threatening legal action against the Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: Party, the member for Forde, the Minister for Trade, the member for Bonner and the health

Speaker: NA
Text: minister, who have all used the Medicare logo in their own political material?

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The Manager of Opposition business knows the rules on props. The

Speaker: NA
Text: members on my left and right will cease interjecting.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Wentworth-Prime Minister) (15:00): There is a question on notice.

Speaker: NA
Text: See if that litigation is as he has described.

Speaker: NA
Text: Domestic and Family Violence

Speaker: Ms HENDERSON
Text: Corangamite) (15:00): My question is to the Minister for Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Services. Will the minister update the House on what the government is doing to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: support services to people affected by family and domestic violence. How important is it that

Speaker: NA
Text: the government provides these services in our community?

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: question on this very important issue. Of course, on 28 October of this year, the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister announced $100 million worth of support to the third action plan for reducing

Speaker: NA
Text: violence against women, and, in September of 2015, the Prime Minister announced a $100

Speaker: NA
Text: million Women's Safety Package. The question was directed to the way in which these fund

Speaker: NA
Text: important services. Perhaps there is no more important service being funded with this very

Speaker: NA
Text: large increase in funding, which has been made possible by the commitment of the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, than the 1800RESPECT hotline. That translates to practical assistance for women in

Speaker: NA
Text: need, on the ground. Since its inception, the hotline has been-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hill interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Bruce.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: counsellors from the rape and domestic violence services. Since 2010, there has been a much

Speaker: NA
Text: greater awareness of the issue and that has given rise to a greater number of people wanting to

Speaker: NA
Text: use this hotline. That is, in itself, a measure of some success as awareness increases.

Speaker: NA
Text: The unfortunate outcome, however, was that, before we undertook recent reforms, the call

Speaker: NA
Text: wait time had blown out to over 10 minutes, which had meant that a whole range of women

Speaker: NA
Text: who were seeking assistance had actually given up waiting, and the call abandonment rate had

Speaker: NA
Text: lifted to 44 per cent. As a government, with the funding that the Prime Minister allocated, we

Speaker: NA
Text: did three things. Firstly, we commissioned an independent report to look into best practice

Speaker: NA
Text: models here and overseas. Secondly, we worked with Medibank Health Solutions to try and

Speaker: NA
Text: tailor the single best practical option that we could institute here. That option involved a first

Speaker: NA
Text: responder triage model, so that the first person you would talk to would be someone with at

Speaker: NA
Text: least a three-year degree qualification in a relevant tertiary field plus a minimum of two years

Speaker: NA
Text: experience in counselling. If you needed specialist trauma counselling, you were seamlessly

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: directed to that at the very point of the phone call. Thirdly, we steeled ourselves to what is,

Speaker: NA
Text: inevitably, the level of criticism you get when you engage in reform of this nature. Ms Jenna

Speaker: NA
Text: Price, through the Sydney Morning Herald, said that this would destroy 1800RESPECT. The

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Griffith, in agreeing with that, said that the changes were terrible and that they

Speaker: NA
Text: would divert people away-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Moreton.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: to know that these have been the results: 80 per cent of calls are now answered in 20 seconds.

Speaker: NA
Text: The average call wait time has dropped from over 10 minutes to 35 seconds. The call

Speaker: NA
Text: abandonment rate in this incredibly important area has dropped from 44 per cent to 5.5 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent. They are not terrible changes, as we were led to believe by the member for Griffith in

Speaker: NA
Text: the context of the election campaign; they are tremendous changes that help women in their

Speaker: NA
Text: greatest time of need when domestic violence- (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Murray-Darling Basin

Speaker: Mr BURKE
Text: Watson-Manager of Opposition Business) (15:04): My question is to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister. When the Deputy Prime Minister personally insisted on receiving the water

Speaker: NA
Text: portfolio in September 2015, did he keep secret from the Prime Minister his intention to

Speaker: NA
Text: undermine the additional 450 gigalitres in the Murray-Darling Basin Plan? Did the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister have any idea prior to Friday that his deputy had put in writing that the Basin Plan

Speaker: NA
Text: would not be completed, and since then, has the Prime Minister, in any way, reprimanded the

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Prime Minister for free ranging on the Basin Plan?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hunt interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The Minister for Industry, Innovation and Science.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Wentworth-Prime Minister) (15:04): Characteristically, from the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition, we have one misrepresentation after another. The fact is the government is

Speaker: NA
Text: committed to the Basin Plan. If I may just remind honourable members, the section I referred

Speaker: NA
Text: to from the Basin Plan was from the Basin Plan 2012, so this is a plan that the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member is very familiar with. Indeed, I see here on the front page:

Speaker: NA
Text: I, Tony Burke, Minister for Sustainability, Environment, Water, Population and Communities…

Speaker: NA
Text: Gosh, no wonder he was so busy with all of those things to do. He could not pay attention to

Speaker: NA
Text: water. There it is. This is the plan the honourable member promulgated as minister, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: section to which I referred is in his plan, and that is part of the plan to which we are

Speaker: NA
Text: committed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Energy Security

Speaker: Ms FLINT
Text: Boothby) (15:05): My constituency question is to the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Environment and Energy. Can the minister update the House on what the government is doing

Speaker: NA
Text: to provide a more reliable and affordable electricity supply for the constituents and businesses

Speaker: NA
Text: in my electorate of Boothby and across South Australia. Is the minister aware of any

Speaker: NA
Text: alternative approaches?

Speaker: Mr FRYDENBERG
Text: Kooyong-Minister for the Environment and Energy) (15:06): I

Speaker: NA
Text: thank the member for Boothby for her question and acknowledge her deep concern for the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: very high electricity prices her constituents pay, which are the highest in the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Electricity Market and some 50 per cent higher than the wholesale electricity prices that they

Speaker: NA
Text: pay over the border in Victoria. This makes life tough for Lucas Earthmovers, a family owned

Speaker: NA
Text: business that I visited in the electorate of Boothby. It also makes life tough for the households

Speaker: NA
Text: in Mitcham and Brighton and the small businesses in Dover Gardens and Somerton Park.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know that Premier Weatherill was conducting a big experiment-in his own words-

Speaker: NA
Text: by the high uptake of intermittent power, namely solar and wind. But that big experiment

Speaker: NA
Text: failed when 1.7 million South Australians went into the black after the blackout in that state.

Speaker: NA
Text: Just yesterday we found out from the Australian Energy Regulator that there were some

Speaker: NA
Text: 10,000 electricity disconnections in South Australia over the last year. Of all the states and

Speaker: NA
Text: territories monitored by the AER, this was the highest number, and the amount owed by those

Speaker: NA
Text: hardship customers in South Australia was the highest of any state or territory monitored by

Speaker: NA
Text: the AER. That is why the coalition is determined to improve energy security and energy

Speaker: NA
Text: affordability. We are doing that by pushing reforms into the gas market through the COAG

Speaker: NA
Text: Energy Council, by commissioning the Finkel review into energy security, by looking into the

Speaker: NA
Text: effectiveness of the limited merits review process and by trying to get a coordinated,

Speaker: NA
Text: harmonised approach across the states and the federal government when it comes to the

Speaker: NA
Text: renewable energy target.

Speaker: NA
Text: But we are getting no help from those opposite, because they persist with their 50 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent-unrealistic and job-destroying-renewable energy target; they persist with a carbon tax,

Speaker: NA
Text: which we heard from the member for Hunter is a tax; and they persist in trading away blue-

Speaker: NA
Text: collar jobs in the regions, in the coal-fired power stations, in order to win Green votes in the

Speaker: NA
Text: city. We know that the Leader of the Opposition wants to take Jay Weatherill's experiment

Speaker: NA
Text: and take it national. Shame on him. But you have to understand: it is not just business and the

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition who have a problem with Labor's approach; it is also members of the party

Speaker: NA
Text: represented by those opposite. Graham Richardson has described the Labor Party's policy as

Speaker: NA
Text: stupid, as a farce and as a sell-out of the poor and the pensioners. They are not my words;

Speaker: NA
Text: they are Graham Richardson's. Only the coalition can deliver energy security and energy

Speaker: NA
Text: affordability for all Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: Murray-Darling Basin

Speaker: Mr SHORTEN
Text: Maribyrnong-Leader of the Opposition) (15:09): My question is to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister. I refer to the Deputy Prime Minister's letter of 17 November to the South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian government, indicating that the government would abandon its obligation to

Speaker: NA
Text: deliver 450 gigalitres of water to the Murray-Darling Basin through efficiency measures.

Speaker: NA
Text: Does the Deputy Prime Minister's letter reflect government policy?

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Wentworth-Prime Minister) (15:09): Could the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition assist us by showing where in that letter the word 'abandoned' is used?

Speaker: NA
Text: A government member: Not once!

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Not once. Yet again the Leader of the Opposition is misrepresenting

Speaker: NA
Text: what ministers have said. He has no regard for the truth. He gave a long speech today in

Speaker: NA
Text: which he thoroughly misrepresented statements by the Minister for Immigration and Border

Speaker: NA
Text: Protection-dishonestly did so. And I might say, on the subject of the recklessness of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition, he quoted the member for Cowan, who said, 'I am fearful that the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: minister's comments will be used by an extreme few who would seek to harm the fabric of our

Speaker: NA
Text: society.'

Speaker: Mr Shorten
Text: Mr SPEAKER -

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: You can't take it, can you?

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The Prime Minister will resume his seat.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Your dishonesty-

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The Prime Minister will resume his seat. Members on both sides will

Speaker: NA
Text: cease interjecting. The Leader of the Opposition on a point of order?

Speaker: Mr Shorten
Text: On relevance. It was a very straight question: does the Deputy Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister's letter reflect government policy-yes or no?

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Joyce interjecting-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Henderson: Mr SPEAKER -

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The Leader of the House and the Deputy Prime Minister will cease

Speaker: NA
Text: interjecting. The member for Corangamite will resume her seat. The Prime Minister has the

Speaker: NA
Text: call.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: The Deputy Prime Minister, the government, is committed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: policy, which is to implement the Basin Plan, but the Basin Plan has conditions and

Speaker: NA
Text: qualifications and was set in place by the member for Watson when he was the minister. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have just read a portion of it, and achieving those neutral or improved social or economic

Speaker: NA
Text: outcomes is challenging. We recognise that, and that is why we need all jurisdictions to work

Speaker: NA
Text: together in a constructive way to achieve it. But what we have seen today is this consistent

Speaker: NA
Text: dishonest misrepresentation by the Leader of the Opposition. If it is not the Deputy Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, it is the immigration minister-he is misrepresenting one minister after another, all

Speaker: NA
Text: reckless to the consequences of what he says, promoting anxiety, stirring up resentment,

Speaker: NA
Text: stirring up conflict. He has no regard for the consequences of what he does other than his own

Speaker: NA
Text: political interest.

Speaker: Mr Shorten
Text: Mr Speaker, I seek leave to table the letter from Barnaby Joyce, because I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not think the Prime Minister has seen it.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The Leader of the Opposition will refer to members-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Henderson: Mr SPEAKER -

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Corangamite will resume her seat. Members on both

Speaker: NA
Text: sides will cease interjecting.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Julie Bishop interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The foreign affairs minister will cease interjecting. I say to the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Corangamite: the Practice makes very clear that leaders of political parties have certain

Speaker: NA
Text: precedence. The Leader of the Opposition will nonetheless refer to members by their correct

Speaker: NA
Text: titles.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Mr Shorten
Text: Yes. Thank you for that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Leave not granted.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: I call the member for Corangamite, finally.

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members: Hurray!

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria: Infrastructure

Speaker: Ms HENDERSON
Text: Corangamite) (15:13): My constituency question is to the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Infrastructure and Transport. Could the minister update the House on the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: $1.5 billion Victorian infrastructure package, including $25 million for one of Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: most important tourist attractions, the iconic, the majestic, the awe-inspiring Great Ocean

Speaker: NA
Text: Road?

Speaker: Mr CHESTER
Text: Gippsland-Minister for Infrastructure and Transport) (15:13): I thank

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Corangamite for her question. I am not surprised to hear those opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: cheering the member for Corangamite. She is a very popular local member, and I note her

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to securing funding for that iconic touring route the Great Ocean Road.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Turnbull-Joyce government is focused on delivering a $50 billion infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: investment program right across Australia-in our cities, in our major regional centres, in our

Speaker: NA
Text: rural and remote communities. We do that because we recognise that investing in good

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure not only can change people's lives but it can save people's lives. Too many

Speaker: NA
Text: people are dying and too many people are being seriously injured on our roads. Tragically, as

Speaker: NA
Text: of today 257 people have died on Victorian roads this year. The total last year was 226. Every

Speaker: NA
Text: death, obviously, is one too many, and that is why we are investing in safer roads right across

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, in projects like the Great Ocean Road.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was pleased to be with the Prime Minister last week in Melbourne when we announced a

Speaker: NA
Text: $1.5 billion Victorian infrastructure package, and part of that package was $25 million for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Ocean Road through our $345 million regional roads package, which will see projects

Speaker: NA
Text: completed right across Victoria. The projects in the member for Corangamite's own seat

Speaker: NA
Text: involve safety measures around the recent landslips and rock-falls which have-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hill interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Bruce is warned.

Speaker: Mr CHESTER
Text: impacted severely on this most scenic of all coastal routes. The member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Corangamite has been very active in calling for the Victorian government to match that

Speaker: NA
Text: $25 million, and I am very confident that the Victorian government will come on board and

Speaker: NA
Text: yield to her campaign and support us in that regard. I commend the member for Corangamite

Speaker: NA
Text: for her advocacy.

Speaker: NA
Text: I heard the member for Wannon cheering as well, and I want to recognise the work that is

Speaker: NA
Text: going to occur in his electorate on the Princes Highway upgrades. There is work also along

Speaker: NA
Text: the Hamilton Highway and the Geelong Ring Road. There is planning for the duplication of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Midland Highway between Geelong and Bannockburn.

Speaker: NA
Text: In fact, there are projects right across Victoria which are going to be made possible through

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister's announcement last week. We are getting on with the job of delivering the

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure that Victoria needs. This government, under the Victorian $1.5 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure package, is also delivering $220 million for the Murray basin freight rail

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: project. The member for Mallee has been a very strong advocate for that project. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: $500 million to go towards the Monash Freeway upgrade, bringing a total of a billion dollars

Speaker: NA
Text: to go on reducing congestion on that route. The members for La Trobe, Deakin, Aston and

Speaker: NA
Text: Chisholm have all been strong advocates for improvements to that congested route. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: $350 million for the upgrade of the M80 Ring Road. And, as I mentioned, there is $345

Speaker: NA
Text: million for rural and regional roads. One of the signature projects will be the $97 million for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Echuca-Moama bridge, for which the new member for Murray has been a very strong

Speaker: NA
Text: advocate.

Speaker: NA
Text: So this is a good deal. It is a good deal for Victorians and it is a good deal for the Victorian

Speaker: NA
Text: government. I am sure they will come on board and match that $1.5 billion. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Murray-Darling Basin

Speaker: Mr SHORTEN
Text: Maribyrnong-Leader of the Opposition) (15:16): My question is to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister. Did the Prime Minister have any advance notice of the contents of his

Speaker: NA
Text: deputy's letter of 17 November?

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Wentworth-Prime Minister) (15:16): The Deputy Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: understands the Basin Plan very well, as do I-as, indeed, does the member for Watson-and

Speaker: NA
Text: he understands that the government is committed to fulfilling it and he understands the

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions of the basin plan and the need for jurisdictions to work together to ensure it is

Speaker: NA
Text: delivered. And the commitment of our government to the basin plan is absolute. But it is a

Speaker: NA
Text: plan which presents significant challenges, which the member for Watson understood back in

Speaker: NA
Text: 2012 when he had the northern basin aspects of the plan reviewed to look at precisely these

Speaker: NA
Text: issues of ensuring that there is neutral or improved socioeconomic outcomes.

Speaker: NA
Text: And, on that note, Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) notes that:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) 1 December marks World AIDS Day, which is held every year to raise awareness about the

Speaker: NA
Text: issues concerning HIV and AIDS, and is a day for people to show their support for people living with

Speaker: NA
Text: HIV and to commemorate people who have died; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) the theme for World AIDS Day this year is 'HIV is still here-and it's on the move';

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) acknowledges the roles played by people living with HIV and their friends, family, supporters,

Speaker: NA
Text: AIDS activists and researchers, past and present, in making living with HIV possible; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) will support actions to reduce stigma and prevent new HIV transmissions, and work towards a cure.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Notice given 21 November 2016.)

Speaker: NA
Text: 7 MR HASTIE: To move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) notes that:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) from 21 to 28 of October the Minister for Veterans' Affairs undertook a veterans mission to

Speaker: NA
Text: Korea; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) eight veterans joined the Minister to tour battlefields and attend commemorations, including Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Gordon Hughes DSM, Mr Graham Connor, Mr Les Hall, Mr Jack Lang, Mr John Murphy, Lieutenant

Speaker: NA
Text: Commander Les Powell RAN (Retd.), Colonel Peter Scott DSO (Retd.), and Mr Ray Seaver;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) acknowledges that:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) this year marks the 65th anniversaries of the Battle of Maryang San and the Battle of Kapyong;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) the Battle of Maryang San took place on 3 October when the 3rd Battalion, The Royal Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Regiment, as part of the 28th British Commonwealth Infantry Brigade, took part in Operation

Speaker: NA
Text: Commando, which included the capture of Hill 317, where 20 Australians were killed and 89

Speaker: NA
Text: wounded-noted as the most significant Australian action of the Korean War;

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) in the Battle of Kapyong on 22 to 25 April 1951, the 27th British Commonwealth Infantry

Speaker: NA
Text: Brigade, including the 3rd Battalion, The Royal Australian Regiment, was instrumental in stalling the

Speaker: NA
Text: Chinese advance on Seoul, with 32 Australians being killed, 59 wounded and 3 taken prisoner;

Speaker: NA
Text: (d) more than 17,000 Australians served in the Korean War and the post armistice period, with more

Speaker: NA
Text: than 1,200 wounded; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (e) the names of 356 Australians killed in Korea are listed on the Australian War Memorial Roll of

Speaker: NA
Text: Honour; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) notes:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) that although it has been called the 'forgotten war' in Australia, Korea and its people are still

Speaker: NA
Text: grateful for the significant contribution the Australian forces made in the defence of a free Republic of

Speaker: NA
Text: Korea; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) the service and sacrifice of those who fought in the Korean War.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Notice given 22 November 2016.)

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 MR HILL: To move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) notes that:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) there is a current controversy pertaining to the so called 'palace letters' between the then

Speaker: NA
Text: Governor-General Sir John Kerr and Her Majesty The Queen in the months leading up to the dismissal

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Whitlam Government; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) this correspondence has been declared 'personal' and therefore secret at 'Her Majesty the Queen's

Speaker: NA
Text: instructions'; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) acknowledges that:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) these letters are a matter of our national history which should be made available to the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: people;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) regardless of the merits or otherwise of the dismissal, Australians deserve to know the extent to

Speaker: NA
Text: which The Queen involved herself in the sacking of an elected Australian Government; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) the very notion of 'personal' letters between the Monarch and the Governor-General offends all

Speaker: NA
Text: concepts of transparency and democracy that we hold dear; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) call on the Australian Government to take steps to have the documents released.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Notice given 21 November 2016.)

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: and

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Text: 3 MS HUSAR: To move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) acknowledges that:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) Saturday 3 December 2016 is International Day of People with Disability (IDPwD);

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) the United Nations proclaimed IDPwD for the first time in 1992 as a way of promoting better

Speaker: NA
Text: understanding of disability issues and as a sign of support for the dignity, rights and wellbeing of people

Speaker: NA
Text: with disabilities; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) each year, the United Nations chooses a theme for IDPwD and this year's theme is 'Achieving 17

Speaker: NA
Text: Goals for the Future We Want', which draws attention to the 17 Sustainable Development Goals and

Speaker: NA
Text: how these goals can create a more inclusive and equitable world for people with disabilities;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) encourages all Members of Parliament to support IDPwD in their electorates; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) reaffirms its commitment to:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) ensuring Australians with a disability get the support they need; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) an adequately funded and resourced National Disability Insurance Scheme.

Text: 4 MS FLINT: To move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) urges all Australians to drive safely and with consideration for fellow road users over the upcoming

Speaker: NA
Text: summer holidays;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) notes the Government has made significant investments in road safety including:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) $500 million from 2014-15 to 2018-19 in the Black Spot Program (BSP);

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) an additional $200 million from 2015-16 that makes an important contribution to reducing the

Speaker: NA
Text: national road toll under the National Road Safety Strategy and Action Plan; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) completing 977 projects under the BSP which has saved an estimated 116 lives and prevented

Speaker: NA
Text: 5,959 injuries from crashes over 10 years;

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) encourages all state and territory governments to address the over-representation of men in road

Speaker: NA
Text: fatalities through improved driver information and education; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) calls on all Australians to drive carefully over the summer period.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Notice given 22 November 2016.)

Speaker: NA
Text: 5 MR J. H. WILSON: To move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) notes that in 2012, following a comprehensive and rigorous process, the then Labor Government

Speaker: NA
Text: declared 40 marine parks in Commonwealth waters, creating the world's first and largest comprehensive

Speaker: NA
Text: national network of marine parks;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) notes with concern that there is increasing pressure on Australia's marine environment, as indicated

Speaker: NA
Text: by frequent and severe bleaching of coral reefs across Australia's northern waters, extensive and

Speaker: NA
Text: unprecedented dieback of mangroves, and the loss of large areas of kelp forests in southern Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: waters;

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) notes that Australia's marine environment is the most biologically diverse in the world according to

Speaker: NA
Text: the 2010 Census of Marine Life, with our oceans spanning tropical, temperate and sub-Antarctic waters,

Speaker: NA
Text: and where at least 33,000 marine species have been identified (many of which are found nowhere else

Speaker: NA
Text: on earth);

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) notes that Australia is a signatory to the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and as

Speaker: NA
Text: such is required to both conserve as well as sustainably utilise its Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ);

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) notes the economic opportunity that marine parks bring regional communities as evidenced by long

Speaker: NA
Text: standing marine parks in Australia, including the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park which is worth over

Speaker: NA
Text: $6 billion to the Queensland economy, and others including Ningaloo Marine Park, the Great Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Bight, Lord Howe Island, Solitary Islands Marine Park and Maria Island National Park;

Speaker: NA
Text: (6) notes the clear evidence that marine parks play an important economic role in accelerating the

Speaker: NA
Text: recovery of depleted fisheries, and that the long term net effect on fisheries of increased resilience and

Speaker: NA
Text: sustainability from highly protected marine reserves is positive;

Speaker: NA
Text: (7) notes that in the 1990s the then Coalition Government put in place a systematic approach for

Speaker: NA
Text: declaring a comprehensive, adequate, and representative network of marine parks in Australia's EEZ,

Speaker: NA
Text: and proceeded to declare 22 marine parks in Commonwealth waters;

Speaker: NA
Text: (8) notes with concern that:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) in December 2013 the incoming Coalition Government suspended Labor's marine parks from

Speaker: NA
Text: operation by re-declaring the parks in order to set aside their management arrangements and

Speaker: NA
Text: commencement date, pending the conduct of a politically motivated and unnecessary review; and

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) after almost 3 years, these 40 marine parks have not been implemented, existing in statute only-

Speaker: NA
Text: leaving 5 of Australia's 6 marine regions with little to no protection at a time when the threats to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's valuable and important marine environment are increasing;

Speaker: NA
Text: (9) notes that in the May 2016 budget the Coalition Government committed to completing the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: development of the management plans for the new parks within 12 months;

Speaker: NA
Text: (10) notes that in the recent consultation by Parks Australia, over 50,000 submissions were received

Speaker: NA
Text: from around Australia, including from more than 5,000 recreational fishers, calling for the reinstatement

Speaker: NA
Text: of the marine parks and their high level marine national park zoning, without further delay or loss of

Speaker: NA
Text: protection;

Speaker: NA
Text: (11) notes that the Expert Science Panel of the Coalition Government's own review recognises both the

Speaker: NA
Text: extensive science that went into the development of the marine parks developed by the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Government and the scientifically proven benefits of marine national parks;

Speaker: NA
Text: (12) notes the Bioregional Advisory Panel of the Coalition Government's own review recognised the

Speaker: NA
Text: extensive consultation that has occurred in developing the marine reserves developed by the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, stating that there was in fact a considerable amount of 'consultation fatigue' expressed by

Speaker: NA
Text: many stakeholders;

Speaker: NA
Text: (13) notes the increasing move by other countries to put in place large and highly protected marine

Speaker: NA
Text: parks in their EEZs, including action taken by the United States, Palau, Chile, New Zealand, the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingdom, and, most recently, the declaration in October 2016 by 24 nations, including Australia, of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Ross Sea marine park in the Antarctic high seas; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (14) calls on the Coalition Government to bring the Commonwealth network of marine parks that were

Speaker: NA
Text: declared in 2012 into operation without further delay, and with no loss of marine national park

Speaker: NA
Text: protection.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Notice given 22 November 2016.)

Speaker: NA
Text: Time allotted-remaining private Members' business time prior to 1.30 pm

Speaker: NA
Text: Speech time limits-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr J. H. Wilson-5 minutes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other Members-5 minutes. each.

Speaker: NA
Text: [Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 4 x 5 mins]

Speaker: NA
Text: The Committee determined that consideration of this should continue on a future day.

Speaker: NA
Text: Items for Federation Chamber (4.45 pm to 7.30 pm)
