Text: 6 MR VAN MANEN: To move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) notes that:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) the 'Declaration of Intent on a Strategic Dialogue' between the Government of Australia and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government of the Netherlands was signed by Foreign Minister Bishop and Foreign Minister Koenders

Speaker: NA
Text: on 2 November 2016, in Canberra;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) the Declaration has been updated from the one signed in February 2014 by Foreign Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: Bishop and the then Foreign Minister Timmermans to reflect current events and increased closeness

Speaker: NA
Text: between our two countries through our shared commitment to achieve accountability with respect to the

Speaker: NA
Text: downing of MH17; and

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) the Declaration commits Australia and the Netherlands to enhanced cooperation on international

Speaker: NA
Text: security, trade and investment, human rights and development issues; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) welcomes enhanced economic and security cooperation between Australia and the Netherlands.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Notice given 21 November 2016.)

Speaker: NA
Text: Time allotted-20 minutes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Speech time limits-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr van Manen-5 minutes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other Members-5 minutes. each.

Speaker: NA
Text: [Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 4 x 5 mins]

Speaker: NA
Text: The Committee determined that consideration of this should continue on a future day.

Speaker: NA
Text: 7 MR HAYES: To move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) notes that:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) since 2014, Da'esh (also known as ISIL) has been carrying out terror campaigns against

Speaker: NA
Text: Christians, Assyrians, Mandaeans, Yezidis, and other ethnic and religious minorities in Iraq and Syria;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) these campaigns have taken the form of mass murders, torture, rape, kidnappings, sexual

Speaker: NA
Text: enslavement and other crimes; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) these atrocities constitute war crimes, crimes against humanity, and genocide;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) noting that the United Nations mandated Independent International Commission of Inquiry on Syria

Speaker: NA
Text: has declared that Da'esh's actions against the Yazidi people amount to genocide, calls on the:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) Australian Government to refer to the Da'esh atrocities as war crimes, crimes against humanity

Speaker: NA
Text: and genocide; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) United Nations and Member States to co-ordinate measures to prevent further atrocities occurring

Speaker: NA
Text: in Syria and Iraq and take all necessary action to hold those responsible to account; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) commends:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan, the Lebanese Republic, the Republic of Turkey and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Kurdistan Regional Government in Iraq, for their ongoing support and efforts to shelter and protect

Speaker: NA
Text: those fleeing the violence in Syria and Iraq; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) those nations that are providing a permanent home for Syrian and Iraqi refugees who are

Speaker: NA
Text: escaping persecution and violence.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Notice given 21 November 2016.)

Speaker: NA
Text: Time allotted-20 minutes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Speech time limits-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hayes-5 minutes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other Members-5 minutes. each.

Speaker: NA
Text: [Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 4 x 5 mins]

Speaker: NA
Text: The Committee determined that consideration of this should continue on a future day.

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) congratulates the Government on the success of the National Stronger Regions Fund (NSRF);

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) Government is investing $125,286,955 million in 40 projects around Queensland under 3 rounds

Speaker: NA
Text: of the NSRF; and

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities and support stronger and more sustainable communities across Queensland.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: 9 MS SWANSON: To move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) calls on the Government to:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) establish a national inter-governmental taskforce to co-ordinate the response of state/territory and

Speaker: NA
Text: federal government agencies to the perfluorinated and polyfluorinated (perand poly-fluoro) alkyl

Speaker: NA
Text: substances contamination on and around Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) bases at Williamtown and

Speaker: NA
Text: Oakey, and throughout Australia;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) develop a nationally consistent approach for screening and health guidelines, assessments,

Speaker: NA
Text: containment, management standards and remediation protocols for Commonwealth sites and their

Speaker: NA
Text: surroundings that are identified as being contaminated with perand poly-fluoro alkyl substances;

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) provide:

Speaker: NA
Text: (i) a breakdown and schedule of spending of the $55 million allocated from the defence budget to

Speaker: NA
Text: deal with contamination at and around RAAF bases caused by perand poly-fluoro alkyl substances;

Speaker: NA
Text: (ii) transparency into the Government's perand poly-fluoro alkyl substances interdepartmental

Speaker: NA
Text: committee, including a breakdown of its composition, terms of reference and meeting schedule; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (iii) a timeline for when, how, and by whom the issue of perand poly-fluoro alkyl substances

Speaker: NA
Text: will be brought to the COAG; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (d) inform Williamtown residents when its proposed dialogue will begin on buybacks of properties

Speaker: NA
Text: contaminated by perand poly-fluoro alkyl substances; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) while welcoming the New South Wales Environmental Protection Agency's lifting of fishing bans

Speaker: NA
Text: implemented as a result of the contamination, calls on the Government to:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) ensure income support is available to affected commercial fishers through to March 2017; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) advocate for leniency by lending institutions with respect to business and home loan repayments

Speaker: NA
Text: and lending practices involving properties in the Williamtown investigation zone.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Notice given 9 November 2016.)

Speaker: NA
Text: Time allotted-30 minutes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Speech time limits-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Swanson-5 minutes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other Members-5 minutes. each.

Speaker: NA
Text: [Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 6 x 5 mins]

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: The Committee determined that consideration of this should continue on a future day.

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 MR RAMSEY: To move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) recognises that:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) the Strzelecki Track is a vital freight and tourist route connecting Adelaide to the Moomba Gas

Speaker: NA
Text: fields in South Australia's far north-east and South East Queensland;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) the route is used extensively by pastoralists, mining vehicles and tourists and is no longer fit for

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose due to pot holes, bulldust and closures from flooding;

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) it can take more than 12 hours for heavy transport to negotiate 338 kilometres from Lyndhurst to

Speaker: NA
Text: Moomba;

Speaker: NA
Text: (d) the Track is used by many tourists heading into the heart of Australia and visiting some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: wonders of outback South Australia and Queensland and with a proper standard road there is great

Speaker: NA
Text: potential to grow this industry; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (e) the Track is also used by heavy transport which supports the exploitation of the Moomba Gas

Speaker: NA
Text: Fields and trucks carrying supplies to, and cattle from, properties and they are totally reliant on this

Speaker: NA
Text: route;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) notes that:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) the Track cuts through remote and inhospitable country where emergency services are reliant on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Royal Flying Doctor Service;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) more than 30 road trains a day navigate the Track each day carrying vital equipment for the gas

Speaker: NA
Text: industry and thousands of dollars of damage is done to each of these trucks on a daily basis; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) rain can close the road for up to six weeks as it did in 2010 when large sections were washed

Speaker: NA
Text: away or left underwater and on average shuts the road for 45 days a year; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) calls on the state and federal governments to work together in an urgent manner to bring about the

Speaker: NA
Text: sealing of this vital route.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Notice given 21 November 2016.)

Speaker: NA
Text: Time allotted-25 minutes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Speech time limits-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ramsey-10 minutes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other Members-5 minutes. each.

Speaker: NA
Text: [Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 1 x 10 mins + 3 x 5 mins]

Speaker: NA
Text: The Committee determined that consideration of this should continue on a future day.

Text: 12 MS MCGOWAN: To move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) notes that:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) the nbnTM Fair Use Policy is unfair for rural and regional Australia;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) rural nbnTM users have restricted data speeds, limits on capacity and have to pay more for a

Speaker: NA
Text: poorer service;

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) under the nbnTM Interim Satellite Service, rural users had 'off peak' data from 11pm to 2pm;

Speaker: NA
Text: (d) on the new nbnTM Sky MusterTM Satellite Service, the 'off peak' data has now changed to between

Speaker: NA
Text: 1am and 7am; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (e) the consequence of the nbnTM Fair Use Policy is that businesses, students, home workers and

Speaker: NA
Text: farmers have reduced Internet access and pay comparatively more; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) calls on the Government to:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) implement the recommendations of the 2015 Regional Telecommunications Review and review

Speaker: NA
Text: the nbnTM Fair Use Policy in light of the impact on rural families and businesses;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) maximise the amount of data available under the satellite service; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) revert the off-peak period in the nbnTM Fair Use Policy to 11pm to 2pm, to accommodate the

Speaker: NA
Text: realities of rural life.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Notice given 22 November 2016.)

Speaker: NA
Text: THE HON A. D. H. SMITH MP

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker of the House of Representatives

Speaker: NA
Text: 23 November 2016

Speaker: NA
Text: DOCUMENTS

Speaker: NA
Text: Presentation

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Documents are tabled in accordance with the list circulated to honourable members earlier

Speaker: NA
Text: today. Full details of the documents will be recorded in the Votes and Proceedings.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE

Speaker: NA
Text: Domestic and Family Violence

Speaker: NA
Text: The SPEAKER (15:18): I have received a letter from the honourable member for Griffith

Speaker: NA
Text: proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for

Speaker: NA
Text: discussion, namely:

Speaker: NA
Text: The need to address family violence as a national priority.

Speaker: NA
Text: I call upon those honourable members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their

Speaker: NA
Text: places.

Speaker: NA
Text: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their

Speaker: NA
Text: places-

Speaker: Ms BUTLER
Text: Griffith) (15:19): It is, of course, a very important week to talk about

Speaker: NA
Text: family violence-violence against women and their children. This Friday, 25 November, is

Speaker: NA
Text: the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women. It is also the

Speaker: NA
Text: commencement of 16 days of activism against gender related violence that concludes on 10

Speaker: NA
Text: December, which is International Human Rights Day, as members would know.

Speaker: NA
Text: Family violence is a national priority, and it should be treated that way in this country. On

Speaker: NA
Text: average, at least one woman is killed by a partner or former partner in Australia each week.

Speaker: NA
Text: One in three Australian women has experienced physical violence since the age of 15. One in

Speaker: NA
Text: five Australian women has experienced sexual violence. One in four Australian women has

Speaker: NA
Text: experienced physical or sexual violence from an intimate partner. One in four Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: women has experienced emotional abuse by a current or former partner. And women are at

Speaker: NA
Text: least three times more likely than men to experience violence from an intimate partner. These

Speaker: NA
Text: sets of statistics are repeated so often in this place-and they are repeated for a very good

Speaker: NA
Text: reason, because family violence is a national epidemic and, as I said earlier, it should be a

Speaker: NA
Text: national priority.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a nation, we do need to do better when it comes to family violence. I am really proud

Speaker: NA
Text: that it was a Labor government that introduced and instigated a plan, under the great

Speaker: NA
Text: leadership of then Minister Tanya Plibersek, who instigated the National Plan for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Reduction of Violence against Women and their Children 2010-2022. This is an excellent

Speaker: NA
Text: document that is currently under its third action plan, which was announced in October this

Speaker: NA
Text: year. Much more needs to be done when it comes to fulfilling the aspirations of that plan: for

Speaker: NA
Text: a country that does not suffer from this epidemic of domestic and family violence that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have seen here for such a long period of time.

Speaker: NA
Text: I wanted to make some observations about some policy challenges that arise in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: family violence. For example, it has been almost three years since the coalition government

Speaker: NA
Text: announced its cuts to community legal centres, which directly provide front-line services to

Speaker: NA
Text: domestic violence victims. From 1 July 2017, community legal centres or CLCs are facing a

Speaker: NA
Text: 30 per cent funding cliff, with almost $35 million in cuts. And that is a terrible shame, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Speaker Coulton-welcome to the chair-because, obviously, access to legal services

Speaker: NA
Text: and the assistance that surrounds legal services is incredibly important for women who are

Speaker: NA
Text: seeking domestic violence orders, and for women who are in the family law courts, who need

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance to manage the experience of going through the family law courts. Legal assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: is incredibly important.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Another thing that is incredibly important for people who have left a violent relationship is

Speaker: NA
Text: housing. Domestic violence is a leading cause of homelessness in this country. It is incredibly

Speaker: NA
Text: important that the National Partnership Agreement on Homelessness be renewed. I call on the

Speaker: NA
Text: government to confirm that it will renew the National Partnership Agreement on

Speaker: NA
Text: Homelessness, which expires very soon, and therefore that it will give those services that

Speaker: NA
Text: provide housing for homeless people, including homeless women who have left violent

Speaker: NA
Text: situations, the certainty that they need to continue their programs and ensure that their

Speaker: NA
Text: workforce does not leave.

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaking of the National Partnership Agreement on Homelessness, it has actually now

Speaker: NA
Text: been more than two years since the coalition government's cuts to that partnership agreement's

Speaker: NA
Text: capital expenditure component. There were two annual cuts of $44 million-so an $88

Speaker: NA
Text: million cut-to capital expenditure on homelessness in this country, at a time when people

Speaker: NA
Text: across the country are crying out for more housing options for women and children who have

Speaker: NA
Text: been forced to leave home because they have been facing family violence at home.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have also been talking in this parliament today about family law, and I mentioned it

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier. There is a really important reform that needs to happen in relation to family law. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: been more than two years since the Productivity Commission recommended that the

Speaker: NA
Text: government reform family law processes so that perpetrators of family violence could not

Speaker: NA
Text: personally cross-examine their victims. It has also been a little bit more than 12 months since

Speaker: NA
Text: Women's Legal Services Australia wrote to the Minister for Women and to the Attorney-

Speaker: NA
Text: General to ask them to implement cross-examination reform in this country. In February this

Speaker: NA
Text: year in Senate estimates, the Attorney-General said that nothing would be done in that term of

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament to give effect to this recommendation, but we found out in April that a roundtable

Speaker: NA
Text: had been held in relation to this issue back in March. It is now November and there has been

Speaker: NA
Text: no news from the government about this crucial cross-examination reform in that intervening

Speaker: NA
Text: period.

Speaker: NA
Text: We invited the government today in question time to get on board with our policy. Our

Speaker: NA
Text: policy would require judges at the first mention in a family law proceeding-by which time

Speaker: NA
Text: you will have seen on the papers the disclosure of any allegations of family violence-to

Speaker: NA
Text: consider whether vulnerable witnesses can be protected using existing measures, like video-

Speaker: NA
Text: conferencing, having witnesses behind screens or having a support person, but, then, if that

Speaker: NA
Text: were not enough, to require a judge to consider whether they should refuse to allow an alleged

Speaker: NA
Text: perpetrator to personally cross-examine the alleged victim. Of course, it is important that

Speaker: NA
Text: accusers be able to be cross-examined by the accused. We do not seek to prevent people from

Speaker: NA
Text: cross-examining, but we say that it should be able to be done through a lawyer-through

Speaker: NA
Text: someone who is a professional; through someone who is bound by a code of ethics; through

Speaker: NA
Text: someone who is bound by professional responsibility obligations and under the scrutiny of

Speaker: NA
Text: legal profession regulators. That is what we say the court should be able to do.

Speaker: NA
Text: The court should be able to order that someone who has been accused of abusing, of

Speaker: NA
Text: assaulting, of committing crimes against the other party in the family law matter should not be

Speaker: NA
Text: allowed to revictimise and retraumatise that person through personally grilling them in a

Speaker: NA
Text: courtroom, through using family law proceedings to personally grill them.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Ms BUTLER
Text: I hear the member for Moreton agreeing with me. He has been such a

Speaker: NA
Text: strong advocate of this reform. He has been a key driver of this reform. Labor has a strong

Speaker: NA
Text: policy. We will, if elected, implement this change to cross-examination, but it should not have

Speaker: NA
Text: to wait that long. We know it and the government know it. It is time for the government to

Speaker: NA
Text: move to commit to making the legal change and to commit to providing the additional legal

Speaker: NA
Text: aid funding that would be needed so that both parties could have a lawyer if that power were

Speaker: NA
Text: required. This is a crucial reform. It is not just the Productivity Commission or Women's

Speaker: NA
Text: Legal Services Australia who say so; it is also Rosie Batty, the former Australian of the Year,

Speaker: NA
Text: who has been campaigning so hard on her campaign for safety first in family law. This is a

Speaker: NA
Text: crucial reform. We have already waited long enough. The government know that they need to

Speaker: NA
Text: do this, and it is about time that they moved on it.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has been about a year and half since this government's cuts to Family Violence

Speaker: NA
Text: Prevention Legal Services-which are Aboriginal family violence prevention legal services-

Speaker: NA
Text: were reversed, but the government has yet to provide any assurance to those services of any

Speaker: NA
Text: ongoing funding beyond 2018. Some funding was recently announced in October, but it was

Speaker: NA
Text: only a year's funding for a handful of services and no services have as yet been funded

Speaker: NA
Text: beyond 2018. These are incredibly important services that serve women who are most at risk

Speaker: NA
Text: of family violence. The Prime Minister himself has, I think, recited the statistics that, if you

Speaker: NA
Text: are an Aboriginal woman or an Islander woman, you are 34 times more likely to be a victim

Speaker: NA
Text: of family violence than a non-Aboriginal or Islander women. It is also the case that you are

Speaker: NA
Text: something like 60 times more likely to suffer a head injury.

Speaker: NA
Text: These statistics are chilling for us, and they are a reason that certainty should be given to

Speaker: NA
Text: these frontline, key services that do incredible work on the smell of an oily rag. If you are out

Speaker: NA
Text: west, if you are in Roma, the Family Violence Prevention Legal Service covers hundreds of

Speaker: NA
Text: square kilometres with only a handful of staff. These are not expensive services but they are

Speaker: NA
Text: critical services for Aboriginal women and Islander women, and there should be a stronger

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment from this government to continue to funding them.

Speaker: NA
Text: In question time today the Minister for Social Services had a go at me-believe it or not,

Speaker: NA
Text: on White Ribbon Day acknowledgment, of all days-for complaining about the fact that he

Speaker: NA
Text: has taken the $5 million that they had committed to 1800RESPECT and, instead of giving it

Speaker: NA
Text: to Rape and Domestic Violence Services Australia to hire more professional specialist trauma

Speaker: NA
Text: counsellors, has given it to MHS, the private firm that was linked to the data breach involving

Speaker: NA
Text: defence force personnel a couple of years ago, and has said to MHS, 'Take this money and

Speaker: NA
Text: create a triaging service to divert people away from the more professional specialised

Speaker: NA
Text: counsellors.' They advertised for counsellors-the people to take the phone calls-and the

Speaker: NA
Text: qualifications were lesser. The advertising required people to be able to commit to working

Speaker: NA
Text: from home. I would like to know whether the minister is proud of the fact that fewer people

Speaker: NA
Text: are actually making a call directly to a specialist qualified trauma counsellor in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: family violence when they are traumatised. If I were him, I would not be proud of that fact. I

Speaker: NA
Text: would also like the minister to confirm and to commit that all of the people answering those

Speaker: NA
Text: telephone calls are women. So far I have seen very little from anyone to confirm that that is

Speaker: NA
Text: the case.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is so much more to do. We need to work hard on this. I think that it would be

Speaker: NA
Text: wonderful if we had genuine bipartisanship on pursuing these reforms. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Mr TUDGE
Text: Aston-Minister for Human Services) (15:29): I am pleased to rise in

Speaker: NA
Text: support of the member for Griffith's matter of public importance motion today, which is the

Speaker: NA
Text: need to address family violence as a national priority. I admire the member for Griffith's

Speaker: NA
Text: commitments to this area. The reason why I get up in support of her motion is because it is

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed already a national priority, and it was this government which put it on the national

Speaker: NA
Text: agenda predominantly when Prime Minister Turnbull came to office as Prime Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indeed, the very first cabinet decision of the Turnbull government was the $100 million

Speaker: NA
Text: Women's Safety Package. I will go through that package in a few moments time, but, before

Speaker: NA
Text: doing so, can I say that as all of us across all sides of this chamber would agree, violence

Speaker: NA
Text: against women and children is completely unacceptable in any form.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a husband, as a father of two daughters and as the son of a mother, it is almost

Speaker: NA
Text: unfathomable for me to think that there are men out there who would physically harm the

Speaker: NA
Text: girls and women in their lives. It is unfathomable for so many of us. But when you look at the

Speaker: NA
Text: data, unfortunately, it occurs way too frequently. The member for Griffith talked about some

Speaker: NA
Text: of that data for domestic violence. I will just reiterate some of those figures, which are truly

Speaker: NA
Text: staggering. This is from the Domestic Violence Prevention Centre website. They have some

Speaker: NA
Text: data which shows: just under half a million Australian women reported that they had

Speaker: NA
Text: experienced physical or sexual violence or sexual assault in the past 12 months; more than a

Speaker: NA
Text: million women had experienced physical or sexual assault by their male current or ex-partner

Speaker: NA
Text: since the age of 15; over a third of women who experienced physical assault in the 12 months

Speaker: NA
Text: before the survey said the perpetrator was a current or previous male partner; a third said the

Speaker: NA
Text: perpetrator was a male family member or friend; a third of women had experienced physical

Speaker: NA
Text: violence since the age of 15; and one in five women had experienced sexual violence since

Speaker: NA
Text: the age of 15.

Speaker: NA
Text: And, of course, we know that so many physical assaults, sexual assaults and family

Speaker: NA
Text: violence episodes are not reported at all to the police but they are truly staggering figures. But

Speaker: NA
Text: behind every single one of those pieces of data is a person, is a child in many cases or is a

Speaker: NA
Text: family that may have been devastated because of the violence which had been committed

Speaker: NA
Text: against that woman or against that girl. It is truly a tragic situation when we still have

Speaker: NA
Text: statistics like that and, of course, in the Indigenous community the figures are just so much

Speaker: NA
Text: higher again. If time permits, I will reflect on that towards the end of my remarks.

Speaker: NA
Text: Governments, and particularly the national government, should be leading in this area and

Speaker: NA
Text: should be leading to address some of the statistics and some of the domestic violence which is

Speaker: NA
Text: occurring at way too high a rate. This government has been the most proactive federal

Speaker: NA
Text: government that has ever been in this place in addressing domestic violence. I mentioned at

Speaker: NA
Text: the outset that the very first decision of the Turnbull cabinet was a $100 million Women's

Speaker: NA
Text: Safety Package.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Burney interjecting-

Speaker: Mr TUDGE
Text: When you look at some of the issues that funding package went towards, it

Speaker: NA
Text: went towards very practical measures which are now being implemented, for example: $12

Speaker: NA
Text: million to trial with states the use of innovative technology to keep women safe; $5 million

Speaker: NA
Text: for safer technology, including working with telecommunications companies to distribute safe

Speaker: NA
Text: phones to women and with the eSafety Commissioner to develop a resource package about

Speaker: NA
Text: online safety for women; $17 million to keep women safe in their homes by expanding

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: successful initiatives like the Safer in the Home program to install CCTV cameras and other

Speaker: NA
Text: safety equipment; $5 million to expand the 1800RESPECT number, which the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Services referred to in question time; and a $2 million increase in funding for

Speaker: NA
Text: MensLine for tools and resources to support perpetrators not to reoffend.

Speaker: NA
Text: I could go on, but all the details of the $100 million package that was announced are now

Speaker: NA
Text: public.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the Prime Minister himself said a few weeks ago, that package is now having real,

Speaker: NA
Text: tangible results on the ground. He referred to a couple of things in his remarks when he was

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Queensland Premier at the COAG summit. He referred, for example, to the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: there are now 12 new specialist domestic violence units and five health justice partnerships

Speaker: NA
Text: which are now operational as a result of that funding. Those services are being delivered by

Speaker: NA
Text: community legal centres and legal aid commissions at locations across Australia. Since

Speaker: NA
Text: January of this year, 1,400 services have been provided to 535 women experiencing family

Speaker: NA
Text: violence-82 per cent of whom have one or more children-and it provides a very integrated

Speaker: NA
Text: case-management approach. The 1800RESPECT line has also had a significant take-up since

Speaker: NA
Text: the announcement. Since the additional funding has been introduced, over 80 per cent of calls

Speaker: NA
Text: are answered within 20 seconds, which is a very significant improvement. That has been a

Speaker: NA
Text: very good initiative which came out of that package.

Speaker: NA
Text: That package was informed very much by Rosie Batty and Ken Lay and the work they did

Speaker: NA
Text: to support that package being developed. I am a bit disappointed about some of the snide

Speaker: NA
Text: remarks coming across from the other side. Of all the issues that we deal with, surely this is

Speaker: NA
Text: one which should be above politics.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr TUDGE
Text: Just in recent times, we announced a further $100 million package, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: the Third Action Plan 2016-19, and that has a number of initiatives as well including: $20

Speaker: NA
Text: million allocated to prevention and early-intervention programs to break the cycle of domestic

Speaker: NA
Text: and family violence; and $15 million to improve and expand national, domestic and family-

Speaker: NA
Text: violence services, which includes the 1800RESPECT number and other initiatives. There has

Speaker: NA
Text: been a record amount of funding being put into domestic violence services from this

Speaker: NA
Text: government. It has also had the imprimatur of the Prime Minister-firstly of Tony Abbott and

Speaker: NA
Text: now of Malcolm Turnbull, who has made this a national issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr TUDGE
Text: I want to just briefly address perhaps the most important issue-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Coulton): Order! The minister just might resume his

Speaker: NA
Text: seat. I have had a request that, due to the serious nature of this MPI, we have some respect in

Speaker: NA
Text: the House, and I think that goes for both sides. I will have no more interjections or I will be

Speaker: NA
Text: evicting people.

Speaker: Mr TUDGE
Text: Above and beyond the services that we are funding, though, perhaps the

Speaker: NA
Text: most important part in really addressing domestic violence is changing attitudes, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: changing attitudes amongst men. This is a task which all men should be facing up to and

Speaker: NA
Text: reconsidering, but it is also a task on which the government can, in part, inform and lead. One

Speaker: NA
Text: of the things that we have done is allocate $30 million to a national campaign called 'Let's

Speaker: NA
Text: stop it at the start'. We are six months into this three-year campaign, and it is already having

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: some quite considerable results, which we are very pleased to see. For example, between

Speaker: NA
Text: April and June this year, the ad, which was put on YouTube, was the most watched

Speaker: NA
Text: advertisement on YouTube, with more than 36 million views. It has already influenced 67 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of all those who have seen these campaigns, and almost two-thirds of people have said

Speaker: NA
Text: they have taken action as a result of these campaigns.

Speaker: NA
Text: We can take action there, but we also need to take action in the local football clubs and in

Speaker: NA
Text: local communities, where all men can step up and say no in relation to disrespecting women

Speaker: NA
Text: because, ultimately, as the Prime Minister frequently says, violence often starts from

Speaker: NA
Text: disrespecting women in the first place. This campaign is about respecting women. All of us

Speaker: NA
Text: can make a difference, particularly the men in our society. We have a serious package, we are

Speaker: NA
Text: doing serious things in relation to this, but we need further work. I commend this motion.

Speaker: Ms HUSAR
Text: Lindsay) (15:39): Community leaders especially speak as advocates about

Speaker: NA
Text: domestic violence, but they rarely speak as victims. I would like to do something a little

Speaker: NA
Text: different today. In my first speech in this place, I said 29 out of my 36 years of life had been

Speaker: NA
Text: affected by domestic violence. I am a survivor of family violence, and it has taken me a long

Speaker: NA
Text: time to overcome the trauma of that and be where I am today. I know there are a lot of women

Speaker: NA
Text: out there, many of whom suffer in silence, and today I stand in solidarity with survivors and

Speaker: NA
Text: with those women who are afraid to speak. I will use my story, told in this place, to advocate

Speaker: NA
Text: for the change we need. I will use the prelude to White Ribbon Day, which is on this Friday,

Speaker: NA
Text: as an opportunity to shine a light into the darkest corner of my own life.

Speaker: NA
Text: The first 13 years of my life were marred by physical domestic violence committed

Speaker: NA
Text: towards my mother at the hands of my always-drunk-when-abusive father. My dad was the

Speaker: NA
Text: son of a World War II German soldier who committed many acts of violence against his own

Speaker: NA
Text: wife and against his seven children. My father had been raised in a home where violence was

Speaker: NA
Text: the accepted norm at a time when society said these things were private matters. Whilst the

Speaker: NA
Text: blows that landed on my mother during my childhood did not land on me physically, they

Speaker: NA
Text: might as well have. The trauma inflicted was the same. I recall it vividly-and in great detail.

Speaker: NA
Text: Each episode of this violence over my first 13 years was different, but the aftermath was

Speaker: NA
Text: always the same: dad would apologise and promise to be different, and that would work for

Speaker: NA
Text: just a short time.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the evening of another round of abuse, Dad launched the family dinner of that night at

Speaker: NA
Text: the wall. The stain remained on that wall for a very long time, but the stain in my heart would

Speaker: NA
Text: linger much longer. Mum then bundled my sister and me into the family car and we fled. We

Speaker: NA
Text: would go to the refuges in our community until, after so many years and so many incidents,

Speaker: NA
Text: my father knew the locations and we were not safe there anymore. We then shifted to staying

Speaker: NA
Text: in hotels, which were located above pubs, where the people below were loud, and sometimes

Speaker: NA
Text: their noise would spill into the streets, waking me and reminding me that I was not in my own

Speaker: NA
Text: bed or in my own home. I was in a foreign place because I was not safe in my home.

Speaker: NA
Text: One night, when Mum was hurrying to get my sister and me out, dad had removed and

Speaker: NA
Text: smashed the distributor cap from the car, rendering it useless and leaving us trapped. The

Speaker: NA
Text: police fetched us that time. I still remember sitting in the Penrith police station well into the

Speaker: NA
Text: early hours of the morning and the police officers giving us pink milk while we waited. The

Speaker: NA
Text: police did their best. Again, after this event, my mum returned home.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: We know many, many women return time and time again, even when their lives are

Speaker: NA
Text: massively disrupted, along with those of their children, and I hope that the blame that was

Speaker: NA
Text: launched at my Mum during the nineties for not leaving is no longer part of the 'solution'

Speaker: NA
Text: around domestic violence and that the question of 'why doesn't she just leave' quits being

Speaker: NA
Text: asked. Eventually, though, the courage rises up, services step up and women stand up, finally

Speaker: NA
Text: leaving-but not before one last terrible incident. There were 13 police cars the last time

Speaker: NA
Text: physical violence affected my childhood. But this was the end of the physical violence once

Speaker: NA
Text: and for all. Whilst the physical part ceased, other abuse around finance and control ramped

Speaker: NA
Text: right up. Sadly, the wheel of domestic violence continues to affect my life as a grown woman

Speaker: NA
Text: with children of my own. The last 16 years of my life have been and continue to be affected

Speaker: NA
Text: by domestic and family violence.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the limited time I have left, I would like to take this opportunity to thank opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: leader Bill Shorten for his continued support of my personal situation, his understanding and

Speaker: NA
Text: the support he provides to me. I would like to thank my caucus colleagues and our staff who

Speaker: NA
Text: know my story yet do not judge me and continue to provide support. I would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledge the Penrith Women's Health Centre, who have been providing services to my

Speaker: NA
Text: community for 30 years, including to my mum then and to my own family now.

Speaker: NA
Text: In my experience I have found that victims mostly do not talk about domestic violence

Speaker: NA
Text: because other people do not talk about domestic violence. For many years I was embarrassed

Speaker: NA
Text: and I was ashamed. I know that I should not have been but I was. I hope that today I have lent

Speaker: NA
Text: my voice, my story and my passion for advocating for change to the choir of the white ribbon

Speaker: NA
Text: movement to stand up, to speak out and to act. Thank you.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr LLEW O'BRIEN (Wide Bay) (15:45): Before I go on, I would like to acknowledge

Speaker: NA
Text: the very difficult speech just given by the member for Lindsay. It is certainly a display of how

Speaker: NA
Text: domestic violence affects the people who are involved in it, and those around them.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a very serious matter and, yes, there is a need to address family violence as a

Speaker: NA
Text: national priority, absolutely. We need to have a coordinated approach to address it, we need

Speaker: NA
Text: the appropriate responses to acts of domestic violence and we need the appropriate education

Speaker: NA
Text: to prevent domestic violence. We need to have, as a society, a better understanding of

Speaker: NA
Text: domestic violence. If we are going to tackle this issue at a community and social level, we all

Speaker: NA
Text: need to understand what domestic violence is. With domestic violence, what first comes to

Speaker: NA
Text: mind is a very violent attack by a man on his partner in the family. That is a tragedy, and it is

Speaker: NA
Text: what we need to identify as the most significant and important area of domestic violence that

Speaker: NA
Text: we need to address. But we also need to understand that domestic violence has a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: different levels and, as the Prime Minister said earlier, that domestic violence always starts

Speaker: NA
Text: with disrespect.

Speaker: NA
Text: Domestic violence also shows its ugly head in control, when the abuser starts to control the

Speaker: NA
Text: victim through any number of different methods-whether it is controlling their social

Speaker: NA
Text: environment, who they are allowed to see or the clothes they are allowed to wear. It really is a

Speaker: NA
Text: terrible, terrible situation to be in, and it spans all cultures and sociodemographic areas-

Speaker: NA
Text: unfortunately, it is particularly prevalent in Indigenous communities. The problem focuses on

Speaker: NA
Text: women, and it should be, because women are predominantly the victims. But an area that I

Speaker: NA
Text: probably recognise, in some ways, more than most is that women can also be offenders when

Speaker: NA
Text: it comes to family violence, and men can be victims.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: When I first became a police officer, there was a change to the law that added same-sex

Speaker: NA
Text: couples to the area of family violence. I think we always need to recognise that the family has

Speaker: NA
Text: changed over many years, and that a victim of family violence in a same-sex couple suffers in

Speaker: NA
Text: the same way as a victim in a hetrosexual relationship. We need to respond, and we always

Speaker: NA
Text: need to recognise that. It is something that I have seen over and over again, and it is an area of

Speaker: NA
Text: the community that is often forgotten.

Speaker: NA
Text: When it comes to education, as parents we need to let our sons know that only cowards

Speaker: NA
Text: beat women. Only cowards commit those acts that destroy families. And, as a father, I want

Speaker: NA
Text: my daughter to know that she does not have to put up with it. As the member for Lindsay said

Speaker: NA
Text: before, quite often women go back, and it is such a complex area. It is so devastating when

Speaker: NA
Text: people look at women who continue to return to violent relationships and they just do not

Speaker: NA
Text: understand the control that their abuser has over them. We need to educate our daughters that

Speaker: NA
Text: they should never put up with being the victim of abuse.

Speaker: NA
Text: The coalition is acting with regard to family violence. We have implemented quite a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of plans, including the action plan that sets out 36 practical actions under six priority

Speaker: NA
Text: areas. We are doing the work on family violence. Family violence is something that, as a

Speaker: NA
Text: society, we should never put up with. It is one of the motivating factors that sees me here as a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of parliament, and I am proud to be part of a government that is addressing this issue.

Speaker: Mr GOSLING
Text: Solomon) (15:50): I stand to speak about family violence and White

Speaker: NA
Text: Ribbon Day, which is marked this Friday, as is the International Day for Elimination of

Speaker: NA
Text: Violence against Women. I want to acknowledge my friend, the member for Lindsay, and all

Speaker: NA
Text: of the speakers. I was proud to attend the White Ribbon breakfast here in Parliament House

Speaker: NA
Text: this morning. I want to acknowledge all of those whose lives have been affected by the

Speaker: NA
Text: scourge of family violence and I want to acknowledge all of those who are working to make

Speaker: NA
Text: things better.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will touch on the Northern Territory's situation and, hopefully, will give some good

Speaker: NA
Text: examples. I am proud to be a member of a party that is proposing concrete practical steps to

Speaker: NA
Text: address family violence in our communities. While I am not taking anything away from what

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister had to say this morning, I am proud of the initiatives that our leader has

Speaker: NA
Text: highlighted, including the issue of family violence leave, the initiatives around revenge porn

Speaker: NA
Text: and also how we can change how our courts run so that victims of family violence are not

Speaker: NA
Text: then taken through another process of unnecessary trauma.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the reasons that I welcome our leader's approach is because of the impact of family

Speaker: NA
Text: violence on the people of Darwin and Palmerston-my electorate. The overall effect of family

Speaker: NA
Text: violence in the Northern Territory is substantial.

Speaker: NA
Text: For example, we have by far the highest rate of homicide offences related to family

Speaker: NA
Text: violence in the country. In the last three years, there have been 75,000 incidents of family

Speaker: NA
Text: violence in the Northern Territory-out of a population of 244,000. At least one child is

Speaker: NA
Text: subjected to family violence in the NT every day; 44 per cent of family violence orders were

Speaker: NA
Text: breached, and 44 per cent of family violence offenders were repeat offenders. Rates of

Speaker: NA
Text: assaults related to family violence were more than four times higher in the NT than in any

Speaker: NA
Text: other Australian state or territory. These are obviously not stats to be proud of, and we are

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly not proud of them in the Northern Territory. But we look at them in the cold light of

Speaker: NA
Text: day and commit ourselves to making things better. There is a long way to go.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: One thing that we are very proud of is that there are volunteers working both in the

Speaker: NA
Text: protection space and in the legal space-with the refuges. But there are also people, strong

Speaker: NA
Text: men, working with other men in men's groups to encourage them to be the agents for change

Speaker: NA
Text: in their communities. One such organisation is the 'No More' campaign, which is headed by

Speaker: NA
Text: local Aboriginal leader, Charlie King. He is an inspirational man. He is widely known for his

Speaker: NA
Text: role as an ABC sports broadcaster, but he has also tirelessly dedicated himself to this No

Speaker: NA
Text: More campaign.

Speaker: NA
Text: The campaign started in 2006. It followed a large meeting of Indigenous men from right

Speaker: NA
Text: across the Northern Territory. I stress that, obviously, family violence is not just an issue to

Speaker: NA
Text: do with Indigenous men-but Charlie King has seen the need and called together people from

Speaker: NA
Text: 37 different locations throughout the Northern Territory. They came together and made a

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment that they were going to work to make sure that there was no more family

Speaker: NA
Text: violence. They have been working on that for some time, and I am very proud to say that

Speaker: NA
Text: Charlie King will be coming here to Canberra next week and will be bringing some

Speaker: NA
Text: countrymen with him, and they will be talking about the initiatives that they have committed

Speaker: NA
Text: to.

Speaker: NA
Text: When we address family violence on a national scale, it is important that we support

Speaker: NA
Text: groups that are tackling family violence on the local level. We need to make sure that

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations that are working with people caught up in family violence are properly funded. I

Speaker: NA
Text: want to acknowledge all of those people who work in the refuges and the legal services of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Northern Territory. Keep doing your work. It is absolutely essential. And I want to say well

Speaker: NA
Text: done to Charlie King and I look forward to seeing him here next week.

Speaker: Ms LANDRY
Text: Capricornia-Deputy Nationals Whip) (15:55): I thank the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: raising the issue of domestic violence. I agree with the sentiments that family violence should

Speaker: NA
Text: be a national priority-and indeed it is. As I have said before, there are few places in

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland that witness higher rates of domestic violence than my electorate of Capricornia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Capricornia police district reports the highest rate of domestic violence in Queensland.

Speaker: NA
Text: While the statistics are marginally improving, according to Rockhampton police the rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: domestic violence attacks here is 141 per cent higher than the state average.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last year, to assist families in trauma caught up in the cycle of domestic violence and other

Speaker: NA
Text: Family Court matters, the Turnbull-Joyce government took a bold and positive step to appoint

Speaker: NA
Text: a permanent Federal Court Circuit judge to be based in Rockhampton. Judge Anne Demack

Speaker: NA
Text: held her first sitting on 7 March, presided over by the Chief Judge of the Federal Circuit

Speaker: NA
Text: Court, his Honour Judge John Pascoe.

Speaker: NA
Text: I lobbied hard for the Commonwealth Attorney-General to make this appointment, in a city

Speaker: NA
Text: where family violence is out of control. This appointment was both supported and hailed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Central Queensland Law Association as the most significant decision for the legal

Speaker: NA
Text: industry in Capricornia in over 40 years. It directly helps some of the most disadvantaged

Speaker: NA
Text: families that are caught up in the cycle of domestic violence, and subsequent custody and

Speaker: NA
Text: family law disputes.

Speaker: NA
Text: The new permanent Federal Court Circuit judge services all of Central Queensland,

Speaker: NA
Text: including Rockhampton, Mackay, Gladstone and Emerald. But, to my surprise, this was

Speaker: NA
Text: criticised by the state Labor government. Queensland's state Labor Attorney-General, Yvette

Speaker: NA
Text: D'Ath, and the federal opposition's shadow Attorney-General, the member for Isaacs, both

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: denigrated the appointment of a new federal judge in Rockhampton. They were more

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned about bricks and mortar than the safety and survival of victims and the improved

Speaker: NA
Text: and more timely access to a Family Court judge in a regional area with the worst record for

Speaker: NA
Text: family violence.

Speaker: NA
Text: An article dated 17 February this year in the Queensland Times reports:

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland Attorney-General Yvette D'Ath has accused her federal counterpart, Senator George

Speaker: NA
Text: Brandis, of incorrectly referring to a Rockhampton courtroom as vacant and refusing to contact her

Speaker: NA
Text: about courthouse arrangements for the judge, Anne Demack.

Speaker: NA
Text: "There is no vacant courtroom," she told Queensland Parliament …

Speaker: NA
Text: That was a load of rubbish. In the same article, it was reported:

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal Circuit Court of Australia chief Richard Foster told the committee he wrote to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland Justice Department's Deputy Director-General and to Ms D'Ath.

Speaker: NA
Text: "I received a response on 7 January saying, 'services are limited but basically we do have some

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity; …

Speaker: NA
Text: "Now that (Sen Brandis) has made the announcement … we can accommodate it."

Speaker: NA
Text: So there was room at the inn after all-albeit be it with renovations, which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth was happy to pay for.

Speaker: NA
Text: In February, the Brisbane Times reported Queensland's Attorney-General as saying Judge

Speaker: NA
Text: Demack's appointment was 'an empty gesture to serve a cynical political purpose'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Well, today, on the topic that domestic violence needs to be a national priority, can the

Speaker: NA
Text: member of Isaacs please explain what on earth his state counterpart means and why he too

Speaker: NA
Text: objected to the appointment? The Liberal-National coalition is standing up for the most

Speaker: NA
Text: vulnerable in our community, an area hit by the highest domestic violence rates in the state,

Speaker: NA
Text: while the Labor Party say appointing a permanent judge to Rockhampton is cynical. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: just rubbish. Do they want these families to travel to Brisbane and wait years for a chance to

Speaker: NA
Text: front a judge to arbitrate family disputes and violence? In the so-called Labor heartland that is

Speaker: NA
Text: Rockhampton city, the Labor Party has failed the most vulnerable families at a time when

Speaker: NA
Text: they most need faster access to the Federal Court.

Speaker: NA
Text: The positive steps the government are taking include the recent announcement at the

Speaker: NA
Text: COAG summit that we would commit $100 million to Commonwealth initiatives under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Action Plan, including $20 million for preventative strategies and cultural change; $15

Speaker: NA
Text: million for front-line services like housing and financial support; $10 million to prevent forms

Speaker: NA
Text: of sexual violence, including nonconsensual sharing of intimate images; $25 million to

Speaker: NA
Text: address family violence in Indigenous communities; and $30 million for front-line family

Speaker: NA
Text: violence legal services.

Speaker: Dr FREELANDER
Text: Macarthur) (16:00): I am pleased to rise to support the motion moved

Speaker: NA
Text: by the member for Griffith. For most of my career I have had mainly positive interaction with

Speaker: NA
Text: families. However, there has always been some exposure to family violence. Having worked

Speaker: NA
Text: on call at my local hospital with a busy paediatric and maternity unit, I have seen some bad

Speaker: NA
Text: things that have been etched in my memory.

Speaker: NA
Text: I remember two twins-one of whom died; the other survived with severe cerebral palsy-

Speaker: NA
Text: who at eight weeks of age had their skulls smashed so severely that when I resuscitated them

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: it felt like their heads were the smashed shell of a boiled egg. I remember the child shaken

Speaker: NA
Text: and bashed so severely at the age of three that she never saw, walked or talked again. I

Speaker: NA
Text: remember the two-year-old boy who was so severely punched that his liver was described as

Speaker: NA
Text: looking like red jelly at autopsy. I remember the six-year-old girl who was starved to death in

Speaker: NA
Text: her own home. I remember the mother made hemiplegic and unable to care for her children

Speaker: NA
Text: following an attack by her partner. So these are real things, and they have been real things to

Speaker: NA
Text: me in my career.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know that there is a strong correlation with violence against children and violence

Speaker: NA
Text: against women. Some of the women I have seen with their children have been murdered by

Speaker: NA
Text: their partners. I know that there is more that we could do. Firstly, let me say that I abhor the

Speaker: NA
Text: phrase 'domestic violence'. It implies a somewhat benign event. This is not a benign event.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nothing could be further from the truth, as I have seen. Secondly, I do know that all of us in

Speaker: NA
Text: this parliament abhor violence in families, and we are at one in wanting to deal with it.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think it is a great thing that men are taking responsibility for crimes that are

Speaker: NA
Text: predominantly perpetrated by men. We must also educate our young people, especially those

Speaker: NA
Text: exposed to family violence, about its causes and about prevention strategies. Most of all, we

Speaker: NA
Text: need to fund legal support and access to housing for those women and children fleeing violent

Speaker: NA
Text: households. Domestic violence is pernicious and it is evil. We have done a little better of late

Speaker: NA
Text: with recognising the evil, even though for many that recognition has come too late.

Speaker: NA
Text: Violence in the home is seen, properly, as a national problem, but it needs to be dealt with

Speaker: NA
Text: at all levels of government. We do now have a national plan and a national approach which,

Speaker: NA
Text: in the broad, has widespread support not just amongst law-makers but also in the community.

Speaker: NA
Text: We should also have a national registry of perpetrators of family violence. For example, when

Speaker: NA
Text: the ACT government recently imposed-and in an election year-a flat rate of $30 per

Speaker: NA
Text: household for a Safer Families Levy to address the consequences of family violence there was

Speaker: NA
Text: barely a ripple of disapproval. And that is a good thing.

Speaker: NA
Text: But it is the pernicious side to violence and its pervasive effect on families and on children

Speaker: NA
Text: that make it so hard to contemplate, to explain and to address. Good intentions are not

Speaker: NA
Text: enough. The job of governing extends beyond just passing laws and saying the right things at

Speaker: NA
Text: the right time, or even appropriating the necessary funding. It involves ensuring that what we

Speaker: NA
Text: do actually works. Governments especially need to ensure that the left hand knows what the

Speaker: NA
Text: right hand is doing. And we need to be more open about our approach to family violence.

Speaker: NA
Text: Stripping community legal services of over a third of their funding makes no sense if you are

Speaker: NA
Text: genuine about addressing family violence and providing support and protection to those who

Speaker: NA
Text: most need it.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the few free services that provide comprehensive assistance for women and families

Speaker: NA
Text: escaping family violence are Community Legal Centres. The Macarthur Legal Centre in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate includes a Women's Domestic Violence Court Advocacy Service. That centre and

Speaker: NA
Text: those like it provide information, referrals, advocacy and support for women and children

Speaker: NA
Text: when they most need it. They help with the housing department, Centrelink and police

Speaker: NA
Text: referrals. That is as you would expect. Let's give the people doing the job, and who have been

Speaker: NA
Text: doing it for many, many years, the appropriate resources and the help that they deserve and

Speaker: NA
Text: need. I have seen many good people try their best to make life better for those traumatised and

Speaker: NA
Text: trapped by the fear and the physical reality of violence in the home.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: We have finally realised that this is not an isolated or localised problem; it is more akin to a

Speaker: NA
Text: national emergency. There is impetus for meaningful change right across our country and

Speaker: NA
Text: across our parliament. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs WICKS (Robertson) (16:05): I also welcome this opportunity to speak on this matter

Speaker: NA
Text: of public importance moved by the member for Griffith. If there ever was a matter of public

Speaker: NA
Text: importance, this surely would be it. Domestic and family violence is about more the what is

Speaker: NA
Text: spoken about in this place and in these corridors; it is also about shifting the culture across our

Speaker: NA
Text: nation. I want to commend all speakers in this very important debate, particularly the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Lindsay. I thank the member for Lindsay for her courage in speaking out. I certainly hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that that will encourage more people to also speak out and, in doing so, help us shift the

Speaker: NA
Text: culture across the nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the Prime Minister said in his address to this morning's White Ribbon breakfast, what

Speaker: NA
Text: we are talking about today is a matter of respect.

Speaker: NA
Text: Disrespecting women does not always result in violence against women. But all violence against

Speaker: NA
Text: women begins with disrespecting women.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is backed up by the national statistics, which are shocking. One in three women have

Speaker: NA
Text: been a victim of physical or sexual violence since the age of 15 by someone known to them.

Speaker: NA
Text: One in four women have been emotionally abused by a partner, and one woman dies almost

Speaker: NA
Text: every week at the hand of a current or former partner.

Speaker: NA
Text: When I spoke earlier today with Brisbane Water Local Area Command Superintendent

Speaker: NA
Text: Danny Sullivan it became clear that these statistics are just as true in my electorate of

Speaker: NA
Text: Robertson, where, on average, every two hours a police vehicle will respond to a domestic

Speaker: NA
Text: violence call on the Central Coast-not every two weeks, not every two days, but every two

Speaker: NA
Text: hours. That is why I helped to facilitate a local domestic violence committee in my electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: with local community leaders and local experts meeting together to discuss grassroots

Speaker: NA
Text: solutions and to also help start a conversation with more families, teachers, young people and

Speaker: NA
Text: schools, in particular. Slowly, I believe that we can see a change in the conversation on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Central Coast and across our nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: We can see this in one simple but breathtaking local visual statement, where Brisbane

Speaker: NA
Text: Water Local Area Command has overseen an extraordinary community push to plant white

Speaker: NA
Text: poppies on the grass at The Skillion at Terrigal this year. Similar to a sea of red poppies

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier this year as we commemorated Anzac Day, these white poppies honour the thousands

Speaker: NA
Text: of victims of domestic and family violence. I am told that volunteers worked for hundreds of

Speaker: NA
Text: hours to hand-make 55,000 poppies that were placed there on Monday in the shape of a

Speaker: NA
Text: ribbon. Terrigal provides a stunning backdrop to the display, a display which was three years

Speaker: NA
Text: in the making. Our local police partnered with women's empowerment and advocacy group

Speaker: NA
Text: Zonta to help make the display a reality, and I am advised that the Central Coast Council also

Speaker: NA
Text: contributed $6,000 for the materials. We even had local businesses lending a helping hand,

Speaker: NA
Text: with Burson Auto Parts at Gosford donating screwdrivers at short notice after volunteers

Speaker: NA
Text: arrived to discover that the ground was too hard for the wooden poppy stems. School students

Speaker: NA
Text: walking past have been dropping in to help out and the local newspaper, the Express

Speaker: NA
Text: Advocate, has done an excellent job in promoting this initiative. I commend Superintendent

Speaker: NA
Text: Sullivan and his team, including Gillian Mitchell, Tim Jeffrey, Jessica Bradbury, Nick Carroll

Speaker: NA
Text: and Peter Watson. These are our local men and women on the front line, who do an

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: outstanding job. I look forward to meeting them on Sunday and encourage our community to

Speaker: NA
Text: join us as we walk up the Terrigal Skillion to make a statement in condemning the actions of

Speaker: NA
Text: those who commit domestic violence.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also take this opportunity to commend the Turnbull government on its announcement

Speaker: NA
Text: today of the new eSafety Commissioner, Julie Inman Grant. The commissioner will have a

Speaker: NA
Text: strong focus on online safety and the issue of non-consensual sharing of intimate images,

Speaker: NA
Text: often described as revenge porn. She has a big task ahead, but I am pleased to see that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Turnbull government will conduct a public consultation process on proposed civil penalties in

Speaker: NA
Text: this area, targeted at both the perpetrators and those sites which host intimate images and

Speaker: NA
Text: videos shared without consent.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is much more that this government is doing too, including a $30 million national

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign called Stop it at the Start to change young people's attitudes to women and violence,

Speaker: NA
Text: in partnership, of course, with our states and territories. We have also launched the third

Speaker: NA
Text: action plan, with an additional $100 million investment. This complements the existing work

Speaker: NA
Text: of states and territories around Australia, including in New South Wales, where video is now

Speaker: NA
Text: collected by police when attending a domestic violence incident which is then able to be

Speaker: NA
Text: submitted to court as evidence. I understand from Superintendent Danny Sullivan that our

Speaker: NA
Text: local police command is leading the state in taking advantage of this initiative. Finally, we

Speaker: NA
Text: have the $100 million Women's Safety Package, which includes expanding the

Speaker: NA
Text: 1800RESPECT frontline services, drastically reducing wait times. I commend the government

Speaker: NA
Text: on its strong leadership and approach to this most important of issues and encourage all of us

Speaker: NA
Text: here to continue to promote the need for leadership in standing up against domestic and

Speaker: NA
Text: family violence.

Speaker: Ms STANLEY
Text: Werriwa) (16:10): I rise to speak on this matter of public importance,

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledging that this Friday we observe White Ribbon Day and the International Day for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Elimination of Violence against Women. Moreover, I acknowledge the courage of the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Lindsay, who by telling her story today in this place vividly illustrates why we

Speaker: NA
Text: must eliminate all violence against women and children. The deepest scars from family

Speaker: NA
Text: violence are often invisible and stay with victims for life. It creates a deep and long-term

Speaker: NA
Text: harm, not only to them but to those around them, that can engulf whole families, especially

Speaker: NA
Text: the children. To feel that you are trapped, with no recourse, no way to act and nowhere to go,

Speaker: NA
Text: is suffocating and further isolating in itself. The statistics are stark and confronting too. While

Speaker: NA
Text: one instance of family violence is one too many, to hear that one in four women has

Speaker: NA
Text: experienced physical or sexual violence at the hands of an intimate partner is appalling, and

Speaker: NA
Text: yet it is known that many more incidents of domestic violence go unreported.

Speaker: NA
Text: When something as harmful and damaging as this continues to be so common, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: incumbent on us in this place to act. I am proud to be part of a party that champions women

Speaker: NA
Text: and the contribution that they make to our communities, our workplaces and our homes. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: also proud of the commitments that were announced by the member for Maribyrnong this

Speaker: NA
Text: morning, commitments that go beyond simply acknowledging that the status quo is not good

Speaker: NA
Text: enough and instead propose strong practical actions that seek to improve the protection for

Speaker: NA
Text: victims and witnesses of family violence. The reforms that Labor has proposed would compel

Speaker: NA
Text: a judge to consider whether a vulnerable witness should be protected in cases where domestic

Speaker: NA
Text: violence is alleged. This would mean that, where a judge believes the mechanisms available

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: to him or her under the Family Law Act are insufficient to protect such vulnerable witnesses,

Speaker: NA
Text: the judge will be empowered to direct that all unrepresented litigants in the matter be

Speaker: NA
Text: represented by legal aid. This means that vulnerable children and women will not have to

Speaker: NA
Text: suffer cross-examination by their perpetrators. Not only is this a practical reform advocated

Speaker: NA
Text: by many non-government organisations and the Productivity Commission's Access to justice

Speaker: NA
Text: report; it is most importantly a reform that will mean that victims are not further harmed.

Speaker: NA
Text: The cuts to frontline community legal services continue to be of great concern in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate. Reducing the funding of these services by 30 per cent means that fewer women can

Speaker: NA
Text: access the legal support services they need when they are in crisis. On top of that, the

Speaker: NA
Text: uncertainty of the funding beyond 2017 for the national partnership agreement means that

Speaker: NA
Text: there will be fewer opportunities for those fleeing domestic violence to find somewhere to

Speaker: NA
Text: stay. In fact, the New South Wales Liberal government's reduction in funding for those

Speaker: NA
Text: refuges has meant that there have been refuges closed which were operating for 30 years and

Speaker: NA
Text: doing a fine job. We owe it to every family affected. We need to do more, we can do more to

Speaker: NA
Text: address this and we should just do it.

Speaker: Mr ALEXANDER
Text: Bennelong) (16:13): I would like to thank the member for Griffith for

Speaker: NA
Text: raising this matter today. This is one of the most pressing issues facing Australia and I am

Speaker: NA
Text: proud of this government's and, equally, Labor's records on the issue of domestic violence.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Friday is White Ribbon Day. We have already discussed this in the Federation Chamber

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier this week. I had the honour to speak on the topic and I would again like to thank the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Gellibrand for raising it, but it is so important that I have no issue repeating

Speaker: NA
Text: myself in this chamber.

Speaker: NA
Text: White Ribbon Day is a day to honour and recognise the suffering of victims of domestic

Speaker: NA
Text: violence and reaffirm our commitment to ending domestic violence in Australia. I am very

Speaker: NA
Text: proud to be a White Ribbon ambassador. On Monday I restated my oath: 'I pledge never to

Speaker: NA
Text: commit, condone or remain silent about violence against women.' These simple words are a

Speaker: NA
Text: prescription for a safer life and a better society. This oath should stop violence in its tracks

Speaker: NA
Text: but, sadly, as we know, words and intentions are not enough. That is why I am proud of the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's record on domestic violence.

Speaker: NA
Text: Domestic violence has been at the forefront of the coalition's agenda since we came to

Speaker: NA
Text: office in 2013, and we have built momentum around the issue. The first act of the Turnbull

Speaker: NA
Text: government was to announce a $100 million Women's Safety Package, which focused on

Speaker: NA
Text: practical, immediate action to keep women and children safe as well as improving training for

Speaker: NA
Text: frontline workers. One massive success that is saving lives includes expansion of the

Speaker: NA
Text: 1800RESPECT frontline service. Our new model for telephone counselling has reduced the

Speaker: NA
Text: average call wait time for victims of domestic violence from 10 minutes to just 35 seconds-

Speaker: NA
Text: and I agree with the member for Griffith: women should be manning these phones.

Speaker: NA
Text: We also launched the evocative Stop it at the Start campaign, which dominated water

Speaker: NA
Text: cooler conversations earlier this year. The ad has been viewed 36 million times, and 67 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of all influences-parents, family members, teachers, coaches and employers-have seen

Speaker: NA
Text: the campaign and, of those, 68 per cent have taken action. Essentially, almost half of all

Speaker: NA
Text: influences have seen the campaign, absorbed its message and done something in response to

Speaker: NA
Text: it, including reconsidering the way they behave towards others and talking with a young

Speaker: NA
Text: person about respect in relationships.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Just last month, the government co-hosted the COAG National Summit on Reducing

Speaker: NA
Text: Violence against Women and their Children. The summit brought together first ministers,

Speaker: NA
Text: women's safety ministers as well as academics and experts in domestic and family violence,

Speaker: NA
Text: and leaders in business and the not-for-profit sector to review progress and highlight best

Speaker: NA
Text: practices in efforts to reduce violence. At the summit, COAG launched the Third Action Plan

Speaker: NA
Text: of the National Plan to Reduce Violence against Women and their Children 2010 to 2022.

Speaker: NA
Text: This includes a $100 million commitment for preventative strategies and cultural change, for

Speaker: NA
Text: frontline services like housing and financial support, to prevent forms of sexual violence, to

Speaker: NA
Text: address family violence in Indigenous communities and $30 million for frontline family

Speaker: NA
Text: violence legal services. These funds and initiatives represent a big commitment from the

Speaker: NA
Text: government to ending the scourge of domestic violence. I, with everyone involved in their

Speaker: NA
Text: implementation, wish success, and I hope that together we can make a difference. As the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister said earlier this morning, 'There is still so much more to do. We can't be

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfied while even one person is in danger.'

Speaker: NA
Text: Violence against a partner is never excusable. No matter how tense relationships may get,

Speaker: NA
Text: violence is never the answer, and victims of abuse must know that it is never their fault. I say

Speaker: NA
Text: to all men: the most masculine and the most manly thing you can do is always respect your

Speaker: NA
Text: partner. Today marks the day to make these statements, but that respect must be respected

Speaker: NA
Text: every day of the year.

Speaker: NA
Text: I congratulate, respect and admire the member for Lindsay's contribution. Her contribution

Speaker: NA
Text: reminds us of the words said previously in this place, 'Courage and heroism do not always

Speaker: NA
Text: wear a uniform and carry a rifle.'

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Coulton): This discussion has concluded.

Speaker: NA
Text: BILLS

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasury Laws Amendment (Fair and Sustainable Superannuation) Bill 2016

Speaker: NA
Text: Superannuation (Excess Transfer Balance Tax) Imposition Bill 2016

Speaker: NA
Text: Returned from Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: Message received from the Senate returning the bills without amendment or request.

Speaker: NA
Text: COMMITTEES

Speaker: NA
Text: Joint Standing Committee on Treaties

Speaker: NA
Text: Report

Speaker: Mr ROBERT
Text: Fadden) (16:19): On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties, I

Speaker: NA
Text: present the following reports: Report 164 Air Services-Kuwait, Air Services-Bahrain and

Speaker: NA
Text: Report 166 Implementation Procedures for Airworthiness-USA; Convention on Choice of

Speaker: NA
Text: Courts-accession; GATT Schedule of Concessions-amendment; Radio Regulations-partial

Speaker: NA
Text: revision.

Speaker: NA
Text: Report made a parliamentary paper in accordance with standing order 39(e).

Speaker: Mr ROBERT
Text: by leave-I present the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties reports 164

Speaker: NA
Text: and 166, which contain the committee's review of six treaty actions. Four had been tabled in

Speaker: NA
Text: the 44th Parliament. Then the inquiries lapsed when parliament was dissolved. These treaties

Speaker: NA
Text: were subsequently referred to the committee at the beginning of the 45th Parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: There are also two air service agreements in Report 164. The first is with Kuwait and

Speaker: NA
Text: follows the standard Australian model air service agreement and is expected to facilitate

Speaker: NA
Text: further trade and tourism between our two countries. The second is a protocol to amend the

Speaker: NA
Text: current air service agreement with Bahrain and provide far more liberal route rights and tariff

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions for both countries. It also changes reference from the 'State of Bahrain' to the

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Kingdom of Bahrain'. The committee has recommended that both air service agreements be

Speaker: NA
Text: ratified.

Speaker: NA
Text: Turning to Report 166, the Implementation Procedures for Airworthiness with the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States of America will enable Australian manufacturers to gain access to the US aviation

Speaker: NA
Text: market, which, as we know, is one of the largest in the world. It will certainly encourage

Speaker: NA
Text: innovators to invest in new technologies and, especially, modification and modernisation of

Speaker: NA
Text: old aircraft.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Convention on Choice of Court Agreements sets out how courts will treat jurisdiction

Speaker: NA
Text: clauses in private contracts. In these clauses, the contracting parties agree in which court

Speaker: NA
Text: system they will resolve any disputes. Australia's accession to the convention will provide

Speaker: NA
Text: greater clarity and certainty in this area, especially for those seeking private agreements

Speaker: NA
Text: across borders.

Speaker: NA
Text: Further, the amendments to Australia's Schedule of Concessions in the General Agreement

Speaker: NA
Text: on Tariffs and Trade, which we all know as GATT, will remove tariffs on a range of

Speaker: NA
Text: technology products and eliminate agricultural export subsidies. The committee

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledges the significance of these two ministerial decisions. We note that both will

Speaker: NA
Text: provide incremental improvements for Australian consumers and farmers, which is not only

Speaker: NA
