Text: good for those on the land. However, further work always needs to be done to reduce

Speaker: NA
Text: domestic subsidies and non-tariff barriers, if more progress is to be made on liberalising

Speaker: NA
Text: global trade.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, the partial revision of the Radio Regulations updates the international use of the

Speaker: NA
Text: radio frequency spectrum, including the allocation of spectrum to radio communication

Speaker: NA
Text: services. These regulations ensure the rational, efficient and equitable use of this global

Speaker: NA
Text: resource called a spectrum. The revisions will improve a wide range of areas including:

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions for the growing demand for mobile broadband services; improving aeronautical

Speaker: NA
Text: communications capabilities; and provisions to improve radar for collision avoidance and

Speaker: NA
Text: driver-warning systems. Acceptance of the revisions will allow Australia to align itself with

Speaker: NA
Text: the rest of the world in its regulation of the radio-frequency spectrum.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee recommends that binding treaty action be taken for all of the treaty actions

Speaker: NA
Text: in the report. On behalf of the committee, I commend these reports to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: BILLS

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Jobs Path: Prepare, Trial, Hire)

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill 2016

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Consideration resumed of the motion:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: to which the following amendment was moved:

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: That all the words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

Speaker: NA
Text: "Whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House notes that the Turnbull

Speaker: NA
Text: Government cannot guarantee that, under Youth Jobs PaTH (Prepare, Trial, Hire):

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) jobs will not be displaced by cheaper labour;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) wages will not be undercut and some participants will be paid below minimum award wages;

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) participants' safety will not be compromised and that adequate insurance arrangements will be

Speaker: NA
Text: provided;

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) participants won't be used to help businesses sidestep unfair dismissal protections; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) it will prioritise using small to medium enterprises in PaTH because they have a demonstrated

Speaker: NA
Text: track record of employing more job seekers through the jobactive programme".

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr CRAIG KELLY (Hughes) (16:23): It is a privilege to have the opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: continue my comments on the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Jobs Path:

Speaker: NA
Text: Prepare, Trial, Hire) Bill 2016. I actually was not going to speak on this bill but I heard the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Lalor talk about the movie The Pursuit of Happyness. It is actually a true story

Speaker: NA
Text: based on an American gentleman named Chris Gardner. He was born in 1954 to an

Speaker: NA
Text: underprivileged background. His childhood was racked with poverty, domestic violence,

Speaker: NA
Text: alcoholism and family illiteracy. In his late 20s he found himself in jail. Coming out of jail

Speaker: NA
Text: with no experience, no college education, no degree and no connections, he took on an

Speaker: NA
Text: internship, which is what this legislation is all about. He took on an internship at a

Speaker: NA
Text: stockbroking firm to learn the ropes. He realised that with that background, without having an

Speaker: NA
Text: education, he had to strive harder, work harder and work smarter. He had to use his time as

Speaker: NA
Text: best he could. They say he was the first to arrive at work and the last to leave, even though he

Speaker: NA
Text: was unpaid on an internship.

Speaker: NA
Text: Eventually, he got a job. He then went on to work for another broking firm and then took

Speaker: NA
Text: the risk of breaking out on his own. With $10,000 in capital and the only piece of furniture

Speaker: NA
Text: being a single desk, he started up his own broking firm, called Gardner Rich. The rest is

Speaker: NA
Text: history. He went on to have a net worth today of over $60 million. He made his first million

Speaker: NA
Text: dollars by the age of 34 and, to celebrate, he bought himself a black Ferrari previously owned

Speaker: NA
Text: by Michael Jordan.

Speaker: NA
Text: He owns a multimillion dollar apartment in Chicago's Trump Tower, and President-elect

Speaker: NA
Text: Trump has said of Chris Gardner that his story is a tremendous lesson in tenacity. He has also

Speaker: NA
Text: recently written a book titled Start Where You Are: Life Lessons in Getting from Where You

Speaker: NA
Text: Are to Where You Want to Be. One of the chapters is 'Learn the ropes first, then conquer

Speaker: NA
Text: Rome'. The story of the movie The Pursuit of Happyness, the true life story of Chris Gardner

Speaker: NA
Text: is something that should be held up as an example of entrepreneurship, of tenacity and of hard

Speaker: NA
Text: work, and the reason that having internships is such an important part of our economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: If Chris Gardner were here I am sure he would speak of the importance of internships and

Speaker: NA
Text: the importance of this coalition policy. We know what those in the Labor Party have. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: to the young Chris Gardners out there today in Australian society who will take advantage of

Speaker: NA
Text: this policy to get themselves an internship, to lift themselves up and create a success of their

Speaker: NA
Text: lives. To think that the Labor Party is going to vote against this, well, it tells us everything

Speaker: NA
Text: about the modern Labor Party. I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Mr MCCORMACK
Text: Riverina-Minister for Small Business) (16:27): I rise to sum up on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Jobs Path: Prepare, Trial, Hire) Bill 2016.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill introduces legislative amendments that help give effect to the Youth Jobs PaTH

Speaker: NA
Text: Program announced in the 2016-17 budget as part of the Youth Employment Package. The

Speaker: NA
Text: best form of welfare that any government can provide is a job. We know that when seeking to

Speaker: NA
Text: enter the labour market for the very first time many young people do not have the skills and

Speaker: NA
Text: experience employers look for. This can make it harder to get a start. It can leave them

Speaker: NA
Text: susceptible to long-term unemployment and welfare dependency. The Liberal-Nationals

Speaker: NA
Text: government is committed to supporting young people to acquire the skills they need in order

Speaker: NA
Text: to move from welfare into work. The Youth Jobs PaTH-prepare-trial-hire-program will

Speaker: NA
Text: maximise the chances of jobseekers under 25 in getting a job, in obtaining employment. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: three elements. Prepare: employability skills training to help young jobseekers learn the skills

Speaker: NA
Text: expected by employers so that they are more competitive when they are applying for a job.

Speaker: NA
Text: Trial: voluntary internships of four to 12 weeks to give jobseekers a chance to show what they

Speaker: NA
Text: can do in a real workplace, with financial incentives to participate for both businesses and

Speaker: NA
Text: jobseekers. Hire: a new youth bonus wage subsidy of up to $10,000 to support businesses

Speaker: NA
Text: wanting to hire young people.

Speaker: NA
Text: These three initiatives-skills training, real work experience and wage subsidies-are an

Speaker: NA
Text: investment by the coalition government in the future of Australia's young people. Young

Speaker: NA
Text: people are the leaders of tomorrow. This will instil confidence and encourage their transition

Speaker: NA
Text: into employment. It will enhance their employability to maximise the chances of obtaining a

Speaker: NA
Text: job and moving off income support-obtaining a job and keeping that job. It will also allow

Speaker: NA
Text: them to experience a broad range of personal and financial opportunities that come with being

Speaker: NA
Text: employed. These amendments are designed to help young jobseekers by making sure that

Speaker: NA
Text: young people undertaking PaTH internships receive the full benefit of their participation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Youth Jobs PaTH internship incentive payments to participants will not be considered as

Speaker: NA
Text: income for social security and veterans' entitlement purposes, and that is important. This

Speaker: NA
Text: means the participants will receive the full amount of the incentive payments on top of their

Speaker: NA
Text: existing social security payments or their veterans' entitlements. The amendments also aim to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that eligible young people, in particular circumstances, will be able to have their social

Speaker: NA
Text: security payments restored without having to make a new claim. If they lose their job, through

Speaker: NA
Text: no fault of their own, with an eligible employer within 26 weeks of ceasing to receive income

Speaker: NA
Text: support they can then reconnect to government services and income support.

Speaker: NA
Text: In conclusion, the passage of this bill will ensure young people are afforded every

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to become fully engaged and job ready to maximise their chances of finding work

Speaker: NA
Text: as quickly as possible. Youth unemployment imposes significant economic costs through

Speaker: NA
Text: lower workforce participation and related welfare costs-as a regional member of parliament,

Speaker: NA
Text: I know this as well as anyone, youth unemployment rates generally being higher in regional

Speaker: NA
Text: areas than they are elsewhere-not to mention the greater social cost to the young person,

Speaker: NA
Text: their families and our local communities. It comes at a great cost.

Speaker: NA
Text: We cannot stand idly by while there are tens of thousands of young people who stand to be

Speaker: NA
Text: at risk of long-term welfare dependence-I would say intergenerational welfare dependence. I

Speaker: NA
Text: call upon those in this place to support Youth Jobs PaTH and this legislation, which will give

Speaker: NA
Text: young jobseekers the full benefit of this program.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The original question was that this bill be now read a second time. To

Speaker: NA
Text: this, the honourable member for Chifley has moved as an amendment that all words after 'that'

Speaker: NA
Text: be omitted with a view to substituting other words. The immediate question is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment be agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: The House divided. [16:35]

Speaker: NA
Text: Consideration in Detail

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill-by leave-taken as a whole.

Speaker: Mr HUSIC
Text: Chifley) (16:42): We have had the opportunity through the course of this

Speaker: NA
Text: debate to outline a number of concerns that we have about the program design that will be

Speaker: NA
Text: supported by the passage of this bill. This bill does two things: one is that it provides a top-up

Speaker: NA
Text: to income support levels, and the second thing it does is that it allows someone to re-engage

Speaker: NA
Text: with the social security system if they have not been successful in holding down a job through

Speaker: NA
Text: the PaTH program.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: A number of us will no doubt be taking the opportunity during consideration in detail to

Speaker: NA
Text: focus on different elements of the actual PaTH legislation that is being considered, and we

Speaker: NA
Text: would also like to take the opportunity to ask the government for answers to questions that we

Speaker: NA
Text: feel were simply not answered by the government, with all due respect to the minister at the

Speaker: NA
Text: table. A series of concerns have been raised relating to things such as the definition of what an

Speaker: NA
Text: intern would be and whether or not, for example, this bill would allow for the displacement of

Speaker: NA
Text: existing jobs. We also asked questions about whether or not wages would be undercut as a

Speaker: NA
Text: result of this system. Even with the top-up that is provided people will be paid at a rate that is

Speaker: NA
Text: less than the national minimum wage, and we have expressed concerns about that.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have also expressed concerns about whether or not people who are in the unfortunate

Speaker: NA
Text: position of experiencing a workplace accident would be covered by workplace compensation

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation and what the arrangements would be around that. It is a bit hard to imagine that a

Speaker: NA
Text: $200 top-up to income support will cover people in the instance where they are injured, have

Speaker: NA
Text: significant medical costs, are unable to participate in the program and may be potentially

Speaker: NA
Text: prevented, as a result of that injury, from taking up employment. These are all serious

Speaker: NA
Text: questions and none of them, I say with the greatest of respect to the minister at the chair who

Speaker: NA
Text: has been provided with the summation to provide to the House, has been addressed. So I think

Speaker: NA
Text: it is important that in consideration in detail these things be looked at.

Speaker: NA
Text: Importantly, one of the issues is that this bill will enable, in effect, churn. It recognises that

Speaker: NA
Text: there will be churn in this program-that is, that there will be people who will go through the

Speaker: NA
Text: PaTH program, will potentially start with an employer and then not be retained by that

Speaker: NA
Text: employer and will have to re-engage with the social security system. So there are questions

Speaker: NA
Text: that certainly arise out of schedule 2 of the government's bill, where it allows for a suspension

Speaker: NA
Text: instead of cancellation of income support. This addresses the need for safeguards in the event

Speaker: NA
Text: business fire employees within 26 weeks instead of following through on their commitment. I

Speaker: NA
Text: would like to ask: how much of this churn does the government estimate will happen as a

Speaker: NA
Text: result of the program? How many workers does the government anticipate will not make the

Speaker: NA
Text: full six months after participating in this program? With the government guarantee that

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses will not churn through free interns instead of hiring long-term employees? How

Speaker: NA
Text: will that churn be monitored? What steps will be put in place to identify it before interns are

Speaker: NA
Text: placed and after? Who will monitor those rates? Is a tip-off line in the National Customer

Speaker: NA
Text: Service Line enough to pick up instances of churn across 30,000 placements in up to 20,000

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses a year? How will the government know whether interns are accepted and other

Speaker: NA
Text: employees in the organisations are retrenched? How much information about its company and

Speaker: NA
Text: its staffing will a business have to provide to be eligible to accept more interns under PaTH?

Speaker: Mr MCCORMACK
Text: Riverina-Minister for Small Business) (16:47): I thank the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Chifley-the shadow minister-for his questions. They are pertinent ones. I

Speaker: NA
Text: understand and acknowledge that. I am not going to endeavour to answer the hypothetical

Speaker: NA
Text: questions towards the end of his consideration in detail, but some of those earlier in his

Speaker: NA
Text: remarks I will answer.

Speaker: NA
Text: The internship is an opportunity for individuals on income support to gain valuable work

Speaker: NA
Text: experience in a real workplace on a voluntary basis. There is nothing wrong with that. This

Speaker: NA
Text: should not be confused with paid work, as individuals will continue to remain on income

Speaker: NA
Text: support whilst undertaking the internship. The youth employment package will equip young

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: jobseekers by getting them ready, giving them a go and getting them a job. I would have

Speaker: NA
Text: thought, given those wonderful ideals, that Labor would have gotten on board with the bill as

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed by the government in its original form.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am asked how this form of work is legal and how it complies with the Fair Work Act. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: not work; it is work experience, and like other work experience programs such as the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Work Experience Program, internship participants will not be employees for the purposes of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Fair Work Act. In particular, this is because the Social Security Act provides that people

Speaker: NA
Text: will not be employees for the purpose of the act merely because they are undertaking an

Speaker: NA
Text: activity under their employment pathway plan. No legislative change is needed to exempt the

Speaker: NA
Text: internships from the coverage of the Fair Work Act because of the following: the Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Security Legislation Amendment (Employment Services Reform) Bill 2008 amended 631C of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Social Security Act to provide that from July 2009 approved programs of work and any

Speaker: NA
Text: other activities, including the employment pathway plan, did not give rise to an employer-

Speaker: NA
Text: employee relationship. That is important.

Speaker: NA
Text: What protections will be in place to prevent employers from abusing the program,

Speaker: NA
Text: including displacement? I was asked that by the member for Chifley. Employers who

Speaker: NA
Text: participate in the internship program must be able to show real prospects of ongoing work.

Speaker: NA
Text: There will be safeguards to ensure that existing workers are not displaced. The program sets a

Speaker: NA
Text: maximum duration of 12 weeks and the number of weekly hours worked in a placement

Speaker: NA
Text: comes in at 25 hours. So internships will be voluntary for both businesses and jobseekers and

Speaker: NA
Text: will be co-designed by them to ensure that placements meet both of their needs. Importantly,

Speaker: NA
Text: the government will closely monitor the way employers use the program to ensure they are

Speaker: NA
Text: not exploiting or churning-a word the member for Chifley used-and burning jobseekers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Employers who are exploiting jobseekers will be blocked from using the program, as they

Speaker: NA
Text: should be.

Speaker: NA
Text: Employment services providers will also be responsible for brokering internship

Speaker: NA
Text: placements and ensuring places are consistent with program guidelines. This includes the

Speaker: NA
Text: safety of jobseekers. Everybody in this parliament is adamant that the safety of jobseekers and

Speaker: NA
Text: workers is always paramount. Although internships are not an employer-employee

Speaker: NA
Text: relationship, businesses have a duty of care to provide a safe work environment-as the small

Speaker: NA
Text: business minister I know how important that is-and appropriate supervision for jobseekers

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaking internships. This includes ensuring compliance with applicable state and territory

Speaker: NA
Text: occupational health and safety legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also have to say that the Youth Jobs PaTH initiative is going to be good for Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: jobseekers. I know the member for Chifley did not raise this, but he would probably like to

Speaker: NA
Text: know that of the 115,000 Indigenous jobseekers in employment services, around 76,000-

Speaker: NA
Text: roughly two-thirds-are being supported by jobactive, a further 29,000 are participating in the

Speaker: NA
Text: remote Community Development Program and 9,000 in disability employment services.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a good program. As the small business minister I commend it. I commend

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses to get on board with the program. Moreover, I commend jobseekers to absolutely

Speaker: NA
Text: take part and participate in this program because it will give them real meaning, real work and

Speaker: NA
Text: a real pathway for the future.

Speaker: Ms BURNEY
Text: Barton) (16:51): I do not disagree with the sentiments of the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Small Business. Labor believes in employment and youth employment as away of breaking

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: disadvantage. There is no question about that. However, the youth unemployment figures are

Speaker: NA
Text: not reflected when you average out employment figures here in Australia, as is often done by

Speaker: NA
Text: the government. Spruiking unemployment figures is a smokescreen for the extreme level of

Speaker: NA
Text: youth unemployment in many regions across this country, including the Central Coast and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hunter. I know the figures for these areas very well. Employment is an important pathway out

Speaker: NA
Text: of entrenched disadvantage. There is no question about that. Where Labor parts ways and the

Speaker: NA
Text: reason that the member for Chifley has moved these amendments is the nature of this

Speaker: NA
Text: program. Please do not pretend that it is anything other than an election thought-bubble. We

Speaker: NA
Text: all watched it. We all saw it. There was no detail then and there seems to be even less detail

Speaker: NA
Text: now.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Chifley has highlighted a number of questions that we would like

Speaker: NA
Text: answered. I have come out of the New South Wales parliament, where, strangely, ministers

Speaker: NA
Text: did answer the questions raised in debate by the opposition. That is why you have three

Speaker: NA
Text: people sitting over there in those chairs, working away, I am assuming, to provide you with

Speaker: NA
Text: the answers to the questions that we are raising. That is what I am used to. It is sadly not what

Speaker: NA
Text: I see in this parliament. The issue that I am very much wanting to know about, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: with my shadow portfolio responsibilities of human services, is where this program intersects

Speaker: NA
Text: in a real way with Centrelink and the administration of Centrelink. There must be a

Speaker: NA
Text: connection somewhere if the participants are recipients of, I am assuming, mostly Newstart.

Speaker: NA
Text: This concerns me deeply when I look at some of the real issues with Centrelink, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: the lack of access to information and the extreme waiting times for people who are trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: get some information about their situation. I was in the Northern Territory on the weekend,

Speaker: NA
Text: and people there were waiting between three and six hours to get some sort of response from

Speaker: NA
Text: Centrelink. The IT system is nothing short of clunky. The casualisation of the staff is extreme.

Speaker: NA
Text: It seems to me that these issues need to be considered in the administration of this program. In

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, it is unclear to me how this program is going to be administered, where it is going to be

Speaker: NA
Text: administered from and what government agencies will have the responsibility for ensuring its

Speaker: NA
Text: overall implementation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will be a little more specific. The questions I raise are very much a microcosm of what the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Chifley raised. I would like to know where the checks and balances are for this

Speaker: NA
Text: program. I have seen on countless occasions initiatives being undertaken, without real thought

Speaker: NA
Text: as to what the actual consequences were going to be, and how the checks and balances were

Speaker: NA
Text: to be put in place. I want to know how many interns one firm can have. I want to see and have

Speaker: NA
Text: explained to me, as we do on this side, what a detailed implementation plan is and whether

Speaker: NA
Text: there is any evaluation, given the Auditor-General's report about a number of programs just

Speaker: NA
Text: recently. How will this program be implemented? Who will do it? What is the plan? And

Speaker: NA
Text: what agencies are going to be responsible in its implementation? Is there an evaluation plan

Speaker: NA
Text: built in? What will be counted in that evaluation plan? How will we know whether it is

Speaker: NA
Text: successful or not?

Speaker: NA
Text: The other issue is the human side of this. What will happen to a young person who is long-

Speaker: NA
Text: term unemployed-and this program is being held out to be the panacea for your long-term

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed-if they are placed as intern after intern, after intern, with never any real

Speaker: NA
Text: outcome because of the way in which the program is structured? It seems to me that these are

Speaker: NA
Text: legitimate questions. I am not being cheeky, minister. I am asking these questions because I

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: think they need to be answered to make sure that this program does what it says it is going to

Speaker: NA
Text: do- (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr MCCORMACK
Text: Riverina-Minister for Small Business) (16:56): I will answer the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Barton's questions inasmuch as she asked about the relationship between

Speaker: NA
Text: Centrelink and the Department of Employment. Of course those organisations talk with each

Speaker: NA
Text: other. They always do. They do with the coalition in government, they did when Labor was in

Speaker: NA
Text: power and they will continue to do that. That is just a given. This youth employment package

Speaker: NA
Text: was announced in the 2016-17 budget. It is an $840.3 million investment over four years to

Speaker: NA
Text: assist young people to develop the ability, skills and real work experience they need to get a

Speaker: NA
Text: job.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Barton, coming from Whitton as she does, would understand the

Speaker: NA
Text: importance of young people getting a job. I know she does. I know she served in the New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales parliament. I know she had a fine record of service to that state parliament. I

Speaker: NA
Text: know that she, like me, as the small business minister, wants to see as many young people in

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs as possible. This package represents just that; it is a substantial investment in our youth.

Speaker: NA
Text: There could be no finer investment by a government than in our youth. It will ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: young Australians receive job ready skills, which will enable them to obtain a foothold in the

Speaker: NA
Text: job market. It will build on initiatives introduced by the government under the Youth

Speaker: NA
Text: Employment Strategy. And it will work to further boost young people's job prospects by

Speaker: NA
Text: helping them to be better prepared for the workplace.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Barton asked whether it would lead to an intern after intern, after intern

Speaker: NA
Text: situation. I can understand the member for Barton asking that question. But I know as an

Speaker: NA
Text: employer, before I got into parliament, as an editor of The Daily Advertiser newspaper at

Speaker: NA
Text: Wagga Wagga and then as a small business owner, if you have a good intern and they prove

Speaker: NA
Text: they were job ready-once they prove that they are capable of doing what you want them to

Speaker: NA
Text: do-you gave them a job. If there was a job there, you gave them that job. I am sure that

Speaker: NA
Text: employers across Australia will relish the opportunity to get good, young people job ready,

Speaker: NA
Text: focused on what they need to do, trained up and understanding the whys and wherefores of a

Speaker: NA
Text: workplace. If a job becomes available, they will get that position. It just makes good sense. It

Speaker: NA
Text: makes good business sense. It is what good bosses do. These measures, combined with

Speaker: NA
Text: existing initiatives, including the Transition to Work Service, Empowering YOUth Initiatives

Speaker: NA
Text: and the ParentsNext Project, will be putting young job seekers on a pathway to finding and,

Speaker: NA
Text: most importantly, keeping a job.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the core of the youth employment package is the Social Security Legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (Youth Jobs Path: Prepare, Trial, Hire) Bill 2016, the bill that we are considering

Speaker: NA
Text: in detail now. It is a $751.7 million initiative. It maximises the chances of jobseekers under 25

Speaker: NA
Text: years of age getting a job. That is the age group where many of them leave school and many

Speaker: NA
Text: have seen their parents unemployed and their grandparents unemployed. We, as a

Speaker: NA
Text: government, want to get those young people into jobs because the best way out of welfare is

Speaker: NA
Text: into a job. The best way to a better future is a job. I understand that, as the Minister for Small

Speaker: NA
Text: Business. I know the members for Barton and Chifley and all those opposite get that. We on

Speaker: NA
Text: this side, of course, get it, because we are the side that understands how important getting

Speaker: NA
Text: youth employed is.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: The youth employment package also includes measures on encouraging entrepreneurship

Speaker: NA
Text: and self-employment, designed to encourage young Australians to start a business and to

Speaker: NA
Text: create their own job. The package provides a step-by-step pathway to work, which directly

Speaker: NA
Text: deals with the major challenges to employment faced by young people-particularly in

Speaker: NA
Text: regional areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whilst we are talking about regional areas and young people, we should also mention the

Speaker: NA
Text: backpacker tax, and why we want to make sure that the backpacker tax is fixed at 19 per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: not 10½, so that foreign workers are faced with young Australians who are going to be paying

Speaker: NA
Text: a higher level of tax. We want to make sure that we get that fruit picked, make sure that those

Speaker: NA
Text: abattoirs are serviced, make sure that those pubs have the hospitality staff needed. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: many provisions, not just this one. There are many pieces of legislation that are so important

Speaker: NA
Text: and so critical to get through in these final few days of the 2016 parliament, to ensure that we

Speaker: NA
Text: get youth employed. And we must ensure that this particular legislation is carried.

Speaker: Ms SHARKIE
Text: Mayo) (17:01): Thank you, minister, for answering many of the questions

Speaker: NA
Text: that I have, but there are still so many that remain unanswered. The PaTH program will affect

Speaker: NA
Text: 120,000 young people, so it is imperative that government gets it right, particularly as this

Speaker: NA
Text: program affects our most vulnerable people entering the workforce.

Speaker: NA
Text: While I support the government in ensuring that we are supporting young people, I think

Speaker: NA
Text: that this is too important to leave so many areas vague or open to ministerial or administrative

Speaker: NA
Text: discretion. I would like to ask the minister a number of questions relating to this. To begin

Speaker: NA
Text: with, how would the government ensure that employment service providers will explain to

Speaker: NA
Text: participants their rights in the workplace before an internship commences? How will the

Speaker: NA
Text: government disallow program participants from working beyond standard hours-for

Speaker: NA
Text: example, not just beyond the standard number of hours per day and beyond the standard

Speaker: NA
Text: number of continuous hours, but working without a break as well? We know young people

Speaker: NA
Text: are so eager to please and they are going to be so desperate for this free internship to turn into

Speaker: NA
Text: a job.

Speaker: NA
Text: In my electorate there is 17 per cent youth unemployment. I meet hundreds of young

Speaker: NA
Text: people who are so desperate for a job. How will the government ensure that participants are

Speaker: NA
Text: able to afford the travel costs to attend the compulsory training components of the program,

Speaker: NA
Text: and what special conditions and consideration will be given to rural participants whose travel

Speaker: NA
Text: costs are considerably higher than other participants? The minister has a rural electorate like

Speaker: NA
Text: me. There are no cheap buses-there are no buses for young people to get on. They will need

Speaker: NA
Text: to somehow put petrol in the car and then get to that place of work, which may be 20 or 30

Speaker: NA
Text: kilometres away. How will the government ensure that participation in the internships will be

Speaker: NA
Text: purely voluntary, and there will be no penalty beyond losing internship payments for

Speaker: NA
Text: withdrawing from an internship?

Speaker: NA
Text: I acknowledge the minister's comments in relation to the duty of care of the employer, but

Speaker: NA
Text: how will the government ensure that the health and safety of participants in internships will

Speaker: NA
Text: be adequately protected and that adequate compensation will be available to participants,

Speaker: NA
Text: should they become sick or injured as a result of a workplace incident? I would be devastated

Speaker: NA
Text: to think that I supported legislation where, six months down the track, a young person in a

Speaker: NA
Text: butcher store who is so keen to work, so eager, loses their hand and then has no compensation

Speaker: NA
Text: and no rights of reply. I would be devastated to think that I supported that legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: How will the government ensure that program participants are provided with sufficient

Speaker: NA
Text: protections from bullying and sexual harassment? Again, we are talking about the most

Speaker: NA
Text: vulnerable people-many entering the workforce for the first time. How will the government

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that large businesses do not abuse this scheme and use it purely as a source of cheap

Speaker: NA
Text: labour, replacing existing jobs? Surely this program should not be designed for cafes? How

Speaker: NA
Text: long does it take to learn how to make a coffee and to go out and wait tables? This program

Speaker: NA
Text: should be focused on people who are in trades, on where we know there will be jobs in the

Speaker: NA
Text: future and on where we know small businesses will be able to connect and put on apprentices

Speaker: NA
Text: and trainees. We know that we have 160,000 less trainees and apprentices today than we had

Speaker: NA
Text: just a few years ago. That is where the focus of this must be.

Speaker: NA
Text: How will you ensure that there is sufficient focus and support for our most vulnerable

Speaker: NA
Text: young people, for young people from Aboriginal backgrounds, young people who have had

Speaker: NA
Text: possible connections with juvenile justice, and young people who are guardian-of-the-

Speaker: NA
Text: minister children? We need to ensure that those young people are properly supported and get

Speaker: NA
Text: the most out of this scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: How will the government ensure that there are effective complaints systems in place for

Speaker: NA
Text: program participants concerned with unreasonable treatment by their host organisations? I

Speaker: NA
Text: would also like to touch upon the previous member's comments about the program being

Speaker: NA
Text: properly reviewed and evaluated. Adding to that, I would like to say that it must be

Speaker: NA
Text: independently evaluated, and that review must be publicly available.

Speaker: NA
Text: In closing, I am very concerned about medically certified sickness or compassionate

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons, such as even the death of a close family member, not being reasonable excuses for a

Speaker: NA
Text: program participant to end their involvement in the program. Surely this needs to be

Speaker: NA
Text: addressed.

Speaker: Mr MCCORMACK
Text: Riverina-Minister for Small Business) (17:06): Thanks to the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Mayo for her questions. They are important ones. I will just give a bit of an

Speaker: NA
Text: outline of the program to attempt to relieve some of her fears and concerns, which I would say

Speaker: NA
Text: are unfounded. I can assure the member for Mayo it is a good program. It has been well

Speaker: NA
Text: thought through, with consultation with key stakeholders and business groups, and in

Speaker: NA
Text: particular it provides jobs and hopes and opportunities for young Australians. The Jobs Youth

Speaker: NA
Text: PaTH improves upon and complements existing supporting programs by providing real world

Speaker: NA
Text: solutions to the real world employment challenges facing young people-young people in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate of Riverina, young people in the honourable member's electorate of Mayo. I know

Speaker: NA
Text: her electorate well.

Speaker: NA
Text: The employability skills training will be intensively delivered in two blocks of three weeks,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the close engagement with employers in the training's design means that it will deliver

Speaker: NA
Text: real results. A wide range of organisations have already been consulted, as I have just

Speaker: NA
Text: discussed, on the training and their feedback will inform its implementation. The internship

Speaker: NA
Text: placement is different from existing work experience activities because it delivers a formal

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity for young people to understand the work environment and at the same time it

Speaker: NA
Text: gives employers an opportunity to ensure the job seeker is a good fit for their business. Other

Speaker: NA
Text: key differences include: under the internship job seekers will receive a $200 per fortnight

Speaker: NA
Text: supplement on top of their income support payment, so that is a bonus, and employers will

Speaker: NA
Text: receive an up-front payment of $1,000 to host an intern, so that is good for them too. So it is a

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: win-win situation. Previous wage subsidies for youth under 30 provided employers with up to

Speaker: NA
Text: $6,500, GST inclusive, over 12 months if they hired an eligible job seeker. The new youth

Speaker: NA
Text: bonus wage subsidy provides up to $10,000 over six months. In addition, all wage subsidies

Speaker: NA
Text: for job seekers aged 25 to 29 years-parents, Indigenous, mature age and the long-term

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed-will be further enhanced, including payment over six months.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Mayo asked about sexual harassment, about bullying in the workplace and

Speaker: NA
Text: about safety in the workplace. I can assure her that all those fit under this legislation. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course no government would put in a plan that was going to give bullies in the workplace the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to perpetrate their crimes-and they are crimes-against young people. There has

Speaker: NA
Text: been some suggestion that participants are going to be paid only $4 an hour. The Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Council of Trade Unions have suggested that. The claim that the scheme will see young

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians paid so little per hour is a blatant lie, and the ACTU really should issue-

Speaker: Mr Husic
Text: Rubbish!

Speaker: Mr MCCORMACK
Text: No, it is not rubbish. They should issue an apology for trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: mislead Australians. Dare I say it, that is typical of that organisation. Under the innovative

Speaker: NA
Text: Youth Jobs PaTH plan, the payment of $200 per fortnight is on top of the existing income

Speaker: NA
Text: support that the job seeker already receives. It is an opportunity for individuals, as I have said

Speaker: NA
Text: before, with income support to gain valuable work experience in a real workplace on a

Speaker: NA
Text: voluntary basis but with all the conditions that a usual employee would benefit from, would

Speaker: NA
Text: be subjected to and would have the experience of. This should not be confused with paid

Speaker: NA
Text: work as individuals will continue to stay on income support whilst undertaking the internship.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a good employment package. It is good for youth. It is good for young Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: It makes them job ready. Many of them have not experienced this sort of undertaking before,

Speaker: NA
Text: this sort of opportunity, and I can assure the member for Mayo that particularly for regional

Speaker: NA
Text: areas, particularly for young people in country regions, this is a good deal for them. It makes

Speaker: NA
Text: them job ready. Employers and representative organisations such as the Business Council of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry consistently state that young

Speaker: NA
Text: people need to improve their employability skills and have recent work experience. This

Speaker: NA
Text: PaTH program enables just that. Australian Bureau of Statistics data shows that more than

Speaker: NA
Text: 100,000 unemployed young people aged 15 to 24 have never worked before. It is a staggering

Speaker: NA
Text: statistic. Job seekers who undertake work experience are more likely to find sustainable

Speaker: NA
Text: ongoing employment. The department's administrative data for December 2014 showed that

Speaker: NA
Text: of the job seekers who undertook unpaid work experience, almost half were in employment

Speaker: NA
Text: three months later compared to 26 per cent for other activities.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr BRIAN MITCHELL (Lyons) (17:11): It is a sad day in Australian governance when

Speaker: NA
Text: a first-term opposition MP has to school a minister of the Crown on a piece of government

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation. The ACTU is absolutely right-it is $4 an hour on top of the Centrelink payment

Speaker: NA
Text: that they would normally already get. To say otherwise is simply a blatant falsehood. The

Speaker: NA
Text: minister and I share a history. I too am the former editor of a local newspaper-though not

Speaker: NA
Text: one quite so salubrious as The Daily Advertiser in Wagga! Our newspaper also had interns.

Speaker: NA
Text: They were university interns, usually students in their third year, or graduates. The big

Speaker: NA
Text: difference between them and what is being proposed now is that they were what most people

Speaker: NA
Text: would understand interns to be, which is young people learning on-the-job training for the

Speaker: NA
Text: profession of their choice-invaluable work experience. It was a win for the employer-we

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: got a warm body to give some extra work to-but they got training, they got mentorship and

Speaker: NA
Text: they got a body of work that they could then use when they went out to get a real job.

Speaker: NA
Text: The minister is quite right-if a good intern came along you would give them a job if a job

Speaker: NA
Text: was available. That is the key-if a job was available. The problem with this scheme is that it

Speaker: NA
Text: promotes, it incentivises, churn. You are going to give $1,000 to an employer every 12 weeks.

Speaker: NA
Text: If you are a small business employer and you are on the bones of your bum a little bit and the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity is there to turf a worker every 12 weeks and get a thousand bucks every 12

Speaker: NA
Text: weeks, you are going to take it up. The minister will assure us in a moment that that will

Speaker: NA
Text: never happen-'Trust us, we would make sure that would not happen.' But I will tell you

Speaker: NA
Text: what, Minister-people game the system all the time. They find the loopholes, they find the

Speaker: NA
Text: gaps. Unless this is tied down and ironclad, that is what is going to happen. People will be

Speaker: NA
Text: ripped off, kids will be churned through this system every 12 weeks and dodgy employers

Speaker: NA
Text: will pocket that $1,000. One of my key concerns with this proposal is that it seeks to depress

Speaker: NA
Text: wages. It essentially creates a pool of free labour, and that then depresses wages for

Speaker: NA
Text: everybody else in the community. It treats young people as disposable-it tells them they are

Speaker: NA
Text: worth not quite as much as the rest of us. That, to me, is just not right.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have a number of questions which hopefully the minister can answer in some detail. First,

Speaker: NA
Text: what happens if an intern sustains an injury at work?

Speaker: NA
Text: Are interns covered by workers' compensation? The government simply has not addressed

Speaker: NA
Text: this important question. Will the base $200 a fortnight include the possibility of being made to

Speaker: NA
Text: work on public holidays and weekends? Does a penalty rates regime apply for these times? I

Speaker: NA
Text: suspect it does not. What is going to happen? For a worker who gets penalty rates with these

Speaker: NA
Text: times, the employer will say, 'There is a worker I have got to pay penalty rates to, and there is

Speaker: NA
Text: a free bit of labour.' Guess who will get those hours? It is absolutely outrageous. I would like

Speaker: NA
Text: some clarification on that. What qualification will an intern earn after four to 12 weeks in a

Speaker: NA
Text: workplace working 15 to 25 hours a week? Will they get a certificate? Will they get a trade

Speaker: NA
Text: qualification? Will they get anything to send to another employer, or will it just be, 'Thanks

Speaker: NA
Text: very much, on your way,' while somebody else comes in through the front door?

Speaker: NA
Text: The minister assures us there will be safeguards. When you are dealing with legislation of

Speaker: NA
Text: this magnitude and when you are dealing with the lives of hundreds of thousands of young

Speaker: NA
Text: people, we need better in legislation than 'Just trust us.' We need to see the detail before it is

Speaker: NA
Text: put to the parliament. That is why Labor is going to seek to refer this to a Senate review. The

Speaker: NA
Text: minister said he can assure the member for Mayo that it is a good policy. She had some very

Speaker: NA
Text: good questions. I, too, represent a rural seat and I, too, know young people who find it very

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult to get to work. They do not all have cars and public transport is absolutely woeful. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is very expensive to get around. These are questions that need to be answered as well.

Speaker: NA
Text: The minister said this will deal with the real-world challenges. A real-world challenge for

Speaker: NA
Text: young people is getting fair pay in the workplace. Australians have worked for generations to

Speaker: NA
Text: get fair pay and fair conditions for Australians in workplaces. We are simply not prepared to

Speaker: NA
Text: give it up on what is looking more and more like a dodgy free employment scheme.

Speaker: Ms SWANSON
Text: Paterson) (17:16): I was listening intently to the minister as he said that

Speaker: NA
Text: there would be organisations that would broker partnerships for this program. I would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: directly ask the minister: which organisations will broker this program? Are they the same

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations that were completely decimated by the 2014 budget when the then Treasurer Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Hockey stood up and announced that he would no longer continue the very successful

Speaker: NA
Text: brokerage partnership programs that had been occurring and which saw many young people

Speaker: NA
Text: find work. After that, we saw an increase in joblessness with our young people. That was a

Speaker: NA
Text: direct result of what this government did to absolutely eliminate and annihilate those fantastic

Speaker: NA
Text: programs that were working and that this government did not support and did not continue.

Speaker: NA
Text: We on this side understand that youth unemployment truly is a scourge in our society and it

Speaker: NA
Text: is vital that we all work together to create the best environment that we can for our young

Speaker: NA
Text: people to get a job. We welcome additional resources being invested in youth employment,

Speaker: NA
Text: but I am convinced, as is Labor, that this Youth Jobs PaTH, as it stands, is not the best way to

Speaker: NA
Text: support young jobseekers or invest Commonwealth funds. It is not a pathway to employment,

Speaker: NA
Text: but, rather, a road to nowhere in my assessment.

Speaker: NA
Text: The amendment that Labor proposes seeks guarantees that this legislation will not be used

Speaker: NA
Text: to exploit young people or to undermine workforce standards. As the member for Mayo

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed out, these young people are so keen to impress. They really are desperate for those

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs. How will they not be exploited? We have all been in situations where you might stay

Speaker: NA
Text: back for those extra couple of hours when you are trying your best to get an absolutely great

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity. How will we ensure that these young people will not be exploited? We have real

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns about whether this actually presents a genuine opportunity for young people to gain

Speaker: NA
Text: meaningful employment or whether it is just going to be completely unworkable.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no firm definition of what an intern is under the program or what sectors they

Speaker: NA
Text: could be asked to work in. Large numbers of participants could be used within companies at

Speaker: NA
Text: one time, as we have already pointed out. There is a distinct difference between companies

Speaker: NA
Text: and the organisations that brokered programs in the past, as was pointed out earlier in the day.

Speaker: NA
Text: Also, large numbers of these interns could completely negate the need for existing employees

Speaker: NA
Text: in certain sectors, such as hospitality. And, as my colleague just pointed out, the penalty rate

Speaker: NA
Text: issue is one of the most glaring ones. What is going to cover someone who should be paid the

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate penalty rates for being away from their family on a weekend, as opposed to an

Speaker: NA
Text: intern being brought in and being taken advantage of? These are real and genuine concerns

Speaker: NA
Text: that we have.

Speaker: NA
Text: At a time when wages growth is at its lowest on record, there are very real concerns that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Youth Jobs PaTH program could be used to undermine wages across many industries. It

Speaker: NA
Text: will not be just young people and would-be workers who will suffer but all workers in lower-

Speaker: NA
Text: paying jobs who would be forced to compete with what is, virtually, slave labour. The Youth

Speaker: NA
Text: Jobs PaTH program does not specify real job areas in which jobseekers will acquire skills. All

Speaker: NA
Text: we have been told is that these programs will give young people the skills that employers tell

Speaker: NA
Text: us that they need. We need to know what these skills are. What are they? How will it work? I

Speaker: NA
Text: still want to know the definition of an intern. I want to know what they will be doing and I

Speaker: NA
Text: want to know what, more importantly, they will be learning. I want to know how this

Speaker: NA
Text: government can guarantee that it will not depress wages and I want the government to

Speaker: NA
Text: guarantee that it will not displace jobs.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also want the government to guarantee that it will provide vital access to workers'

Speaker: NA
Text: compensation. It is no good saying, 'Everything will be okay; they will be safe and we would

Speaker: NA
Text: not put anything in place that would put anyone in a dire situation.' Well, I may be new but I

Speaker: NA
Text: am not quite that naive. We want to see this properly accounted for. The safety of our young

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: people should be legislated. This government has an appalling record when it comes to

Speaker: NA
Text: helping young people. Apprenticeship numbers have been absolutely in freefall for the past

Speaker: NA
Text: three years. We have had the VET scheme; we have had Work for the Dole, which has not

Speaker: NA
Text: worked out well; and, I guarantee, in a few years we will be hearing how this has not worked

Speaker: NA
Text: out as well. These answers must be found.

Speaker: Ms CHESTERS
Text: Bendigo) (17:21): I also have a number of questions for the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Small Business, or the person representing the minister-and we are not quite sure who that is

Speaker: NA
Text: at the moment. Perhaps it is the Minister for Infrastructure and Transport, who is sitting at the

Speaker: NA
Text: table, who is now representing the minister on this issue. Hopefully whoever is going to

Speaker: NA
Text: answer these questions is listening closely, because on this side we have raised a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: serious questions that we believe the government needs to answer, and our friends on the

Speaker: NA
Text: crossbench have also raised questions in relation to this program.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since I made my speech on the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Jobs Path:

Speaker: NA
Text: Prepare, Trial, Hire) Bill 2016 in the second reading debate, the government still has not

Speaker: NA
Text: responded to the concerns that I and many others raised. I reiterate the concerns about

Speaker: NA
Text: occupational health and safety. Where do these interns fit with regard to occupational health

Speaker: NA
Text: and safety? What happens if they are injured on a worksite? Do they complete a claim form?

Speaker: NA
Text: Are they entitled to workers compensation? Are they entitled to days off in payment of that?

Speaker: NA
Text: What happens if a worker is injured? We have already seen what has happened in the Work

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Dole scheme. There is no responsibility whatsoever if somebody is injured, we have

Speaker: NA
Text: heard-and we know that a young person tragically lost their life while involved in a Work

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Dole scheme. We need the government to guarantee that that will not happen with this

Speaker: NA
Text: system.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have heard-and again the government has not responded on this-about the issue of

Speaker: NA
Text: pressure being applied to wages. This scheme says that somebody will get their youth

Speaker: NA
Text: allowance payments and $4 on top of that. What happens if they work on a weekend? Will

Speaker: NA
Text: they get an extra top-up for penalty rates? Is that being accounted for? What will this

Speaker: NA
Text: government do to ensure that these interns are not being used late at night, in the evenings, on

Speaker: NA
Text: penalty-rate days? Also, what is the government doing to ensure that these people, who will

Speaker: NA
Text: effectively be on a payment of Newstart plus $4 an hour, are not undercutting jobs and

Speaker: NA
Text: workers in these places? What about in places where there is a collective agreement in place

Speaker: NA
Text: that pays much more than this? Will the government guarantee that workers are not displaced

Speaker: NA
Text: in terms of shifts or hours? Will it guarantee that these interns will not take hours away from

Speaker: NA
Text: casuals who are relying on shifts to make ends meet?

Speaker: NA
Text: The government has also not been clear about how these interns will intersect with, and

Speaker: NA
Text: what rights they will have under, the Fair Work Act. Again, the government has not been

Speaker: NA
Text: clear with the Australian people and with the prospective interns about how the Fair Work

Speaker: NA
Text: Act will apply to these young people. Will they have access to the unfair dismissal

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions? The reason the government is twisted in so many knots is that, currently under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Fair Work Act, there is no classification for an intern-none whatsoever. So, if a young

Speaker: NA
Text: person who is engaged in the program is dismissed, what happens to their payments? The

Speaker: NA
Text: government has said that they need to be able to prove that it was not their fault. That is so

Speaker: NA
Text: arbitrary. Who decides that dispute if an employer says, 'You're gone,' and the intern says,

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: 'That's unfair'? Who is the arbiter? Who gets to decide that? If you are a worker, you are

Speaker: NA
Text: protected under the unfair dismissal provisions. In this particular situation, we do not know.

Speaker: NA
Text: Also, the government have still failed to prove that these are not $4-an-hour supermarket

Speaker: NA
Text: internships-a concern that has been raised not just by the union movement but by young

Speaker: NA
Text: people themselves. The government still have not convinced us or the Australian people that

Speaker: NA
Text: this will not cut jobs. For a government that rant a lot about jobs and growth, they have failed

Speaker: NA
Text: to demonstrate how this program will not take jobs away from young people, and they need to

Speaker: NA
Text: come in here and make that clear. It used to be considered a bit of a rite of passage that a

Speaker: NA
Text: young person's first job would be in retail or hospitality. The government need to guarantee

Speaker: NA
Text: that, with this internship, they are not taking away jobs that otherwise would have gone to

Speaker: NA
Text: young people. They have failed to address that question. They have failed to answer that.

Speaker: NA
Text: They should come in here and address the concerns that have been raised not just by people in

Speaker: NA
Text: this House but by people within the community.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr BRIAN MITCHELL (Lyons) (17:26): I have been sitting here very patiently waiting

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Minister for Small Business to actually answer my questions. This is consideration in

Speaker: NA
Text: detail of the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Jobs Path: Prepare, Trial, Hire)

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill 2016, and I have been very polite, I think. I asked him what I thought were fairly decent

Speaker: NA
Text: questions about whether young people on these so-called internships will be paid penalty

Speaker: NA
Text: rates, whether they will be made to work long and extraordinary hours through the night,

Speaker: NA
Text: whether they will be given access to transport options-all sorts of questions that the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: has failed to answer, perhaps because the minister is no longer here. The Minister for Small

Speaker: NA
Text: Business seems to have so little interest in this matter that he has departed the chamber and

Speaker: NA
Text: seems to have left his intern, the Minister for Infrastructure and Transport, in his place. I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: you are getting more than $4 an hour, Minister! On the matter of highly paid interns, I cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: go past the fact that my predecessor, the former member for Lyons Mr Eric Hutchinson, has

Speaker: NA
Text: got a pretty nice internship himself, with Senator Stephen Parry, the President of the Senate. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is a little more than $4 an hour, of course. It is around $160,000 a year, to attend functions. So

Speaker: NA
Text: that is not bad.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am happy to stand here all day-I am here all week-and wait for the minister to come

Speaker: NA
Text: into the chamber and actually answer some of the very serious questions that have been put by

Speaker: NA
Text: me, the member for Mayo, the member for Paterson and the member for Bendigo, amongst

Speaker: NA
Text: others. These are very important questions. This is supposedly-so the government says-a

Speaker: NA
Text: panacea for the scourge of youth unemployment. I do not think there is anybody in here who

Speaker: NA
Text: is not desperately serious to see this matter addressed. Youth unemployment across the

Speaker: NA
Text: country is far too high. Where we differ is on how to address it. On this side, what we know

Speaker: NA
Text: is: you educate young people, you train young people and you provide them with pathways to

Speaker: NA
Text: work via apprenticeships. Yes, there are legitimate internships, such as those that university

Speaker: NA
Text: students and graduates go through, where they train for a short amount of time on the job and

Speaker: NA
Text: they get a portfolio of work, they have mentorship and they are on their way. That is a

Speaker: NA
Text: legitimate internship. A legitimate internship is not being employed by the local fish and chip

Speaker: NA
Text: shop, where the employer gets $1,000 to put you on behind the deep fryer, and you stand

Speaker: NA
Text: there for 12 weeks shuffling the fries and then you are out the door and somebody else walks

Speaker: NA
Text: in. That is not a legitimate internship. That is free labour, and what that means is that the kid

Speaker: NA
Text: next door does not get that job. The kid next door does not get that job on proper wages

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: because that job has been taken up by free labour paid for by the taxpayer. That is just a

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayer-funded rort for business. It is just not right. So the member for Bendigo asked a very

Speaker: NA
Text: good question on those matters.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am still here; the minister still has not arrived. I do not know what could be keeping him.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is supposedly a very serious matter that the government has put to the House. We really

Speaker: NA
Text: need answers on these questions. I really would like to see him answer them.

Speaker: Mr HUSIC
Text: Chifley) (17:30): What is becoming clear is this: this is a massive new

Speaker: NA
Text: program. What is being proposed here or what will be supported by this bill is something way

Speaker: NA
Text: higher than what the government has ever done. They have an existing program, the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Work Experience Program. It takes 6,000 people. This program boosts that up five times:

Speaker: NA
Text: 30,000 young Australians will go through this program. It is an entirely new system. A lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: people have legitimate concerns: that jobs will be displaced; that people who would have got

Speaker: NA
Text: a job independently will be replaced by an intern. And 'intern' has not even been defined;

Speaker: NA
Text: there is no definition from those opposite of what an 'intern' is. They may be an intern barista;

Speaker: NA
Text: they may be an intern construction worker; they may be an intern retail assistant-which

Speaker: NA
Text: completely flies in the face of what the general public thinks an intern is.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those people would be paid below the national minimum wage. Bear in mind: the national

Speaker: NA
Text: minimum wage right now is $17.70 an hour. But an intern who works 25 hours a week and

Speaker: NA
Text: receives only their Newstart payments plus the $200 top-up will earn $14.50 an hour. The

Speaker: NA
Text: small business minister was saying that the ACTU should apologise because they were

Speaker: NA
Text: misrepresenting the situation. Guess what? The stats are clear. These people-these interns;

Speaker: NA
Text: these young Australians-will be brought in at a lower rate than the national minimum wage.

Speaker: NA
Text: As wisely observed by the member for Mayo, we have no understanding about what the

Speaker: NA
Text: span of hours will be on any given day. They are supposed to work 15 to 25 hours a week.

Speaker: NA
Text: How do we know that they will not work 12 hours a day without a break? That is a legitimate

Speaker: NA
Text: question that was being posed. We have had questions about whether or not penalty rates

Speaker: NA
Text: would be undermined.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have had a whole stack of concerns. But guess what? We are not going to get answers

Speaker: NA
Text: today, because what is going to happen is: the minister at the table here is just going to do

Speaker: NA
Text: them as one job lot and thinks that he will answer them in five minutes. And he will not. None

Speaker: NA
Text: of the questions that have been raised through the course of this consideration in detail, about

Speaker: NA
Text: a program that is massively expanding on what is currently being done, that will involve

Speaker: NA
Text: young people-questions that everyone wants to get legitimate answers to-will not be

Speaker: NA
Text: answered by this government.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a clear demonstration that, as the member for Barton said, they engaged in an election

Speaker: NA
Text: thought-bubble. Six months after this program was announced in the federal budget, they still

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot define what an intern is. They still cannot give us assurances that these people will be

Speaker: NA
Text: covered by workers' compensation. They still cannot give us assurances that the interns will

Speaker: NA
Text: not be used to displace jobs, in a market where people are already underemployed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Underemployment is already at an all-time high. People are already concerned about wages

Speaker: NA
Text: growth flatlining. There are all these concerns out there. But this government will not answer.

Speaker: NA
Text: And I am sorry, but-with the greatest respect to the minister, who I have great time for: it

Speaker: NA
Text: is not good enough, Minister, to have all these members of parliament raise legitimate

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: questions and to have them just pushed off into one five-minute job lot. Not only do these

Speaker: NA
Text: members deserve answers; the Australian public, who will be seeing this new thought-bubble

Speaker: NA
Text: unveiled, deserve answers as well.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is basically April 2017 when this program comes in, and we still do not have answers

Speaker: NA
Text: about what is going to happen. I actually think we do need to get answers. We need to get

Speaker: NA
Text: answers to the question about workers' compensation, because, in the submission made by the

Speaker: NA
Text: department to the Senate inquiry that is going on now, published on the website, we are now

Speaker: NA
Text: told that the Department of Employment has insurance arrangements in place to cover

Speaker: NA
Text: jobseekers undertaking activities, including group personal accident insurance and combined

Speaker: NA
Text: liability insurance. But what happens if someone is permanently incapacitated as a result of an

Speaker: NA
Text: accident through being involved in an internship? What happens to them? At what rate do

Speaker: NA
Text: they get paid out? At what rate can they expect income support? Where do they go? Do they

Speaker: NA
Text: go on to DSP? What happens there? They will be placed in the invidious situation of being

Speaker: NA
Text: locked out of the job market. And we do not even know the details about the coverage.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are the types of questions that deserve to be answered, and they should not be treated

Speaker: NA
Text: disrespectfully, through the way that they are being managed right now-with all due respect

Speaker: NA
Text: to the minister.

Speaker: Mr CHESTER
Text: Gippsland-Minister for Infrastructure and Transport) (17:35): I thank

Speaker: NA
Text: the members opposite for their questions and their contributions to this debate, and I thank

Speaker: NA
Text: them for their impending support for the bill which is before the House.

Speaker: Mr Husic
Text: We've still got questions!

Speaker: Mr CHESTER
Text: And there will be more questions. I am going to answer some of the ones

Speaker: NA
Text: that I have got to in the last 10 or 15 minutes, Member for Chifley.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the members are aware, the youth employment package was announced in the 2016-17

Speaker: NA
Text: budget and is an investment in the order of $840 million, which will be implemented over

Speaker: NA
Text: four years to assist young people to develop their employability skills and provide them with

Speaker: NA
Text: the work experience they need to get a job. I thank the members opposite because I think they

Speaker: NA
Text: are very sincere in their enthusiasm for helping young Australians receive the job-ready skills

Speaker: NA
Text: they need which will enable them to obtain a foothold in the job market. It does build on other

Speaker: NA
Text: initiatives that the Turnbull government has implemented under the youth employment

Speaker: NA
Text: strategy, which will further boost young people's job prospects by making sure they are in a

Speaker: NA
Text: position to be better prepared to join the workplace.

Speaker: NA
Text: Members asked questions as to: 'Why aren't the jobseekers undertaking internships paid at

Speaker: NA
Text: the minimum wage?' Under this program, placements do not constitute an employer-employee

Speaker: NA
Text: relationship and do not involve wages or salaries. The jobseekers continue to receive their

Speaker: NA
Text: income support as well as a $200 fortnightly supplement, which is paid by the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: government. The program will provide those young jobseekers aged from 17 to 24 with an

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to show prospective employers what they can do in the workplace while gaining

Speaker: NA
Text: those valuable work skills and experience. I am sure members opposite would agree with me

Speaker: NA
Text: that quite often all a young person needs is a chance to get a foothold, to get their foot in their

Speaker: NA
Text: door, to demonstrate that they have the capacity to hold down employment. This internship

Speaker: NA
Text: program gives them a chance to prove their suitability for future employment.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: In terms of the question about whether it complies with the Fair Work Act: the internship is

Speaker: NA
Text: not work; it is work experience, as members opposite would be aware. In relation to the need

Speaker: NA
Text: for such initiatives: it has been a matter of concern put to the government by organisations

Speaker: NA
Text: such as the Business Council of Australia and the Australian Chamber of Commerce and

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry, who have consistently stated that young people need to improve their employability

Speaker: NA
Text: skills and to have had recent work experience. The ABS data shows that more than 100,000

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed young people aged 15 to 24 have never worked before. That is an important

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration when we reflect on the position put by the government in relation to this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation-100,000 young people aged 15 to 24 have never actually worked before. Giving

Speaker: NA
Text: them the opportunity to prove their abilities in the workplace is an endeavour worth pursuing.

Speaker: NA
Text: In terms of protections to be put in place-and I acknowledge the questions raised by

Speaker: NA
Text: several speakers regarding protections to prevent employers from abusing the program,

Speaker: NA
Text: including the displacement effect, which I think some members referred to-employers who

Speaker: NA
Text: participate in the internship program must be able to show real prospects of ongoing work and

Speaker: NA
Text: there will be safeguards to ensure that existing workers are not displaced by the scheme. The

Speaker: NA
Text: program sets a maximum duration of 12 weeks, and the number of weekly hours worked in

Speaker: NA
Text: the placement will be 25 hours. The internships will be voluntary for both the businesses and

Speaker: NA
Text: the jobseekers and be co-designed by them to ensure that the placements meet both their

Speaker: NA
Text: needs. Again, that is an important consideration. For this to work, it has to be in the interests

Speaker: NA
Text: of the young person themselves and it also has to be seen to be of some benefit to the business

Speaker: NA
Text: sector, which will be passing on the opportunity for these young people to learn those skills

Speaker: NA
Text: with the on-the-job training provided through the internship program. It will be up to the

Speaker: NA
Text: government to ensure-and I take the caution in the spirit that it was meant-that the program

Speaker: NA
Text: is closely monitored to ensure that the employers who use the program are not exploiting and

Speaker: NA
Text: not, to use the vernacular, churning and burning young people by simply rotating them

Speaker: NA
Text: through. If they are seen to be exploiting young jobseekers they will be excluded from the

Speaker: NA
Text: program in the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do want to acknowledge the contribution by members opposite, and I am sure there will

Speaker: NA
Text: be other questions that will be raised. But I would hasten to say that this is a comprehensive

Speaker: NA
Text: package that has targeted services and support for all unemployed young people. It is a well-

Speaker: NA
Text: designed package, with an evidenced-based pathway to help young Australians into the

Speaker: NA
Text: workplace. It offers, I think, a meaningful and rewarding opportunity for young jobseekers

Speaker: NA
Text: and employers a like to bridge the gap and to get young people working.

Speaker: Ms SHARKIE
Text: Mayo) (17:40): I will not take up too much more of the House's time, but

Speaker: NA
Text: I do have a couple of concerns. Prior to me coming to this House, this was an area of my own

Speaker: NA
Text: employment. So it is something that I am particularly passionate about. The focus of this

Speaker: NA
Text: program needs to be about young people. What I am not aware of, and what is not detailed in

Speaker: NA
Text: the legislation, is: what career mentoring will be provided to the young person to ensure they

Speaker: NA
Text: are placed in a work setting that will fit with their talent and their career goals, or will they

Speaker: NA
Text: just be shunted anywhere that suits the jobactive provider?

Speaker: NA
Text: The minister has mentioned health and safety. In relation to my previous question, he said

Speaker: NA
Text: that it was in the legislation. But I could not see in the legislation any specific legislative

Speaker: NA
Text: protections for young people. I note that the minister, now responding to the questions, has

Speaker: NA
Text: detailed that this is not an employee-employer relationship. Therefore, my concerns are even

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: more heightened about the protection of young people, vulnerable people-many of whom, as

Speaker: NA
Text: the minister acknowledged, have not even been in a work placement before. How do we know

Speaker: NA
Text: that they will be safe and respected in the workplace and that they will have rights and

Speaker: NA
Text: protections?

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to ask why jobactive providers were chosen to deliver this. Why are they in

Speaker: NA
Text: the legislation? Why not Transition to Work providers? That is a government program. We

Speaker: NA
Text: know that they tendered out the program to youth specialist providers and organisations that

Speaker: NA
Text: are recognised and well respected across the industry. They know how to work with young

Speaker: NA
Text: people and they get the best out of young people. So why would this program be working

Speaker: NA
Text: through jobactive providers and not Transition to Work?

Speaker: NA
Text: Another query I have particularly relates to my electorate and to all rural electorates across

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. If you are registered training organisation as well as possibly being the successful

Speaker: NA
Text: provider of this program, you will not be able to train your young people in your RTO as well

Speaker: NA
Text: as place them into employment. I understand that the government was probably trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that there was not double-dipping-it is one of those favourite words at the moment.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, when you are in a regional area, there is often one organisation and that

Speaker: NA
Text: organisation often only has one or two staff members. So it is really going to be impossible in

Speaker: NA
Text: regional and rural Australia for this program to be effectively delivered-and that is where I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe we need this program to be delivered the most.

Speaker: NA
Text: In relation to the training, I would also like to say that, from my reading of the legislation, a

Speaker: NA
Text: young person will not receive that $200 per fortnight while they are in the training component

Speaker: NA
Text: of this program; it is only when they are in the placement. Again, how do you afford to get to

Speaker: NA
Text: training? Anyone who is on youth allowance is only getting just over $400 a fortnight to live

Speaker: NA
Text: on if they are on the independent rate. Out of that, they have to feed themselves, they have to

Speaker: NA
Text: clothe themselves and they have to cover rent. It is so far below the poverty line that the idea

Speaker: NA
Text: that we would have an expectation that a person would also get to their own training without

Speaker: NA
Text: any subsidies-which are provided under Work for the Dole but not under this program-

Speaker: NA
Text: while you are in the training component-seems grossly unfair.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would also like to talk about the trades and industries that will be targeted. I am very

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned that this will be a program that essentially will be picked up in hospitality and in

Speaker: NA
Text: retail-areas where we know it does not take 12 weeks to train a young person. We certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: do not need any more baristas; what we need are plumbers, painters, electricians and

Speaker: NA
Text: hairdressers. We need people to work in a variety of areas where we know that there are

Speaker: NA
