Text: career opportunities for young people where they will very quickly learn a range of skills that

Speaker: NA
Text: are transferrable and will have a certificate in their hand and they will not be making coffee at

Speaker: NA
Text: age 29 and waiting on tables. These young people deserve more than that.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to go back to a couple of other issues that I have raised previously. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly concerned about the level of ministerial discretion and administrative discretion

Speaker: NA
Text: in this legislation. The government is spending an enormous amount of money on this

Speaker: NA
Text: program-so you have got to get it right. You cannot afford to waste this money and put

Speaker: NA
Text: young people, who are our most vulnerable people, in the workforce in a worse situation.

Speaker: Ms LAMB
Text: Longman) (17:45): I was sitting in my office, watching what was happening

Speaker: NA
Text: down here in the chamber and I felt compelled to come on down and speak to this. It was just

Speaker: NA
Text: over a week ago that I found myself here speaking to the Social Security Legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (Youth Jobs Path: Prepare, Trial, Hire) Bill 2016. As I mentioned back then,

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor has always supported meaningful investment and initiatives that give young people a

Speaker: NA
Text: real pathway towards long-term, stable employment because, as I am sure the minister would

Speaker: NA
Text: agree, there is real dignity in having a job. I am a mother of four boys and they range from 16

Speaker: NA
Text: to 26-so I am a mother and also a worker. Up until a few months ago, I was a worker just

Speaker: NA
Text: like my boys are. I know that there is real dignity in having a job. I know about being able to

Speaker: NA
Text: put food on the table, to put a roof over your head, to be able to join the local sporting team

Speaker: NA
Text: and to be a member of my community, and that comes from having a job. I know that

Speaker: NA
Text: firsthand. I would like to thank the member for Mayo for those questions that she raised and I

Speaker: NA
Text: look forward to waiting for the minister to answer them as well because I am keen to hear

Speaker: NA
Text: those answers.

Speaker: NA
Text: The point that I felt compelled to come down and make about this proposal is that there are

Speaker: NA
Text: several elements about the program that have the potential to undermine what our country has

Speaker: NA
Text: fought hard for in the way of workforce standards. The first thing I would like to raise is that

Speaker: NA
Text: we should all be alarmed by any proposal that allows a business to pay workers below the

Speaker: NA
Text: award rate. We have heard it a number of times before. I was in my suite and I could hear the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister arguing around $4 an hour. Having 17to 24-year-olds participate in an internship

Speaker: NA
Text: for 25 hours a week, earning $100 a week-I do not need a calculator, but I am happy to get it

Speaker: NA
Text: out of my office and bring it down to the minister if he needs a hand-that is $4 an hour. If he

Speaker: NA
Text: needs one, please pass it on that I can hand one over to him.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have always believed in a fair day's pay for a fair day's work. We have award rates in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country because, as a society, we believe that low-paid workers should have economic

Speaker: NA
Text: security and should be protected from exploitation. In question time today, I heard the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister say, 'We back the workers.' Well, I tell you what, I wonder how that young,

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland, 7-Eleven worker feels about that backing of the Prime Minister. I wonder how

Speaker: NA
Text: backed that worker feels when I watch the video of that. The second concern I have got is the

Speaker: NA
Text: real risk of companies cycling through young workers and using them as cheap labour. You

Speaker: NA
Text: could be working early mornings, you could be working late nights, you could be working

Speaker: NA
Text: weekends and you could work Christmas Day-nothing to stop you-in any industry at all.

Speaker: NA
Text: In my electorate, we not only have unemployment but also have underemployment. Those

Speaker: NA
Text: are workers who are already working but are actually looking for more hours. The real risk is

Speaker: NA
Text: that they can lose their hours. You do need to look any further than Longman to have see how

Speaker: NA
Text: underemployment is playing out. At Caboolture Community Action, where they feed the

Speaker: NA
Text: hungry and the homeless-and I have spoken about this great organisation a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: times-we are seeing more and more people turning up that do have jobs but do not have

Speaker: NA
Text: enough hours. There is enough money to put fuel in the car and there is enough money to pay

Speaker: NA
Text: the rent but there is not enough money for food. That is the real story of underemployment.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I said before, we have always supported meaningful investment. We will always

Speaker: NA
Text: support initiatives that give young people a pathway through unemployment because, like I

Speaker: NA
Text: said, I know in Longman there is nothing more dignifying than having a decent job. Over the

Speaker: NA
Text: last week, as I am sure many people have, I have been to a lot of school awards ceremonies

Speaker: NA
Text: celebrating the achievements of our children, but the one thing that parents keep asking me

Speaker: NA
Text: about, and the thing that always resonated with me, was jobs for our children. This is the stuff

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: that is concerning for them. We cannot allow a proposal like this to go through unchecked.

Speaker: NA
Text: We must have security.

Speaker: NA
Text: My questions-and I am happy for him to get back to me on these-to the minister are:

Speaker: NA
Text: what guarantee will he give us that people will not lose their casual hours? Those people who

Speaker: NA
Text: are underemployed already in my community, what guarantee will they have that they will

Speaker: NA
Text: not lose their casual hours that they want more of? What guarantee-and I heard the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Mayo raise this as well-will our kids have that they will know their rights at work as they

Speaker: NA
Text: first start at a place of employment?

Speaker: Mr HUSIC
Text: Chifley) (17:50): As has been evident through the course of the consideration

Speaker: NA
Text: in detail, there are quite a few members within this chamber that have expressed deep

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns about the program design that will be supported by this bill. We think this is a major

Speaker: NA
Text: new initiative by the government, which we have expressed concerns about from the get-go

Speaker: NA
Text: that this has been rushed through, not thought through and that the program design has flaws

Speaker: NA
Text: in there that could cause real problems for young, unemployed Australians. No-one for a

Speaker: NA
Text: moment is suggesting that youth unemployment in this country is not a problem; it is a

Speaker: NA
Text: problem. No-one is suggesting that new measures do not need to be considered, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: given the performance of, for example, the Work for the Dole program that is unable to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide jobs for young Australians. Three months after they have completed Work for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Dole, nearly 90 per cent of those participants do not find work. They are not in full-time jobs.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I said during my contribution in the substantive debate, I was stunned at the blase way in

Speaker: NA
Text: which the departmental secretary said that Work for the Dole is not about finding a job. That

Speaker: NA
Text: would come as big news to the bulk of Australians who expect that a program like that will

Speaker: NA
Text: get people ready for employment. That program is tanking. This government has not found a

Speaker: NA
Text: way to reverse the slide for that program.

Speaker: NA
Text: They have now come up with this program, a program which I note is modelled on

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas programs, and others have also observed that this has been modelled on attempts

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas to do similar things. In its submission to the Senate inquiry that is underway, the

Speaker: NA
Text: ACTU raised valid concerns, which were dismissed by the Minister for Small Business-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Ryan: Shame!

Speaker: Mr HUSIC
Text: In response to the member for Lalor's interjection, it will be a shame if this

Speaker: NA
Text: program fails as well and falls in a heap and we have to come back here and address those

Speaker: NA
Text: failures. In its submission, the ACTU said the United Kingdom tried a similar scheme, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Youth Employment Scheme, YES, in 2013. This scheme was launched in January 2013 and

Speaker: NA
Text: was wound up in July 2014, with fewer than half the estimated placements having been made

Speaker: NA
Text: and no clear increase in real job placements. The YES scheme, like the Youth Jobs Path

Speaker: NA
Text: program, had a top-up element for the participant, a subsidy for the employer-tick, tick; both

Speaker: NA
Text: of these things are available under the proposed program-a shorter work experience

Speaker: NA
Text: component and a longer skills development component.

Speaker: NA
Text: That scheme tanked, so the question to the government is: if we look at overseas models,

Speaker: NA
Text: can you give assurances to the House that the model being proposed here and that is

Speaker: NA
Text: supported by this bill will actually be successful? This is a $752 million program, Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is $5.7 million allocated to it in this bill. Where is the rest? Has the $5.7 million taken

Speaker: NA
Text: into account the 'cycling through'-as the member for Longman referred to it-of people? We

Speaker: NA
Text: do not know that.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Longman mentioned the possibility of this cycling through. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: genuinely concerned that in some major businesses you will get a big group of these interns

Speaker: NA
Text: being brought in who will, just coincidentally, be put on weekends where penalty rates would

Speaker: NA
Text: not apply to them because they are already getting their payment. But the people who were

Speaker: NA
Text: earning those penalty rates would suddenly find that they did not have to come in for that

Speaker: NA
Text: shift. That is a big issue for people in those positions. The biggest champions of this type of

Speaker: NA
Text: program have been within the hospitality sector. They have never engaged in the jobactive

Speaker: NA
Text: program. Big businesses have never taken up those jobactive jobseekers. It has been small and

Speaker: NA
Text: medium enterprises who have done so. But we find that the ones that are quoted by those

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite when they are talking about the program are these big champions: the Business

Speaker: NA
Text: Council of Australia and AiG. Of course they would champion it. The concern is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: smaller businesses that have done the great thing by the country and have taken on more and

Speaker: NA
Text: more jobactive participants will not be the ones that are prioritised under this program. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: an issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are watching this program closely. We are very concerned that people will be ripped

Speaker: NA
Text: off, that the program will fail and that it will be young people who will be forced to carry the

Speaker: NA
Text: cost, not this government, for a thought bubble announced in a budget leading into a hastily

Speaker: NA
Text: called election. Minister, there are deep concerns about this program and what it will actually

Speaker: NA
Text: achieve.

Speaker: Mr CHESTER
Text: Gippsland-Minister for Infrastructure and Transport) (17:55): In

Speaker: NA
Text: closing, I would like to thank members opposite for their contributions to this debate on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Jobs Path: Prepare, Trial, Hire) Bill 2016. I

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledge the very genuine interest that many members have shown in what is an issue

Speaker: NA
Text: that has been particularly difficult for governments on both sides of this House to solve. If

Speaker: NA
Text: solving youth unemployment were easy, the government would have solved it in the last three

Speaker: NA
Text: years or those opposite would have solved it in their six years. It simply has proven to be

Speaker: NA
Text: quite an intractable issue for federal governments to manage.

Speaker: NA
Text: The minister responsible is open to the practical suggestions that have been put forward by

Speaker: NA
Text: those opposite, and I am sure that there will be more opportunities for that conversation to

Speaker: NA
Text: occur. I think we have a shared desire across the chamber to get more young people off the

Speaker: NA
Text: dole, get them off unemployment benefits and get them into employment, and this is an

Speaker: NA
Text: important piece of legislation in that. It provides for $840 million over four years.

Speaker: NA
Text: I take up the comments of at least one previous member who said that there is real dignity

Speaker: NA
Text: in having a job. This program is about trying to find ways to get young people work

Speaker: NA
Text: experience so they go on to have meaningful employment. We believe the package will work

Speaker: NA
Text: because it provides a step-by-step pathway for young people to deal with some of those major

Speaker: NA
Text: challenges that young people in particular face when it comes to finding employment. These

Speaker: NA
Text: challenges are a lack of employability skills, a lack of experience and difficulties in

Speaker: NA
Text: competing with other jobseekers when it comes to actually being selected for the job.

Speaker: NA
Text: We believe that this program will have good support from the business sector, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: in the small business sector, which is a critical employer of young people right around

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. It is well placed to give young people that chance, that foot in the door, that

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to learn new skills that may well lead to their overcoming any barriers that they

Speaker: NA
Text: may face in getting established in the workplace. Once they get that first opportunity, I am

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: very confident that they will have the capacity to develop a work ethic, which will stand them

Speaker: NA
Text: in good stead in the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is important to stress-and several members have raised this issue-that under this

Speaker: NA
Text: internship approach jobseekers will receive a $200 per fortnight supplement, which is on top

Speaker: NA
Text: of their income support payment. It is important for members to recognise that. The young

Speaker: NA
Text: people participating in this program will retain their income support payment and receive a

Speaker: NA
Text: supplement on top of it. So it is not $4 per hour; it is actually a payment on top of the benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: they are already receiving, which is provided by Australian taxpayers. It is true that the

Speaker: NA
Text: employers will also receive an up-front payment in the order of $1,000 to host and intern. As I

Speaker: NA
Text: said in my previous comments, it is up to the government to make sure that any businesses

Speaker: NA
Text: found to be exploiting the system are forced off it and to provide those protections for the

Speaker: NA
Text: young unemployed people. Internships will be voluntary for both the businesses and the

Speaker: NA
Text: young people involved. They will be co-designed by them to make sure the needs of both are

Speaker: NA
Text: met. I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Reading

Speaker: Mr CHESTER
Text: Gippsland-Minister for Infrastructure and Transport) (17:59): by

Speaker: NA
Text: leave-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Criminal Code Amendment (War Crimes) Bill 2016

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Consideration resumed of the motion:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr DREYFUS
Text: Isaacs-Deputy Manager of Opposition Business) (17:59): Labor takes a

Speaker: NA
Text: bipartisan approach to all matters of national security. We will always act to ensure that our

Speaker: NA
Text: police and armed forces, both domestically and abroad, have the powers they need to combat

Speaker: NA
Text: terrorism.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Criminal Code Amendment (War Crimes) Bill 2016 updates Australian domestic law

Speaker: NA
Text: to reflect changes in international law in relation to the treatment of members of organised

Speaker: NA
Text: armed groups in non-international armed conflict. It reduces legal uncertainty for our armed

Speaker: NA
Text: forces overseas when they engage with non-state armed groups such as ISIL. It is an

Speaker: NA
Text: unfortunate reality that, in the last few decades, groups like ISIL, rather than hostile nations,

Speaker: NA
Text: have become the main threat with which we are forced to engage overseas. It has taken a

Speaker: NA
Text: while for international and domestic legal systems to catch up with that change.

Speaker: NA
Text: These amendments provide legal certainty to members of the Australian Defence Force so

Speaker: NA
Text: that they can target members of organised armed groups with lethal force without the risk of

Speaker: NA
Text: potentially committing an offence under Australian domestic law. In particular, this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: amends division 268 of the Criminal Code, which provides for offences in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: genocide, crimes against humanity, war crimes and crimes against the administration of

Speaker: NA
Text: justice in the International Criminal Court. If passed, it will mean that war crimes offences

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: only apply if the person or persons affected are neither taking an active part in the hostilities

Speaker: NA
Text: nor are members of an organised armed group, and the perpetrator knows of or is reckless as

Speaker: NA
Text: to the factual circumstances establishing that the person or persons are neither taking an active

Speaker: NA
Text: part in the hostilities nor are members of an organised armed group.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other parts of the bill amend sections of the Criminal Code which apply the international

Speaker: NA
Text: humanitarian law principle of proportionality in relation to attacks on military objectives in

Speaker: NA
Text: non-international armed conflicts. Other small amendments have been made to reflect

Speaker: NA
Text: changes to international law.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill was thoroughly scrutinised by the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Intelligence

Speaker: NA
Text: and Security, the PJCIS, as with all national security bills which pass through this parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: The PJCIS was fortunate to have amongst its members the member for Eden-Monaro who, as

Speaker: NA
Text: a distinguished former member of the Australian Army Legal Corps, has specific expertise in

Speaker: NA
Text: relevant areas of international law. I thank him for his counsel in this matter. The PJCIS heard

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence from the Attorney-General's Department, the Department of Defence and eminent

Speaker: NA
Text: international lawyers Professor Tim MCCormack and Professor Ben Saul.

Speaker: NA
Text: One point of concern for the committee was to ensure that there is a clear understanding of

Speaker: NA
Text: what is meant by 'members of an organised armed group'. Such groups can often contain a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of different actors, not just combatants-support personnel, for instance, and even

Speaker: NA
Text: administrative personnel. Non-state groups, by their nature, are formed of very different kinds

Speaker: NA
Text: of personnel when compared to national armies-they are often not so organised or

Speaker: NA
Text: professional in their constitution. However, it is worth noting that this would not appear to be

Speaker: NA
Text: the case when it comes to ISIL, which is just as highly organised as some armies.

Speaker: NA
Text: Professor Saul noted that there was some controversy in international law as to the

Speaker: NA
Text: definition of 'members of an organised armed group' and suggested that it be defined as 'those

Speaker: NA
Text: with a continuous combat function within that group'. The committee's report notes that, while

Speaker: NA
Text: the most appropriate approach to determining membership of an organised armed group

Speaker: NA
Text: continues to be debated, Australia's key coalition partners and allies already operate in

Speaker: NA
Text: accordance with the international law which this bill will extend to cover Australian forces.

Speaker: NA
Text: This approach aims to treat organised armed groups on an equal footing with state armed

Speaker: NA
Text: forces and recognises that members of those groups, whether they are direct combatants

Speaker: NA
Text: providing combat support or providing combat service support, are all contributing to the

Speaker: NA
Text: military effort of the group and should not be given the same protection as civilians in an

Speaker: NA
Text: armed conflict.

Speaker: NA
Text: The explanatory memorandum to the bill also makes clear that the term 'organised armed

Speaker: NA
Text: group' is to be interpreted in a constrained way, such that persons performing civilian-type

Speaker: NA
Text: functions in territory controlled by an organised armed group would not be considered to be

Speaker: NA
Text: members of that group for the purpose of the legislation. This is a complex area of

Speaker: NA
Text: international law, and it is right that a nuanced approach is taken.

Speaker: NA
Text: The rise of ISIL, and al-Qaeda before it, has changed much about our world. It has made

Speaker: NA
Text: global theatres of conflict far less rigid and more difficult to define. It means conflicts

Speaker: NA
Text: crisscross state borders and national jurisdictions, drawing in far more players and introducing

Speaker: NA
Text: highly complex dynamics. Such changes have elevated the role of international law as a

Speaker: NA
Text: means of regulating conflict. This is a necessary outcome of conflicts no longer taking place

Speaker: NA
Text: country to country but country to non-state-armed group, with many different theatres of

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: conflict. Therefore it is right and necessary that Australian law is kept up to date with

Speaker: NA
Text: international law.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our armed forces have been doing a superb job in this new and uncertain world. Outgoing

Speaker: NA
Text: United States President Barack Obama praised the 'remarkable' work of our armed forces,

Speaker: NA
Text: noting that, after the United States, Australian forces are the largest on-the-ground presence in

Speaker: NA
Text: the fight against ISIL. Labor supports our armed forces in this important work. By fighting

Speaker: NA
Text: terror at its source, they are helping to keep Australians safe. It is right that, when Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: servicemen and women engage in armed conflict against ISIL and other like groups overseas,

Speaker: NA
Text: they are given legal certainty about what they are doing. They cannot do their job properly, if

Speaker: NA
Text: there is the remotest concern about the legality under Australian law. I am pleased that this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill will offer them that certainty.

Speaker: NA
Text: In recent years in Australia, notably under the prime ministership of the now member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Warringah, the debate about counterterrorism measures in this country had a tendency to

Speaker: NA
Text: reach a hysterical fever pitch. Instead of looking after the best interests of our country, the

Speaker: NA
Text: government seemed far more interested in playing wedge politics. I am happy to say that it

Speaker: NA
Text: appears that time has passed under the current prime ministership, and a calmer and bipartisan

Speaker: NA
Text: attitude to matters of national security has been resumed. Among all the storm and fury, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: important to note that our armed forces have been getting on with the job overseas. We should

Speaker: NA
Text: be very proud of what they have achieved so far and continue to achieve. Labor will support

Speaker: NA
Text: them every step of the way.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the short number of sitting weeks allocated to the 45th Parliament so far, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliamentary Joint Committee on Intelligence and Security has handled five inquiries and

Speaker: NA
Text: produced the same number of completed reports. Some of these reports have been on highly

Speaker: NA
Text: complex bills, unprecedented in Australia or even the developed world. It speaks volumes for

Speaker: NA
Text: the work ethic and skill of the PJCIS secretariat that such a great amount of work has been

Speaker: NA
Text: completed in such a short time.

Speaker: NA
Text: As it did in the 44th Parliament, Labor has taken a steadfast bipartisan approach to these

Speaker: NA
Text: bills. We have worked cooperatively with the new membership of the Parliamentary Joint

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee on Intelligence and Security, and its new chair the member for Deakin, to come to

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement on many difficult issues. It is an effort that I am proud of, and I think that other

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the committee can be proud too. The agreement reached on the passage of this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill is one of the fruits of this cooperative working relationship. I, on behalf of Labor, will

Speaker: NA
Text: work to ensure that relationship continues. I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr SUKKAR
Text: Deakin) (18:09): It is good to be able to follow the member for Isaacs'

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution on Criminal Code Amendment (War Crimes) Bill 2016. I want to echo his

Speaker: NA
Text: sentiments, as Chair of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Intelligence and Security, that

Speaker: NA
Text: we have had a big workload. This has been part of that workload, but the urgency with which

Speaker: NA
Text: we have worked in a cooperative way to review and ultimately recommend that this bill be

Speaker: NA
Text: passed is really for one purpose, and that is to give legal certainty to our men and women in

Speaker: NA
Text: the ADF.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a credit to the leadership of our Prime Minister, who has put his full imprimatur behind

Speaker: NA
Text: this, to bring forward a legal uncertainty-that has certainly been in place for a very long time

Speaker: NA
Text: as the member for Isaacs has said-an area where Australian domestic law has not kept pace

Speaker: NA
Text: with international law. It has been an ambiguity for some time but it took our Prime Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: this Prime Minister, to elevate the issue and ensure that we are now seeking to plug that gap.

Speaker: NA
Text: So I want to give credit of course to the PJCIS, I want to give credit to all of the members,

Speaker: NA
Text: including the member for Isaacs, and I want to give credit also to the secretariat who have

Speaker: NA
Text: done an amazing job in relation to this bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: In essence, as I have just said, the purpose of this bill and the purpose of these amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: is to bring into line the Australian domestic law with international law in the way we treat

Speaker: NA
Text: members of organised groups in noninternational armed conflict. The bill represents a key

Speaker: NA
Text: component of a range and suite of responses and measures that this government is seeking to

Speaker: NA
Text: implement to ensure that the threat of terrorism is addressed not only here on our own shores

Speaker: NA
Text: but from where it springs, particularly in the Middle East.

Speaker: NA
Text: In essence the purpose of this legislation is to ensure that the ADF is able to target

Speaker: NA
Text: members of organised terrorist groups. That, in its essence, is what we are ensuring that they

Speaker: NA
Text: can do and, importantly, these amendments, in my view, will be crucial to the ongoing

Speaker: NA
Text: operations of the ADF against ISIS in Iraq and Syria.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know that members of these terrorist militias act as combatants, and our ADF

Speaker: NA
Text: personnel should be able to engage with them as such. This bill achieves its intended aims

Speaker: NA
Text: primarily through amending several sections of war crimes offences in division 268 of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Criminal Code and to introduce the concept of organised armed group in noninternational

Speaker: NA
Text: armed conflicts.

Speaker: NA
Text: The proposed amendments draw a clear distinction between civilians on one hand and

Speaker: NA
Text: members of organised armed groups. As division 268 currently stands, war crimes offences

Speaker: NA
Text: may allow members of the ADF to be held liable for action against members of these armed

Speaker: NA
Text: groups in a noninternational armed conflict.

Speaker: NA
Text: Schedule 1 of the bill contains four parts. Part I will amend the war crimes offences in

Speaker: NA
Text: 268.70, 268.71 and 268.72 of the Criminal Code relating to murder, mutilation and cruel

Speaker: NA
Text: treatment of persons in the context of noninternational armed conflict so that those offences

Speaker: NA
Text: would only apply if the persons are either not taking part in the hostilities nor are they

Speaker: NA
Text: members of that relevant organised armed group-in this case Daesh-and the perpetrator

Speaker: NA
Text: knows of or is reckless as to the factual circumstances establishing that that person is not a

Speaker: NA
Text: member or taking active part in those hostilities. The bill also introductions the principle of

Speaker: NA
Text: proportionality in relation to attacks on military objectives in noninternational armed

Speaker: NA
Text: conflicts. This is done by amending other provisions in division 268.

Speaker: NA
Text: In broad terms, what I would like to conclude by saying-and I do not intend to use my

Speaker: NA
Text: entire allocation of time here because these issues I think have been aired very

Speaker: NA
Text: comprehensively not only by the Prime Minister but also the Leader of the Opposition. What

Speaker: NA
Text: we are seeking to do here is just to ensure that we can operate with our partners in armed

Speaker: NA
Text: conflicts in an environment where those whom we are fighting, those whom we are opposing

Speaker: NA
Text: are unconventional in the way they operate-unconventional in the sense that they are not a

Speaker: NA
Text: state. We do not think that via technical aspects of our domestic law they should be protected

Speaker: NA
Text: by provisions that, when originally drafted, were intended to protect civilians and those who

Speaker: NA
Text: were not engaged in activities that assisted in those hostilities.

Speaker: NA
Text: So this is, in a sense, an uncontroversial change. But, as with all amendments in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: the fear of war, they of course require significant review. I am pleased that we have conducted

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: that review through the PJCIS in a very thorough way. We were obviously assisted by the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that the will of our ADF, the will of our security and intelligence agencies was so one-sided as

Speaker: NA
Text: far as these proposed amendments go, because we do not want any Australian member of the

Speaker: NA
Text: ADF to, in any way, be potentially subject to negative legal recourse by defending the values

Speaker: NA
Text: of our country and by defending the values of Western liberal democracy in fighting

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations like Daesh. It is for that reason that, again, I want to thank the Prime Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Attorney-General; of course, I want to thank the PJCIS.

Speaker: NA
Text: I commend these amendments to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr MIKE KELLY (Eden-Monaro) (18:16): I acknowledge the previous comments of

Speaker: NA
Text: both the shadow Attorney-General and the chair of the PJCIS, the member for Deakin, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: congratulate him on his appointment as the chair of that committee. He is doing a very good

Speaker: NA
Text: job of getting that ball rolling with a lot of new members on the committee. It is a great

Speaker: NA
Text: privilege to be a member of the committee. We have a lot of fine experience and expertise

Speaker: NA
Text: that has been brought to bear through the membership. It does do very important work on an

Speaker: NA
Text: important bipartisan basis. A lot of people who sit outside this building often only see the

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament through the prism of question time and do not realise that there is such a deep

Speaker: NA
Text: body of work that is done on a very good, cooperative, bipartisan basis outside of those

Speaker: NA
Text: theatrical moments in here.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also really want to acknowledge: the input of Major General John Frewen and his ADF

Speaker: NA
Text: team, who came and were very generous with their support in answering questions from the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee; the Attorney-General's; and, in particular, too, the committee's support staff, who

Speaker: NA
Text: are a very good team who have provided tremendous support in what has been a very busy

Speaker: NA
Text: period. Also, I would like to acknowledge the public contributions that were made by the

Speaker: NA
Text: ICRC, the International Committee of the Red Cross, who I have had the privilege of working

Speaker: NA
Text: closely with over many, many decades now-30 years, really. I also acknowledge professors

Speaker: NA
Text: Ben Saul and Tim MCCormack, who provided very good quality contributions. Professor Tim

Speaker: NA
Text: MCCormack is someone who I have known for many years and who I worked very closely

Speaker: NA
Text: with. He has supported the ADF in working our way through from some very difficult and

Speaker: NA
Text: challenging issues very much like the subject matter that this legislation deals with.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to build on the comment that the shadow Attorney-General made about

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's willingness to work with the government on security issues. I can assure the House

Speaker: NA
Text: and the community in general that Labor has a very solid, dependable and strong national

Speaker: NA
Text: security policy team. In particular, the Leader of the Opposition has very sound instincts on

Speaker: NA
Text: these issues. I would not be here if that was not the case. I think we have very solid grounds to

Speaker: NA
Text: be confident that the management of national security from both the government and

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition points of view is being conducted on a sound basis. We have been reinforced on

Speaker: NA
Text: the opposition side by the addition of very fine members in the member for Cowan and also

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Solomon, who brings to this parliament his military experience as well. He is

Speaker: NA
Text: a good friend who I knew before his time in the parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have heard some specific details about the legislation. But to put it in context-I think

Speaker: NA
Text: this is very important to understand-the Defence Force and all of our military forces in the

Speaker: NA
Text: free would have been coming to grips with very difficult circumstances since the end of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Second World War. A lot of our operational circumstances have been characterised by these

Speaker: NA
Text: situations of dealing with non-state actors. They are very difficult situations of actually being

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: able to identify the enemy in many circumstances. I think that was particularly characteristic

Speaker: NA
Text: in situations like Vietnam, which added extra tension and stress for our members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence Force who returned and had ongoing, lingering problems afterwards that were not

Speaker: NA
Text: well understood. It is very important for us to provide as much clarity as we can in those

Speaker: NA
Text: operational circumstances, but it is also important that we are very careful in the way that we

Speaker: NA
Text: structure our targeting processes and the way we use force and deploy force judiciously in

Speaker: NA
Text: counterinsurgency and stabilisation operations. Any time that you cause collateral civilian

Speaker: NA
Text: casualties you will be potentially setting back your overall strategic mission.

Speaker: NA
Text: I speak as someone who was involved in the Defence Force for 30 years, but who has

Speaker: NA
Text: recently separated from the reserve. In that time, I can reassure the community and the House,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Defence Force always operated at the upper end, the highest end, of

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements of international law. In addition to that, in these circumstances-and bearing in

Speaker: NA
Text: mind the importance of discipline in targeting-the Defence Force operates well beyond the

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements of law in many circumstances, as well, understanding the importance of the

Speaker: NA
Text: impact of its decisions and the use of force in general.

Speaker: NA
Text: This legislation effectively takes into account a history and tradition of those conflicts and

Speaker: NA
Text: the development of the law to try and catch up with those circumstances. We have had

Speaker: NA
Text: through the Geneva Convention post Second World War the additional of Common Article 3.

Speaker: NA
Text: It dealt with non-international armed conflicts, but was very inadequate in dealing with all the

Speaker: NA
Text: complexity.

Speaker: NA
Text: Beyond that time, we had the development of additional protocol I and additional protocol

Speaker: NA
Text: II in particular, which deals with non-international armed conflicts in even more detail. Then,

Speaker: NA
Text: of course, we saw the development of the Rome statute, which tried to codify in practical

Speaker: NA
Text: terms all of this experience in reality. We had a body of law that was also evolved from the

Speaker: NA
Text: tribunal that dealt with the situation of the Bosnian conflict, trying to define these issues of

Speaker: NA
Text: members of organisations, what armed organisations are and putting some definition around

Speaker: NA
Text: that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Really, what this legislation does is acknowledge that, in the circumstances that we are in

Speaker: NA
Text: in Iraq, for example, you have an armed organisation with individuals who are not only

Speaker: NA
Text: providing direct support to combat activities and engaging in those combat activities but

Speaker: NA
Text: providing what we from a military background would call combat support and combat

Speaker: NA
Text: services support. That is wrapped around the facilitation of military operations through what

Speaker: NA
Text: you might call engineering support in more professional circumstances but also in the

Speaker: NA
Text: logistics of conducting these operations and attacks. We recognise that in Iraq we have a non-

Speaker: NA
Text: state organisation that effectively controls large amounts of territory and is able to operate

Speaker: NA
Text: close to the state-like capacities in controlling that territory-financial resources and ordnance

Speaker: NA
Text: and military resources. This obviously poses a particular issue for our people, who have to, if

Speaker: NA
Text: you like, deal with the definition of a proper target in those circumstances. What we found

Speaker: NA
Text: was that the translation of what actually existed in international law was not effective in the

Speaker: NA
Text: way that the Criminal Code was developed in dealing with what we had refined through the

Speaker: NA
Text: Rome statute and state practice and experience.

Speaker: NA
Text: This legislation effectively deals with that situation, and it is so important to take away the

Speaker: NA
Text: uncertainty for our defence personnel. We do not want to expose them to any allegations of

Speaker: NA
Text: having conducted themselves inappropriately, potential criminal action and that sort of thing.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: So these amendments open up our targeting possibilities in Iraq, which have been constrained

Speaker: NA
Text: with that problem hanging over our personnel. They will be able to go out there and

Speaker: NA
Text: effectively prosecute operations against those people that we know are actively participating

Speaker: NA
Text: in this conflict against our forces and against the coalition forces and Iraqi forces so that we

Speaker: NA
Text: can bring this operation to a successful conclusion and rid the world, at least at this level of its

Speaker: NA
Text: current threat, of an organisation and of people who are, quite rightly, determined as evil and

Speaker: NA
Text: as a force that must be confronted by the free world and its forces.

Speaker: NA
Text: I commend the men and women of our Australian Defence Force who have been engaged

Speaker: NA
Text: in that effort. It is an effort which is not just about dealing, as we would say, kinetically with

Speaker: NA
Text: the enemy but about building the capacity of the Iraqi security forces so that they will be able

Speaker: NA
Text: to take charge of their own security. Ultimately, the mission is to make ourselves redundant.

Speaker: NA
Text: As in many circumstances we have found ourselves in along those lines, whether in

Speaker: NA
Text: Afghanistan, in Iraq or in other conflicts around our own region-for example, Timor, Samoa

Speaker: NA
Text: and other places-it is about building capacity so that we can not only withdraw our own

Speaker: NA
Text: input but ensure that those locations do not descend back into circumstances where we need

Speaker: NA
Text: to intervene in the future. I think we should have learned a lot of lessons out of Iraq in that

Speaker: NA
Text: respect. Having gone through all the expense of blood and treasure and having spent a year

Speaker: NA
Text: there myself working with coalition forces to try and achieve that result, and failing miserably

Speaker: NA
Text: because we did not address effectively the 80 per cent equation of the counterinsurgency

Speaker: NA
Text: theorem-that is, 20 per cent security and 80 per cent social, economic and political and those

Speaker: NA
Text: two things needing to be meshed effectively-we did not do a good enough job of that, which

Speaker: NA
Text: led to the situation where we are back there now. So it is important that we get it right this

Speaker: NA
Text: time, and this legislation is really part of that story.

Speaker: NA
Text: I reassure the House that, as I have said, the targeting discipline of our Australian defence

Speaker: NA
Text: forces is top-class. It has often been the case in all of the deployments I have been in that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian operators and targeteers have had a very positive influence in the coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances they have been in. We take to the table an approach that has also influenced

Speaker: NA
Text: other coalition partners to be extremely careful with that targeting process, which has had a

Speaker: NA
Text: very positive influence on the way these operations have been conducted.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will say that we are now in this process of the post-US election period, where we are now

Speaker: NA
Text: all looking to see what the new approach will be of the US administration after President-elect

Speaker: NA
Text: Trump is sworn in. Of course, during the campaign there was a lot of hyperbole and rhetoric,

Speaker: NA
Text: as there always is in political campaigns, but there was a lot of talk around how we deal with

Speaker: NA
Text: Daesh and some people may be concerned about whether we would be moving to a new

Speaker: NA
Text: approach that may lead to indiscriminate targeting. Certainly we would hope that will not be

Speaker: NA
Text: the case. Really, it will be a lot about what the appointments of the administration are and

Speaker: NA
Text: how the information and departmental support are dealt with in that process of setting up this

Speaker: NA
Text: new administration, but I do note that President-elect Trump is considering the appointment

Speaker: NA
Text: of General Mattis as Secretary of Defense. General Mattis was with us in Iraq. At the time

Speaker: NA
Text: that I was there, he was in command of the 1st Marine Division, which is a division well

Speaker: NA
Text: known to Australia. Its symbol-its shoulder flash-is the Southern Cross and its formation

Speaker: NA
Text: anthem is Waltzing Matilda. So we have quite a historic familiarity with the 1st Marine

Speaker: NA
Text: Division. General Mattis was quite a character, he said a lot of colourful things and his

Speaker: NA
Text: nickname is quite colourful, but I want to reassure people that this is someone we could have

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: confidence in. He would be a good adviser in circumstances like this. He is someone who

Speaker: NA
Text: grew up in that marine tradition under Commandant Krulak of the Three Block War,

Speaker: NA
Text: understanding those complexities and depths and levels of operation. It is a bit like 3D chess

Speaker: NA
Text: these days, but he understood that. He grew up in that conceptual regime and also helped

Speaker: NA
Text: them write better counterinsurgency, or COIN, doctrine for the marines and the US Armed

Speaker: NA
Text: Forces. So he does understand counterinsurgency theory very well and the judicious use of

Speaker: NA
Text: force, with a very exemplary career in the military himself in many different circumstances.

Speaker: NA
Text: So I would be reassured if he is finally appointed as the Secretary of Defense for a Trump

Speaker: NA
Text: administration.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to, again, thank the members of the committee and those who provided the material

Speaker: NA
Text: for the committee to come up with a good result on this legislation. This committee is

Speaker: NA
Text: providing a very good mechanism for vetting measures on security. Everything that has gone

Speaker: NA
Text: into that committee, in my experience over the last three years as a security adviser for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition and now in this role, has always been improved as it has come out

Speaker: NA
Text: the other end of the funnel and, as I say, always in a very good bipartisan spirit.

Speaker: NA
Text: I commend the legislation to the House, and I salute the service of the men and women of

Speaker: NA
Text: our ADF who will be at the sharp end of implementing the consequences of this legislation. I

Speaker: NA
Text: wish them safe return.

Speaker: Mr CREWTHER
Text: Dunkley) (18:30): I rise today to speak on the Criminal Code

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (War Crimes) Bill 2016. I particularly thank the Joint Committee on Intelligence

Speaker: NA
Text: and Security, which is chaired by Michael Sukkar, for the wonderful work that he and the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee have done on this legislation. We see around the world, in Australia and

Speaker: NA
Text: internationally, an increased international threat of terrorism as well as terrorist acts and war

Speaker: NA
Text: crimes. We have seen, in particular, recent terror attacks, whether it be in Canada, whether it

Speaker: NA
Text: be in Syria or elsewhere. There is a continual threat to our security and our way of life, and it

Speaker: NA
Text: is pleasing to see the committee and the parliament continuing to work to protect us.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indeed, we live in a more interconnected world, particularly with social media, with an

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing need for regional and international engagement. It is crucial that we work with our

Speaker: NA
Text: international partners and key allies around the world, including the United States. Our

Speaker: NA
Text: activities in the way that our defence forces operate overseas have an international impact;

Speaker: NA
Text: they are not just of sole domestic relevance. As the Prime Minister said in his address this

Speaker: NA
Text: morning, 'No one country can fight terrorism on its own.' It is more important than ever to

Speaker: NA
Text: make sure that the way our military operates is compatible with our allies.

Speaker: NA
Text: In Australia we have a dualist approach to international law, which means that, in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: international treaties, we implement them at the domestic level as well to bring them into

Speaker: NA
Text: force. This bill, at the domestic level, alters Australian law so that it is in line with

Speaker: NA
Text: international law. Currently, the inconsistency leaves a gap between laws, which means that

Speaker: NA
Text: legal prosecution is possible when undertaking operational activities. This is something we

Speaker: NA
Text: wish to avoid when conducting legitimate operations. Critical to the protection of our ADF

Speaker: NA
Text: personnel and decision-makers is this legislation, which aims to ensure that organised armed

Speaker: NA
Text: groups such as Daesh, otherwise known as ISIL, who are becoming a greater threat than even

Speaker: NA
Text: some conventional military forces, can be legitimately targeted.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am very pleased to have with me this week a member of the Defence Force Major Rob

Speaker: NA
Text: Marlow, who has served in Iraq as well as other areas. He is doing a terrific job and is with

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: me this week as part of the parliamentary program, in which I recently had the opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: go to Iraq and Syria, in the air, in a refuelling operation, as well as to Afghanistan on the

Speaker: NA
Text: ground and the UAE, to our bases.

Speaker: NA
Text: We cannot keep operating on an outdated understanding of conflict with traditional armed

Speaker: NA
Text: force structures operating simply within the bounds of the traditional notion of states,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly with groups like Daesh, which operates across traditional state borders.

Speaker: NA
Text: Otherwise, we will be constantly playing catch-up in a legislative sense. This, therefore,

Speaker: NA
Text: cripples our defence forces due to an inaccurate perspective of the nature of conflict.

Speaker: NA
Text: Going to the substance of this bill, it will ensure that the changing nature of conflict does

Speaker: NA
Text: not escape our legislative definitions. Prior legislation left our Defence Force and our Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: personnel in a legal grey area, which was restrained by our domestic Criminal Code. This bill

Speaker: NA
Text: goes to the crux of the matter by amending the Criminal Code Act 1995. It makes the

Speaker: NA
Text: distinction in domestic laws between civilians and organised armed groups. This is a

Speaker: NA
Text: distinction which already exists in international law. It applies in the context of non-

Speaker: NA
Text: international armed conflicts as well as regular armed conflicts-that is, a conflict that

Speaker: NA
Text: involves one or more non-state organised armed groups. It is, indeed, a thing of recent times

Speaker: NA
Text: not to be simply facing a state or state-sponsored enemy. An organised group by definition is

Speaker: NA
Text: one which at least has a minimal degree of organisation. It has some kind of command

Speaker: NA
Text: structure or hierarchy. Its existence forms part of a collective purpose that is related to the

Speaker: NA
Text: broader hostilities and involves the use of force to achieve its purposes. It also incorporates a

Speaker: NA
Text: sufficient connection to non-international conflicts and can exist within a larger entity.

Speaker: NA
Text: To make sure that a person cannot be charged with domestic law offences in the incident of

Speaker: NA
Text: a death of or an attack on a member of an organised armed group, even if they are not taking a

Speaker: NA
Text: direct part in the hostilities, is a key aspect of this bill. With Daesh, we see an ideological

Speaker: NA
Text: threat to us, our allies and those civilians and others within the countries in which Daesh

Speaker: NA
Text: operates. It is key not only to combat those who are targeting people on the ground in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: combatants but also to those members of the organisations who might, for example, form the

Speaker: NA
Text: administrative wing and assist those fighters on the ground, who may not be technically

Speaker: NA
Text: fighting but are enabling the conflict aspects of the organised armed groups-for example, the

Speaker: NA
Text: training of suicide bombers, those recruiting fighters, those involved in propaganda or

Speaker: NA
Text: logistics, those who manage social media propaganda, where we have seen Daesh be

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly active on Twitter and other platforms, or those in weapons and ammunition

Speaker: NA
Text: transfer or production.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second important aspect of this bill is the protection of civilians. The bill aligns

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian domestic law with the approach and view of international law when viewed in the

Speaker: NA
Text: context of the international humanitarian principle of proportionality. The principle of

Speaker: NA
Text: proportionality, according to the International Committee of the Red Cross, is:

Speaker: NA
Text: Launching an attack which may be expected to cause incidental loss of civilian life, injury to

Speaker: NA
Text: civilians, damage to civilian objects, or a combination thereof, which would be excessive in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: the concrete and direct military advantage anticipated is prohibited.

Speaker: NA
Text: As Minister Dutton noted in his speech with respect to this bill:

Speaker: NA
Text: The principle prohibits attacks which are expected to cause incidental loss of life or injury to

Speaker: NA
Text: civilians that would be excessive in relation to the concrete and direct military advantage anticipated.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: So this bill does not reduce protections for civilians, and it is definitely important to note that.

Speaker: NA
Text: The amendments to distinguish civilians from organised armed groups, under Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: domestic law, are an important aspect of this bill. Existing protections for civilians remain the

Speaker: NA
Text: same, including for medical people, religious people and those not involved in combat. It

Speaker: NA
Text: maintains prohibitions against deliberate targeting of civilians, and this is a fundamental

Speaker: NA
Text: principle of international humanitarian law.

Speaker: NA
Text: The amendments reflect international humanitarian law stating that civilian death or injury,

Speaker: NA
Text: within the principle of proportionality, do not incur charges of war crimes, including of

Speaker: NA
Text: murder. To reiterate the concept of proportionality regarding civilians, the bill actually

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns where civilian deaths or injury are the result of an attack on a military objective,

Speaker: NA
Text: launched in circumstances where the decision-makers and personnel did not reasonably

Speaker: NA
Text: expect the attack would cause incidental civilian death or injury that is excessive in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: the concrete and direct military advantage anticipated. This is part of the aspect in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: protection of civilians.

Speaker: NA
Text: Having previously worked in Kosovo in the former Yugoslavia as an international lawyer

Speaker: NA
Text: on property rights to do with people who lost possession of their property due to the war, I

Speaker: NA
Text: saw the direct impact of war crimes, as well as crimes against civilians, and the impact of

Speaker: NA
Text: breaches to international humanitarian law. It is definitely important, particularly in the

Speaker: NA
Text: aftermath of conflict, to ensure that laws enable the targeting of combatants while protecting

Speaker: NA
Text: civilians and ensuring proportionality.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill will ensure minimal impact on genuine civilians. It is about ensuring protections

Speaker: NA
Text: do not apply to members of organised armed groups, while at the same time ensuring the

Speaker: NA
Text: adequate protection of civilians. It amends division 268 to provide express recognition of the

Speaker: NA
Text: distinction between civilians and organised armed groups. It is legally relevant and

Speaker: NA
Text: compatible with human rights and freedoms that are recognised and declared in the

Speaker: NA
Text: international instruments listed in section 3 of the Human Rights (Parliamentary Scrutiny) Act

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill ensures that Australia is endorsing and codifying at the domestic level the position

Speaker: NA
Text: of international humanitarian law on the subject of conflict and proportionality, ensuring that

Speaker: NA
Text: we can target both state combatants, as well as armed groups and non-state actors, including

Speaker: NA
Text: Daesh.

Speaker: NA
Text: Realistically, this bill will ensure that our combatants on the ground, including those such

Speaker: NA
Text: as Major Rob Marlow, who is with me this week, can operate while ensuring that they are in

Speaker: NA
Text: compliance with both international and domestic law. So they can directly combat the forces

Speaker: NA
Text: of Daesh and combatants on the ground, while at the same time protecting civilians. It is in

Speaker: NA
Text: exceptional circumstances, of course, that Australia will owe human rights obligations beyond

Speaker: NA
Text: its territory, particularly when this bill operates extraterritorially.

Speaker: NA
Text: I personally would like to thank the committee again for their wonderful work on this bill,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly the work of Mr Michael Sukkar as well as Minister Dutton and others who have

Speaker: NA
Text: had a say directly in the implementation of this bill. I look forward to it passing the chamber

Speaker: NA
Text: so that it will ensure our ADF personnel can operate in the field of armed conflict and ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that they are safe and protected in doing so, whether it is Major Rob Marlow or the many

Speaker: NA
Text: other ADF personnel. I look forward to this bill passing the House and to the implementation

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: of this bill in domestic law, ensuring that we are in compliance with our international

Speaker: NA
Text: obligations.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Code Amendment (War Crimes) Bill 2016. I would particularly like to commend the

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution by the member for Eden-Monaro, and also the member for Isaacs. The member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Eden-Monaro is not only on the Joint Committee on Intelligence and Security, which has

Speaker: NA
Text: looked at this piece of legislation, but, from his previous life in the ADF as a colonel, is an

Speaker: NA
Text: internationally recognised expert on international humanitarian law. He has been in conflict

Speaker: NA
Text: zones and has had to make and advise on rules of engagement. When the member for Eden-

Speaker: NA
Text: Monaro speaks on this topic he is heard around the world by people who respect his analysis.

Speaker: NA
Text: I thank them for their contributions. I also point out that there is obviously a bipartisan

Speaker: NA
Text: approach to this piece of legislation, as is so often the case when it comes to defence matters.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is the role of parliament to make sure that all of our federal laws are fit for purpose, that

Speaker: NA
Text: they address the mischief intended to be addressed, and that there are no unintended

Speaker: NA
Text: consequences when it comes to legislation passed by the Commonwealth parliament. This bill

Speaker: NA
Text: addresses an anomaly in the war crimes offences so that it will target only the mischief

Speaker: NA
Text: intended and cures a potential unintended consequence. Sadly, the current law has not kept up

Speaker: NA
Text: with the nature of global conflicts. Sadly, our Defence personnel are engaged in a different set

Speaker: NA
Text: of circumstances to those from 100 years ago, when people dug trenches and knew where the

Speaker: NA
Text: enemy was. There is an area of law that deals with this. Like state law or industrial law, which

Speaker: NA
Text: I used to practise in, there is, basically, law that deals with warfare or with international

Speaker: NA
Text: humanitarian law. Obviously, a law that simultaneously permits and regulates the use of force

Speaker: NA
Text: might sound bizarre to some people listening tonight, but military necessity and the principle

Speaker: NA
Text: of proportionality are designed to balance the existence of armed hostilities with consideration

Speaker: NA
Text: of humanity.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Red Cross does a lot of work in this area. It was formed out of conflict. Right when the

Speaker: NA
Text: Red Cross was first formed, there was the realisation that people were dying after war for no

Speaker: NA
Text: good reason. Since then the Red Cross has done a lot of great work. I am one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliamentary Friends of the Red Cross and I particularly point out the International

Speaker: NA
Text: Humanitarian Law magazine put out by the Australian Red Cross. In particular, I recommend

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Pen and Sword: Journalism and International Humanitarian Law' to the journalists in

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament House. It raises some interesting questions.

Speaker: NA
Text: International humanitarian law distinguishes between conflict between the armed forces of

Speaker: NA
Text: states-you might almost say traditional warfare-and conflicts in which one or more of the

Speaker: NA
Text: combatants are non-governmental. It also distinguishes between organised armed groups and

Speaker: NA
Text: civilians. This bill will ensure that Australia's domestic criminal laws with respect to war

Speaker: NA
Text: crimes are in line with the requirements of international humanitarian law. Our Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: personnel have been restricted in their operations overseas against non-government groups

Speaker: NA
Text: such as Daesh. Australia's allies, operating under international humanitarian law, have been

Speaker: NA
Text: able to operate freely against these Daesh targets. This bill before the chamber will address

Speaker: NA
Text: this anomaly by excluding from our domestic war crimes legislation criminal liability when

Speaker: NA
Text: organised armed groups are targeted by our Defence Force. It will ensure that organised

Speaker: NA
Text: armed groups do not benefit from the protections that are actually afforded to civilians. This

Speaker: NA
Text: will bring our domestic war crimes legislation in line with international humanitarian law

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: derived from the Geneva Conventions and the Protocols Additional to the Geneva

Speaker: NA
Text: Conventions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Could I particularly mention a former Labor minister, Robert Tickner, who is, I understand,

Speaker: NA
Text: in Geneva at the moment doing great work for the Red Cross. Obviously, the Red Cross is

Speaker: NA
Text: always neutral and has always received bipartisan support in this parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: The legislation before the House has reasonable objectives to ensure that our Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: personnel are protected. We are very lucky in this country. For most of us, if we see an Army

Speaker: NA
Text: vehicle driving down our streets, we are proud. If we see a RAAF plane, we are proud. If we

Speaker: NA
Text: see a naval vessel in our day-to-day lives, we are proud to see that. Our ADF makes us proud,

Speaker: NA
Text: not nervous. That is not the case in all other 200 countries around the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Speaker Buchholz, I particularly mention my hometown of St George-because I

Speaker: NA
Text: know of your connection with it-where ADFA recently undertook some graduate training

Speaker: NA
Text: that was like a hostage situation. I was talking to some friends from St George that were

Speaker: NA
Text: staying with me last week, and they said it was the best thing for the town. It was incredible;

Speaker: NA
Text: all these Army vehicles, and people had to play terrorists and victims. It was a great boost for

Speaker: NA
Text: the town's economy. Hopefully, ADF will recruit some personnel out of St George in the next

Speaker: NA
Text: little while, because the people were very impressed with the young men and women of

Speaker: NA
Text: ADFA-who are some of our nation's brightest-and the way they carried themselves in my

Speaker: NA
Text: hometown. Well done to those ADFA people, who I think will be graduating soon.

Speaker: NA
Text: When we see our ADF personnel, our reaction is that we are proud of them. We always are,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I say hello to those people from our Defence Force that are in parliament this week as part

Speaker: NA
Text: of the parliamentary placement program. Hopefully, they are still keen to be associated with

Speaker: NA
Text: the parliament after seeing it up close. I think, sometimes when you see democracy up close,

Speaker: NA
Text: it might be like watching how to make a sausage. It might be tasty, but you do not want to

Speaker: NA
Text: look too closely at it, and I say that as the son of a butcher.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nevertheless, we must remember the important and dangerous work that our ADF

Speaker: NA
Text: personnel do both here and in far-flung corners of the world. We should never be complacent

Speaker: NA
Text: about their service and never be complacent about our Defence Force. We need to look after

Speaker: NA
Text: them while they are serving, and I would also like to mention the legal officers that do much

Speaker: NA
Text: of that work. I have had some connections with them on the encouragement of the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Eden-Monaro, who pointed out the great work that they do. It is a way to keep a lawyer's

Speaker: NA
Text: shingle ticking over. But part of modern warfare is to be able to understand the laws of

Speaker: NA
Text: engagement. It is not like 100 years ago on the Somme, when you were in a trench and you

Speaker: NA
Text: knew where the enemy was. Now, you might be making life and death decisions about

Speaker: NA
Text: something while sitting in Kansas looking at an image provided by a drone. You might be

Speaker: NA
Text: making decisions about civilians or making decisions about people that are not state entities,

Speaker: NA
Text: rather, they are groups that are using human shields. They are very difficult legal decisions,

Speaker: NA
Text: and legal advice needs to be given to the commanding officers. The modern commanding

Speaker: NA
Text: officer would have a very close relationship with their legal officer.

Speaker: NA
Text: We need to look after them when they are serving and make sure they get the right

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment, the right advice and the right training. But also, we need to look after our service

Speaker: NA
Text: personnel when they return to our shores. I mention our Returned Services League and those

Speaker: NA
Text: other veterans' groups, like Soldier On, Legacy, the Vietnam Veterans Association and many

Speaker: NA
Text: others that do a wonderful job of supporting both current and ex-serving members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Defence Force and their families. In my electorate of Moreton, there are five RSL

Speaker: NA
Text: clubs: Sherwood/Indooroopilly, Salisbury, Stephens, Sunnybank and Yeronga/Dutton Park.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are all doing great work. I have spent quite a bit of time with these clubs over the years,

Speaker: NA
Text: as a member of parliament. I worked closely with them for the commemoration of the 100th

Speaker: NA
Text: anniversary of the Gallipoli landings. The RSL, as we all know, has a very proud tradition. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is one of our oldest national organisations, founded in 1916, so it is in its second 100 years of

Speaker: NA
Text: service to the people of Australia. As well as supporting and serving our ex-service men and

Speaker: NA
Text: women, the RSL promotes a secure, stable and progressive Australia. We are indebted to it

Speaker: NA
Text: for the services that it provides.

Speaker: NA
Text: The orientation of Parliament House is towards the War Memorial, no doubt so that all

Speaker: NA
Text: members of parliament and senators are aware of the sacrifice of those that have come before.

Speaker: NA
Text: Two weeks ago we commemorated Remembrance Day in Moreton and around Australia. On

Speaker: NA
Text: 11 November 1918 the guns of the Western Front fell silent after more than four years of

Speaker: NA
Text: horrific continuous warfare. It is an important day when Australians of all races and creeds

Speaker: NA
Text: remember those who gave their lives for freedom-that horrible sacrifice of 60,000

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian soldiers-and then the damage done after that war to numerous people, too many

Speaker: NA
Text: to count: people who did return, perhaps having lost limbs; the many families who lost family

Speaker: NA
Text: members; and the families of people who returned as well. There was horrific suffering.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also attended a very special ceremony here at Parliament House with the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Veterans' Affairs, where we commemorated not those who died in battle but those who died

Speaker: NA
Text: after returning. It was a very moving ceremony. I am sure the minister would agree. It was

Speaker: NA
Text: quite moving to place a poppy in a cross to commemorate those who took their own lives,

Speaker: NA
Text: sadly, upon returning. I know the minister is doing some good work in that area to look after

Speaker: NA
Text: those who return.

Speaker: NA
Text: Modern warfare takes its toll on our defence personnel not only physically but also

Speaker: NA
Text: emotionally and psychologically. As I said, a decision might be made thousands of miles from

Speaker: NA
Text: where someone might die, but it still will take a toll on our ADF personnel and contractors

Speaker: NA
Text: and all sorts of people associated with modern warfare. Some returning service men and

Speaker: NA
Text: women, sadly, never recover, and some find it impossible to go on. We remembered, at the

Speaker: NA
Text: ceremony here in Parliament House, those men and women who could not find the will to go

Speaker: NA
Text: on, who were tormented by the horrors that they had seen fighting for our freedom, for our

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian way of life. It is important to do all we can to protect the men and women of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's defence forces, both while they are fighting abroad and when they return. This bill

Speaker: NA
Text: will help protect our brave men and women who are fighting abroad on our behalf, in

Speaker: NA
Text: conflicts that sometimes have no boundaries and against an enemy who is difficult to identify

Speaker: NA
Text: and, sadly, will do anything and will not respect international humanitarian law. I thank our

Speaker: NA
Text: ADF personnel for their service and commend this legislation to the House.

Speaker: Ms BRODTMANN
Text: Canberra) (18:55): We are witnessing a rapid transformation in the

Speaker: NA
Text: nature of armed conflict. The world looks very different to how it looked in 2002, when the

Speaker: NA
Text: existing Criminal Code provisions were enacted. We see it today in the rise of organised

Speaker: NA
Text: armed groups such as ISIS and the way these groups engage in non-international armed

Speaker: NA
Text: conflict. The world looks very different, and so do the laws that govern it. So it is appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: that Australian law is updated in accordance with updates to international law.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: The Criminal Code Amendment (War Crimes) Bill 2016 amends division 268 of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Criminal Code Act 1995 to align Australian domestic law with international laws governing

Speaker: NA
Text: the treatment of members of organised armed groups who participate in non-international

Speaker: NA
Text: armed conflicts. The bill recognises the distinction between a civilian and a member of an

Speaker: NA
Text: organised armed group. Members of an organised armed group do not benefit from the

Speaker: NA
Text: protections under international humanitarian law afforded to civilians or medical and religious

Speaker: NA
Text: personnel. These amendments today ensure that members of organised armed groups receive

Speaker: NA
Text: treatment equivalent to members of regular armed forces under the law.

Speaker: NA
Text: These amendments are a reflection of what we have seen and experienced as a community

Speaker: NA
Text: since 2002, and there have been massive changes. We know we are in a different time, and

Speaker: NA
Text: this should be reflected in law. This distinction already exists in international humanitarian

Speaker: NA
Text: law. We should remove all doubt that it also exists in Australian domestic law. These

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments are not proposed with only current conflicts in mind. This is about setting a

Speaker: NA
Text: principal piece of legislation with which to go forward.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, as with any legislation, it should reflect the time. When circumstances change,

Speaker: NA
Text: as always, so too should Australia's legal environment. And we should expect them to change,

Speaker: NA
Text: for the participants in conflict shape the nature of the conflict. We are seeing today armies at

Speaker: NA
Text: war with civilians and with civilisation. With ISIS, we have a flag in search of a nation. Its

Speaker: NA
Text: ambitions are destruction. Its enemies are modernity. Its weapons are anything and

Speaker: NA
Text: everything.

Speaker: NA
Text: But there is a third front in ISIS's war, and it is one that does not get quite so much

Speaker: NA
Text: attention. Its fight is against the West and its fight is against the Muslim world, but its third

Speaker: NA
Text: fight is against female empowerment and all that it allows. Its fight is against women's access

Speaker: NA
Text: to education, women's freedom of association, women's freedom of religion, women's

Speaker: NA
Text: freedom of movement, women's freedom of speech-women's freedom. Its war is against

Speaker: NA
Text: women, and, in this war too, every weapon is fair game.

Speaker: NA
Text: The 2015 ISIS manifesto 'Women in the Islamic State: Manifesto and Case Study' advises

Speaker: NA
Text: that the role of women is to 'remain hidden and veiled'. The manifesto declares that 'women

Speaker: NA
Text: gain nothing from the idea of their equality with men apart from thorns' and that they should

Speaker: NA
Text: focus on their 'divine duty of motherhood'. The same manifesto states that it is 'legitimate for

Speaker: NA
Text: a girl to be married at the age of nine' and that women should not get degrees. According to

Speaker: NA
Text: ISIS, women should only leave their homes in 'exceptional circumstances', such as

Speaker: NA
Text: committing jihad.

Speaker: NA
Text: The United Nations estimates that ISIS has forced some 1,500 women, teenaged girls and

Speaker: NA
Text: boys into sexual slavery-these are old figures; I hate to think what sort of figures we are

Speaker: NA
Text: looking at now-but anecdotal evidence suggests that the true figure is far, far greater. The

Speaker: NA
Text: UN envoy on sexual violence in conflict found that girls from Iraq and Syria were made to

Speaker: NA
Text: engage in the most unspeakable acts of sexual violence. ISIS's justification for these acts, as

Speaker: NA
Text: outlined in its pamphlet-yes, that is right: a pamphlet-on female captives and slaves is that

Speaker: NA
Text: 'it is permissible to capture' and 'to have sexual intercourse' with 'unbelieving women'. Once

Speaker: NA
Text: captured, these unbelieving women can be bought and they can be sold, as-and I am quoting

Speaker: NA
Text: here from the pamphlet on female captives and slaves-'they are merely property, which can

Speaker: NA
Text: be disposed of.'

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: One so called 'unbelieving woman' is Nadia Murad. Nadia was 19 when her Yazidi village

Speaker: NA
Text: in Northern Iraq was captured by ISIS. Nadia watched, alongside her mother and sisters, as

Speaker: NA
Text: the men in the village-including her brothers-were brutally slaughtered. For the next eight

Speaker: NA
Text: months, Nadia was abused and she was raped by ISIS troops. She was held in captivity by 13

Speaker: NA
Text: different 'owners'. Nadia, 19 years old, from a Yazidi village in Northern Iraq was held in

Speaker: NA
Text: captivity by 13 different 'owners'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nadia is a reminder of why it is important that we note this third front, the impact on

Speaker: NA
Text: women-and not because it is a new one. The Book of Lamentations recounts that: 'Women

Speaker: NA
Text: have been ravished in Zion, and virgins in the towns of Judah.' During the 15th and 16th

Speaker: NA
Text: centuries, throughout much of the world, the right to commit acts of sexual violence against

Speaker: NA
Text: the objects of one's conquest was considered a form of earned compensation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Second World War showed us a level of human tragedy that we have never seen. It

Speaker: NA
Text: was in this context that the character of sexual violence in conflict was altered, because it

Speaker: NA
Text: became mechanised then. To use one example, it is estimated that the Soviet army raped

Speaker: NA
Text: anywhere between one million and two million women in Eastern Europe and Germany

Speaker: NA
Text: during one year, 1945. So: the Soviet army raped one million to two million women in

Speaker: NA
