Text: Eastern Europe and Germany during 1945; in one year, one army, one million women.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the Bosnian War, rape was an official order. Rape camps were deliberately established.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reported aim of these camps was to impregnate the Muslim and Croatian women held

Speaker: NA
Text: captive. This occurred in the context of a patrilineal society, in which children inherit their

Speaker: NA
Text: father's ethnicity; hence, the 'rape camps' aimed at the birth of a new generation of Serb

Speaker: NA
Text: children. It was a tool of ethnic cleansing. It was a mode of genocide-and I use that word

Speaker: NA
Text: carefully, because, if what we are seeing today in Iraq and Syria constitutes genocide, we

Speaker: NA
Text: should call it out for what it is. It is a form of crime with a long history, and it is one that

Speaker: NA
Text: needs a new form of response. I propose that we prosecute the perpetrators.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Friday marks the beginning of the 16 Days of Activism against Gender Violence. It

Speaker: NA
Text: will also be the launch of the 'Prosecute, don't perpetrate' campaign, which calls for an end to

Speaker: NA
Text: the impunity currently enjoyed by those who commit acts of sexual violence in the theatre of

Speaker: NA
Text: armed conflict. The 'Prosecute, don't perpetrate' campaign calls for the investigation and

Speaker: NA
Text: prosecution of sexual violence committed by Australians who have travelled to Iraq and Syria

Speaker: NA
Text: to fight with Daesh.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know that Daesh has used sexual violence as a tactic of war. Sexual violence is a war

Speaker: NA
Text: crime, and we should treat it as such. The occurrence of systematic rape is well documented

Speaker: NA
Text: in Iraq and Syria. It is a crime against humanity; it is a crime against women; and we should

Speaker: NA
Text: treat it as such. The United Nations Human Rights Council has published reports of Daesh's

Speaker: NA
Text: intentions to impose: 'measures to prevent Yazidi children from being born'. This is genocide,

Speaker: NA
Text: and we should treat it as such. By some accounts-and we have heard quite a bit about it this

Speaker: NA
Text: week-over 100 Australians have travelled to Iraq and Syria to fight with Daesh and other

Speaker: NA
Text: extremist groups. We need to investigate and prosecute the sexual violence they have

Speaker: NA
Text: perpetrated as war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocide, for these are all crimes

Speaker: NA
Text: under Australian domestic legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: We also need to remind ourselves that sexual violence in conflict is not inevitable. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: that everyone just thinks that this is basically the by-product of war-the raping of women;

Speaker: NA
Text: the raping of small girls; the raping of small boys-and just thinks, 'Oh, gee; that's bad, but

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: this is just a by-product of war.' We saw it with the Second World War. We saw it in Bosnia.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not simply a sad consequence of war. It is how war is now being fought, and ISIS is using

Speaker: NA
Text: sexual violence as a weapon of war-as an orchestrated, coordinated, industrialised tactic of

Speaker: NA
Text: terror. It is a horrifying evolution of an age-old practice, and it is now the means to a very

Speaker: NA
Text: different end. And its use is a crime we cannot excuse.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to conclude by thanking a range of women who have been very active in this space

Speaker: NA
Text: for a very long time, who are still maintaining the rage and who are behind this campaign to

Speaker: NA
Text: prosecute, not perpetrate. I have met most of these women since I have been in the shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence portfolio over the last four years. I have met most of them through the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Strategic Policy Institute, which has a number of seminars on women, peace and security and

Speaker: NA
Text: the range of UN resolutions that have emerged in this area.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is very important that we keep discussing this issue and that we do not just sweep it

Speaker: NA
Text: under the carpet. It is important that we keep maintaining the rage about this issue, because it

Speaker: NA
Text: is not something that is going to go away by our basically just saying, 'Oh, sorry, but that is

Speaker: NA
Text: just a by-product of war; we're just going to have to put up with it.' It is unacceptable. As I

Speaker: NA
Text: said: women are being raped-and not just raped; enslaved. Nadia had-what was it?-13

Speaker: NA
Text: 'owners'. Small children-small girls and boys-are being raped and held as sex slaves, with

Speaker: NA
Text: 13 owners plus. It is unacceptable. It is brutal. It is hard to imagine the lives that these women

Speaker: NA
Text: are enduring under this hideous, monstrous existence.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to do a call-out to a number of people who have been very active in keeping this

Speaker: NA
Text: issue on the agenda and reminding us as leaders and as a community that we cannot take our

Speaker: NA
Text: eye off this issue. We do need to maintain our attention on this issue. I want to, first of all,

Speaker: NA
Text: thank Peter Jennings and his team at the Australian Strategic Policy Institute for having

Speaker: NA
Text: regular seminars on this issue. I was at a panel discussion probably a month ago where we had

Speaker: NA
Text: a woman who had just been involved in representing Australia on the UN 1325 and other

Speaker: NA
Text: resolutions. We also had Brad Orchard, from the Department of Defence, who is actually

Speaker: NA
Text: implementing the UN 1325 and other resolutions from the defence perspective.

Speaker: NA
Text: We also had the wonderful Jennifer Wittwer, who is going to be our new representative in

Speaker: NA
Text: the UN, hopefully shortly. I understand she has had a bit of a bad bout with health but has

Speaker: NA
Text: recently got the all-clear. So she will, I hope, be winging her way to New York to be a

Speaker: NA
Text: fantastic representative for Australia in the very near future. I also want to thank Lisa

Speaker: NA
Text: Sharland, who has been very, very active in this space for a long time. She is probably one of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's leading experts on women, peace and security. She has worked on this issue in

Speaker: NA
Text: Africa, the United States, Europe and Asia. She is one of our leading experts here in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. Again, I want to thank her for educating me on this issue and constantly bringing to

Speaker: NA
Text: my attention the fact that we need to maintain the rage.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also want to thank Susan Hutchinson for her continuing campaigning on this most crucial

Speaker: NA
Text: issue. I spoke about this issue yesterday and it was wonderful to have Susan in the gallery

Speaker: NA
Text: listening to the speech. She is an expert on women, peace and security and she has

Speaker: NA
Text: championed this issue with energy and dedication. She recognises, as I do, that asking for

Speaker: NA
Text: existing laws to be enforced should not be a controversial demand, should not really be much

Speaker: NA
Text: of a big ask. She recognises, as I do, that we should never excuse or tolerate incidents of

Speaker: NA
Text: sexual violence in armed conflict. She recognises, as I do, that we have the power to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: justice to the victims of these heinous crimes.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: War crimes are criminalised in the Geneva Conventions Act 1957 and the War Crimes Act

Speaker: NA
Text: 1945. Genocide and crimes against humanity are outlawed in the International Criminal Court

Speaker: NA
Text: Act 2002. These laws need to be implemented. International law matters, and these laws need

Speaker: NA
Text: to be implemented. That is why we propose to amend the Criminal Code to better reflect it.

Speaker: NA
Text: We seek to harmonise international humanitarian law with Australian domestic law, because

Speaker: NA
Text: we recognise that the challenge we share is a common one.

Speaker: Mr KEENAN
Text: Stirling-Minister for Justice and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Counter-Terrorism) (19:10): I thank all members who have participated in this debate on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Criminal Code Amendment (War Crimes) Bill 2016. National security does deserve a

Speaker: NA
Text: bipartisan approach from this parliament. To date, this parliament has provided that approach

Speaker: NA
Text: and I think it is a good reflection on the fact that, in this vitally important policy area, we can

Speaker: NA
Text: work together to make sure that Australia is as safe as we can possibly make it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Passage of the Criminal Code Amendment (War Crimes) Bill 2016 will ensure that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Defence Force can conduct targeted operations against organised armed groups,

Speaker: NA
Text: such as the military arm of Daesh, to the extent permitted by international humanitarian law.

Speaker: NA
Text: These amendments also provide important legal certainty for ADF personnel in undertaking

Speaker: NA
Text: those operations. As the Prime Minister outlined in the House today in his address to

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament on national security and counterterrorism, this bill is part of a suite of actions taken

Speaker: NA
Text: by the government to empower our agencies and our defence forces to keep us safe. The bill

Speaker: NA
Text: has been subjected to careful scrutiny by the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Intelligence

Speaker: NA
Text: and Security, which concluded that the amendments would provide appropriate protection for

Speaker: NA
Text: civilians, while maintaining the capacity to conduct operations against legitimate military

Speaker: NA
Text: targets.

Speaker: NA
Text: I did not have the opportunity to listen to every contributor to this debate, although I did

Speaker: NA
Text: catch a lot of what the member for Canberra said. She reminded us about the barbarity of the

Speaker: NA
Text: enemy that we are facing and the sexual violence, the enslavement of women and men-

Speaker: NA
Text: imagine an organisation that has been brought back slavery on an industrial scale-and the

Speaker: NA
Text: crucifixions. I had a very productive meeting with the King of Jordan this afternoon and,

Speaker: NA
Text: during that meeting, I learnt that one of his pilots was put in a cage and burnt alive, and that

Speaker: NA
Text: that was then used as propaganda in the course of the Islamic State. They throw homosexuals

Speaker: NA
Text: from roofs if they are discovered. What they inflict on the populations that have been under

Speaker: NA
Text: their control is an affront to basic human decency.

Speaker: NA
Text: We should be very proud of the fact that the Australian Defence Force is out there targeting

Speaker: NA
Text: them, killing them and ultimately defeating them. These are people who are pure evil. I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: say that in any hyperboles way; look at their actions. We do need to call it out for what it is

Speaker: NA
Text: and we should all join together to support the work that the ADF is doing. This bill makes

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that the ADF are not subject to any legal ramifications as a result of their very deliberate,

Speaker: NA
Text: targeted and effective actions in defeating this barbaric enemy.

Speaker: NA
Text: I thank the House for the support that this bill has been given, and I appreciate that the

Speaker: NA
Text: House can come together to assist the passage of important amendments such as these.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Reading

Speaker: Mr KEENAN
Text: Stirling-Minister for Justice and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Counter-Terrorism) (19:13): by leave-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: COMMITTEES

Speaker: NA
Text: Law Enforcement Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: Membership

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Buchholz) (19:14): I have received a message from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate acquainting the House that Senator Bilyk has been discharged from the Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Joint Committee on Law Enforcement and that Senator Farrell has been appointed as a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the committee.

Speaker: NA
Text: BILLS

Speaker: NA
Text: Civil Nuclear Transfers to India Bill 2016

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Consideration resumed of the motion:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr MARLES
Text: Corio) (19:14): I rise this evening to speak in favour of and, in the process,

Speaker: NA
Text: to indicate Labor's support for the Civil Nuclear Transfers to India Bill 2016. Labor supports

Speaker: NA
Text: peaceful nuclear cooperation with India, which includes the exportation of uranium to India

Speaker: NA
Text: subject to a range of strong safeguards, many of which were assisted, facilitated and, indeed,

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiated by the previous Labor government with the government of India. What this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: will in essence do is provide certainty for the Australian export of uranium to India in the

Speaker: NA
Text: context of our law. That is important because, in turn, it will provide certainty to exporters

Speaker: NA
Text: here in Australia, which will assist in creating Australian jobs; it will provide a benefit to

Speaker: NA
Text: India, which desperately needs the development of a civil nuclear industry, and our uranium

Speaker: NA
Text: will help support that; and it will also assist in the development and increasing development

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australian-Indian bilateral relations.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the outset, I want to make it clear that Labor takes a principled approach when it comes

Speaker: NA
Text: to issues regarding the export of uranium. Labor has a history of leadership on nuclear

Speaker: NA
Text: nonproliferation and disarmament. We absolutely and passionately believe in prohibiting and

Speaker: NA
Text: eliminating nuclear weapons as a humanitarian imperative, and we therefore have always

Speaker: NA
Text: taken a judicious and prudent approach to both the mining and the exportation of uranium

Speaker: NA
Text: from Australia. Most importantly, we support the export of uranium to India only under the

Speaker: NA
Text: most stringent of conditions, which ensure that Australian uranium: can only be used for

Speaker: NA
Text: civilian purposes in India; cannot, therefore, be diverted for military uses; can never be used

Speaker: NA
Text: in the development of nuclear weapons; and does not contribute, therefore, in any way to the

Speaker: NA
Text: proliferation of nuclear weapons.

Speaker: NA
Text: Recognising that these safeguards and protections exist, and noting that our bilateral

Speaker: NA
Text: cooperation with India is beneficial to both nations, Labor is supporting this bill. In doing so,

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor recognises the government's urgency in the passage of this bill-acknowledging that

Speaker: NA
Text: there are Australian suppliers close to finalising initial contracts for supply to India, and India,

Speaker: NA
Text: having already worked for over 10 years with the Nuclear Suppliers Group to demonstrate

Speaker: NA
Text: sufficient credentials in this area, is prepared to begin importing uranium from Australia. As I

Speaker: NA
Text: have said, we also acknowledge the need to provide Australian businesses and exporters with

Speaker: NA
Text: certainty. While there is now an urgent need to pass this bill, in our view, this could have been

Speaker: NA
Text: avoided with better planning. It is unfortunate that the government failed to handle this bill in

Speaker: NA
Text: a more timely manner. In the September 2015 JSCOT report, Report 151, the committee

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly recommended, in recommendation 5, that the government:

Speaker: NA
Text: … outline the legal advice it has received concerning whether the proposed Agreement between the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government of Australia and the Government of India on Cooperation in the Peaceful Uses of Nuclear

Speaker: NA
Text: Energy breaches Australia's obligations under the South Pacific Nuclear Weapons Free Zone Treaty.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government has, with more than a year's time, failed to provide this legal advice and it is

Speaker: NA
Text: unfortunate. Australia's international treaty obligations deserve careful consideration, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: government ought to have provided this advice in a timely manner.

Speaker: NA
Text: That said, Australia recognises India's strong nonproliferation record, and we acknowledge

Speaker: NA
Text: the separation that exists within India's civil and military nuclear industries. As I have said,

Speaker: NA
Text: India has worked for more than 10 years with the Nuclear Suppliers Group to demonstrate its

Speaker: NA
Text: credentials in this area. India has diligently pursued its credentials as a responsible nuclear

Speaker: NA
Text: nation, and its work within the global nonproliferation and safeguards system has contributed

Speaker: NA
Text: to its shift towards greater regional and global leadership. Australia's agreement to supply

Speaker: NA
Text: uranium to India has been negotiated with due caution and is supported by appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: international agreements and strong safeguards. The safeguards in place which apply to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's supply of uranium to India are conditions set out by the Nuclear Suppliers Group

Speaker: NA
Text: framework, the International Atomic Energy Agency framework and the Australia-India

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement on civil nuclear cooperation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nuclear Suppliers Group is a group of nuclear supplier countries that seeks to contribute to

Speaker: NA
Text: the nonproliferation of nuclear weapons, of which Australia is a member. In 2008, the NSG

Speaker: NA
Text: declared that, due to sufficient commitment and action taken by India in support of nuclear

Speaker: NA
Text: nonproliferation, nuclear trade with India was permissible. The NSG framework also includes

Speaker: NA
Text: safeguards and conditions, with IAEA safeguards being a condition of supply. Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: exported nuclear material will exclusively remain in India's civil nuclear sector, to which the

Speaker: NA
Text: IAEA applies strong safeguards and independent inspections. These safeguards are

Speaker: NA
Text: comparable to the safeguards that underpin Australia's other nuclear cooperation agreements.

Speaker: NA
Text: India agrees, in relation to uranium imports under the IAEA conditions, that:

Speaker: NA
Text: … no such item is used for the manufacture of any nuclear weapon or to further any other military

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose and that such items are used exclusively for peaceful purposes and not for the manufacture of

Speaker: NA
Text: any nuclear explosive device.

Speaker: NA
Text: Through the Australia-India Nuclear Cooperation Agreement, India and Australia agree that

Speaker: NA
Text: the:

Speaker: NA
Text: … use of nuclear energy for peaceful purposes should be consistent with the objectives of non-

Speaker: NA
Text: proliferation of nuclear weapons and with the respective international obligations of states;

Speaker: NA
Text: Following the NSG's 2008 decision to permit nuclear trade with India, many countries

Speaker: NA
Text: including the US, Canada, France, Japan and Korea established nuclear cooperation with

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: India. Over 10 years ago, India's then Prime Minister, Manmohan Singh, agreed in a joint

Speaker: NA
Text: statement with US President George W Bush, which stated:

Speaker: NA
Text: India would reciprocally agree that it would be ready to assume the same responsibilities and practices

Speaker: NA
Text: and acquire the same benefits and advantages as other leading countries with advanced nuclear

Speaker: NA
Text: technology, such as the United States.

Speaker: NA
Text: At this time, Prime Minister Singh committed to the IAEA process of separating India's

Speaker: NA
Text: civilian and military nuclear facilities and programs. This process also included the step of

Speaker: NA
Text: India voluntarily placing its civilian nuclear facilities under IAEA safeguards. More recently,

Speaker: NA
Text: in January 2015, Prime Minister Narendra Modi and President Barack Obama made a further

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to civil nuclear cooperation, including a commitment to US-built nuclear

Speaker: NA
Text: reactors, which will contribute to India's energy security.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor acknowledges the lengthy and intensive process that India committed to over a

Speaker: NA
Text: decade ago and has been diligently pursuing ever since. India's commitment to non-

Speaker: NA
Text: proliferation and disarmament is not just an advancement of our ability to engage in bilateral

Speaker: NA
Text: nuclear cooperation; it also benefits global progress on nuclear responsibility.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill is consistent with the position taken by Labor when in government and the positon

Speaker: NA
Text: articulated in Labor's national party platform. Labor's national platform supports the export of

Speaker: NA
Text: uranium only under the most stringent conditions and safeguards. Since 2011, the platform

Speaker: NA
Text: specifically allows for supply to India on the basis of our bilateral relations and key steps

Speaker: NA
Text: taken by India towards nuclear non-proliferation. The current Labor national platform states:

Speaker: NA
Text: In relation to India, an important strategic partner for Australia, commitments and responsible actions in

Speaker: NA
Text: support of nuclear non-proliferation, consistent with international guidelines on nuclear supply, will

Speaker: NA
Text: provide an acceptable basis for peaceful nuclear cooperation, including the export of uranium, subject to

Speaker: NA
Text: the application of strong safeguards.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor in government began the process addressed in this bill. In 2008, as a member of the

Speaker: NA
Text: NSG, Australia supported a decision to enable nuclear trade with India. In 2009, as a member of the board of governo

Speaker: NA
Text: Since that visit, the governments of both Australia and India have taken steps to implement

Speaker: NA
Text: the commitment then made by former prime ministers Gillard and Singh.

Speaker: NA
Text: The way in which this bill operates is to make Australia's compliance with our international

Speaker: NA
Text: treaty obligations under the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons and the

Speaker: NA
Text: South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty clear by law. In terms of the Treaty on the Non-

Speaker: NA
Text: Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, it is understood that the obligations under the frameworks

Speaker: NA
Text: which I have just described in many respects equal and even go beyond what is required

Speaker: NA
Text: under the NPT. In respect of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty, there is an

Speaker: NA
Text: argument, which this piece of legislation ultimately clarifies, to make sure that our export of

Speaker: NA
Text: uranium to India is compliant in law with that treaty. It is important to acknowledge that the

Speaker: NA
Text: original intent of that treaty related to nuclear testing within the Pacific and, of course, what is

Speaker: NA
Text: being proposed here does nothing to undermine that. None of the other state parties to that

Speaker: NA
Text: treaty have raised any objection to the very public position that Australia has taken in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: to its export of uranium to India and, in terms of what we do in respect of supporting India's

Speaker: NA
Text: civil energy generation in a way that does not give rise to carbon emissions, there is obviously

Speaker: NA
Text: a climate change benefit that benefits those in the region.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is important to acknowledge the significance of the exportation of Australian uranium to

Speaker: NA
Text: India from the perspective of India. India's civil nuclear energy generation capacity is vitally

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: needed by that country. In India today about 300 million people exist without access to

Speaker: NA
Text: electricity. There is an increasing dependence on imported energy resources to satisfy that

Speaker: NA
Text: rising demand. Its primary energy consumption more than doubled between 1990 and 2011. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is the world's third-largest energy consumer and the third-largest CO2 emitter, and in that

Speaker: NA
Text: context nuclear generated energy is critical to its future.

Speaker: NA
Text: The passage of this bill will also provide significant benefits here in Australia. Whilst India

Speaker: NA
Text: right now represents a modest market for Australian uranium in the short term, it does have

Speaker: NA
Text: very significant growth potential. India's Department of Atomic Energy is seeking to buy up

Speaker: NA
Text: to 1,500 tonnes of uranium from Australia over the next five years. India currently has 22

Speaker: NA
Text: operable reactors, with five under construction and another 20 planned within the next eight

Speaker: NA
Text: to 10 years. As new reactors come online from the early 2020s, Australia could expect to

Speaker: NA
Text: supply a significant part of the 2,000 tonnes annually that India will require. Obviously, as

Speaker: NA
Text: India continues its ambitious plans to grow to where it has 25 per cent of its power from

Speaker: NA
Text: nuclear sources by 2050, our position in that export market is critically important.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, there is also strategic benefit from increased cooperation with India. Australia and

Speaker: NA
Text: India have shared a commitment to peace, prosperity and stability in our region. We share a

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to rules-based order. Australia has a deep interest in not just strengthening the

Speaker: NA
Text: bilateral relationship with India but also supporting India's growing leadership role in our

Speaker: NA
Text: region. It is in our interest to encourage India's growing leadership in the Indian Ocean and

Speaker: NA
Text: across the Indo-Pacific. In 2009, under the previous Labor government, the Australia-India

Speaker: NA
Text: bilateral relationship was elevated to strategic partnership level. We enjoy warm bilateral

Speaker: NA
Text: relationships, including a broad trade and investment relationship and rich people-to-people

Speaker: NA
Text: links. Australia's defence and security ties with India have grown substantially over the past

Speaker: NA
Text: several years. An element of this cooperation is a senior officials level of dialogue between

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and India on nuclear non-proliferation and disarmament. This type of bilateral

Speaker: NA
Text: exchange enhances the capacities of both our nations to contribute to the global advancement

Speaker: NA
Text: of non-proliferation and disarmament. For all these reasons, Labor is happy to support this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate interrupted.

Speaker: NA
Text: ADJOURNMENT

Speaker: NA
Text: The SPEAKER (19:30): It being exactly 7.30 pm, I propose the question:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House do now adjourn.

Speaker: NA
Text: Climate Change

Speaker: Ms ROWLAND
Text: Greenway) (19:30): Australia needs to step up when it comes to action

Speaker: NA
Text: on climate change. Donald Trump's recent election in the United States means that there is

Speaker: NA
Text: now increased uncertainty over the Paris climate change agreement. Even though the

Speaker: NA
Text: president-elect now claims to have an open mind on the agreement, throughout his campaign

Speaker: NA
Text: for the presidency, Mr Trump pledged to cancel it.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the COP22 meeting held recently in Marrakech, it was announced that Fiji would be the

Speaker: NA
Text: president of the COP23 meeting in Germany next year. This is a significant achievement for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Fijian government, and one on which I congratulate them sincerely. Hopefully, it will be a

Speaker: NA
Text: defining moment for the debate around climate change. Fiji's Prime Minister, Frank

Speaker: NA
Text: Bainimarama, whom I have had the honour of meeting on several occasions, used the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment to appeal to President-elect Trump for a change of heart and policy on climate

Speaker: NA
Text: change. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Sir, you have said that you do not believe that climate change is man-made … I am especially alarmed

Speaker: NA
Text: by reports that you intend to withdraw from the Paris Agreement, which would be disastrous for every

Speaker: NA
Text: person on earth. I appeal to you to show the leadership that the rest of the world expects the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States to take on this issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia should support this show of policy leadership in this area from one of our largest

Speaker: NA
Text: Pacific neighbours. We also have a significant role to play in meeting our commitments in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Paris Agreement. For our Pacific Island neighbour nations like Fiji, Kiribati and the Marshall

Speaker: NA
Text: Islands, this is not only a debate about targets and technology; it is a debate about their very

Speaker: NA
Text: survival. These island nations are battling not only against rising sea levels but also against

Speaker: NA
Text: more frequent and damaging storms and cyclones. Cyclone Winston, which hit Fiji earlier this

Speaker: NA
Text: year, was the strongest tropical cyclone ever recorded in the Southern Hemisphere, killing 44

Speaker: NA
Text: people and leaving many homeless. In inviting President-elect Trump to visit his country,

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister Bainimarama brought the consequences of climate change into sharp focus.

Speaker: NA
Text: He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: We will show you how we are already having to move entire communities out of the way of the rising

Speaker: NA
Text: seas and you can meet the families of the 44 Fijians who were killed last February.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians are always generous in helping our neighbours when disaster hits. We were large

Speaker: NA
Text: contributors to help Vanuatu recover from Cyclone Pam in 2015, the Philippines from

Speaker: NA
Text: Typhoon Haiyan in 2013, and Fiji from Cyclone Winston earlier this year, but we should not

Speaker: NA
Text: just be worried when a disaster hits. We can take action to reduce our carbon footprint and

Speaker: NA
Text: assist with mitigation efforts. For example, the IAG's recent report on natural disasters found

Speaker: NA
Text: that every dollar spent on natural disaster mitigation efforts can save at least $2 and help to

Speaker: NA
Text: prevent future losses. The benefits of mitigation are often unseen and expensive, and often we

Speaker: NA
Text: do not fully appreciate them until they are actually needed. It can be a hard policy to

Speaker: NA
Text: prosecute, but it is an absolutely necessary one because, while climate change impacts on all

Speaker: NA
Text: communities, it particularly hurts those who already have the least.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia must do more to help our neighbours, and one of the ways we can do this is by

Speaker: NA
Text: taking serious action on climate change. On that point, I was delighted this week to meet with

Speaker: NA
Text: representatives of Micah Australia from my local area. They are focused on Australia being a

Speaker: NA
Text: good neighbour in our region and helping developing countries who are increasingly being hit

Speaker: NA
Text: by more severe natural disasters. As Micah states: 'Beyond responding to emergencies when

Speaker: NA
Text: they occur, it will be critical that the global community acts decisively to build communities

Speaker: NA
Text: that are resilient in the face of these disasters.'

Speaker: NA
Text: We on this side of the House completely agree, and we know that that is what the majority

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australians want. Unfortunately, we have a government that is full of climate change

Speaker: NA
Text: deniers and a Prime Minister who is beholden to them. This is despite his once declaring that

Speaker: NA
Text: he would not lead a party that was not as committed as himself to tackling climate change.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor believe the science, and we understand the need for real action on climate. That is why

Speaker: NA
Text: we took a comprehensive climate change and energy policy to the last election, including a

Speaker: NA
Text: plan to reduce pollution and increase renewables. If we are serious about meeting our

Speaker: NA
Text: obligations under the Paris Agreement, then the government should strengthen their 2030

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: targets as well as implement real policies to reduce emissions, especially in the electricity

Speaker: NA
Text: sector.

Speaker: NA
Text: I and my colleagues on this side of the House will continue to support real action on

Speaker: NA
Text: climate change in this parliament. We stand with the overwhelming majority of nations that

Speaker: NA
Text: are now committed to reducing emissions and stopping the devastating impacts of climate

Speaker: NA
Text: change. Our Pacific island neighbours like Fiji should not only have Australia's help after

Speaker: NA
Text: natural disaster hits to help them rebuild. We can, and should, do more to make sure their

Speaker: NA
Text: homelands are not washed away by the impacts of climate change.

Speaker: NA
Text: Youth Unemployment

Speaker: Mr VASTA
Text: Bonner) (19:35): Tonight I rise to speak on a vital issue in my electorate-

Speaker: NA
Text: the issue of youth unemployment. I would like to address the effect of youth unemployment

Speaker: NA
Text: on the community and what this government is doing to help young people to find and stay in

Speaker: NA
Text: work. I would also like to mention a local organisation in Bonner that is doing a fantastic job

Speaker: NA
Text: with young locals to help boost their job prospects.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am pleased to say the latest figures show unemployment is continuing to fall and jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: growth is on the rise under this coalition government. Over 50,000 more young Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: have found jobs in the last 18 months, which is a great accomplishment. However, there is

Speaker: NA
Text: more to be done to address the barriers young people face to employment.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have heard many heartbreaking stories from young jobseekers and their parents about the

Speaker: NA
Text: mental strain of searching for work for months on end, and I want to assure my constituents

Speaker: NA
Text: that the government is tackling this issue head on. This year the government expanded on its

Speaker: NA
Text: existing youth employment initiatives such as the Transition to Work service and

Speaker: NA
Text: Empowering YOUth Initiatives program by introducing the $840 million youth employment

Speaker: NA
Text: package. A central part of this package is the Youth Jobs PaTH (Prepare-Trial-Hire) program.

Speaker: NA
Text: Youth Jobs PaTH will give thousands of young Australians a chance to get real work

Speaker: NA
Text: experience and a real job through pre-employment government-funded skills training,

Speaker: NA
Text: internships lasting four to 12 weeks and a youth bonus wage subsidy of up to $10,000 for

Speaker: NA
Text: employers.

Speaker: NA
Text: This program will represent a great opportunity for local youth and local businesses when

Speaker: NA
Text: it launches in April 2017. It will help young people to be better prepared for the workplace

Speaker: NA
Text: and encourage more businesses to hire them. I have been happy to hear from local businesses

Speaker: NA
Text: that are interested in Youth Jobs PaTH, and I encourage more businesses in my electorate to

Speaker: NA
Text: register online to participate and host an intern.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am proud that local businesses and groups in Bonner have already rallied to help

Speaker: NA
Text: disadvantaged youth find work. BABI Youth and Family Service is one outstanding local

Speaker: NA
Text: organisation that for years has been giving young people training and employment

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities. Recently, BABI's general manager, Michelle MCNamara, shared with me a

Speaker: NA
Text: promising new social enterprise project that will involve the whole community to help

Speaker: NA
Text: vulnerable and disadvantaged young people find work. The two-year program would see

Speaker: NA
Text: BABI team up with local businesses and RTOs to deliver valuable counselling, training and

Speaker: NA
Text: work experience for young locals.

Speaker: NA
Text: The program will address the barriers young people face getting into employment, from

Speaker: NA
Text: mental health issues to lack of transport. I am proud to support this project and I look forward

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: to seeing it get off the ground. BABI has serviced the Bayside and Redlands area for over 30

Speaker: NA
Text: years. I commend them for their outstanding work and I wish them all the best in their future

Speaker: NA
Text: work helping young people where they need it most. The government will continue to support

Speaker: NA
Text: local youth employment programs like those run by BABI. I look forward to seeing Youth

Speaker: NA
Text: Jobs PaTH begin next year and seeing more positive employment outcomes for young people

Speaker: NA
Text: in my electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Holt Electorate: Sikh Community

Speaker: Mr BYRNE
Text: Holt) (19:38): I was honoured last week to meet His Holiness Sant Baba

Speaker: NA
Text: Amar Singh Ji at the Gurdwara Sahib Nanaksar temple in Lynbrook for a very important

Speaker: NA
Text: discussion about community resource building for our region. His holiness is a world-

Speaker: NA
Text: renowned figure who has worked with many political leaders, including former United

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingdom Prime Minister Tony Blair, on issues like poverty alleviation, educational

Speaker: NA
Text: development and religious projects around the world. He is truly an internationally significant

Speaker: NA
Text: figure within the Sikh community.

Speaker: NA
Text: Baba Ji, realising the enormous liberating power of education, has opened up schools

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout India and abroad, providing much-needed education to the needy. In 1988, Baba Ji

Speaker: NA
Text: had the foresight to purchase a piece of land in Lynbrook. This is in 1988-a long, long time

Speaker: NA
Text: ago-and there was not a lot out there. He bought this piece of land to build a new Sikh

Speaker: NA
Text: temple and to cater for the growing Sikh population in Victoria, which now totals

Speaker: NA
Text: approximately 45,000 people. At the time that Baba Ji was travelling around the suburb of

Speaker: NA
Text: Lynbrook it would have been, effectively, farmland, so it was great foresight by His Holiness

Speaker: NA
Text: and it took great vision to create that opportunity for the Sikh community to have the temple

Speaker: NA
Text: there. And I am sure that over time, provided that governments of all persuasions provide

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate support, it will become an iconic community based facility.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sikhism is one of the world's largest formalised religions and it traces its origins to Guru

Speaker: NA
Text: Nanak who lived in India in the 15th century. Many of the world's Sikhs live in the Punjab

Speaker: NA
Text: region; however, there are large communities in a lot of other countries, including Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The local Sikh community in my constituency is an amazing community. They are a very

Speaker: NA
Text: integrated community. They are a community that really does make a difference in my area.

Speaker: NA
Text: And they were a community that came to the forefront when we had issues of community

Speaker: NA
Text: concern about community safety, which is now making the headlines in papers like the

Speaker: NA
Text: Herald Sun. But it was their direct face-to-face consultation and input that alerted me to the

Speaker: NA
Text: extent of the difficulties we are facing with community safety in our region-because of what

Speaker: NA
Text: they told me, because of the Sikh community.

Speaker: NA
Text: They were the first community that organised a community safety forum with Victoria

Speaker: NA
Text: Police, which allowed us to discuss this issue. This was during the federal election campaign,

Speaker: NA
Text: so we are talking a long time before it really, in a manner of speaking, hit the broadsheets like

Speaker: NA
Text: the Herald Sun. So I would like to commend them for the work that they have done on behalf

Speaker: NA
Text: of the overall community.

Speaker: NA
Text: After speaking with Baba Ji and committee members Manpal Singh, Raj Singh and

Speaker: NA
Text: Kamalpreet Singh, I look forward to working in partnership with them and to obtaining the

Speaker: NA
Text: approximately $1.2 million dollars in funding that is needed for a community kitchen, a

Speaker: NA
Text: community bathroom, doors, lift, community area and car park to complete the temple.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: But I think also what has occurred in the United Kingdom is that, when Tony Blair was

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister, Baba Ji spoke to him, and they obtained government funding to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: the school was actually built in the United Kingdom. What happened after that is that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: going to become one of the first Sikh universities in Europe. So this is the trajectory I think

Speaker: NA
Text: that this fantastic facility in Lynbrook can follow. The fact that his Holiness has actually spent

Speaker: NA
Text: so much time coming down to Australia, motivating his community and talking to political

Speaker: NA
Text: leaders, like myself, means that we can bring this project to fruition, on a collective basis not

Speaker: NA
Text: just on a singular basis.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is an iconic temple which is yet to be completed, by importantly a school facility also.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have had a lot of discussion about multiculturalism and what it means. But I can tell you

Speaker: NA
Text: what I see with the Sikh community. I see a community that wants to create a facility

Speaker: NA
Text: primarily for the rest of the community not just for the Sikh community. As I said, it is a

Speaker: NA
Text: community that was concerned and wanted to talk to me about their community safety before

Speaker: NA
Text: it became a very popular issue. But it is now a community that wants to build facilities so that

Speaker: NA
Text: they can feed the poor and the homeless. They have a situation where they will feed people on

Speaker: NA
Text: a consistent basis if they can get the centre up and running properly.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the story of Australia. It is a great story, and I will do what I can to assist the Sikh

Speaker: NA
Text: community to complete their mission and their journey on behalf of the community.

Speaker: NA
Text: Agriculture Industry

Speaker: Mr BROAD
Text: Mallee) (19:43): I want to talk a bit about agriculture, because it is

Speaker: NA
Text: something very dear to my heart and because it is also something that is very dear to the

Speaker: NA
Text: economic driver of my community. We have been instrumental-largely under the leadership

Speaker: NA
Text: of Andrew Robb, who is sadly now no longer with us in the parliament and now under Steve

Speaker: NA
Text: Ciobo, the current Minister for Trade, Tourism and Investment-in developing market

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities. Market opportunities are so important if we are going to drive prosperity.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have delivered the free trade agreement with China, Japan and South Korea. I had the

Speaker: NA
Text: privilege of being in Tokyo and Beijing in the last couple of weeks and I can see the benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: of those agreements. We are working on a good outcome for water. What Minister Joyce is

Speaker: NA
Text: doing is trying to bring communities together and deliver the Murray-Darling Basin Plan in a

Speaker: NA
Text: way that also ensures that there is prosperity for our farmers through access to water.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are building the freight links. We have recently committed $220 million to upgrade the

Speaker: NA
Text: Murray Basin Rail Project. That $220 million partners with $220 million from the state

Speaker: NA
Text: government to help us get our product to the port from where we grow it in the north of the

Speaker: NA
Text: state of Victoria.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fourth key element to driving prosperity is access to workers. I just want to touch on

Speaker: NA
Text: the backpacker tax for a little bit. We have a source of workers in our horticultural industry

Speaker: NA
Text: that is made up of some backpackers; it is made up of some Pacific Island workers, it is made

Speaker: NA
Text: up of some locals, it is made up of some contractors. It is important that we have a mix of

Speaker: NA
Text: workers. Ultimately, a backpacker does not take a Australian job. If you get someone who is

Speaker: NA
Text: going to work out in the field and actually pick the fruit and put it in a box, you now have a

Speaker: NA
Text: product that is in a box that someone can market-someone can drive a truck, someone can

Speaker: NA
Text: fix that truck, someone can work as an exporter, someone can be a marketer, a developer and

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: a grower of that product. Without the person that is going to pick the product, the whole

Speaker: NA
Text: system falls down.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have looked at the backpacker tax issue through four key caveats, and I think these

Speaker: NA
Text: caveats remain fair and consistent. Thirty-two-and-a-half per cent tax fails the fairness test. It

Speaker: NA
Text: gets up to over 40 degrees. You cannot expect a person to be out picking fruit in over 40

Speaker: NA
Text: degrees and then giving a third of that money to the government. It just fails the fairness test.

Speaker: NA
Text: Also, though, a foreign worker should pay at least as much tax as an Australian. Currently, a

Speaker: NA
Text: backpacker is paying no tax. They take a tax out at 13 per cent, but they claim that back and

Speaker: NA
Text: get no tax. That does not pass the fairness test. So the argument that a backpacker should even

Speaker: NA
Text: pay 10½ per cent tax, which is what the Labor Party are putting forward with the amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: from Jacqui Lambie, means that an Australian worker is still paying more tax than a

Speaker: NA
Text: backpacker. So that does not pass the fairness test.

Speaker: NA
Text: The third is: the employment of backpackers must be easy to administer. Wherever

Speaker: NA
Text: possible we should be trying to take the red tape and the workload off people who employ

Speaker: NA
Text: people. The fourth is: the workforce numbers must keep coming. This is where I want to

Speaker: NA
Text: touch on the amendments that Senator Xenophon is suggesting to the backpacker tax and to

Speaker: NA
Text: add my weight to those. What he is saying is: currently a person who is receiving

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment benefits, or currently a person who is receiving a pension, can lose much of

Speaker: NA
Text: those benefits if they go out and do a seasonal work job. I have a strong belief that the best

Speaker: NA
Text: way for a person to get a job is to have a job. So if we can make it easier for a person to be

Speaker: NA
Text: engaged in the workforce, they are more likely to then stay engaged in the workforce.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think finding a landing of anywhere between 15 and 19 per cent is fair. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: encouraging and making it easier for people to work a season-and many of our pensioners in

Speaker: NA
Text: my patch would come out and work a season-and not lose their benefits would also be fair. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think we need to land this one. Ultimately, the great opportunities there are only realised if we

Speaker: NA
Text: have people who are going to go out and work in our fields. We can grow the economy. We

Speaker: NA
Text: must give certainly. I think, and I hope, the parliament is big enough to resolve this one

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Defence Force Parliamentary Program

Speaker: Ms RISHWORTH
Text: Kingston) (19:48): The Australian Defence Force Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Program offers a unique opportunity to parliamentarians like myself to gain a better

Speaker: NA
Text: understanding of the roles our ADF play in supporting Australia's national interests in the

Speaker: NA
Text: world.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was joined by my parliamentary colleagues the member for Bruce, the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Solomon and the member for Dunkley, as well as Senator James Patterson and Senator Skye

Speaker: NA
Text: Kakoschke-Moore, in visiting our ADF personnel recently on operations in the Middle East.

Speaker: NA
Text: The ADF currently have four major operations in the Middle East, undertaking missions on

Speaker: NA
Text: land, in the air and at sea. These include Operation OKRA, Operation HIGHROAD,

Speaker: NA
Text: Operation MANITOU and Operation ACCORDIAN. In the short two-to-three-day briefing

Speaker: NA
Text: and training we received on arrival-which everyone deploying into the Middle East theatre

Speaker: NA
Text: of operations is required to undertake-it quickly became obvious to me that there is a great

Speaker: NA
Text: deal of complexity and skill involved in Australia's ongoing contribution to these operations.

Speaker: NA
Text: The ADF leave nothing to chance, and I witnessed their professionalism and commitment to

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: ensuring our deploying troops have all of the training, preparation and support to undertake

Speaker: NA
Text: their missions safely.

Speaker: NA
Text: Seeing firsthand the main logistics hub for the Middle Eastern region gave me a great deal

Speaker: NA
Text: of insight into the scale of support needed to ensure that Australia's success occurs in the

Speaker: NA
Text: offshore operations. As we visited the various missions, I was struck by the range of different

Speaker: NA
Text: roles our people are conducting in these joint operations and the diverse range of skills

Speaker: NA
Text: inherent to our Defence Force personnel.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would particularly like to mention the ADF personnel I met who are supporting the air

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign in Iraq and Syria. Their commitment to assisting the Iraqi forces in the fight against

Speaker: NA
Text: Daesh is a significant Australian contribution to the coalition effort. What especially struck

Speaker: NA
Text: me was the seriousness and professionalism with which they undertook their duties. These

Speaker: NA
Text: personnel clearly understood the grave consequences of their actions, always holding

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves accountable, constantly considering all of the secondand third-order effects on

Speaker: NA
Text: the civilian population before making operational decisions. This was an overwhelmingly

Speaker: NA
Text: proud and humbling experience for me that I was able to hear about firsthand.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would also like to mention 7 RAR, who are based in my home state of South Australia at

Speaker: NA
Text: Edinburgh. The regiment is playing an exceptionally important force protection role for our

Speaker: NA
Text: military, mentoring teams in Afghanistan. I was surprised to learn that several of the young 7

Speaker: NA
Text: RAR soldiers that I spoke to were undertaking their first operational deployment overseas. It

Speaker: NA
Text: was surprising because I could not fault their professionalism and the pride they took in their

Speaker: NA
Text: mission. I also spoke personally with our military mentors who are helping to rebuild and

Speaker: NA
Text: professionalise the Afghan army officer corps training at the Afghan National Army Officer

Speaker: NA
Text: Academy in the Qargha area of Kabul. Our mentors are doing an excellent job to train the

Speaker: NA
Text: trainers at the academy, ensuring that these officers are equipped to provide military and

Speaker: NA
Text: leadership training to future Afghan army officers. This initiative will clearly enable the

Speaker: NA
Text: government of Afghanistan to have a professional and well-trained army to ensure the future

Speaker: NA
Text: security of their country. There was an overwhelming sense of gratitude from the Afghan

Speaker: NA
Text: trainers, who expressed to me their appreciation of the guidance our Australian officers

Speaker: NA
Text: provide them. In concert with the deployed UK forces, it is clear to me that our military

Speaker: NA
Text: mentors are making a valuable contribution to the future of a safe and secure Afghanistan.

Speaker: NA
Text: The time spent on the ADF PP enabled me to see firsthand the investment Australia is

Speaker: NA
Text: making in the Middle East, and our efforts and contribution are significant. Most importantly,

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to acknowledge how hard our ADF personnel are working, both in Australia and

Speaker: NA
Text: on deployment, to support and prosecute the mission we have set them in the Middle East

Speaker: NA
Text: region. Their ongoing commitment and sacrifice-and that of their families-does not go

Speaker: NA
Text: unrecognised by this parliament. I pay tribute to them. Being away from loved ones is

Speaker: NA
Text: extremely difficult and we thank our ADF personnel for the sacrifice they make. I would like

Speaker: NA
Text: to thank Major Gregory Cranswick and Major Briana Sterling for their support. The

Speaker: NA
Text: experience was incredibly humbling. What I can honestly say to this House is that, witnessing

Speaker: NA
Text: our ADF personnel, I have never been more proud to be Australian.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Bihary, Mr Josh

Speaker: NA
Text: Hoad, Mr Lew

Speaker: Mr ALEXANDER
Text: Bennelong) (19:53): Tonight, I would like to recognise and express

Speaker: NA
Text: my gratitude to two friends and two mentors. Firstly, I would like to talk about Josh Bihary,

Speaker: NA
Text: who for the last six years has been my senior adviser-and I will tell you how we got started.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the day before we came here for the very first time and I knew very little about this place,

Speaker: NA
Text: Josh got married. The honeymoon had to wait and Josh travelled the next day and commenced

Speaker: NA
Text: his training of this wayward child in the art of politics. I would come up with ideas; Josh

Speaker: NA
Text: would get the job to deliver them. We saw kids being left out of activities in playgrounds and

Speaker: NA
Text: we came up with the idea of introducing table tennis so kids of different ethnic backgrounds

Speaker: NA
Text: could play with each other and engage. We went to Hyundai with business plans that they

Speaker: NA
Text: accepted, we got table tennis tables put in all 40 schools in the electorate and kids engage in

Speaker: NA
Text: this great sport. We brought the Bennelong Cup here just last week, where eight countries

Speaker: NA
Text: played at the highest level of table tennis. We saw problems in small businesses, where big

Speaker: NA
Text: companies were squeezing them out, and we invented this thing called the Bennelong Village

Speaker: NA
Text: Businesses campaign. We got discounts on advertising, we letter-dropped and we promoted

Speaker: NA
Text: small business. We saw a problem with people with disability not being able to find work. We

Speaker: NA
Text: came up with an idea called Bennelong Gardens and we got the land for them to establish

Speaker: NA
Text: commercial market gardens on and give themselves employment and that independence.

Speaker: NA
Text: When we were writing the maiden speech, we came across the fact that we had never had a

Speaker: NA
Text: plan of spatial settlement and that we had effected this incredible imbalance of settlement. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have been working on that one ever since. We have come up with the concepts of retrofitting

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure and effecting decentralisation through high-speed rail. Many people laugh at

Speaker: NA
Text: high-speed rail, but this can be funded through value capture. Five years ago, when we started

Speaker: NA
Text: talking about value capture, nobody knew what value capture was. Now you will not see one

Speaker: NA
Text: day where a newspaper does not refer to value capture and the power of value capture to

Speaker: NA
Text: retrofit infrastructure into our cities. Infrastructure should be associated with land planning

Speaker: NA
Text: and the combination is dynamic because it uplifts the value of land that you can then capture

Speaker: NA
Text: the value from and create a sustainable funding model.

Speaker: NA
Text: With Josh's integrity and friendship, you would not meet a more honest, decent and

Speaker: NA
Text: hardworking man. Now his marriage has a greater chance of going much longer, until that

Speaker: NA
Text: awful moment when death might part us! They have two beautiful children and I apologise to

Speaker: NA
Text: Karen!

Speaker: NA
Text: This week, I have the great pleasure of having Jenny Hoad staying in my house. On Friday,

Speaker: NA
Text: we will play tennis. That is not that unusual, except Jenny is 84 years of age. I am so pleased

Speaker: NA
Text: to have Jenny, who is Lew Hoad's widow, stay with me. Today is Lew Hoad's birthday. Lew

Speaker: NA
Text: Hoad, in many people's minds, is the greatest tennis player that ever lived. Pancho Gonzales,

Speaker: NA
Text: who was the world champion eight times, said he had no say in the outcome of matches when

Speaker: NA
Text: he played Lew-and then he would say some expletives about what he thought of Lew and

Speaker: NA
Text: what he would do to him on a tennis court. Rod Laver, who was the greatest player of all in

Speaker: NA
Text: many people's minds and won the grand slam twice, said he had no say in the outcome of

Speaker: NA
Text: matches when he played Lew and he thought Lew was the greatest player of all time. When

Speaker: NA
Text: Rod won the grand slam in 1962 and turned professional, Lew had all but retired. Lew went

Speaker: NA
Text: into training for six weeks and the tennis twins Ken Rosewall, the world professional

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: champion, and Lew played a series of 13 matches each against Rod Laver, the man who had

Speaker: NA
Text: just won the grand slam. Ken dominated Rod and won 11 out of those 13 matches. Lew

Speaker: NA
Text: dominated Rod to a greater extent and won all 13 matches-and continued to dominate Rod

Speaker: NA
Text: every time they played.

Speaker: NA
Text: When I was a young boy of 10 years old, Lew gave us a tennis camp. He taught me

Speaker: NA
Text: rhythm, evaluating shots and the essence of professional or percentage tennis. He would come

Speaker: NA
Text: out to our house and look in on how I was going on the way to waterski at the Narrabeen

Speaker: NA
Text: lakes. He was always friendly and engaging whenever I ran into him at Wimbledon or the

Speaker: NA
Text: French Open. He remained a friend. Tragically, leukaemia took him at the age of 60. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed to do a 100-kilometre walk around Bennelong, as we did for motor neurone disease

Speaker: NA
Text: last year, to raise awareness of the great Lew Hoad and raise awareness of and raise money

Speaker: NA
Text: for leukaemia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Timms, Ms Michelle

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Text: Menzies) (19:58): I rise to acknowledge tonight one of Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: greatest sportswomen, Michelle Timms, who just recently was inducted as the first legend in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Basketball Hall of Fame and, indeed, prior to that was named in the

Speaker: NA
Text: international federation hall of fame, only the second Australian to be named after the male

Speaker: NA
Text: player Andrew Gaze. Michelle started with the Bulleen Boomers in my electorate in 1984 and

Speaker: NA
Text: completed her career as a player with the Phoenix Mercury from 1997 to 2001. She

Speaker: NA
Text: subsequently became a coach, most recently the assistant coach of the Chinese national team.

Speaker: NA
Text: She made 264 appearances for the Australian national team. She participated in four world

Speaker: NA
Text: championships and three Olympic Games, winning a silver medal and a bronze medal. She

Speaker: NA
Text: has just returned to Bulleen, where, indeed, her daughter is now playing basketball and

Speaker: NA
Text: hoping to emulate her mother.

Speaker: NA
Text: Known as 'Timmsy', Michelle, at just five feet four inches tall, was one of the grittiest

Speaker: NA
Text: players in world basketball. The point guard player pioneered the involvement of Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: at a world level. With her familiar crop of short hair, she was one of the most feared

Speaker: NA
Text: competitors on the international scene. Let's pay tribute to Michelle Timms for her wonderful

Speaker: NA
Text: career.

Speaker: NA
Text: House adjourned at 20:00

Speaker: NA
Text: NOTICES

Speaker: NA
Text: The following notices were given:

Speaker: Mr Morrison
Text: to present a Bill for an Act to amend the Corporations Act 2001, and for

Speaker: NA
Text: related purposes.

Speaker: Mr Frydenberg
Text: to present a Bill for an Act to amend the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of

Speaker: NA
Text: Exports and Imports) Act 1989, and for related purposes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Ley: to present a Bill for an Act to amend the National Health Act 1953, and for

Speaker: NA
Text: related purposes.

Speaker: Mr Tehan
Text: to present a Bill for an Act to amend the law relating to veterans' entitlements

Speaker: NA
Text: and military rehabilitation and compensation, and for related purposes.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Wednesday, 23 November 2016

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Ms Bird) took the chair at 10:00.

Speaker: NA
Text: CONSTITUENCY STATEMENTS

Speaker: NA
Text: Franklin Electorate: Centrelink and Medicare

Speaker: Ms COLLINS
Text: Franklin) (10:00): Members in this place might remember earlier this year

Speaker: NA
Text: when a Centrelink and Medicare office in my electorate was slated for closure by the coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: government. Senator Catryna Bilyk and I ran a community campaign and had a petition with

Speaker: NA
Text: more than 3,000 signatures, and we managed to get the government to backflip on its decision

Speaker: NA
Text: to close the Centrelink office. What they did was co-locate the Centrelink office with a

Speaker: NA
Text: Service Tasmania office, which is a one-stop shop for state government services. We raised

Speaker: NA
Text: some concerns with the minister at the time and with local Liberal Senators Eric Abetz and

Speaker: NA
Text: David Bushby about the services that would be at this new Service Tasmania co-location with

Speaker: NA
Text: Centrelink and Medicare.

Speaker: NA
Text: In March I got a letter back from the Minister for Human Services, Alan Tudge, where the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister assured me in writing that the agreement with Service Tasmania 'will result in no

Speaker: NA
Text: change to the service offering for Kingston residents'. Sadly, there has been a change in

Speaker: NA
Text: services-and not for the better. Both my office and Senator Bilyk's office have been

Speaker: NA
Text: overwhelmed with concerned people talking about the lack of privacy in the new centre,

Speaker: NA
Text: talking about their concerns about not being able to get the services that they once accessed at

Speaker: NA
Text: the previous Kingston office, and talking about how they are now being told that they need to

Speaker: NA
Text: travel into Hobart for those services.

Speaker: NA
Text: What I do not think the minister fully understood at the time is that the Centrelink and

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare office is the only Medicare office south of Hobart for many thousands of residents,

Speaker: NA
Text: and we are talking about areas where there is not a lot of good public transport. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Centrelink office in Hobart is poorly located and not on a public transport route. It is very

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult for residents from the Huon and Kingborough areas generally to get access to

Speaker: NA
Text: Centrelink and Medicare services in Hobart. We are so concerned about this that Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Bilyk and I have written to the whole Kingston and Blackmans Bay communities asking them

Speaker: NA
Text: to fill out a survey about their experiences at that new Centrelink and Medicare office.

Speaker: NA
Text: What we want to do is go back to the minister and remind him of his undertaking, remind

Speaker: NA
Text: him that he said there would be no reduction in services and prove to him that there has

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed been a substantial reduction in services. What this government is doing to people who

Speaker: NA
Text: are relying on Medicare and Centrelink services is not good enough. They should be ashamed

Speaker: NA
Text: of what is happening to this very important public service that so many of our citizens rely on.

Speaker: NA
Text: When they go to the doctor and they need a reimbursement-yes, it is all moving towards

Speaker: NA
Text: being electronic, but there are times when you need a face-to-face interview. There are times

Speaker: NA
Text: when you cannot resolve your issue over the phone or on an app, or the app is down or you

Speaker: NA
Text: have to wait forever in a queue-for several hours sometimes-on the phone to Centrelink

Speaker: NA
Text: and Medicare. Sometimes you need that face-to-face interaction, and the residents in my area

Speaker: NA
Text: of Kingston, Blackmans Bay and down the Huon deserve that service. I am going to keep

Speaker: NA
Text: fighting for them to get it.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Water Safety

Speaker: Mr EVANS
Text: Brisbane) (10:03): As we move into summer, as temperatures rise and the

Speaker: NA
Text: school holidays start, Australians will be following a long-time tradition in flocking to the

Speaker: NA
Text: water-pools, the beach, creeks, rivers and dams all around our continent. I would like to take

Speaker: NA
Text: this opportunity to raise the awareness of Brisbane families, and all families around Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: of the importance of water safety. Australia, sadly, has some of the worst drowning statistics

Speaker: NA
Text: of any country around the world. It should not surprise anybody to know that the drownings

Speaker: NA
Text: are most likely to occur over the summer period. In the 12 months to 30 June this year,

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia recorded about 280 drownings-in other words, about one a day-and 66 of those

Speaker: NA
Text: fatalities unfortunately were in Queensland. Far too many of those who drowned were kids.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have spoken previously in this chamber about the great work of Kidsafe Queensland in

Speaker: NA
Text: their work to raise awareness around kids' safety and reducing accidents around the home. I

Speaker: NA
Text: want to commend all parents who are taking steps to ensure their children learn to swim. Last

Speaker: NA
Text: week I was able to visit a local business in Brisbane teaching swimming and water safety to

Speaker: NA
Text: children from the earliest ages. I met with Ben Holland and his very energetic and passionate

Speaker: NA
Text: team at the Aquatic Achievers swim school based in Paddington, who are doing great work

Speaker: NA
Text: preparing our kids-and their parents-for the pool, beach and creeks this summer.

Speaker: NA
Text: In encouraging all parents to consider talking to their kids about water safety, taking them

Speaker: NA
Text: to swim schools and enjoying the summer safely, I would also highlight some other benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: of swimming in terms of giving kids a chance to be more active and fit. The recent Active

Speaker: NA
Text: Healthy Kids Australia report card gave Australian kids a D minus for overall physical

Speaker: NA
Text: activity levels. National data indicates that only about one in five Aussie kids is meeting the

Speaker: NA
Text: daily physical activity guidelines, which recommend about 60 minutes a day of physical

Speaker: NA
Text: activity. I hope we can inspire more families to take advantage of their local swim schools for

Speaker: NA
Text: the fitness benefits and also because every drowning that occurs is one too many.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also note that earlier this year the Turnbull government, in conjunction with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Water Safety Council, launched the Australian Water Safety Strategy 2016-2020.

Speaker: NA
Text: The strategy outlines priority areas where various water safety bodies, governments at

Speaker: NA
Text: different levels and other interested stakeholders can work together to prevent drownings. It

Speaker: NA
Text: aims to reduce fatal drownings by 50 per cent by the year 2020.

Speaker: NA
Text: In closing, I would like to commend the work of the team at the Aquatic Achievers swim

Speaker: NA
Text: school in Paddington. I would like to give a shout-out to the Queensland surf lifesavers; to

Speaker: NA
Text: Kidsafe and the many other water safety bodies doing great work around Australia; and to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hon. Sussan Ley, the Minister for Health and Aged Care and Minister for Sport, for her role

Speaker: NA
Text: in launching the Australian Water Safety Strategy. Most of all, I would like to dedicate this

Speaker: NA
Text: speech to the parents helping their kids to learn to swim. I urge all families, when taking to

Speaker: NA
Text: the water this summer, to be safe.

Speaker: NA
Text: Pensions and Benefits: Pension Assets Test

Speaker: Mr CONROY
Text: Shortland) (10:06): On 1 January 2017 the Turnbull government's cuts to

Speaker: NA
Text: the pension assets test will kick in. These will cut the age pension for 330,000 elderly

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians. Nearly 3,000 pensioners in Shortland will have their pension cut or cancelled.

Speaker: NA
Text: The average reduction in income is nearly $4,000 per annum and, since over a quarter of the

Speaker: NA
Text: residents in Shortland are over the age of 60, this will have a profound impact in my

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate. It is another example of this government's appalling attack on pensioners in our

Speaker: NA
Text: community. Pensioners who have done the right thing throughout their lives, pensioners who

Speaker: NA
Text: have made a great contribution to our community, are under relentless attack from this

Speaker: NA
Text: government, which does not care about them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Independent analysis shows that these new cuts will affect half of all new retirees within 10

Speaker: NA
Text: years. More than a million retirees will be affected by these cuts, including 700,000 people

Speaker: NA
Text: who will retire in the next decade. Any pensioner home owner couple with more than

Speaker: NA
Text: $375,000 in assets will have their part pension cut, and any single home owner pensioner with

Speaker: NA
Text: more than $250,000 in assets will have their part pension cut. Currently, for every $1,000 of

Speaker: NA
Text: assets that you own over the assets-free area your pension is reduced by $1.50 per fortnight.

Speaker: NA
Text: From 1 January next year it will be $3. So the most profound impact of this change to the

Speaker: NA
Text: assets test will not be on pensioners at the top end with regard to assets. It will be on those in

Speaker: NA
Text: the middle: pensioners who might have somewhere between $300,000 and $500,000 worth of

Speaker: NA
Text: assets, which is not an unreasonable amount if they have, say, sold up in Sydney and retired to

Speaker: NA
Text: my region to enjoy the much better quality of life. They will be profoundly impacted by these

Speaker: NA
Text: changes.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am proud that Labor and I voted against the Liberal government's changes to the pension

Speaker: NA
Text: assets test. We opposed it in parliament. Unfortunately, the Greens and Liberals did, yet

Speaker: NA
Text: again, another dirty deal to cut the pension. There will be another impact on 190,000

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners if the Prime Minister gets his way and limits overseas travel for Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another issue is the failure of this government to update deeming rates in line with falling

Speaker: NA
Text: interest rates. The government has failed to adjust the deeming rates for more than 18 months

Speaker: NA
Text: despite the official interest rate falling from 2¼ per cent to 1½ per cent. This is another

Speaker: NA
Text: pension cut by stealth.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am proud to be part of the Labor Party, which introduced the pension and gave pensioners

Speaker: NA
Text: the greatest rise ever. Those on the other side, the Liberal-National government, are only

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned with cutting the pension while at the same time giving a $48 billion tax cut to their

Speaker: NA
Text: corporate mates. Yet again it demonstrates the skewed priorities of those on the other side:

Speaker: NA
Text: cutting pensions while giving a tax cut to the richest people in our community. I say: shame

Speaker: NA
Text: on Mr Turnbull and his government!

Speaker: NA
Text: Bradfield Electorate: Stronger Communities Program

Speaker: Mr FLETCHER
Text: Bradfield-Minister for Urban Infrastructure) (10:09): I am very

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased to rise to speak about the Hornsby Eco Garden. This project in Hornsby is funded in

Speaker: NA
Text: part by the Turnbull government's Stronger Communities Program. It will be built on a site on

Speaker: NA
Text: the corner of Sherbrooke Road and Burdett Street in Hornsby, within my electorate, and will

Speaker: NA
Text: give members of the local community a chance to learn some of the principles of

Speaker: NA
Text: permaculture and to generally improve their health and wellbeing.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to congratulate Hornsby council for the work it has done in supporting this

Speaker: NA
Text: important initiative. I particularly also want to congratulate all of the members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: community who developed this concept, secured the support of Hornsby council and then put

Speaker: NA
Text: forward a compelling grant application under the Stronger Communities Program. I had the

Speaker: NA
Text: chance to meet a number of those involved in developing and championing this concept at the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: future site of the Hornsby Eco Garden just a few Saturdays ago. I was extremely impressed

Speaker: NA
Text: with the plans that the community has for the development of this garden and their vision of

Speaker: NA
Text: this garden as being a place where people who live in the surrounding area, including those

Speaker: NA
Text: who might live in apartments and who do not have a garden of their own, to come and enjoy

Speaker: NA
Text: the garden and participate in planting, tending and harvesting of the plants that will form part

Speaker: NA
Text: of this garden.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is exactly the kind of initiative which the Stronger Communities Program is designed

Speaker: NA
Text: to support and I am very pleased at the range and calibre of projects which are being

Speaker: NA
Text: supported under the Stronger Communities Program in Bradfield. Some of the other projects

Speaker: NA
Text: which are being supported include the funding of a Meals on Wheels delivery van for

Speaker: NA
Text: $20,000, improvements to the Triple H broadcasting studio at Waitara for over $6,000 and the

Speaker: NA
Text: purchase of portable goals for the Northern Suburbs Football Association.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a consistent theme across all of these projects, including the Hornsby Eco Garden,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is that this funding supports the work of dedicated members of the community,

Speaker: NA
Text: typically meeting needs which they have identified and which they have taken action to

Speaker: NA
Text: address. This is an example of government funding, in a modest way, supporting very

Speaker: NA
Text: worthwhile community initiatives. I congratulate all involved in the Hornsby Eco Garden and

Speaker: NA
Text: all of the other projects that have secured funding under the Stronger Communities Program

Speaker: NA
Text: in Bradfield.

Speaker: NA
Text: Kennedy Electorate: Water

Speaker: Mr KATTER
Text: Kennedy) (10:12): The annual streamflow of the Flinders River, one of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's biggest rivers, is 6.6 million megalitres. This means that in some years it runs

Speaker: NA
Text: much greater than that and in some years it runs less. The federal parliament and Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: unanimously resolved, with the support of the Greens, to allocate around six million

Speaker: NA
Text: megalitres for the Murray-Darling waters for irrigation. This is around 27 per cent of 21

Speaker: NA
Text: million megalitres streamflow in the Murray-Darling. Applied to the Flinders River, this

Speaker: NA
Text: formula would provide over two million megalitres for irrigation.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, in an extraordinary and appalling decision, the Queensland water resources

Speaker: NA
Text: department of the Queensland government has decided that only 350,000 megalitres will be

Speaker: NA
Text: allocated. Infinitely worse still, it has allocated that 350,000 megalitres to absentee landlord

Speaker: NA
Text: corporations-two of the biggest agricultural corporations in Australia, whose shareholders

Speaker: NA
Text: include two of the richest families in Australia. In sharp contrast, the Hughenden irrigation

Speaker: NA
Text: development corporation, a type of cooperative, requested 200,000 megalitres of the two

Speaker: NA
Text: million megalitres that should be available for irrigation. Within 10 days of the Hughenden

Speaker: NA
Text: community benefit application being received by the Queensland minister-after the

Speaker: NA
