Text: government had sat for 15 months on the application-he rushed the golden handshake for

Speaker: NA
Text: these two big corporations though to a completed allocation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Water is sold in New South Wales at $850 a megalitre. If 230,000 has been allocated to

Speaker: NA
Text: these corporations, as we have heard, then clearly they have received $180 million of

Speaker: NA
Text: allocation: a decision by water resources and their minister to enrich the rich with a $100

Speaker: NA
Text: million golden handshake and to leave the poor infinitely poorer without this water. Since

Speaker: NA
Text: QWRD is only making 350,000 megalitres for allocation, this water is taken, by definition,

Speaker: NA
Text: off the Hughenden and Cloncurry communities, which desperately need that water, and

Speaker: NA
Text: people who live in North Queensland and given to two absentee landlord corporations, both

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: of which may or may not be sold to the Chinese in the near future. Whilst there is no

Speaker: NA
Text: conceivable way one could justify the minister's decision, nor its curious timing, there can be

Speaker: NA
Text: no earthly justification for the actions of QWRD.

Speaker: NA
Text: The history of mismanagement has cost the people of Queensland over $1,000 million: the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tully-Millstream debacle; the Traveston dam; $300 million in inquiries into northern water

Speaker: NA
Text: schemes, with no schemes having ever been built; the Gold Coast desalination plant; and,

Speaker: NA
Text: worst of all, the Cubbie Station decision. A $130 million golden handshake was given to one

Speaker: NA
Text: person, and the officer enabling and facilitating that then moved out to take a position of

Speaker: NA
Text: employment with Cubbie Station. Probably the worst aspect of this decision was that it led to

Speaker: NA
Text: a corruptive water allocation system on the Murray-Darling. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: HealthInfoNet

Speaker: Mr GOODENOUGH
Text: Moore) (10:15): Last week I had the pleasure of meeting Professor

Speaker: NA
Text: Neil Drew, Director of the Australian Indigenous HealthInfoNet, based at Edith Cowan

Speaker: NA
Text: University, who gave me a briefing on his work. I would also like to acknowledge the

Speaker: NA
Text: distinguished contribution of Professor Colleen Hayward AM, Pro-Vice-Chancellor and head

Speaker: NA
Text: of Kurongkurl Katitjin, ECU's Centre for Indigenous Education and Research. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: commendable to have such a leading service operating from our local university.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since its establishment in 1997, HealthInfoNet has been addressing the need for

Speaker: NA
Text: policymakers and health practitioners to have access to the best and most up-to-date

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledge and information about Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health. An important

Speaker: NA
Text: focus of the service is on the development of knowledge exchange tools and resources that

Speaker: NA
Text: synthesise research and other information related to a wide variety of health issues. These

Speaker: NA
Text: resources provided a time-poor health workforce with the capacity to quickly and effectively

Speaker: NA
Text: enhance their knowledge and skills to guide their everyday work in Aboriginal and Torres

Speaker: NA
Text: Strait Islander communities.

Speaker: NA
Text: With over a million visits per year to its web resource, 5,000 easily searchable pages of

Speaker: NA
Text: resources and a bibliography of over 35,000 publications, HealthInfoNet is the go-to web

Speaker: NA
Text: resource for anyone working or studying in the sector. Its suite of knowledge exchange tools

Speaker: NA
Text: and material includes an annual overview of Indigenous health summarising over 300,000

Speaker: NA
Text: health research papers, surveillance data reports and national statistics. It has published 16

Speaker: NA
Text: peer reviewed health topic reviews as well as numerous plain language reviews and

Speaker: NA
Text: newsletters. Knowledge exchange materials now include ebooks, animated infographics and

Speaker: NA
Text: short films. The service is unique in the world, the first resource of its kind, and it is guided

Speaker: NA
Text: by a strong commitment to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander perspectives. It has formal

Speaker: NA
Text: partnerships with a wide range of Indigenous peak health organisations and is guided by over

Speaker: NA
Text: 140 experts on a wide range of health topics. It is recognised internationally and is the winner

Speaker: NA
Text: of many national awards.

Speaker: NA
Text: The HealthInfoNet is aligned with key government objectives addressing key policy and

Speaker: NA
Text: strategic goals identified in national policy documents, including the National Aboriginal and

Speaker: NA
Text: Torres Strait Islander health plan 2013-2023 and the National Aboriginal and Torres Strait

Speaker: NA
Text: Islander Health Workforce Strategic Framework (2011-2015). (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Lalor Electorate: Lalor Heroes

Speaker: Ms RYAN
Text: Lalor-Opposition Whip) (10:18): I have the honour and the privilege to

Speaker: NA
Text: serve the community where I was born and raised and I work hard every day to serve that

Speaker: NA
Text: community, but I am lucky because my community make that easy. It is easy to get up in the

Speaker: NA
Text: morning and go to work every day fighting for a community filled with passionate volunteers

Speaker: NA
Text: and people who work so hard together to build a community. I remember Werribee when it

Speaker: NA
Text: was a small town. Now it is one of the fastest growing growth corridors in the country and a

Speaker: NA
Text: large city of over 200,000, but we still have not lost that sense of responsibility to and for one

Speaker: NA
Text: another that I knew as a child. People in my part of the world do not have a lot, but I think

Speaker: NA
Text: that makes them more generous. When you have gone without yourself, you are more likely

Speaker: NA
Text: to feel the pain of someone doing it tougher than you and give them a hand, and this is

Speaker: NA
Text: reflected in our community everyday.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last month, I had the privilege of holding the third annual Lalor Heroes Awards, where we

Speaker: NA
Text: celebrated many of those local communities, and 27 members of our community who are

Speaker: NA
Text: active volunteers. I want to share those names and have them said aloud in this chamber:

Speaker: NA
Text: Sunil Abbot of Club 60 Tarneit Inc.; Greg Archer from the Rothwell Cemetery Trust and

Speaker: NA
Text: Little River CFA; Wesley Armstrong from the Wyndham Netball Association; Fabian Baynes

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Wyndham Ultimate frisbee; John Campbell of the Wyndham Environment and

Speaker: NA
Text: Community Park; Ritesh Chugh, Australia India Welfare and Cultural Society; Tim Daniels,

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: work that builds community everyday by sharing their passion and passing it on, often to the

Speaker: NA
Text: next generation. We build community everyday in the seat of Lalor by sharing our

Speaker: NA
Text: experiences and working together to build that community.

Speaker: NA
Text: Page Electorate: Schools

Speaker: Mr HOGAN
Text: Page) (10:22): Copmanhurst Public School holds a special place in the

Speaker: NA
Text: hearts of all who went there and recently many students, including some who were there

Speaker: NA
Text: during the 1930s, travelled from far and wide to be at the school to celebrate its 125th

Speaker: NA
Text: anniversary. Also there were former principals Francis Kean and John Molloy, along with

Speaker: NA
Text: current principal Andrew Patterson. To organise this event, a public meeting was held at the

Speaker: NA
Text: Rest Point family hotel, and from there the community got behind the celebrations. I thank

Speaker: NA
Text: Leone Roberts, Don Frame, Philippa Page and Elizabeth Faye from the museum; also the

Speaker: NA
Text: P&C's Franca Scalia, Paul Clausen and Terri and Peter Quiring; and the school's Rhonda

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Dunkel, Latasha Andrews and Tami Parnell. Also helping out were Tod Ensby, Anne Simkus

Speaker: NA
Text: and Colleen Johnson. I thank everyone who organised this, and happy birthday to

Speaker: NA
Text: Copmanhurst Public School.

Speaker: NA
Text: I donate a book to all schools that are happy to accept it for a student for a reason

Speaker: NA
Text: nominated by the school. Today, I would like to acknowledge those whom I know about:

Speaker: NA
Text: Heidi Pitman, Corindi Public School; Hayley Hutchin, Tuntable Creek school; Merlin

Speaker: NA
Text: Bennett, Richmond River campus; Cormac Mercer, Trinity Catholic College; Amellia

Speaker: NA
Text: Andrews, Goonellabah Public School; Kate Mitchell, Alstonville High; Hayley Mitchell from

Speaker: NA
Text: Kadina; Taylah MCMahon from Jiggi; Latrell Hickling, Old Bonalbo Public School; Hannah

Speaker: NA
Text: Czarnecki, Kyogle Public School; Jacinta Berhagen, Bonalbo Central; Will Harris from

Speaker: NA
Text: Eltham Public; Jasper Delman from St Joseph's at Alstonville; Roxanne O'Halloran, Coramba

Speaker: NA
Text: Public School; Patrick Williams-Hardy from Lowanna; Leo Nicholls, Tucabia Public School;

Speaker: NA
Text: Billy Sutherland, Woolgoolga High School; Quinn Lamerton from Larnook; Matilda

Text: Sheehan, St Joseph's at South Grafton; Lucinda Quinn from Wyrallah Public; Dominic Scholl

Speaker: NA
Text: Francis Xavier at Woolgoolga; Izabella Bennett from Dundurrabin; Jessica Deleiuen from

Speaker: NA
Text: Gillwinga; Caleb Ford from South Grafton; Sharhi Ware from Gulmarrad; Jack Smith from

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne Ports Electorate: Arts

Speaker: Mr DANBY
Text: Melbourne Ports) (10:25): The electorate of Melbourne Ports is the heart of

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria's, indeed Australia's, arts community. Some of our major institutions are located

Speaker: NA
Text: there, including the Melbourne Recital Centre, the Malthouse Theatre, the Australian Centre

Speaker: NA
Text: for Contemporary Art, the Arts Centre Melbourne and the National Gallery of Victoria. Some

Speaker: NA
Text: of our educational facilities include the Victorian College of the Arts, The Australian Ballet

Speaker: NA
Text: School, the Victorian College of the Arts Secondary School and our beloved Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: National Academy of Music. On 13 November I was at ANAM to attend a community event

Speaker: NA
Text: that they had put on, featuring their Symphony Orchestra conducted by the dynamic young

Speaker: NA
Text: Venezuelan conductor Ilyich Rivas, accompanied by the equally gifted Elsternwick vocalist

Speaker: NA
Text: Lior, along with staff and guests in a breathtaking performance for the local community.

Speaker: NA
Text: All of these institutions are feeling the pressure from this federal government's cuts to the

Speaker: NA
Text: arts. I have spoken about it many times in this parliament. In most cases the state governments

Speaker: NA
Text: are being forced to pick up shortfalls, as is being done with the Australian National Academy

Speaker: NA
Text: of Music. Anyone who has been to St Kilda knows the famous National Theatre on the corner

Speaker: NA
Text: of Barkly and Carlisle streets, which, after the Second World War, used to be called the

Speaker: NA
Text: Victory Theatre. A wonderful ballet school operates from there-my niece, Shani, attended-

Speaker: NA
Text: and, of course, it has highly developed diplomas for high-end drama workers and dancers.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian National Memorial Theatre's Susan Thacore and I met education minister

Speaker: NA
Text: Birmingham to discuss funding cuts affecting diplomas in acting and ballet. Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: Birmingham advised us that the current model will not be revised for several months and that

Speaker: NA
Text: state governments skills tests need to be looked at, to see whether or not the artists who

Speaker: NA
Text: graduated from there can continue to get VET support. I understand the states are reviewing

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: their skill lists; however, it may prove too late for some students, as two states are required to

Speaker: NA
Text: list before VET-FEE HELP becomes available.

Speaker: NA
Text: The National Theatre Melbourne Drama School graduates include Kat Stewart and Richard

Speaker: NA
Text: Harris from Offspring, Richard Cawthorne, Lawrence Mooney and Bella Heathcote. The

Speaker: NA
Text: National Theatre's ballet graduates include: the great Amber Scott, who is currently principal

Speaker: NA
Text: artist at The Australian Ballet and board director of The National Theatre; soloist with The

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Ballet Jarryd Madden; and Alice Top, a highly awarded choreographer who also

Speaker: NA
Text: graduated from The National Theatre. In the last couple of weeks three of the advanced

Speaker: NA
Text: diploma students have been snapped up for professional caress at the West Australian Ballet

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Singapore Ballet.

Speaker: NA
Text: This institution obviously produces the highest quality drama workers, actors and ballet

Speaker: NA
Text: dancers. It is not the kind of institution that should have been cut back as a result of the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister's campaign against colleges that are producing people from invented courses at the

Speaker: NA
Text: last minute. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Canning Electorate: Dawesville Chemmart Pharmacy

Speaker: Mr HASTIE
Text: Canning) (10:28): In March this year I became aware that the Dawesville

Speaker: NA
Text: Chemmart Pharmacy, in my electorate of Canning, was unable to dispense medications listed

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, making it economically vulnerable as a small

Speaker: NA
Text: business. More importantly, it was unable to perform its primary function as a chemist of

Speaker: NA
Text: providing a basic service to the local community, a community where many people rely upon

Speaker: NA
Text: their local chemist for their health.

Speaker: NA
Text: This was just ridiculous. 'Why?' you may ask. The reason for this is that the pharmacy did

Speaker: NA
Text: not meet the requirements that would allow it to be issued with a PBS approval number.

Speaker: NA
Text: These requirements state: 'At all relevant times there is, within 500 metres, in a straight line

Speaker: NA
Text: from the proposed premises, a supermarket with a gross leasable area of at least 1,000 square

Speaker: NA
Text: metres.' The closest supermarket to the pharmacy at the Dawesville Shopping Centre met this

Speaker: NA
Text: requirement, under the definition of 'gross leasable area', but fell 25 square metres short under

Speaker: NA
Text: the definition of 'gross leasable area retail'. In other words, the pharmacy could not dispense

Speaker: NA
Text: PBS medication because the nearest shopping centre fell short of the size requirement by 25

Speaker: NA
Text: square metres. I call this quibbling. This decision left the community of 7,215 people without

Speaker: NA
Text: suitable access to PBS medications. It is no surprise, then, that when the Dawesville

Speaker: NA
Text: Chemmart started a petition to have this decision overruled, it ended up with 2,300

Speaker: NA
Text: signatures-over 30 per cent of the local population. My office also received a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: letters, emails and phone calls about this matter. Many elderly residents cannot easily travel

Speaker: NA
Text: the 18-kilometre round trip to the nearest PBS-approved pharmacy.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to congratulate the local community for their leadership in fighting this regulation. It

Speaker: NA
Text: shows they have strong, grassroots local leadership. But more importantly, they do not wait

Speaker: NA
Text: for government to fix things, nor do they tolerate bad regulation. To me and to the many

Speaker: NA
Text: people affected by this decision, this was an example of red tape getting the way of common

Speaker: NA
Text: sense. The coalition's priority is to encourage job growth; to encourage small business and to

Speaker: NA
Text: protect Australians from senseless regulation that negatively impacts their lives. That is why I

Speaker: NA
Text: was very pleased to announce that thanks to the Hon. Susan Ley, Minister for Health, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Dawesville Chemmart pharmacy last week received confirmation that it will soon be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: dispense PBS medications. This means that local people will be able to access PBS

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: medicines, and it will also protect that small business-and its employees-from closure.

Speaker: NA
Text: Common sense has prevailed, the Commonwealth government has acted, and the people of

Speaker: NA
Text: Dawesville are the better for it.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Ms Bird): I understand that it is the wish of honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members that constituency statements continue for a further period of 60 minutes. There

Speaker: NA
Text: being no objection, the chair will allow that course to be followed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Perth Electorate: Pride Parade

Speaker: Mr HAMMOND
Text: Perth) (10:31): I rise to discuss a wonderful and momentous

Speaker: NA
Text: celebration that occurred on the weekend in my electorate of Perth, within the City of Perth. It

Speaker: NA
Text: occurs every year, and on 19 November it was time for the annual Pride Parade to

Speaker: NA
Text: commence-there is a reason why my voice has been a bit hoarse in the course of this week! I

Speaker: NA
Text: am very proud to have marched alongside my comrades in Rainbow Labor in the parade. The

Speaker: NA
Text: parade was a wonderful occasion that started on Brisbane Street, went down the heart of

Speaker: NA
Text: William Street in Northbridge and then finished on Lake Street. There were thousands of

Speaker: NA
Text: people involved in the parade, and the overwhelming theme of the parade was 'Love wins'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the banner of 'Love wins,' I was very proud to march alongside other members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party-my federal colleagues from this place, my state colleagues, and also local

Speaker: NA
Text: candidates in the upcoming state election, including our candidate from Mount Lawley,

Speaker: NA
Text: Simon Millman-alongside a Rainbow Labor banner, proudly advocating for marriage

Speaker: NA
Text: equality.

Speaker: NA
Text: What resonated all the way through that march was the feedback from the community-

Speaker: NA
Text: mums and dads, kids, grandmas and grandpas-all of whom were only too happy to join in

Speaker: NA
Text: the chorus advocating for marriage equality. You see, Madam Deputy Speaker, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: overwhelmingly clear that, just because the legislation may have slipped off the radar in this

Speaker: NA
Text: place, the desire and sentiment in our community to make marriage equality a reality has not

Speaker: NA
Text: diminished one single bit. There was uniform endorsement for Labor's position, as we proudly

Speaker: NA
Text: marched along the streets on Saturday night advocating for marriage equality. The reason for

Speaker: NA
Text: the hoarseness of my voice is because I started the chant-perhaps not being the most

Speaker: NA
Text: seasoned campaigner!-right at the start of the march, before realising that I had to keep my

Speaker: NA
Text: tone and passion up for the entire 45 minutes or so. But I tell you what, it was fantastic. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: glad I went out so hard and so early, and maintained the rage, because every single step along

Speaker: NA
Text: the way was met with a glowing affirmation to my calls: 'What do we want?'-'Marriage

Speaker: NA
Text: equality!' And, 'When do we want it?'-'Right now!' And that was precisely what we said

Speaker: NA
Text: from start to finish. Well done, Rainbow Labor-well done, Sonia; well done, Oskar; well

Speaker: NA
Text: done, Andy; well done, Brock-maintain the rage.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mackellar Electorate: Stronger Communities Program

Speaker: Mr FALINSKI
Text: Mackellar) (10:34): I stand before you today to highlight the amazing

Speaker: NA
Text: work that the countless community groups in Mackellar are doing every single day. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: Northern Beaches, we do not wait around for others to fix problems. We come together as a

Speaker: NA
Text: community and we act. That being said, the Turnbull government's message is clear: if you

Speaker: NA
Text: are putting others first, if you get together and make your community a better place, we will

Speaker: NA
Text: support you. Our Stronger Communities Program has seen many recipients of well-deserved

Speaker: NA
Text: funds. The New South Wales Rural Fire Service volunteers on Scotland Island dedicate

Speaker: NA
Text: countless hours and energy to one goal: to help others and strengthen their community. To

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: support their ongoing service they have received $25,000 to fund, among other things, a

Speaker: NA
Text: station extension.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am proud that this government is supporting the Life Education Centre, with close to

Speaker: NA
Text: $10,000 in funding to help provide preventive drug and health education. I speak not only for

Speaker: NA
Text: myself but for the parents of the Northern Beaches in thanking you for your work.

Speaker: NA
Text: Living in one of the most beautiful parts of the world we are so lucky to be surrounded by

Speaker: NA
Text: water-beaches, bays and lagoons. The Terrey Hills radio room of Marine Rescue New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales are but one of the groups of unsung heroes of our waterways. They tirelessly work to

Speaker: NA
Text: keep all of us safe on the water and will finally be able to upgrade their facilities with over

Speaker: NA
Text: $8½ thousand in funding.

Speaker: NA
Text: It would be remiss of me not to thank the thousands of locals, young and old, who take it

Speaker: NA
Text: upon themselves to patrol our 18 beaches every summer we can. Our surf life saving clubs not

Speaker: NA
Text: only keep our beaches safe, but are a place for the community to gather for leadership, for

Speaker: NA
Text: mentorship and, most importantly, for friendship. I am immensely proud that, under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Stronger Communities Program, we have announced close to $35,000 to upgrade the facilities

Speaker: NA
Text: of surf life saving clubs at Avalon, Collaroy and Palm Beach.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Outrigger Canoe Racing Association of New South Wales is a cornerstone

Speaker: NA
Text: group for the numerous paddlers in our community. They will now be able to invest in their

Speaker: NA
Text: GPS location and safety equipment with $8,250 in funding from the Turnbull government.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are the people who ensure all racers have a good and safe time on the water.

Speaker: NA
Text: Port Adelaide Electorate: Ex-Service Clubs

Speaker: Mr BUTLER
Text: Port Adelaide) (10:37): Today I rise to thank and recognise RSLs and the

Speaker: NA
Text: other service organisations in the electorate of Port Adelaide for convening the Remembrance

Speaker: NA
Text: Day services on 11 November this year-from Salisbury RSL to the Seaton RSL, from the

Speaker: NA
Text: West Croydon RSL to the Largs RSL. And, being a port electorate, we also host the Naval

Speaker: NA
Text: Association of South Australia and a very active Merchant Navy Association as well. All of

Speaker: NA
Text: those organisations worked very hard to convene Remembrance Day services this year. But I

Speaker: NA
Text: want to pay particular attention to the Semaphore and Port Adelaide RSL service, which I

Speaker: NA
Text: attend on Anzac Day every year. It is the biggest service in the area; at times, it is the biggest

Speaker: NA
Text: service in South Australia. On Anzac Day it convenes 10,000 people at the Semaphore Angel

Speaker: NA
Text: of Peace. The other reason I attend that service is that in 1924, on behalf of the RSL, my great

Speaker: NA
Text: great uncle laid the stone at the angel at the historic settlement at Semaphore.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to congratulate the sub-branch and President Colin Johns for their service this year.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was a beautiful service that was very well attended by the community. Importantly, it was

Speaker: NA
Text: attended by a number of the school communities in the area. The Alberton Primary School

Speaker: NA
Text: was out there in force and Lucinda Wetherill made a great speech on behalf of young people

Speaker: NA
Text: in the community. Songs were sung by the Dominican Choir and there was generally a very

Speaker: NA
Text: strong level of support demonstrated by the community. As was pointed out by President

Speaker: NA
Text: Colin Johns, this year is the 100th anniversary of the RSL in Australia. I want to pay tribute to

Speaker: NA
Text: the extraordinary work that that organisation has done on behalf of our nation and, in

Speaker: NA
Text: particular, returned service men and women.

Speaker: NA
Text: The theme at Semaphore on 11 November was 'Passing the torch'-the importance of

Speaker: NA
Text: RSLs continually thinking about refreshing their organisations. The point was made that, in

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: spite of that extraordinary work-support services to returned servicemen, advocacy for

Speaker: NA
Text: things like the campaign that my great-uncle Charlie led in the 1920s to ensure that returned

Speaker: NA
Text: servicemen had preference in employment within state public services, and a safe place for

Speaker: NA
Text: returned servicemen to go and be among comrades who understood what they had gone

Speaker: NA
Text: through-it needs to be recognised that it has not been perfect. The Largs Bay RSL in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate was set up because returned servicemen from World War II did not feel welcome at

Speaker: NA
Text: the RSL club at Semaphore. My father is a Vietnam vet and was among 50,000 Vietnam vets

Speaker: NA
Text: who too often did not feel welcome when they returned. The message from president Colin

Speaker: NA
Text: Johns was to recognise the importance of looking to the present and the future, as well as the

Speaker: NA
Text: past. We have 40,000 men and women returning from service in the Middle East who must be

Speaker: NA
Text: the subject of our ongoing attention.

Speaker: NA
Text: Telecommunications

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: telecommunications across my electorate of Barker. Upon being elected in 2013, I was

Speaker: NA
Text: excited to see the coalition government's Mobile Black Spot Program rolled out across the

Speaker: NA
Text: nation. I looked forward to reaping some of these dividends for regional South Australia. The

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition recognised that, in order to attract investment in telecommunications in rural,

Speaker: NA
Text: regional and remote areas, the government needs to incentivise telecommunication companies

Speaker: NA
Text: to invest in the less densely populated areas of our nation. How naive I was to think that our

Speaker: NA
Text: state government in South Australia might too recognise and appreciate this need!

Speaker: NA
Text: Round 1 of the Mobile Black Spot Program included a $100 million commitment from the

Speaker: NA
Text: federal government. In addition to the federal government funding, telecommunications

Speaker: NA
Text: companies contributed $185 million and state and territory governments contributed $87

Speaker: NA
Text: million. I should also pause to acknowledge local government, businesses and community

Speaker: NA
Text: contributions of $1.7 million. This cooperative approach to improving mobile black spots in

Speaker: NA
Text: regional areas across the country resulted in 499 improved or new mobile phone towers from

Speaker: NA
Text: a pool of $385 million. Of the $87 million contributed by state governments to round 1 of the

Speaker: NA
Text: program, the South Australian Labor government contributed a whopping nothing. It is little

Speaker: NA
Text: wonder that South Australia received the bare minimum number of tower upgrades. In my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate, it was a paltry two.

Speaker: NA
Text: Compare this to our Victorian neighbours across the border. The Victorian government saw

Speaker: NA
Text: the opportunity that, sadly, the South Australian state Labor government did not. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Victorian government contributed $21 million to the program. Accordingly, the Victorian

Speaker: NA
Text: government and the Victorians of this great nation received 110 towers. South Australia was

Speaker: NA
Text: competing with other mainland states that had contributed between $10 million and $32

Speaker: NA
Text: million. Our state Labor government put up a total of nothing. Despite a long and dedicated

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign by me and my federal colleague the member for Grey to lobby the state government

Speaker: NA
Text: to contribute a meaningful sum to round 2, Jay Weatherill's Labor government have again

Speaker: NA
Text: failed us, this time putting forward an insulting $2 million. That was all they could spare to

Speaker: NA
Text: resolve one of the major issues for regional South Australians, at a time when they were

Speaker: NA
Text: spending $60 million to shave seven minutes off a bus trip from the northern suburbs of

Speaker: NA
Text: Adelaide. The question remains: what will $2 million translate into for South Australia? I fear

Speaker: NA
Text: it will be very little, and you have Jay Weatherill to blame for it.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Grayndler Electorate: Roads

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Text: Grayndler) (10:43): Today I rise to give voice to the concerns,

Speaker: NA
Text: frustration and suffering of my constituents in the suburb of Haberfield who are being

Speaker: NA
Text: adversely affected by the construction of the WestConnex project. Many have experienced

Speaker: NA
Text: ongoing noise pollution as a result of late-night construction works, as well as increased risk

Speaker: NA
Text: to pedestrian safety caused by large-truck movements in local streets. For several months,

Speaker: NA
Text: residents in Wattle Street and adjoining areas have been suffering from unacceptable late-

Speaker: NA
Text: night noise between 9 pm and 5 am. Older residents and families with small children have

Speaker: NA
Text: been particularly impacted and are finding the ongoing noise pollution very distressing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Residents have informed me that they have continually raised concerns with the Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: Motorway Corporation and New South Wales Roads and Maritime Services about the impact

Speaker: NA
Text: this noise is having on their sleep patterns and quality of life.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unfortunately, to date the response from New South Wales government agencies has been

Speaker: NA
Text: hopelessly inadequate. This extraordinary level of late-night noise pollution is certainly not

Speaker: NA
Text: acceptable. I understand that RMS would prefer to carry out works at night in order to

Speaker: NA
Text: minimise daytime disruption to traffic flows and to expedite completion of the project;

Speaker: NA
Text: however, indefinitely sacrificing the quality of life of hundreds of Haberfield residents in

Speaker: NA
Text: order to meet these objectives is unfair and unprofessional. The failure to police limits on the

Speaker: NA
Text: movement of heavy vehicles in local streets in Haberfield is also posing safety risks for

Speaker: NA
Text: residents there.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are specified routes that trucks working on WestConnex are required to use;

Speaker: NA
Text: however, residents have continually reported to me that drivers are not adhering to this plan.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition to that, some of the work that has been carried out in streets such as Northcote

Speaker: NA
Text: Street have occurred before the notification has gone out to residents saying that this work

Speaker: NA
Text: will occur. When this was raised with one of the workers on site, he said, 'That way we'll get

Speaker: NA
Text: less complaints'. And they wonder why the community are concerned about these issues!

Speaker: NA
Text: Once quiet streets, including those on which primary schools and childcare centres are

Speaker: NA
Text: located, have now become thoroughfares for large and dangerous vehicles because conditions

Speaker: NA
Text: of consent for this project are not being enforced. Added to that is the anguish caused by the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that the head of the planning system in New South Wales, Lucy Turnbull, stated that she

Speaker: NA
Text: was not even aware that houses were being demolished in the heritage suburb of Haberfield.

Speaker: NA
Text: The New South Wales government has a responsibility to protect the amenity of people living

Speaker: NA
Text: in Haberfield; they are not doing the right thing, and they must do better.

Speaker: NA
Text: Goldstein Electorate: Black Rock Life Saving Club

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr TIM WILSON (Goldstein) (10:46): Today I would like to draw attention to the state

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Black Rock Life Saving Club in the wonderful electorate of Goldstein. Over its 88-year

Speaker: NA
Text: history, the club has consistently provided a safe, friendly and welcoming environment for its

Speaker: NA
Text: members and its visitors. The club's volunteers promote the benefits of healthy outdoor

Speaker: NA
Text: activities, water safety, and an awareness of the beach and the aquatic environment that we

Speaker: NA
Text: are so blessed with on Port Phillip Bay. Last year, Black Rock volunteers performed 2,399

Speaker: NA
Text: hours of patrol, assisted a beach-loving community with preventative actions and, of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: rescued those people in need. We are indebted to them for their service.

Speaker: NA
Text: The clubhouse is used by a variety of community groups, including schools, hospitals and

Speaker: NA
Text: sporting teams. We sincerely wish that this could continue, but unfortunately the failing state

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: of repair and the decaying state of the clubhouse is making it very difficult for this community

Speaker: NA
Text: resource to be used by the people who need it and it may be lost. To address this an active

Speaker: NA
Text: fundraising program is underway, but it remains a mighty challenge given the scale of the

Speaker: NA
Text: work needed. This is because the clubhouse at Black Rock was one of eight clubhouses listed

Speaker: NA
Text: as most in need of urgent renewal by the Life Saving Victoria statewide audit in 2011.

Speaker: NA
Text: Precious resources are being wasted as the decaying facilities are in constant need of repair.

Speaker: NA
Text: The first aid room regularly floods, rendering it unfit for purpose. I have been down to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Black Rock Life Saving Club; I have seen the state of the facilities, and it is truly appalling

Speaker: NA
Text: that people who are trying to save people's lives would have to put up with such

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances.

Speaker: NA
Text: Five years after the audit, the clubhouse renewal remains unfunded by the state

Speaker: NA
Text: government, the Andrews government. The president of the club, Simon Tucker, like many,

Speaker: NA
Text: applauds the fact that some clubhouses have been renewed in that time and have been given

Speaker: NA
Text: injections of support to rebuild their facilities. But there is an issue in that there seems to be a

Speaker: NA
Text: very opaque process of allocation of these funds-not necessarily based on what is 'need' first

Speaker: NA
Text: and foremost.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was astounded the state government was funding solar panels for the existing

Speaker: NA
Text: clubhouses-in fact, it has put some on the Black Rock Life Saving Club, even though the

Speaker: NA
Text: state of facilities is decaying and they need resources and money for the rebuilding of it. The

Speaker: NA
Text: state government needs to take a hard look at its priorities, because when it comes down to it

Speaker: NA
Text: there is an absurdity to approving funding for installing solar panels on a decaying clubhouse

Speaker: NA
Text: that is in dire need of replacement when club volunteers cannot even use basic first aid

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities to the extent we need to make sure we can care for people. I genuinely hope that

Speaker: NA
Text: common sense will be restored, and I can assure the Black Rock Life Saving Club that I will

Speaker: NA
Text: do anything to assist and work with them to fix the state of their clubhouse.

Speaker: NA
Text: Gumana, Dr Gawirrin, AO

Speaker: Mr SNOWDON
Text: Lingiari) (10:49): Sadly, on 19 November this year, Dr Gumana AO

Speaker: NA
Text: passed away surrounded by his family and kinship at his homeland of Gangan in North-east

Speaker: NA
Text: Arnhem Land. He was a spiritual man whose life spanned the transition of his country from

Speaker: NA
Text: an exclusively Yolngu reality to the establishment of the Arnhem Land reserve and the birth

Speaker: NA
Text: of land rights. He is mourned by all Yolngu people of East Arnhem Land as the last of the

Speaker: NA
Text: great lawmen in the area, but also as a humble, kind, patient, gentle and friendly man with a

Speaker: NA
Text: razor-sharp mind and a fierce resoluteness in the face of injustice. He was esteemed by all the

Speaker: NA
Text: Balanda who knew him, and I was privileged to know him well.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Gumana spoke about a vengeance massacre of up to 30 of his people at Gangan when

Speaker: NA
Text: he was a young boy. The young Dr Gumana suffered from Hansen's disease, or leprosy,

Speaker: NA
Text: which caused him the loss of a majority of his fingers and toes, and he was sent to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Channel Island leprosarium at around the age of eight. This was a notorious prison-like

Speaker: NA
Text: hellhole of depravation and neglect. Dr Gumana met and married his wife at Channel Island,

Speaker: NA
Text: learned English and became attracted to elements of Christian philosophy. He remained on

Speaker: NA
Text: Channel Island for nine years, and his release may have coincided with the patient walk-off in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1946 in protest at the atrocious conditions. When he returned to Yirrkala, his discovered his

Speaker: NA
Text: parents were not there. Undaunted, he paddled for over 20 days by dug-out canoe with a

Speaker: NA
Text: friend to be finally reunited with them at Numbulwar.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Gumana's life has been one of incredible courage and intellect. Following his return to

Speaker: NA
Text: Yirrkala in the 50s, he acted as a bridge between the European missionaries and his people in

Speaker: NA
Text: resolving philosophical, spiritual and practical issues which arose on a daily basis. In 1968, he

Speaker: NA
Text: assisted the Yirrkala people and acted as an interpreter when they took their protest over land

Speaker: NA
Text: to the courts. He acted as an interpreter and cultural bridge. He played a key part in the

Speaker: NA
Text: homeland movement of the 1970s in developing his homeland of Gangan. He worked closely

Speaker: NA
Text: with Lance Bennett and the Aboriginal Cultural Foundation in organising overseas dance

Speaker: NA
Text: troupes in 1982 and 1988. He was ordained a Uniting Church minister in November 1991.

Speaker: NA
Text: He said when awarded first prize in the 19th National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander

Speaker: NA
Text: Art Award in 2002, 'I did not make this larrakitj just for my community, but for the world, so

Speaker: NA
Text: that black and white can walk together.' He was a signatory of the Bark Petition-as a

Speaker: NA
Text: thumbprint annexure-in 1963. He was the last surviving artist of the world-renowned

Speaker: NA
Text: Yirrkala Church Panels, also made in that year, which are housed in the Buku-Larrnggay

Speaker: NA
Text: Mulka Art Centre, which he helped to start in 1976 and which still carries his design as its

Speaker: NA
Text: logo. He was an artist of the Barunga Statement, which hangs in this Parliament House.

Speaker: NA
Text: In May 2003, he was made an Officer of the Order of Australia. He was a wonderful man,

Speaker: NA
Text: and, when asked what else he would like said about him, he replied, 'Tell them I'm a man

Speaker: NA
Text: from the bush.' He was a significant Australian, by any measure.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ryan Electorate: Disability Services

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs PRENTICE (Ryan-Assistant Minister for Social Services and Disability Services)

Speaker: NA
Text: (10:53): I rise to speak on and recognise some of the truly remarkable community

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations in my electorate of Ryan, providing support, friendship and inclusion to local

Speaker: NA
Text: residents with disability.

Speaker: NA
Text: The first organisation, with which I recently met after attending their open day, is eWaste

Speaker: NA
Text: Connection. Established by local constituent Monique Lowndes, eWaste Connection is

Speaker: NA
Text: providing skills, support and friendship to their participants. eWaste Connection partners with

Speaker: NA
Text: the Shed West Men's Shed, local schools and other community groups to dismantle and

Speaker: NA
Text: recycle electronic waste including old computers, televisions or obsolete electrical equipment.

Speaker: NA
Text: By partnering volunteer mentors with individuals with disability, eWaste Connection is

Speaker: NA
Text: assisting people with disability to participate in meaningful work. Through this interaction,

Speaker: NA
Text: individuals gain real world experience in work and developing social skills, while reducing

Speaker: NA
Text: the amount of electronic waste being disposed of as landfill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another wonderful organisation in my electorate is the MCIntyre Centre. The MCIntyre

Speaker: NA
Text: Centre, located at Bellbowrie, does amazing work in our community by providing weekly

Speaker: NA
Text: therapeutic equestrian sessions for around 200 young people and children with disabilities.

Speaker: NA
Text: Established in 1964, the centre provides a range of activities and support services for these

Speaker: NA
Text: young people and their families and also receives incredible backing from the community. It

Speaker: NA
Text: was estimated that in 2014-15 more than 10,800 hours were contributed by volunteers to the

Speaker: NA
Text: successful running of the centre. With figures like this it is no wonder the MCIntyre Centre is

Speaker: NA
Text: always on the lookout for more volunteers to assist in grooming and feeding the horses, lesson

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance and the sorting of donations for MCIntyre thrift shops whose profits help fund the

Speaker: NA
Text: therapeutic sessions. The MCIntyre Centre is an integral part of our community and draws

Speaker: NA
Text: individuals from all parts of Brisbane. They continue to enhance the lives of these special

Speaker: NA
Text: young people and help them and their families thrive in these programs. Acknowledgement

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: must also go to the countless hours of volunteer support provided by many dedicated locals

Speaker: NA
Text: who simply want to give back to the community and see the smile on someone else's face.

Speaker: NA
Text: Recently, I was delighted to officially open HELP Enterprises' new office at Mitchelton.

Speaker: NA
Text: HELP provides innovative employment and training models to support job seekers with

Speaker: NA
Text: disability. I am very proud to have such an enthusiastic organisation with a dedicated

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to disability employment services in my electorate of Ryan.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sadly, there are some people who would not give the slightest consideration to these

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations and those of similar ilk. But for those with disability fortunate enough to

Speaker: NA
Text: participate, these community organisations are providing hope to what are challenging lives.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not just about recycling e-waste or riding lessons; it is offering support and inclusion to

Speaker: NA
Text: those in our communities with disability. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Bass Electorate: Launceston Sewerage Improvement Project

Speaker: Mr HART
Text: Bass) (10:56): Launceston's combined sewerage system dates back to the

Speaker: NA
Text: 1860s. It is clearly insufficient to meet the needs of the growing Launceston community. Just

Speaker: NA
Text: 33 per cent of waste water plants met their environmental licence in 2015. Without a modern

Speaker: NA
Text: standard tertiary treatment plant water quality will not improve, the environment will continue

Speaker: NA
Text: to be degraded and the health and safety of Launceston residents will continue to suffer.

Speaker: NA
Text: Before the last election, TasWater guaranteed $400 million over 10 years to a $1.8 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: upgrade of Tasmania's water infrastructure, with the project contingent upon external funding.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am proud that I was able to seek a commitment from federal Labor to provide $75 million

Speaker: NA
Text: for the extensive works required to consolidate an upgrade to Launceston's water and

Speaker: NA
Text: sewerage infrastructure. I said at the time that it was important to make a start, despite the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that the capital requirement was very significant and the project would take many years to

Speaker: NA
Text: complete. Indeed, the Launceston Sewerage Improvement Project is one of the largest urban

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure projects ever undertaken in Tasmania. Infrastructure Australia has

Speaker: NA
Text: independently assessed the project as a priority. I am of the view that it would be inequitable

Speaker: NA
Text: for the burden of such a significant capital project to fall purely upon the ratepayers of

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania.

Speaker: NA
Text: The failure of the Turnbull government to act on this project and commit to the necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure funding is putting at risk the Tamar River environment and the health and safety

Speaker: NA
Text: of Tasmanian communities. So while I am pleased that the Turnbull government has

Speaker: NA
Text: committed $1.5 million for the Tamar River Recovery Plan, it is less than a drop in the river

Speaker: NA
Text: for what is actually required. This so-called plan is meant to improve water quality, while raw

Speaker: NA
Text: sewage continues to pour into the river. Prime Minister Turnbull needs to stop dragging his

Speaker: NA
Text: heels. This 156-year-old sewer needs to be upgraded now.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is not to mention the four new Green Army projects that promote exploitation of

Speaker: NA
Text: young Tasmanians, paying them much less than the minimum wage. They are not even

Speaker: NA
Text: legally workers and they have no workplace rights. The Turnbull government expects us to be

Speaker: NA
Text: excited that instead of these people enrolling in continued education and training or looking

Speaker: NA
Text: for work, they are forcing our young people to perform manual work for less than award rates.

Speaker: NA
Text: So whilst I welcome the government's commitment in this area I question their commitment

Speaker: NA
Text: to genuine improvements to the river. Only Labor had the strategic infrastructure plan for

Speaker: NA
Text: northern Tasmania and particularly for my electorate of Bass.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Berowra Electorate: Hornsby North Public School

Speaker: Mr LEESER
Text: Berowra) (10:58): I rise today to congratulate Hornsby North Public

Speaker: NA
Text: School on their 50th anniversary. I was very pleased to be able to attend the school's 50th

Speaker: NA
Text: anniversary assembly and celebrations on 18 November, when the school community came

Speaker: NA
Text: together to celebrate the history and the future of the school. It was fantastic to join such a

Speaker: NA
Text: warm and welcoming community of parents, teachers, friends and students. The first school

Speaker: NA
Text: visit I did after being elected as the member for Berowra was to open the Hornsby North

Speaker: NA
Text: Public School art fair, so I have a great connection with the school.

Speaker: NA
Text: The school was built in 1966 in response to the residential expansion in the area of

Speaker: NA
Text: Hornsby following the bushfires of 1957, which caused damage to the existing Hornsby

Speaker: NA
Text: school. The first day of the school for 90 excited students and four staff was 31 January 1967.

Speaker: NA
Text: The school quickly became a hub for the local community, bringing together young families

Speaker: NA
Text: who were new to the area and providing the foundation for strong, long-lasting community

Speaker: NA
Text: relationships.

Speaker: NA
Text: A very active group of local parents established the Parents and Citizens Association and,

Speaker: NA
Text: in the early days, they established the annual school fund-raising event of barbecue and

Speaker: NA
Text: fireworks on cracker night in June. The fireworks became very popular, organised by Howard

Speaker: NA
Text: & Sons Pyrotechnics, attracting up to 2,000 people from across the district. From these early

Speaker: NA
Text: foundations in the sixties and seventies the school quickly developed and grew, adding

Speaker: NA
Text: classrooms, a library block, a school hall and other buildings to cater for a growing number of

Speaker: NA
Text: young families in the local area. Today the strong community spirit of Hornsby North remains

Speaker: NA
Text: a strong driving force behind the school.

Speaker: NA
Text: Several of the original parents have seen their grandchildren-and some great

Speaker: NA
Text: grandchildren-now attend school. Hornsby North has educated the great grandchildren of

Speaker: NA
Text: the original orchard owners of the area that the school was built on and there is a special

Speaker: NA
Text: group of former school students who have joined the staff. The Hornsby area continues to

Speaker: NA
Text: attract new young families. They are attracted by the outstanding educational experience, the

Speaker: NA
Text: band, the choir and the exceptional principal, Maree Sumpton. They are also attracted by the

Speaker: NA
Text: spirit of diversity in the school, most notably on display during the international food fair,

Speaker: NA
Text: which provides the foundation for Hornsby's annual autumn fare.

Speaker: NA
Text: Throughout the school's history its parent body has been partner in the school's

Speaker: NA
Text: development and success. I congratulate the Parents and Citizens Association for its

Speaker: NA
Text: remarkable contribution to the school, led by the current president, Kath Millar, and its former

Speaker: NA
Text: president, Lynne Slevin. I also want to acknowledge a number of the parents who have been

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly welcoming to me and who have been engaged in the organisation of the 50th

Speaker: NA
Text: anniversary. They are Melissa Burne, Carolyn Binet, Donna Westwood, Jenelle MCIntosh,

Speaker: NA
Text: Julie Hall and Alexi Boyd. I also pay tribute to the school captains, Charlie and Sebastian,

Speaker: NA
Text: who will leave the school shortly for their high school adventures.

Speaker: NA
Text: Hornsby North's mission is: 'Caring for children; educating for life.' They aim to educate

Speaker: NA
Text: students to become lifelong learners. This is something we should all be striving for, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: commend Hornsby North Public School for its vision and for the students in its care.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Macarthur Electorate: Tharawal Aboriginal Corporation

Speaker: Dr FREELANDER
Text: Macarthur) (11:01): Today I would like to speak about an iconic

Speaker: NA
Text: community organisation in my electorate of Macarthur, the Tharawal Aboriginal Corporation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tharawal is an Aboriginal community controlled medical and health-care service that is

Speaker: NA
Text: unlike any other health-care service in this country. It has been marvelled at and visited by

Speaker: NA
Text: people such as Sir Michael Marmot, head of the World Medical Association and the World

Speaker: NA
Text: Health Organization's chair of the Commission on Social Determinants of Health, who said

Speaker: NA
Text: that Tharawal was making the fantasy of a fairer distribution of power, money and resources a

Speaker: NA
Text: reality. It uses community empowerment, a community controlling the services needed for its

Speaker: NA
Text: population, to improve things for its own community and for others.

Speaker: NA
Text: As we know, there are major discrepancies between Indigenous and non-Indigenous health

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia. We constantly hear of the shorter life expectancy, higher infant mortality, higher

Speaker: NA
Text: drug and alcohol use and poorer overall health. But what we often do not hear are the success

Speaker: NA
Text: stories, and Tharawal is a remarkable success story. It is simply inspiring. It is led by Daryl

Speaker: NA
Text: Wright and a proactive board, all from the local Indigenous community. Over 14,000 people

Speaker: NA
Text: use the services provided by Tharawal, including: medical, specialist and dental services;

Speaker: NA
Text: child and family services, such as maternal and child health and parenting programs; social

Speaker: NA
Text: and emotional wellbeing services; and healthy-living services, such as tackling Indigenous

Speaker: NA
Text: smoking, the good tucker program and the Lyrebird exercise program.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tharawal places a high emphasis on education and uses education to give many

Speaker: NA
Text: disadvantaged children hope. Tharawal is located next to John Warby Public School, one of

Speaker: NA
Text: the most disadvantaged schools in New South Wales. It works with the school to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: extensive educational support. It also works with incarcerated Indigenous children in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Reiby juvenile detention centre, a short distance away.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tharawal is providing support services for university students, from six universities-in

Speaker: NA
Text: medicine, nursing, allied health and education-to do their practical work. Tharawal has plans

Speaker: NA
Text: to grow its service. However, there has recently been a plan put forward by the New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales government to reduce the land that the Tharawal Corporation leases, consequently

Speaker: NA
Text: isolating Tharawal from the community it serves. This plan is short-sighted and, once again,

Speaker: NA
Text: puts short-term financial gains ahead of long-term community benefits.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tharawal is an organisation we need to foster and promote-not tear down. Services need

Speaker: NA
Text: to continue and be improved. We need to empower people and both major political parties

Speaker: NA
Text: need to have a commitment to protecting and improving Tharawal, which is an invaluable

Speaker: NA
Text: community institution.

Speaker: NA
Text: Swan Electorate: Roads

Speaker: Mr IRONS
Text: Swan) (11:04): I rise today to provide the House with an update on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Manning Road on-ramp, which has been an important local issue in my electorate of Swan for

Speaker: NA
Text: many years. In fact, it has been a project that has been discussed since the 1980s. When I

Speaker: NA
Text: became the local federal member for Swan in 2007, constituents began to express their

Speaker: NA
Text: frustration with the lack of an on-ramp at Manning Road to take the traffic south on Kwinana

Speaker: NA
Text: Freeway. In 2009, I did a survey and I received over 1,000 responses with almost unanimous

Speaker: NA
Text: support for the project. As a result, I have continued to campaign for the people of Swan for

Speaker: NA
Text: the provision of a southbound access to the freeway on Manning Road.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: To provide some background for the House, Manning Road connects Albany Highway to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Kwinana Freeway in the southern part of my electorate. It is not only used by thousands of

Speaker: NA
Text: my constituents but by the broader population of Perth. It is also a key road to Curtin

Speaker: NA
Text: University, which boasts of an enrolment of nearly 40,000 at the Bentley Campus, and is used

Speaker: NA
Text: by many others on their daily commute to the city. However, the real issue is that anybody

Speaker: NA
Text: needing to join the Kwinana Freeway and head south from Manning Road is currently

Speaker: NA
Text: required to navigate a complex stretch of road, do a circle around the freeway which involves

Speaker: NA
Text: heading northwards, merging and then a lane change back across the Canning bridge. You

Speaker: NA
Text: then have to merge with the traffic coming off the freeway to get back onto the freeway. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: the cause of immense frustration, but it is also a very dangerous stretch of road in our great

Speaker: NA
Text: state of Western Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition to this, the on-ramp is more urgent than ever to ensure ease of access to the new

Speaker: NA
Text: Fiona Stanley Hospital, with increased demand from patients needing to head south to attend

Speaker: NA
Text: the hospital or the ED. In November last year, I took the Prime Minister to Manning Road,

Speaker: NA
Text: and he said he could see the need for an on-ramp and that heading south is currently quite an

Speaker: NA
Text: elaborate exercise. And then, only a few months on, this government committed to help fund

Speaker: NA
Text: the Manning Road on-ramp. The need for the on-ramp seems blatantly obvious, unfortunately

Speaker: NA
Text: though, Labor has not supported this. When former member for Perth, Alannah MACTiernan,

Speaker: NA
Text: was a WA minister for planning and infrastructure, she rejected the on-ramp project.

Speaker: NA
Text: Similarly, Senator Sue Lines, with a seat in the Senate, certainly does not start her list of

Speaker: NA
Text: priorities with it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The coalition has listened to the community and committed to this funding during the

Speaker: NA
Text: election. Last week, I met with the Western Australian state minister for transport, Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: Marmion, to discuss the state's share of funding and a potential time line for the project. I look

Speaker: NA
Text: forward to further updating the House and the residents of Swan on this project, and would

Speaker: NA
Text: like to thank all the residents of Swan who have inquired about this project and continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: support it not only through sending their messages of support but also by continuing to vote

Speaker: NA
Text: for the coalition at both the federal and state elections. Thank you.

Speaker: NA
Text: Hunter Electorate: Broadband

Speaker: Mr FITZGIBBON
Text: Hunter) (11:07): Very sadly, the divide between city and country in

Speaker: NA
Text: this nation is growing. It is growing in health, education, government service delivery,

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure and, of course, broadband services. This is the legacy of three years under this

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition government.

Speaker: NA
Text: In my own electorate, constituents fall into one of five categories. Some have an inferior

Speaker: NA
Text: copper-based NBN, which they often say is slower and less reliable than their old ADSL2

Speaker: NA
Text: service. Further, many lost their landlines for protracted periods during the switchover, and

Speaker: NA
Text: many still report voice phone dropouts on a regular basis. This problem is most prominent

Speaker: NA
Text: around the townships of Lake Macquarie. The second category are those still waiting for a

Speaker: NA
Text: second-rate NBN and cannot secure an ADSL2 service because Telstra says it does not make

Speaker: NA
Text: the investment because the NBN will come one day. The third category includes those who

Speaker: NA
Text: are receiving fixed wireless. I have to say, pleasingly, I have had few complaints about the

Speaker: NA
Text: fixed wireless service but, of course, too few residents have access to it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fourth group are those who can hope for no coverage other than satellite but are told

Speaker: NA
Text: they do not qualify for satellite. The fifth group have a problem in common with farmers and

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: rural residents right across this nation: they have a satellite service which costs more and is

Speaker: NA
Text: inferior to the services enjoyed by those who live in our capital cities. While those in the cities

Speaker: NA
Text: are spoilt with choice, including options of limitless download capacity for less than $90 a

Speaker: NA
Text: month, the average Sky Muster satellite customer is forced to pay $135 per month for 55

Speaker: NA
Text: gigabytes of download between 7 am and 1 am. Many have no choice but to turn to very

Speaker: NA
Text: expensive wi-fi options to keep their farms running.

Speaker: NA
Text: Rural and remote families face being put on expensive data rations when they connect to

Speaker: NA
Text: the National Broadband Network. Two Sky Muster satellites are the only option for those

Speaker: NA
Text: who live beyond the reach of the NBN fixed wireless tower. Action group Better Internet for

Speaker: NA
Text: Rural, Regional and Remote Australia surveyed 750 Sky Muster customers, with 60 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: saying the satellites did not meet their data needs and 86 per cent that they had connection

Speaker: NA
Text: issues.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the 21st century access to broadband is not a want; it is a need. Much of our farm

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment now relies on connection to broadband services. This is putting our agriculture

Speaker: NA
Text: sector at an international economic disadvantage. This government with its inferior NBN

Speaker: NA
Text: service is letting rural Australia down and it is letting our farmers down.

Speaker: NA
Text: Surrogacy

Speaker: Mr BROAD
Text: Mallee) (11:10): I wish to talk on an issue that is a little bit sensitive and a

Speaker: NA
Text: little bit controversial. Children, of course, are a gift and the ability to have a family is

Speaker: NA
Text: something that we all aspire to. For some-myself included-it eludes us, and then we look at

Speaker: NA
Text: fostering and other things.

Speaker: NA
Text: We support people who want to endeavour to have children through IVF. We have a legal

Speaker: NA
Text: framework around surrogacy. I want to touch on offshore surrogacy. Australian law allows

Speaker: NA
Text: for a surrogate mother in Australia to be a surrogate mother but certainly not to receive a

Speaker: NA
Text: commercial benefit from doing so. Three of our states-New South Wales, the ACT and

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland-currently essentially stop, or make illegal, offshore surrogacy.

Speaker: NA
Text: If a law protects a citizen of Australia because of a principle that we believe in, I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: the principle should run through so that a woman who is not an Australian citizen is also to be

Speaker: NA
Text: protected under Australian law. As we think through the issue of offshore surrogacy we are

Speaker: NA
Text: bound by focus on the rights of the child, by our human rights agreements, but there does not

Speaker: NA
Text: appear to be enough talk about the rights of the surrogate mother. I think this is a space that

Speaker: NA
Text: we need to have a very real discussion in.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is one of the most active countries in the world for surrogacy and for some this

Speaker: NA
Text: has delivered a beautiful child for their family. My fear is that the paying of money to a

Speaker: NA
Text: surrogate mother in a poor country has the risk of serious exploitation, in recognition of the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that that woman is not protected by Australian law. It has the risk of pressures upon that

Speaker: NA
Text: woman. It has the risk of major exploitation of that woman, including whether, in some

Speaker: NA
Text: instances, she actually gets paid. There is a real discussion to be had around how we, as the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian government, ensure that if surrogacy is going to take place, and it is taking place,

Speaker: NA
Text: we protect the surrogate mothers in those poor countries.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are all putting our hands on our hearts today and talking about White Ribbon Day and

Speaker: NA
Text: support for women in domestic violence situations. But the principle has to run true that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have to find a way of ensuring that Australian law protects a surrogate mother. We can do

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: this. We do this with paedophilia overseas. We prosecute if someone partakes in something

Speaker: NA
Text: that is against our principles overseas. I think there is a real discussion to be had on this. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: something we should tackle. It is something that average Australians think we can do better

Speaker: NA
Text: on.

Speaker: NA
Text: Paterson Electorate: Lions Club of Raymond Terrace

Speaker: Ms SWANSON
Text: Paterson) (11:13): Today, I would like to pay tribute to some members

Speaker: NA
Text: of my community in Paterson who are truly deserving of recognition. Last Saturday, I was

Speaker: NA
Text: honoured to give the toast to the Lions Club of Raymond Terrace as they celebrated their 60th

Speaker: NA
Text: birthday. The international Lions Club has 45,000 members, and it is always inspiring to

Speaker: NA
Text: spend time with people who are in service to others. The Lions Club of Raymond Terrace was

Speaker: NA
Text: formed in September 1956 and has given countless hours in the service of our town and

Speaker: NA
Text: community, whether it be at the driver reviver-when people pull over in the busy times of

Speaker: NA
Text: Easter or Christmas, which gives them a chance to have a cuppa and refresh-or providing

Speaker: NA
Text: funds to many worthwhile causes.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 2015 alone, they provided a portable ultrasound machine for the Mater Hospital's

Speaker: NA
Text: oncology unit and contributed a donation of $100,000 to people affected by the flooding in

Speaker: NA
Text: Dungog-a sizeable amount of money for such a small group of people. Lions also support

Speaker: NA
Text: young people and, as a former Lions Youth of the Year, I can attest to the skills and

Speaker: NA
Text: experience that that fantastic arrangement gives to young people, such as I was in the eighties.

Speaker: NA
Text: When we lead such busy lives, it is important to recognise an organisation that fosters service

Speaker: NA
Text: to others. Thank you to the Lions Club of Raymond Terrace.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would also like to congratulate and wish a hearty bon voyage to some young Maitland

Speaker: NA
Text: soccer players and their parents who are off to Amiens in France on Friday. The busload will

Speaker: NA
Text: leave their home ground in East Maitland on a pilgrimage to mark the route their forefathers

Speaker: NA
Text: took 100 years ago, when Maitland's own 34th Battalion set out in 1916 to fight World War I.

Speaker: NA
Text: The 34th Battalion of coalfield lads and Maitland boys did us proud on the battlefields of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Front, receiving commendation for their valour. Apparently they also did us proud

Speaker: NA
Text: on the soccer field in a historic match between the 34th Battalion and the French aerodrome

Speaker: NA
Text: team of Amiens. The 17-year-old boys from my home town of Maitland and the coalfields

Speaker: NA
Text: will recreate that match. Congratulations to Ian Mather and his team for organising a trip of a

Speaker: NA
Text: lifetime to mark the sacrifice of a lifetime. Last week, I presented the players with Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: flags to take to Amiens and I could not help but look at their young faces and think back to

Speaker: NA
Text: the young faces of those boys we sent to war 100 years ago, and the men and women who go

Speaker: NA
Text: to war for us today. On that note, I would like to send my sincere thanks to our Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: personnel serving overseas this Christmas. We are incredibly proud and grateful for what you

Speaker: NA
Text: do. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Country to Canberra 2016

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs SUDMALIS (Gilmore) (11:16): Yesterday, a number of quite inspiring young

Speaker: NA
Text: women gathered in parliament to meet their MPs. They were the winners of the Country to

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra 2016 leadership competition. This is an Australian not-for-profit organisation that

Speaker: NA
Text: empowers young women from regional, remote and rural areas to reach their full potential

Speaker: NA
Text: through a nationwide leadership competition based around gender equality for high school

Speaker: NA
Text: students in regional areas. Winners have their work published, are awarded a trip to Canberra,

Speaker: NA
Text: get to meet influential role models and politicians, connect with mentors through the raising

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Hope Foundation and participate in public speaking and leadership training. I was introduced

Speaker: NA
Text: to Elise Toyer, who is only 16 years old and is currently in year 10 at St Peter's Anglican

Speaker: NA
Text: College in Broulee but actually lives in Batemans Bay. Her role model is her Tia, her father's

Speaker: NA
Text: mother. Elise is passionate about achieving healthcare equality within Australia, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: in rural and remote areas, and would like to become a rural and regional paediatric specialist

Speaker: NA
Text: after she finishes high school.

Speaker: NA
Text: Elise is a vivacious and enthusiastic young woman with a contagious personality. I asked

Speaker: NA
Text: her to send me a copy of her winning entry and the following are her words which she

Speaker: NA
Text: presented in an empathic and powerful video, especially relevant as we emphasise White

Speaker: NA
Text: Ribbon Day this week:

Speaker: NA
Text: Why is gender equality important to me and my community? This is my friend and I proudly laying a

Speaker: NA
Text: wreath on behalf of our local scout group at Anzac Day last year. We were introduced as representatives

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Boy Scouts Association of Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The only problem? We're both girls. That man that introduced us did something we all do-myself

Speaker: NA
Text: included. We attribute certain qualities to a particular gender. The typical view of a woman is meek and

Speaker: NA
Text: humble, submissive and emotional. A man is strong and tough, emotionless. But these stereotypical

Speaker: NA
Text: labels that are doled out to us are not a gift, they are a burden; a heavy weight that limits our potential.

Speaker: NA
Text: For gender equality to occur, we must see past the gender labels given to a person and see their qualities

Speaker: NA
Text: not as female and male but as human.

Speaker: NA
Text: Gender equality means that when the young women in my community become leaders in their

Speaker: NA
Text: schools and workplaces, they are not bossy or rude but confident, strong leaders. As Beyonce said, 'I'm

Speaker: NA
Text: not bossy … I'm the boss.' And when the young men in my community have had a tough week and are

Speaker: NA
Text: struggling to see the light in each day, they know it's okay to ask for help, to talk and to hug. To know

Speaker: NA
Text: that it's okay not to be okay.

Speaker: NA
Text: Gender equality means to me that when I'm a scout and I am out there leading in the community, it's

Speaker: NA
Text: not automatically thought that I belong to a boy's group because those qualities are for men-I belong

Speaker: NA
Text: to Scouts. Because women and men can be both strong and humble and kind and confident.

Speaker: NA
Text: The qualities that make a person aren't male or female-they're human and that's why gender

Speaker: NA
Text: equality is important to me and my community.

Speaker: NA
Text: Elise, you are wonderful. Thank you. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Men's Shed Association

Speaker: Mr KHALIL
Text: Wills) (11:20): I want to acknowledge the work of the Australian Men's

Speaker: NA
Text: Shed Association and, in particular, all the men's sheds in my electorate of Wills. We are all

Speaker: NA
Text: familiar with men's sheds and the good work that they do. They are community spaces

Speaker: NA
Text: modelled after the old-fashioned backyard shed, but not all men's sheds are the same.

Speaker: NA
Text: Depending on which shed you visit, you may see a number of blokes making furniture or

Speaker: NA
Text: perhaps restoring bicycles for a local school. They could be making bird traps or fixing

Speaker: NA
Text: lawnmowers or making a cubbyhouse for Camp Quality to raffle. You often see a few young

Speaker: NA
Text: men as well, working with the older men, learning new skills and learning something about

Speaker: NA
Text: life from the men that they work with. You might also see local elders making traditional arts

Speaker: NA
Text: and crafts. You will usually see teabags and coffee cups strewn about in a comfortable area

Speaker: NA
Text: where men can just sit and talk. You will probably see an area where men can learn to cook

Speaker: NA
Text: for themselves, or even contact family members by computer.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Many men struggle to talk about their feelings and their emotions. They do not really take a

Speaker: NA
Text: serious interest in their own mental health. According to beyondblue, one in eight men will

Speaker: NA
Text: have depression and one in five men will experience anxiety at some stage of their lives.

Speaker: NA
Text: While women are statistically more likely to experience depression and anxiety, men are less

Speaker: NA
Text: likely to talk about it. Depression is a serious and common condition which will not get better

Speaker: NA
Text: by itself. But some men are still subscribing to the idea that they should just tough it out and

Speaker: NA
Text: be self-reliant in any and all circumstances. It is said that because of this, some males are

Speaker: NA
Text: known to drink more and take more risks with their health, and can suffer immensely from a

Speaker: NA
Text: lack of appropriate treatment. Good health is based on many factors, including feeling good

Speaker: NA
Text: about yourself, being productive, contributing to your community, connecting with friends

Speaker: NA
Text: and maintaining an active body and mind. Professor Barry Golding from Federation

Speaker: NA
Text: University, in an address to the 2007 men's shed conference, said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Men don't talk face to face, they talk shoulder to shoulder.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the real power of the men's shed. Your local shed provides a safe and busy

Speaker: NA
Text: environment where men can find many of these things, in an atmosphere of old-fashioned

Speaker: NA
Text: mateship.

Speaker: NA
Text: In Wills, there is already an excellent men's shed in the suburb of Glenroy. I recently met

Speaker: NA
Text: with a group of blokes from Fawkner who are working on the establishment of a men's shed

Speaker: NA
Text: in their area. These guys have been trying to establish a Fawkner men's shed for years. I

Speaker: NA
Text: visited them on a vacant plot of land on Lorne Street in Fawkner, and they told me all about

Speaker: NA
Text: their plans that were already underway. The first project that these guys will have is actually

Speaker: NA
Text: building the shed. I will be backing their bid to get the men's shed up and running in Fawkner.

Speaker: NA
Text: I encourage everyone to get involved in their local men's shed by visiting the Men's Shed

Speaker: NA
Text: Association website for more information.

Speaker: NA
Text: Logan Urban Design Awards

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr VAN MANEN (Forde-Government Whip) (11:22): It is my pleasure to rise in this

Speaker: NA
Text: House today and speak about the achievements of various entities around Logan City in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Logan Urban Design Awards. The 2016 Logan Urban Design Awards were held recently, and

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to congratulate the overall winner, the Beenleigh Artisan Distillery's new visitor

Speaker: NA
Text: centre. Held every two years, the LUDA awards promote excellence in the design and

Speaker: NA
Text: creation of urban environments, large and small, within the City of Logan. The award winners

Speaker: NA
Text: across all categories are chosen for their clever design, delivering excellent community spaces

Speaker: NA
Text: that, in some cases, also put a unique twist on conventional buildings. Beenleigh Artisan

Speaker: NA
Text: Distillery's new visitor centre was named the overall winner for its striking modern cellar door

Speaker: NA
Text: design, introduced to the distillery's entrance by Blueprint Architects. The design was praised

Speaker: NA
Text: for re-imagining the iconic Beenleigh business, while also respecting its heritage-and for the

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit of those in the House: it is the oldest operating rum distillery in Australia. The judges'

Speaker: NA
Text: comments said it was 'a project that exemplifies the value and contribution of good design,'

Speaker: NA
Text: and that the project's 'adaptive and contemporary design unites old and new to breathe fresh

Speaker: NA
Text: life into this Beenleigh business icon'.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Logan Urban Design Awards covered four categories: the Master Planning Award,

Speaker: NA
Text: awarded to master-planned developments and communities; the Landscape Architecture and

Speaker: NA
Text: Urban Infrastructure Award; the Architecture Award, awarded to exemplar building-form

Speaker: NA
Text: projects covering residential, commercial, industrial and institutional; and the Business and

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Events Award, awarded to exemplar businesses, programs or events that contribute our

Speaker: NA
Text: community.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to congratulate all the winners, as well as the nominees, on their commitment

Speaker: NA
Text: to quality design and development within the city of Logan, including: the Master Planning

Speaker: NA
Text: Award winner, My Home and The River Estate; the Landscape Architecture and Urban

Speaker: NA
