Text: Infrastructure Award winner, Jimboomba Community Garden; Architecture Award winner,

Speaker: NA
Text: MCDonalds Underwood and Landini Associates; and the Business and Events Award winner,

Speaker: NA
Text: Extraction Artisan Coffee at Springwood. Those receiving commendation awards were: the

Speaker: NA
Text: Early Bird Breakfast Markets, Cavern Music Concerts, the Rum Rump and Rumba Festival

Speaker: NA
Text: 2015, and The Vicker Ridge. Congratulations to everybody involved for the tremendous work

Speaker: NA
Text: of continuing to build and grow our magnificent community.

Speaker: NA
Text: Corio Electorate: Medicare

Speaker: Mr MARLES
Text: Corio) (11:25): The ongoing freeze of the Medicare rebate has driven up

Speaker: NA
Text: the cost of primary health care across Australia. That is being felt by many Australians, who

Speaker: NA
Text: expressed their voices in huge numbers at the last election. In my electorate of Corio, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: estimated that 12,000 people put off going to the doctor today because of the cost of primary

Speaker: NA
Text: health care and 15,000 people put off gaining their prescriptions because of the costs

Speaker: NA
Text: associated with that. Those numbers are most significant in the northern part of my electorate,

Speaker: NA
Text: in the northern suburbs of Geelong-Norlane and Corio-where health needs are at their

Speaker: NA
Text: most complex. It is in this part of my electorate that we see the highest rates of diabetes, for

Speaker: NA
Text: example. Diseases of poverty are most prevalent there. The refugee populations in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate are most concentrated in that part of it. Their health needs are particularly acute. Dr

Speaker: NA
Text: Mark Kennedy, who runs the Corio Medical Clinic, says:

Speaker: NA
Text: We have more cases of diabetes coming into our clinic than anywhere else in the country. Our clinic

Speaker: NA
Text: and the public in Geelong's Northern suburbs have got long term benefits out of the former Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: government's Primary Care Infrastructure grants; they allowed us to expand and teach new GPs and

Speaker: NA
Text: medical students that are working across the country today.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Abbas Mahmood from the Corio Bay Medical Centre says:

Speaker: NA
Text: Refugees have a greater need for health care and life support infrastructure and a collaborative approach

Speaker: NA
Text: by doctor services will be better able to … support them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Ganes Kunjidapaadhum, who runs the First Point Medical Centre, says:

Speaker: NA
Text: Instead of taking away doctors and health assets it's time the government starts adding doctors and

Speaker: NA
Text: health services dependent on what the public needs.

Speaker: NA
Text: On 15 November-last Tuesday-I called a meeting of those three doctors, who between

Speaker: NA
Text: them cater to about 80 to 90 per cent of the primary health care needs in the north of Geelong,

Speaker: NA
Text: to talk about ways in which they could better coordinate and ways in which we could use

Speaker: NA
Text: them as a voice for the medical needs of the north of Geelong. There was a real sense of

Speaker: NA
Text: excitement amongst them about working together. There is an opportunity, I think, for them

Speaker: NA
Text: to work more closely and to coordinate their resources around, for example, servicing those

Speaker: NA
Text: refugees in the north of Geelong who need medical assistance. Operating with the council is

Speaker: NA
Text: also something which I think they can do better as a group, making sure that overseas doctors

Speaker: NA
Text: who come to Geelong are able to operate in the northern suburbs. This is an important forum.

Speaker: NA
Text: Along with Jason Trethowan, the CEO of the Western Victoria Primary Health Network, we

Speaker: NA
Text: are really excited about the opportunity it presents. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Belair National Park

Speaker: Ms FLINT
Text: Boothby) (11:28): This year marks the 125th anniversary of the Belair

Speaker: NA
Text: National Park. I would like to thank all the dedicated volunteers who give their time to care

Speaker: NA
Text: for what is a really wonderful natural and historical resource in my electorate. The park is

Speaker: NA
Text: nestled in the start of the Mount Lofty Ranges, and it is the second-oldest national park in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. It attracts 250,000 visitors a year. It was created in 1891, when the state of South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia was only 55 years old. It is also the sixth-oldest national park in the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: The success of Belair National Park is testament to its value to the community. More than

Speaker: NA
Text: just a protected green space, it has great public utility and is saturated with South Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: history dating right back to 1837, which is only a year after our state proclamation. The park

Speaker: NA
Text: is complete with ovals, pavilions, tennis courts, barbecues and picnic areas and is a hive of

Speaker: NA
Text: activity for families on the weekends. For those who wish to explore the park's natural beauty,

Speaker: NA
Text: there are a variety of trails suitable for all, from novice walkers up to veteran hikers. While

Speaker: NA
Text: keeping fit and healthy, walkers can marvel at the waterfalls along the aptly named Echo

Speaker: NA
Text: Track to the north, or make their way south along Valley Road up to Amphitheatre Rock. For

Speaker: NA
Text: lovers of history and politics like myself, Belair National Park is also home to the summer

Speaker: NA
Text: residence of former South Australian governors. The residence is a magnificent Victorian

Speaker: NA
Text: mansion which boasts the state's first indoor swimming pool, which is quite a sight to see. I

Speaker: NA
Text: was there to see it myself in early March, which was the launch of the park's birthday

Speaker: NA
Text: celebrations. For a gold-coin donation, the Friends of Old Government House happily conduct

Speaker: NA
Text: tours of this wonderful historical site for tourists and the public.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Friends of Old Government House is just one of the many community groups who

Speaker: NA
Text: devote their time to maintaining the Belair National Park, which covers 835 hectares in total.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Friends of Belair National Park is another one of these volunteer groups involved with

Speaker: NA
Text: the park. They are a committed group that I have had the pleasure of being a member of, and

Speaker: NA
Text: they do a huge amount of work, from weeding and bushland protection to hosting visitors and

Speaker: NA
Text: taking tours of the park, and letting people know about the wonderful flora and fauna that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have. We in Adelaide are lucky to have such a space only 13 kilometres from the city centre.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is right on our doorstep. In this, the 125th year of Belair National Park, I pay tribute to all of

Speaker: NA
Text: those who make the park the wonderful place that it is, and I encourage all South Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: and visitors to South Australia to visit the park on 3 December for the end of the 125th

Speaker: NA
Text: birthday celebrations. I cannot commend it highly enough.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mrs Wicks): In accordance with standing order 193, the time

Speaker: NA
Text: for members' constituency statements has concluded.

Speaker: NA
Text: MOTIONS

Speaker: NA
Text: Equal Rights

Speaker: NA
Text: Consideration resumed of the motion:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) reaffirms its commitment to the right of all Australians to enjoy equal rights and be treated with

Speaker: NA
Text: equal respect regardless of race, colour, creed or origin;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) reaffirms its commitment to maintaining an immigration policy wholly non-discriminatory on

Speaker: NA
Text: grounds of race, colour, creed or origin;

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) reaffirms its commitment to the process of reconciliation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait

Speaker: NA
Text: Islander people, in the context of redressing their profound social and economic disadvantage;

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) reaffirms its commitment to maintaining Australia as a culturally diverse, tolerant and open

Speaker: NA
Text: society, united by an overriding commitment to our nation, and its democratic institutions and values;

Speaker: NA
Text: and

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) denounces racial intolerance in any form as incompatible with the kind of society we are and

Speaker: NA
Text: want to be.

Speaker: Mr BURKE
Text: Watson-Manager of Opposition Business) (11:32): My feelings are very

Speaker: NA
Text: mixed, standing to speak on this motion today. It is a motion which was first moved in the

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament 20 years ago. It was moved at the time that One Nation first entered the House of

Speaker: NA
Text: Representatives; moved by the then Prime Minister, John Howard and supported by the then

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition, Kim Beazley.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the first day of the new parliament, Bill Shorten, the Leader of the Opposition, put to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister that it was time to carry this motion again. The intention was that carrying

Speaker: NA
Text: the motion would be an affirmation of principles that would be unanimously held across

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament. And the Prime Minister, in good faith, took that offer on and made the motion his

Speaker: NA
Text: own. By the time we vote on this-either later today or tomorrow-it is hard to believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: this motion is still supported by every member of the House of Representatives. The second

Speaker: NA
Text: paragraph of the motion-of a 20-year-old motion-says that the House:

Speaker: NA
Text: reaffirms its commitment to maintaining an immigration policy wholly non-discriminatory on grounds

Speaker: NA
Text: of race, colour, creed or origin.

Speaker: NA
Text: It simply cannot be the case that every member of the parliament still believes that. I have no

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt that this motion reflects the majority view of our parliament. But I cannot reconcile that

Speaker: NA
Text: second paragraph with the words that we have heard in recent days from Australia's Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Immigration, when he put the argument not that the Fraser government let the wrong

Speaker: NA
Text: people in but that the people who were let in had children and grandchildren who have

Speaker: NA
Text: behaved in an unacceptable way-and therefore used the phrase that the government had

Speaker: NA
Text: 'made a mistake'. The only point of continuity with those people was that they, being the

Speaker: NA
Text: grandchildren of the people who came through under the Fraser government, were of the

Speaker: NA
Text: same race, were of the same ethnicity and adhered to the same creed. There is no way of

Speaker: NA
Text: reconciling the words of the minister for immigration with the words of this motion. I wish

Speaker: NA
Text: there were.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want this resolution, which is about who we are as a country, to be something that both

Speaker: NA
Text: sides of politics can unanimously agree on. When the Leader of the Opposition put this

Speaker: NA
Text: motion forward and said it is time to move it again, it was not intended to be a wedge through

Speaker: NA
Text: the government. It was not intended to be a point of division; it was intended to be a statement

Speaker: NA
Text: of unity. I cannot, for the life of me, see how that second paragraph of this resolution can in

Speaker: NA
Text: any way be reconciled with the views that the minister for immigration has now put forward.

Speaker: NA
Text: In those views that the minister for immigration has put forward, he has connected issues

Speaker: NA
Text: of race, ethnicity and religion with crime. This part of the language is not new. Back when we

Speaker: NA
Text: had a debate in the 1980s about whether Asian immigration should be held back, the language

Speaker: NA
Text: at the time was about triad gangs, Asian gangs and gangs in Cabramatta. In the sixties and

Speaker: NA
Text: seventies, when people were arguing about whether or not Italian immigration was

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate, the language then was about the links to the Mafia and about crime. I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: accept for one minute that the serious issues of national security that we are dealing with are

Speaker: NA
Text: an excuse to legitimise the racial profiling of a community based on its children and

Speaker: NA
Text: grandchildren.

Speaker: NA
Text: I support this motion because I support its principles and the way they define our nation. I

Speaker: NA
Text: genuinely believe that there is a majority of members in the government who believe and

Speaker: NA
Text: support every clause of this motion. I have no doubt whatsoever that what has been put

Speaker: NA
Text: forward by the minister for immigration is damaging and no better than those arguments that

Speaker: NA
Text: were put forward 20 years ago opposing Asian immigration or those arguments that were put

Speaker: NA
Text: forward in the sixties and seventies opposing migration of Greeks and Italians.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have no doubt that the comments from the minister for immigration will win him votes. I

Speaker: NA
Text: do not care! There has to be a time when we are willing to provide a level of leadership to

Speaker: NA
Text: bring a country together. I expect the comments from the minister for immigration will not

Speaker: NA
Text: result in any change of immigration policy. He will hint at it and he will tempt at it, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: suspect the policy will not in fact change. I suspect also that it will not add a single job to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia nor a dollar to our GDP. But I know some things that it will do. It will make the

Speaker: NA
Text: work of our security agencies harder. It will cause people to feel marginalised when we want

Speaker: NA
Text: them to feel 100 per cent part of our community. It will cause some people, a small minority,

Speaker: NA
Text: to have a sense of licence and permission to belittle and abuse some of their fellow citizens,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that has already commenced.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are two sorts of Australian stories: an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander story that

Speaker: NA
Text: goes all the way back to the first sunrise, and a story of immigration. Every Australian either

Speaker: NA
Text: has one or both of those stories. Modern Australia is about bringing those 24 million stories

Speaker: NA
Text: together. That is what it is. Part of the role of the minister for immigration is making sure that

Speaker: NA
Text: we are as cohesive as possible in making sure that people who might feel marginalised in fact

Speaker: NA
Text: feel every word that is in our citizenship oath.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not want there to be partisanship in a motion like this. The reason it was brought

Speaker: NA
Text: forward was that we believed at the time that we would have a unanimous statement from the

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament that would ostracise some of the voices that have come into the other place and

Speaker: NA
Text: make clear that, while they have been given a really loud microphone, they do not represent

Speaker: NA
Text: the majority of this parliament, they do not represent the story of bipartisan support for

Speaker: NA
Text: modern, multicultural Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want it to be true. The Prime Minister backed the general work of the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Immigration but he did not back those particular words. While ministers for immigration have

Speaker: NA
Text: at different times dealt with challenges in immigration policies and settlement policies for

Speaker: NA
Text: different communities in Australia, you have to go all the way back to the days of the White

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia policy to find a minister for immigration referring to communities that should be

Speaker: NA
Text: excluded based on race or religion. You have to go that far back.

Speaker: NA
Text: We should not underestimate the choices that are being made by this parliament right now.

Speaker: NA
Text: While we might be concerned at the extent to which some racist voices have been handed a

Speaker: NA
Text: big megaphone, there is no megaphone louder in this country than the voice of the parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: itself-and it is at its loudest when we stand together. You cannot equivocate on this stuff:

Speaker: NA
Text: you either support and believe in modern multicultural Australia or you do not-and I have

Speaker: NA
Text: no doubt that the vast majority in this House and the other place do. I implore the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Immigration not to go down the path he has started to step down. There is a way through for

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: him to simply talk about settlement policies, about integration policies, about bringing people

Speaker: NA
Text: into the centre and not link it back to whether a mistake was made by letting people in the

Speaker: NA
Text: door at all based on their race or religion. There is a way forward and I want him to take it.

Speaker: NA
Text: We will define what sort of country we are, and no country has ever grown to prosperity by

Speaker: NA
Text: excluding a minority.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr TIM WILSON (Goldstein) (11:42): I want to start by reiterating some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: sentiments of the previous speaker. We want this motion to be unanimous and we want people

Speaker: NA
Text: in this parliament to support the spirit and ideals of the motion. One of the best ways to get

Speaker: NA
Text: there is not to use it as an opportunity for partisan political discussions designed to divide

Speaker: NA
Text: society but to focus on how we are all coming together as a country. Hopefully, every

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the House of Representatives appeals to the idea that we are all equal before the

Speaker: NA
Text: law and everybody has a place in this country regardless of their background. This is not an

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity for members to score cheap political points because they think it will get them

Speaker: NA
Text: some attention in a newspaper or enable them to go off and send messages to one section of

Speaker: NA
Text: the community or another, as part of their grandstanding exercise, rather than focus on things

Speaker: NA
Text: that improve the human condition. And that is where I was disappointed with the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: speaker and the way he conducted himself. In the end, he was not focusing on what we could

Speaker: NA
Text: do to bring the parliament together and support this motion unanimously. He used it as an

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to grandstand so that he himself could score cheap political points. And that is

Speaker: NA
Text: exactly what this motion is designed to stop.

Speaker: NA
Text: This motion is designed to focus on how we bring the country together and move it

Speaker: NA
Text: forward together. When you look through the principles that underpin it, it is extremely

Speaker: NA
Text: straightforward. It is based on a motion that was passed 20 years ago, through the leadership

Speaker: NA
Text: of John Howard. It is a motion to reaffirm our commitment to 'the right of all Australians to

Speaker: NA
Text: enjoy equal rights and be treated with equal respect regardless of their background'. We all

Speaker: NA
Text: agree. It is a motion to reaffirm our commitment to 'maintaining an immigration policy that is

Speaker: NA
Text: wholly non-discriminatory on grounds of race, colour, creed or origin'. Let's face it, it should

Speaker: NA
Text: also include any other irrelevant attributes. It also says:

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) reaffirms its commitment to the process of reconciliation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander

Speaker: NA
Text: people, in the context of redressing their profound social and economic disadvantage;

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) reaffirms its commitment to maintaining Australia as a culturally diverse, tolerant and open society,

Speaker: NA
Text: united by an overriding commitment to our nation, and its democratic institutions and values; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) denounces racial intolerance in any form as incompatible with the kind of society we are and want to

Speaker: NA
Text: be.

Speaker: NA
Text: At every point, all I have heard from people on the government side-all the ministers, all the

Speaker: NA
Text: members of parliament-has been a commitment to that process and a commitment to those

Speaker: NA
Text: ideals and values. When we use it as an opportunity to divide because we think we score

Speaker: NA
Text: cheap political points it is not just that we distract from the central thrust of it, it is that we

Speaker: NA
Text: undermine and send a message, somehow, to the rest of the community that these values are

Speaker: NA
Text: not shared and extolled. That is why this government takes values and principles so

Speaker: NA
Text: strongly-as do I. In fact, these values in many ways are some of the key reasons that I sought

Speaker: NA
Text: to enter public life in the first place. Because there is no place in society for people to face

Speaker: NA
Text: marginalisation or exclusion simply because of who they are and the basis of how they live

Speaker: NA
Text: their lives.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: What we want is a society where everybody feels an equal investment and an opportunity

Speaker: NA
Text: to contribute, both economically and socially, to build this country from the bottom up, where

Speaker: NA
Text: we have individuals who come together to form families, community and ultimately country.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the type of country we want to be. That is how we achieve a more just society. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: about how we take everybody forward together.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know full well that we still have enormous challenges, particularly with Aboriginal and

Speaker: NA
Text: Torres Strait Islander people, in making sure that they can move forward together as part of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian society around issues of health and economic disadvantage. That is why as Human

Speaker: NA
Text: Rights Commissioner I was very proud to work on issues directly around improving the

Speaker: NA
Text: economic opportunities for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and enabling them to

Speaker: NA
Text: use their land and property rights to achieve greater economic participation, not just as an end

Speaker: NA
Text: in itself but so that we could go on and build opportunities for a greater social dividend for

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, particularly those outside capital cities. I was

Speaker: NA
Text: very happy to enjoy the support of the Attorney-General, George Brandis, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: government in doing that work, because there was so much advantage to it. I might add that I

Speaker: NA
Text: had the support also of many senior Indigenous leaders.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is how you take a country forward together. It is not done by focusing on points of

Speaker: NA
Text: negativity and division to try to achieve some political exercise. You take a country forward

Speaker: NA
Text: together by focusing on the points that unite us as a country and, as the motion says at the

Speaker: NA
Text: end, appeals to our idea of the kind of society and country that we want to be. That is why this

Speaker: NA
Text: government has had such a generous and ongoing commitment to a non-discriminatory global

Speaker: NA
Text: humanitarian program. That commitment, despite the hyperbole and the vented and confected

Speaker: NA
Text: outrage that, let's face it, has come from some of the other speakers, remains utterly resolute

Speaker: NA
Text: from the minister as well as from the government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last financial year the government delivered a total refugee and humanitarian program of

Speaker: NA
Text: 17,555 places, which included 15,502 offshore places. That is the largest offshore intake in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia in 30 years, and was done under this current minister. Australia's annual refugee and

Speaker: NA
Text: humanitarian program is set to grow to 18,750 by 2018-19. That is one of the most generous

Speaker: NA
Text: permanent resettlement programs in the world. We achieve that because we have a strong

Speaker: NA
Text: border protection, we have a commitment from the government to make sure that people

Speaker: NA
Text: smugglers are not rewarded and we have now, to the government's great credit, efforts to

Speaker: NA
Text: resettle in the United States as well as potentially other countries people who were held in

Speaker: NA
Text: offshore detention.

Speaker: NA
Text: You cannot build public confidence and public support for higher rates of migration,

Speaker: NA
Text: generally, as well as for helping people who are seeking asylum from across the world unless

Speaker: NA
Text: the public believes that the borders are secure, that there is a process by which people are

Speaker: NA
Text: treated equally and with dignity and that people's assessment of their claims is based on the

Speaker: NA
Text: legitimacy of their claims, not on their process of arrival. That is what this government has

Speaker: NA
Text: achieved and is one of its great achievements and legacies that it will continue to contribute to

Speaker: NA
Text: the development of this great country. By maintaining public confidence in this issue of

Speaker: NA
Text: border security, which is so vital, the government has continued to be able to offer 16,350

Speaker: NA
Text: visas since July 2015 to those displaced by the conflict in Syria and Iraq-helping people

Speaker: NA
Text: based on legitimacy of their need, not on the process of their arrival. We have also had been

Speaker: NA
Text: able to offer 5,490 people who have been interviewed and assessed as meeting the threshold

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements for a visa and are awaiting the outcomes of health, character and security

Speaker: NA
Text: checks. These new Australians-new Australians-will be provided with the best opportunity

Speaker: NA
Text: to start productive lives and reach their full potential. That is what we want-that is

Speaker: NA
Text: something that is good for our country. Those are the values and the spirit the motion the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister has moved and which we are debating and discussing, and hopefully

Speaker: NA
Text: supporting, very much seeks to achieve.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government is proudly sustaining our world-class resettlement services. Entrants are

Speaker: NA
Text: eligible for the same social service benefits as other humanitarian entrants, including

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare, income support payments, English language tuition, torture and trauma counselling

Speaker: NA
Text: and settlement services. The objective of that is to take people and to enable them to best

Speaker: NA
Text: integrate into Australian society, and then go on and live productive lives. That again goes to

Speaker: NA
Text: the heart and the spirit of the program of the government, but equally what it seeks to achieve

Speaker: NA
Text: when we bring people here is that they can be full participants as new Australians. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: committed to enabling these new Australians to become self-reliant, to stand on their own two

Speaker: NA
Text: feet, not just so they can take care of themselves, though that is very important, but so they

Speaker: NA
Text: can assist those who come in similar waves of migration to contribute to this great country

Speaker: NA
Text: and participate equally in all of Australian society.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is at the heart of what liberalism is-it is a political philosophy built on the idea and

Speaker: NA
Text: the capacity of the individual to make their maximum contribution, to live their lives and be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to make their commitment and contribution to our society. That is why the spirit of this

Speaker: NA
Text: motion goes to the heart of liberalism itself-not labourism, which in the past, sadly, has been

Speaker: NA
Text: at times deliberately exclusionary-which focuses on those uniting principles that bind all

Speaker: NA
Text: people, that sit in the heart of Liberal philosophy and that motivate us, including yourself, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Speaker, to leave our community and come onto the national stage and be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: reaffirm those basic commitments of liberty for all. That is why I support this motion. I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: other members of this House do. In fact, I agree with the aspirations of the previous speaker,

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Watson, and my hope is that support for this motion is achieved unanimously.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the end it does send a message about the type of country we want to be-united, focused

Speaker: NA
Text: on the future and building the potential of every single Australian, new or old, to contribute to

Speaker: NA
Text: this great country. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr GEORGANAS
Text: Hindmarsh) (11:52): I rise to speak on this motion on equality for all

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians. I believe Australians see themselves, rightly, as an egalitarian society and it is

Speaker: NA
Text: vital that we affirm and continue to reaffirm our commitment to equal rights for all in this

Speaker: NA
Text: nation. But in this debate it is equally vital that we ask ourselves what is it exactly that creates

Speaker: NA
Text: and most importantly maintains and protects equal rights. While legislation is important,

Speaker: NA
Text: unless a society is able to adapt and be flexible in the face of changing circumstances, equal

Speaker: NA
Text: rights can become questionable, questioned and challenged. There is no doubt that Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: has made a very successful commitment to human rights. I think we have been one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: most successful countries in the entire world. I cannot think of another nation that has done

Speaker: NA
Text: better in this area than us. But it is imperative that we continue to remind ourselves, and

Speaker: NA
Text: others, of the need for and positive benefits of equal rights. Changes in legislation are

Speaker: NA
Text: important-no-one can deny that-but legislation alone does not ensure equal rights. As we

Speaker: NA
Text: have seen through the debate on section 18C of the Racial Discrimination Act, legislation can

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: be changed, undermining equal rights at the drop of a hat. Unless the wider community is

Speaker: NA
Text: convinced of the importance of defending equal rights, these rights will remain vulnerable.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is our job as policy and law makers to ensure that we make a strong case for the

Speaker: NA
Text: protection of equal rights. My electorate of Hindmarsh is a very diverse community. As I

Speaker: NA
Text: have said many times in this place, approximately 200 languages are spoken in my electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: People have settled there from every corner of the world, from the traditional postwar

Speaker: NA
Text: migrants to the new emerging communities. Every language that you can possibly think of,

Speaker: NA
Text: every nation you can possibly think of is represented within my electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 2016, the ABS estimated almost 27 per cent of Hindmarsh residents were born overseas.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since postwar migration began, Australia has been taking in approximately one million

Speaker: NA
Text: immigrants each decade from every region of the world, and today 15 per cent of the

Speaker: NA
Text: population report that they speak a language other than English at home. I am so proud of the

Speaker: NA
Text: cultural diversity within our nation, and within my electorate of course, because, as I said, I

Speaker: NA
Text: do not think there is any nation in the world that has done it better than us.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have always been a fighter to protect this great cultural diversity, and our

Speaker: NA
Text: multiculturalism, and I will continue to do so, as I know many others in this place will do so,

Speaker: NA
Text: because I believe that our successful multicultural society is truly one of the greatest assets

Speaker: NA
Text: that we have in this nation. Multiculturalism has been an important element in the making of

Speaker: NA
Text: modern Australia, and has been critical to fostering social cohesion and inclusion. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: underpinned cohesion and inclusion, and, through multiculturalism, the Australian experience

Speaker: NA
Text: has shown that diversity can absolutely go hand in hand with stronger social cohesion. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: undoubtedly thanks to successive governments on both sides who have supported

Speaker: NA
Text: multiculturalism and, of course, the broader labour movement.

Speaker: NA
Text: Official racial discrimination, in the form of the Immigration Restriction Act 1901-more

Speaker: NA
Text: commonly known as the White Australia policy-was not removed until the 1970s when the

Speaker: NA
Text: policies around multiculturalism emerged. It was the Whitlam Labor government that set

Speaker: NA
Text: about addressing many of these inequalities, followed by the Fraser and Hawke governments.

Speaker: NA
Text: I remember as a teenager, back in the seventies, attending one of my community's annual

Speaker: NA
Text: functions, the Greek Orthodox ball. This particular night we had some very honoured

Speaker: NA
Text: guests-I will never forget it-and the whole community with just astounded by the

Speaker: NA
Text: attendance of Gough Whitlam and Don Dunstan. It was the first time we had ever seen people

Speaker: NA
Text: of that calibre attend one of our functions. I remember how excited everyone was-and that

Speaker: NA
Text: memory is still vivid in my mind, which could have been something that threw me into

Speaker: NA
Text: politics. To have this great man there, the Prime Minister of Australia, giving a speech and

Speaker: NA
Text: telling us how he valued our community, how he saw the contribution that our community

Speaker: NA
Text: had made, was something that we had never witnessed before. From that moment onwards, I

Speaker: NA
Text: recall feeling equal to everyone else. Any inadequacies that I had about being from a different

Speaker: NA
Text: background or perhaps my parents speaking a different language, being different, was thrown

Speaker: NA
Text: out the window that night because we felt equal. I remember it very well. We still talk about

Speaker: NA
Text: that night in my community in South Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us not forget that immigration to Australia was closely tied to labour market needs. My

Speaker: NA
Text: parents came here after World War II, from a nation that had been absolutely decimated by

Speaker: NA
Text: war. They came here with very little English. They worked in the lowest paid jobs, but they

Speaker: NA
Text: managed to carve out a life for themselves. They did that because of the labour laws that

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: existed in this country. There was a debate after World War II, when we decided to open up

Speaker: NA
Text: immigration-if you look at the Hansards, you will see the debates-where, on the one hand,

Speaker: NA
Text: there was a group within this place, and outside in industry, that agreed with bringing in

Speaker: NA
Text: migrant workers, but wanted to have them on lower pay rates than Australian workers. On the

Speaker: NA
Text: other hand, there was the view of the labour movement that staunchly said, no, they would be

Speaker: NA
Text: on the same pay rates as everyone else if they come out here. And you can imagine how life

Speaker: NA
Text: would have been so different had that not prevailed back then. So in addressing equality, we

Speaker: NA
Text: need to also address inequality in the workplace. We see today many people coming out on

Speaker: NA
Text: different types of visas. I say this: if we have a shortage in particular areas, bring them out as

Speaker: NA
Text: migrants to settle in this nation, to be part of our community, to fill the gaps that are required

Speaker: NA
Text: and to become Australians. Like all of us have. That is really important.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addressing equality, the workplace is fundamental. In 1973, the then Labor government

Speaker: NA
Text: ratified ILO convention 111. This required a commitment to remove discrimination in

Speaker: NA
Text: employment on the basis of race, colour, gender, political opinion, national extraction or

Speaker: NA
Text: social origin. Importantly, however, it also involved taking positive action to promote real

Speaker: NA
Text: equality of opportunity in employment. In 1973, the government's position was fully

Speaker: NA
Text: supported by business, the ACTU and the state governments. As a result of this commitment,

Speaker: NA
Text: the first federal antidiscrimination law, the Racial Discrimination Act 1975, was enacted,

Speaker: NA
Text: making it unlawful to take certain actions by reason of race, colour, religion or national or

Speaker: NA
Text: ethnic origin of a person or a relative or associate of that person.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, before the bill was introduced into parliament, the conservative then Liberal-

Speaker: NA
Text: National Party coalition government came to power in 1975. It took another nine years and a

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party victory before this legislation was finally passed. During this period, those states

Speaker: NA
Text: which had Labor Party governments put in place their own antidiscrimination legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: They took matters into their own hands, enabling citizens to make formal complaints in the

Speaker: NA
Text: face of discrimination based on gender, race, ethnic origin, religion and physical disability.

Speaker: NA
Text: So, while Australia today can be very proud of its equality, it clearly has not always been

Speaker: NA
Text: the case. We only need to recall our treatment of Indigenous Australians, the White Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: policy, the Cronulla riot and our growing mistrust of certain nationalities. Today sometimes I

Speaker: NA
Text: despair when I hear language that is being used in reference to diversity, inclusion and

Speaker: NA
Text: multiculturalism. More and more I hear words of fear, of exclusion, calls for the building of

Speaker: NA
Text: walls and fortresses, calls for the banning of certain clothing, calls for the banning of certain

Speaker: NA
Text: foods and even calls for the banning of certain groups from entering the country. These voices

Speaker: NA
Text: are very, very few, but they are very loud. We must remember that: they are very few but

Speaker: NA
Text: unfortunately very loud.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no doubt that the recent demonisation of refugees has contributed to the language

Speaker: NA
Text: of fear, and it is contaminating the way we view our cultural diversity. But I am certain that in

Speaker: NA
Text: this place, if we take a moment to see this within a global context, we know that there are

Speaker: NA
Text: over 60 million refugees seeking refuge. I support united, equal rights for all, not just for

Speaker: NA
Text: some but for everyone. (Time expired)

Speaker: Dr ALY
Text: Cowan) (12:02): I rise here today to talk about equality for all Australians. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have spent a long part of my life talking about equality and working towards equality. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: devoted many years to that. So I stand here today torn, I guess, in speaking about this issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the one hand, I think: it is the year 2016. Shouldn't we, as a progressive, First World

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: nation, take it for granted that all Australians have equal rights and that the equal rights for all

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians are embedded in everything that we do? Don't all Australians already enjoy equal

Speaker: NA
Text: rights? Why do we even need to be talking about this in this day and age?

Speaker: NA
Text: But, on the other hand, I know through my own experiences that, though we have formal

Speaker: NA
Text: equal rights for most things-bar of course marriage equality-and for most people, those

Speaker: NA
Text: formal rights that are by law accorded to all Australians do not necessarily translate into

Speaker: NA
Text: substantive equality and into substantive rights, into an equality where all Australians are not

Speaker: NA
Text: just accorded equal rights but have equal access to opportunities and equal outcomes. That

Speaker: NA
Text: kind of equality recognises that not all of us start life on an equal playing field. The provision

Speaker: NA
Text: of equal rights for all means that no single person's rights or the rights for some group are

Speaker: NA
Text: over and above anyone else's rights or the rights of another group.

Speaker: NA
Text: This morning I spoke to the media about an experience I had while growing up. When I

Speaker: NA
Text: was 10 years old, I was pursued by a young girl of the same age, 10 years old, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: schoolyard. For some reason she disliked me from the very first day I started at this new

Speaker: NA
Text: school. As a 10-year-old, I never quite understood why she disliked me. I had never done

Speaker: NA
Text: anything to her. We had never had any real altercations in the schoolyard, but Christine-that

Speaker: NA
Text: was her name-and her friend Iris would seek me out every single lunchtime and every single

Speaker: NA
Text: recess time. They would follow me around the playground and taunt me. One lunch time it

Speaker: NA
Text: culminated in Christine spitting in my face, telling me that I was a dirty Muslim, a dirty Arab,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that she hated me because I did not believe in Jesus. Of course, Muslims do believe in

Speaker: NA
Text: Jesus, but that was beside the point. I then went to my teacher Mrs Phillips. I was very

Speaker: NA
Text: distraught when I reported to her what Christine had just done. Rather than her offer any kind

Speaker: NA
Text: of comfort, rather than pull up Christine and Iris for the comments they had made, it was a

Speaker: NA
Text: case of: we are not considered equal.

Speaker: NA
Text: I note that there are some people in this parliament and in this government who would seek

Speaker: NA
Text: to argue that they have a right to free speech. I would ask those people whether they think that

Speaker: NA
Text: their right to free speech is better than or worth more than my right to feel protected, whether

Speaker: NA
Text: they think that their right to be a bigot is worth more than my right to have a form of recourse,

Speaker: NA
Text: to have some form of justice, to be able to call out the things, the activities, the behaviours

Speaker: NA
Text: that are taken against me not because of anything I have said or not because of anything I

Speaker: NA
Text: have done but simply because of the colour of my skin.

Speaker: NA
Text: We cannot claim to have an Australia where all Australians are equal if we do not pursue

Speaker: NA
Text: all rights equally. We cannot claim to have an Australia where every Australian has equal

Speaker: NA
Text: rights if we pursue the rights of one group over and above the rights of another group. All

Speaker: NA
Text: rights are worth pursuing and all rights are worth pursuing equally. So I ask: is my life and

Speaker: NA
Text: my rights the lesser? Am I second-class citizen where my right to feel protected is less than

Speaker: NA
Text: somebody's right to be a bigot? These are questions that I think we should not have to ask in

Speaker: NA
Text: the year 2016; but, sadly, we do have to ask them.

Speaker: NA
Text: This morning I received death threats. I do not worry about myself because, in this place, I

Speaker: NA
Text: am afforded the protections that not many people are afforded. But these were death threats

Speaker: NA
Text: against my family. Somebody came out and said that they would like to kill my family.

Speaker: NA
Text: Where are my rights?

Speaker: NA
Text: Can we honestly say that all Australians have equal rights when we are sitting in this

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament debating about whether or not we should take away an essential law that has

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: served Australia well for 20 years, a part of the Racial Discrimination Act that has served

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia well for 20 years and that has protected people like me for 20 years? Can we

Speaker: NA
Text: honestly say that we have achieved equal rights for all Australians?

Speaker: NA
Text: Just to finish: we cannot talk about equal rights for all Australians without also talking

Speaker: NA
Text: about the substantive and very real fact that inequality exists for many Australians in many,

Speaker: NA
Text: many different ways, not just in the ways that I have just mentioned through my personal

Speaker: NA
Text: story but for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities, for our LGBTIQ

Speaker: NA
Text: communities and for the communities of the outer suburbs for whom inequality exists in the

Speaker: NA
Text: lack of access to infrastructure, services and job opportunities. In my electorate of Cowan, a

Speaker: NA
Text: child growing up in Wanneroo is 30 per cent less likely to finish school. A family living in

Speaker: NA
Text: Lockridge has half the income of those in the inner suburbs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Until we recognise the inequality that exists for people in Australia in all its forms, not just

Speaker: NA
Text: in the forms that affect people like me-because, let us face it, I am also privileged to be in

Speaker: NA
Text: the position that I am in and feel honoured to be in the position that I am in. Inequality also

Speaker: NA
Text: exists for people who are not racially different or who are not religious minorities. It exists in

Speaker: NA
Text: different ways for different people in Australia. Until we recognise the real and substantive

Speaker: NA
Text: impact of those inequalities across Australia, diversely across all forms and all backgrounds

Speaker: NA
Text: for all Australians, we can never stop talking about this. We need to continue talking about

Speaker: NA
Text: this, and, more than that, we need to continue taking action to ensure that those inequalities do

Speaker: NA
Text: not continue to affect standards of living, quality of life and mental health for people across

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. For we will never be truly free, and we will never be a truly progressive country,

Speaker: NA
Text: until we are all well and truly equal.

Speaker: Ms BUTLER
Text: Griffith) (12:12): I too rise to speak in relation to this motion moved by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister and supported by Bill Shorten, the Leader of the Opposition, in what was

Speaker: NA
Text: intended to be a moment of national unity reflecting the same type of moment of national

Speaker: NA
Text: unity that occurred 20 years ago in 1996 when then Prime Minister John Howard and Kim

Speaker: NA
Text: Beazley, the Leader of the Opposition at the time, moved a motion in the same terms. Since

Speaker: NA
Text: this motion was moved, it has become, if anything, more important for national leadership on

Speaker: NA
Text: issues of unity than ever before in the history of this nation. We are in a situation today where

Speaker: NA
Text: decades of commitment to multiculturalism, immigration and reconciliation are at risk of

Speaker: NA
Text: being eroded-where that progress is at risk of being eroded-and that is a terrible thing for

Speaker: NA
Text: our nation. Not only is it a terrible thing because of the sharp end of bigotry and racism but it

Speaker: NA
Text: is a terrible thing because multiculturalism, immigration and movements towards

Speaker: NA
Text: reconciliation have done so much for this country over such a long period of time.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is estimated that 10 million people have arrived and settled in Australia since the First

Speaker: NA
Text: Fleet came here. Seven million of them have come to Australia since 1945, so there has been

Speaker: NA
Text: a massive amount of postwar migration to Australia. That massive amount of postwar

Speaker: NA
Text: migration means that, today, one in four Australians was born overseas and almost half of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians-46 per cent-have at least one parent who was born overseas. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: contributing to making us the incredibly successful multicultural country that we have been

Speaker: NA
Text: for a very long time. It is estimated that migrants provide an estimated fiscal benefit of over

Speaker: NA
Text: $10 billion in their first 10 years of settlement here in Australia, so it is not just a cultural

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution, which is in and of itself very important, but an economic one.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: The economic impacts are worth mentioning because they are so significant. Migration

Speaker: NA
Text: Council Australia estimated that by 2050 migration would be contributing $1.6 trillion to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's GDP. It will have added 15.7 per cent to Australia's workforce participation rate,

Speaker: NA
Text: 21.9 per cent to after-tax real wages for low-skilled workers and 5.9 per cent in GDP per

Speaker: NA
Text: capita growth. They have estimated that by 2050 each individual migrant would be

Speaker: NA
Text: contributing, on average, 10 per cent more to Australia's economy than existing residents.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is not the only set of reporting or modelling in relation to the economic contributions

Speaker: NA
Text: of migrants. Professor Graeme Hugo's report Economic, social and civic contributions of first

Speaker: NA
Text: and second generation humanitarian entrants, which was a study commissioned by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Immigration and Citizenship, found that refugees and other humanitarian

Speaker: NA
Text: entrants provided significant economic benefit to our country. The report's analysis of data by

Speaker: NA
Text: country of birth found that for second-generation humanitarian arrivals-people whose

Speaker: NA
Text: parents came here as refugees-at least half of the nationality groups had a higher level of

Speaker: NA
Text: participation than the Australian-born population and that, because humanitarian entrants are

Speaker: NA
Text: highly entrepreneurial, with a higher than average proportion of those entrants engaging in

Speaker: NA
Text: small and medium business enterprises, that makes a contribution to our economy. Also there

Speaker: NA
Text: is the willingness of people who have come from very difficult situations to fill some low-

Speaker: NA
Text: wage and low-skilled jobs.

Speaker: NA
Text: All of these things are an economic contribution to our nation, and we should remember

Speaker: NA
Text: them, but more importantly when we talk about national unity we should remember the sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: country that we want to be. We should remember the sort of country that we dream of being.

Speaker: NA
Text: Racism, the coarsening of public debate, public attacks and vilification do not just hurt the

Speaker: NA
Text: people who are vilified; they hurt everyone. They hurt our entire society. No-one gets to live

Speaker: NA
Text: on an island in Australia-in a metaphorical sense; obviously there are people living on

Speaker: NA
Text: islands! No person gets to live isolated from our society. That is not the way it works. No

Speaker: NA
Text: matter how wealthy you are, no matter how poor you are, no matter what you do or where you

Speaker: NA
Text: have come from, the nature of Australian society affects your life.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is why we should be very concerned about some of the division that is starting to

Speaker: NA
Text: arise. In my own electorate it took the form of a party that was aimed at stopping Muslim

Speaker: NA
Text: immigration into Australia and that ran against me at the last federal election. It is also a

Speaker: NA
Text: situation where you see vilification and abuse online. The sorts of things that nobody would

Speaker: NA
Text: even have thought of saying on the street 20 years ago are now routinely written online.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was particularly thinking about this today. I was recently in the media talking about a

Speaker: NA
Text: racial vilification case where some students had been alleged to have written some Facebook

Speaker: NA
Text: posts after not being able to use an Indigenous-specific computer lab, using words like,

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Where's the white supremacist lab?' and, 'Why are we meeting segregation with segregation?'

Speaker: NA
Text: There was a Facebook post-and the person whose name was on it said it was a hacking, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course-using the phrase 'ITT' and then the n-word. There were a number of matters alleged

Speaker: NA
Text: in this case.

Speaker: NA
Text: The case itself was not successful, because the judge found that there was no reasonable

Speaker: NA
Text: prospect of success and struck it out around eight months after the applicants had made a

Speaker: NA
Text: strike-out application. That, to me, goes to show something really important, which is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: vilification laws are quite narrow in this country, and rightly so. You want to have vilification

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: laws that meet their aims of both signalling the inappropriateness and wrongness of

Speaker: NA
Text: vilification and providing a remedy when the worst cases of vilification arise.

Speaker: NA
Text: I spoke about that case on television recently, and today I received an email from someone

Speaker: NA
Text: I have known for a long time but not very well, and that is Susan Moriarty. She wrote to me:

Speaker: NA
Text: I am the lawyer acting for Cindy Prior-

Speaker: NA
Text: who was the applicant in that case. She said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Up until Friday 18 November, there were over 9,000 comments-

Speaker: NA
Text: online-

Speaker: NA
Text: about Cindy's case. It has been like being forced to watch a public flogging. 'Just kill her - problem

Speaker: NA
Text: solved' wrote one North American on The Australian Facebook page, while another wrote 'wrap that

Speaker: NA
Text: bitch in plastic and sink her in the sea'. Another wrote 'let's get crowd funding going, so we can

Speaker: NA
Text: bankrupt this black bitch' while another wrote 'she can't have been vilified because if she had she'd been

Speaker: NA
Text: lynched by now'. Another wrote 'this black-

Speaker: NA
Text: 'c-word'-

Speaker: NA
Text: has set back the constitutional amendment - remember that Prior'. Another screamed for her ovaries to

Speaker: NA
Text: be torn from her body and burned so that she could never breed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Moriarty wrote:

Speaker: NA
Text: On and on and on and on went these murderous inclinations by white Australia. She arrived home to

Speaker: NA
Text: read this on her Facebook –

Speaker: NA
Text: I just want you to know that you're a racist bigot and should be held accountable for your racist

Speaker: NA
Text: bigotry. Instead of you flashing a victim card while discriminating against individuals on the basis of

Speaker: NA
Text: their race, why don't you take a step back and realise what a hypocrite and unbelievably racist piece of

Speaker: NA
Text: shit you are-

Speaker: NA
Text: 'c-word. F-word you.'-

Speaker: NA
Text: You need special treatment because you cannot take responsibility for yourself as an individual. Anyone

Speaker: NA
Text: giving you special treatment is just practicing soft bigotry of low expectations. They expect you to be a

Speaker: NA
Text: leech, you-

Speaker: NA
Text: 'f-ing c-word.' Ms Moriarty went on to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: Six month ago, the 'White Lives Matter' movement ... leafleted her-

Speaker: NA
Text: the applicant's-

Speaker: NA
Text: suburb in Western Australia. Because she-

Speaker: NA
Text: the applicant-

Speaker: NA
Text: was unambiguously an indigenous Australian she had remained hidden indoors for several days.

Speaker: NA
Text: What is also interesting is the reaction of some people who went onto a Facebook page that

Speaker: NA
Text: had been created by a former QUT student after that case had been struck out. It was struck

Speaker: NA
Text: out in early November. It makes for pretty awful reading, to be honest. Students or apparent

Speaker: NA
Text: students-maybe they had all been hacked-wrote: 'ITT: n-word' the same quote that had

Speaker: NA
Text: been alleged in this matter. There was a chap-it appears to be a chap, but it is Facebook and

Speaker: NA
Text: maybe they had all been hacked-who said:

Speaker: NA
Text: All the aboriginals accomplished in forty thousand years in Australia is just some shit finger paintings.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another person said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Apparently they're the only "civilisation" to never independently invent the wheel

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Another person said: 'ITT n-word', again, the same quote that was alleged in the case. Another

Speaker: NA
Text: person said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Where's the white supremacist computer lab so I can continue this thread properly

Speaker: NA
Text: Another person said:

Speaker: NA
Text: I wonder if you can say ITT-

Speaker: NA
Text: 'n-word'-

Speaker: NA
Text: on ss2.0 again?

Speaker: NA
Text: The respondent who was alleged to have said it appears to have said-it may not be him;

Speaker: NA
Text: maybe it was hacked:

Speaker: NA
Text: Give it a crack what's the worst that can happen?

Speaker: NA
Text: These things are very concerning. It is a coarsening of our public debate and we should be

Speaker: NA
Text: very worried about it.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: instigated by the opposition leader and moved by the Prime Minister. It is a very important

Speaker: NA
Text: motion that we speak on today: the right of all Australians to enjoy equal rights and be treated

Speaker: NA
Text: with equal respect, regardless of race, colour, creed or origin. It is a very important motion

Speaker: NA
Text: and I am proud to speak here today in the people's place, in Parliament House, where we

Speaker: NA
Text: reaffirm our commitment to ensure that all Australians can enjoy the rights and respectful

Speaker: NA
Text: treatment that is often taken for granted by some of us. This is an important matter,

Speaker: NA
Text: irrespective of whether you are an Indigenous Australian or your ancestors migrated here as

Speaker: NA
Text: convicts or free settlers or arrived here recently from Holland or wherever, or even if you

Speaker: NA
Text: came here seeking asylum, or any other permutation of those. We are not first-, secondor

Speaker: NA
Text: third-generation migrants; we are all Australians who have some of those other

Speaker: NA
Text: characteristics. It saddens me greatly when I hear that members of the multicultural

Speaker: NA
Text: community, especially in my electorate of Moreton, have been treated disrespectfully. My

Speaker: NA
Text: dear departed mum taught me that good manners are always important, and I know that my

Speaker: NA
Text: mum never got anything wrong, so I think she was on the money. Sadly, it still happens that

Speaker: NA
Text: people are treated disrespectfully, as we have heard from speakers in the bipartisan support

Speaker: NA
Text: for this motion.

Speaker: NA
Text: In fact, just last week, members of the Taiwanese, Rwandan, Indian, Fijian, Egyptian,

Speaker: NA
Text: Filipino, Bosnian, Pakistani and South African communities joined me in my electorate office

Speaker: NA
Text: to hear the member for Cowan talk about her experience of growing up in a multicultural

Speaker: NA
Text: community. It was a fascinating discussion but, sadly, many of those present at that table

Speaker: NA
Text: shared their own stories of being the victims of racial discrimination. The shared their very

Speaker: NA
Text: real concerns about the possibility of racial discrimination laws being watered down. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: fortunate that my community on Brisbane's south side is pretty much a model of inclusive

Speaker: NA
Text: cultural diversity. I am not being naive; I know that there are still some racists in the

Speaker: NA
Text: community who sometimes get frustrated and articulate things that are horrible, and every

Speaker: NA
Text: now and then there are some manifestations of racism. But, on the whole, our community-

Speaker: NA
Text: like much of modern-day Queensland, I would suggest-celebrates our diversity and the

Speaker: NA
Text: contributions that members of communities have made to Australia irrespective of where they

Speaker: NA
Text: have come from.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: I would just like to mention a few of these considerable contributions. The Sunnybank

Speaker: NA
Text: RSL, with the support of the local Chinese community, created a memorial for all those

Speaker: NA
Text: Chinese Australians, or people of Chinese heritage, who have served Australia in past wars.

Speaker: NA
Text: The memorial recognises soldiers like Billy Sing and Caleb Shang, who fought in the First

Speaker: NA
Text: World War, and Jack Wong Sue, who served Australia in World War II, to name but a few.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are many other great stories of courage and bravery by the Chinese Australian diaspora,

Speaker: NA
Text: and they have been commemorated by this memorial. Just one of the stories, a well-known

Speaker: NA
Text: story, is that of Private Billy Sing, who was a sniper with the Australian 5th Light Horse

Speaker: NA
Text: Regiment. He was a kangaroo shooter originally but went over to Gallipoli and was

Speaker: NA
Text: conservatively credited with more than 150 kills in Gallipoli. He was known to his fellow

Speaker: NA
Text: soldiers as 'the assassin' and was awarded the Distinguished Conduct Medal for conspicuous

Speaker: NA
Text: gallantry as a sniper at ANZAC.

Speaker: NA
Text: The memorial itself was a labour of love for the Chinese community and it has contributed

Speaker: NA
Text: to stronger links between that community and the local RSL. It is a continuing reminder of the

Speaker: NA
Text: diversity, cooperation, understanding and friendship that exists on Brisbane's south side, and

Speaker: NA
Text: it also goes a long way to recognising the slights and racism that existed, perhaps, 100 years

Speaker: NA
Text: ago when people were allowed to fight and die for their country but were not allowed to own

Speaker: NA
Text: land because they were seen to be not Australian because they were Chinese-and there are

Speaker: NA
Text: others.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also point out that the success of the Chinese war memorial has inspired a

Speaker: NA
Text: commemoration of contributions from other communities. There is currently a project

Speaker: NA
Text: underway, which I am excited to be a part of, to erect a memorial for the Indian Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: service men and women who contributed to Australian war efforts in the past and are doing so

Speaker: NA
Text: now. I was pleased to attend a dinner just a few weeks ago, where the winning design for this

Speaker: NA
Text: memorial was announced. We had a mock-up of the winning design, and 11 students from

Speaker: NA
Text: Griffith University turned up at the dinner. I think it is going to be a great project, so I look

Speaker: NA
Text: forward to working with the Indian Australian community and to seeing that completed

Speaker: NA
Text: memorial in due course. Like the Chinese memorial, there will also be bursaries associated

Speaker: NA
Text: with the memorial, so you will have the physical memorial but then you will have the living

Speaker: NA
Text: bursary where students from local high schools will be urged to research and tell those stories.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would also like to mention the contribution of another Australian. I was very pleased to

Speaker: NA
Text: attend an event on the weekend where the member for Fisher was representing the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister. It was for the Australian African community and, at the event on Saturday night, an

Speaker: NA
Text: award was given for an act of incredible bravery by a former refugee from Sudan. Aguek

Speaker: NA
Text: Nyok came to Australia as a refugee from Sudan and now drives a taxi in Brisbane. He took a

Speaker: NA
Text: break from collecting his passengers to get a haircut at the local Moorooka shops one day last

Speaker: NA
Text: month, and as he left the hairdresser's shop he saw smoke billowing out of a bus on

Speaker: NA
Text: Beaudesert Road-at a bus stop that I walk through every morning when I am in Brisbane.

Speaker: NA
Text: Aguek saw passengers trapped inside and bashed open the back door and, by his bravery,

Speaker: NA
Text: saved 11 people who were trapped inside the bus, which was filling up with toxic fumes. This

Speaker: NA
Text: was an incredible act of bravery. Many people would not run towards flames, especially in a

Speaker: NA
Text: bus that might explode. But this brave Australian says:

Speaker: NA
Text: I just helped people and that is what I am expecting from my fellow Australians if I was in the same

Speaker: NA
Text: situation.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: We can all learn from his bravery and, dare I say it, his humility. Aguek Nyok was the very

Speaker: NA
Text: worthy recipient of the African Australians Bravery and Heroes Award at the celebration of

Speaker: NA
Text: African Australians national awards held at the Brisbane City Hall on Saturday night.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I said, I am very lucky to be constantly reminded in my community of the valuable

Speaker: NA
Text: contributions that can be made by all Australians in a diverse and inclusive community. This

Speaker: NA
Text: motion reaffirms our commitment to maintaining that successful inclusive community. The

Speaker: NA
Text: success of our multicultural communities is in large part dependent on continuing to denounce

Speaker: NA
Text: racial intolerance. The recently announced inquiry into freedom of speech will look at how

Speaker: NA
Text: our laws that prevent racial hate speech are working. It is important to remember that freedom

Speaker: NA
Text: of speech has no explicit constitutional protection. Commonwealth, state and territory

Speaker: NA
Text: legislative protections are not absolute. They contain necessary limits to accommodate the

Speaker: NA
Text: countervailing public interest. There can be a natural tension between one person's right to be

Speaker: NA
Text: free from racial discrimination and another person's perception that they have a right to speak

Speaker: NA
Text: freely. The total freedom of one will negate the rights of the other. It is necessary for good

Speaker: NA
Text: governments to balance these important rights.

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister Gough Whitlam introduced the Racial Discrimination Act in 1975. From

Speaker: NA
Text: memory, I do not think it was broadly supported by the Liberal Party, apart from Neville

Speaker: NA
Text: Bonner, the senator from Queensland; nevertheless, the Fraser government did not do

Speaker: NA
Text: anything to abolish the Racial Discrimination Act when it was in power. This important

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation has been protecting individuals against discrimination for 41 years. Then, just over

Speaker: NA
Text: 20 years ago, the protections in section 18C and exemptions contained in section 18D were

Speaker: NA
Text: added. Then Attorney-General Michael Lavarch said in his second reading speech to

Speaker: NA
Text: introduce the bill:

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill is an appropriate and measured response to closing the identified gap in the legal protection of

Speaker: NA
Text: all Australians from extreme racist behaviour. It strikes a balance between the right of free speech and

Speaker: NA
Text: the other rights and interests of Australia and Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the years since 18C was added the Human Rights Commission has received about 100

Speaker: NA
Text: complaints a year, and most of these are resolved through a conciliation process. Only about

Speaker: NA
Text: five end up in court annually. Obviously the claims are limited. I am supportive of the idea

Speaker: NA
Text: that we do not offend people because of their race, obviously. Religion is something to

Speaker: NA
Text: discuss as another topic. I thank the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition for this

Speaker: NA
Text: motion before the chamber.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr STEPHEN JONES (Whitlam) (12:32): This motion has languished in the basement

Speaker: NA
Text: of parliamentary business for a couple of months-two months does not sound like a lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: time to most Australians but if you look at what has gone on over the last two months, it has

Speaker: NA
Text: been a very long time indeed. Last night I read the Prime Minister's speech on this motion. It

Speaker: NA
Text: was a good speech-a very good speech. There was not a word in there that I could not agree

Speaker: NA
Text: with. Sadly, it was very difficult, looking at the Prime Minister who gave that speech two

Speaker: NA
Text: months ago, who spoke most eloquently and passionately in support of this motion, to

Speaker: NA
Text: recognise the Prime Minister who has done very little in the last couple of days to confront

Speaker: NA
Text: the rising tide of bigotry, including bigotry in this place.

Speaker: NA
Text: The motion reconfirms our commitment to the right of all Australians to enjoy equal

Speaker: NA
Text: rights-a policy which is based wholly on non-discriminatory grounds when it comes to race,

Speaker: NA
Text: colour, creed or country of origin. It reaffirms our commitment to the process of

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: reconciliation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people; it reaffirms our commitment

Speaker: NA
Text: to maintaining Australia as a culturally diverse, tolerant and open society. How easy would it

Speaker: NA
Text: have been during question time yesterday for the Prime Minister to repeat those words that he

Speaker: NA
Text: spoke so passionately not two months ago? What has changed?

Speaker: NA
Text: Much has been written in the last two weeks about what has changed: Trumpism and the US

Speaker: NA
Text: election; back further we can look at Brexit-the vote by millions of Brits to excise

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves from the European Union; and closer to home we can look at the results of the

Speaker: NA
Text: 2016 election and now the monumental swing against the National Party in the New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales by-election in Orange.

Speaker: NA
Text: From Australia, Trumpism looks like a disaffection with the political class-technocrats,

Speaker: NA
Text: the city elites and the experts. Those very same insiders, those experts, are now bemoaning

Speaker: NA
Text: what appears to them to be post-facts politics. In fact, they do it with the exact same vigour

Speaker: NA
Text: the way that their detractors conclude that all of those facts and all those theories are just a

Speaker: NA
Text: conspiracy from the insiders, those very people who are controlling and making the decisions

Speaker: NA
Text: that we do not agree with. There is more than a nagging suspicion amongst this group that the

Speaker: NA
Text: trade deals have got more downside than upside, unless you are a merchant banker. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: belief that immigration policy is working against their interest in some sort of zero-sum, one-

Speaker: NA
Text: more-mouth-to-feed way. In all this, words like 'innovation', 'modernity', 'economic change'

Speaker: NA
Text: and even 'multiculturalism' sound like doublespeak for a future that does not include these

Speaker: NA
Text: people.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a lot we can recognise in our own country in all of this. It really is not that hard to

Speaker: NA
Text: understand if you are listening and, of course, can be a stretch if it is a long way from your

Speaker: NA
Text: lived experience. If you are a city professional putting in 50 to 60 hours a week and pulling in

Speaker: NA
Text: your six-zero-figured salary, it might be a bit hard to understand that upwards of a million

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians are in jobs where they are not getting enough hours to bring in the income which

Speaker: NA
Text: is meeting their cost of living. If you are working these mad hours in the inner city, it might

Speaker: NA
Text: be very difficult for you to understand that there are people who are in a casual or a part-time

Speaker: NA
Text: job who do not have enough work to pay their bills.

Speaker: NA
Text: If you stop listening, you are not going to hear what they are saying. If you are listening,

Speaker: NA
Text: you might hear the guy who is saying: 'I no longer have a permanent job' or 'I'm 29 years of

Speaker: NA
Text: age and I've never had a permanent job' or 'For the last month, I've spent four hours travelling

Speaker: NA
Text: to and from work everyday for a job that I may not have in six months time and people ask

Speaker: NA
Text: me why I don't move from the place where I live to the place where I'm working. I tell you

Speaker: NA
Text: reason I don't move is because I can't afford to rent or buy a house there and I don't even

Speaker: NA
Text: know if I'm going to have that job in a few months time.' These are the people who are deeply

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned with what is going on in Australia and we hear their concerns. When you have a

Speaker: NA
Text: decent conversation with these people, when you duck below the dog-whistling and all the

Speaker: NA
Text: noise and the concern and you talk to them about their concerns, you talk to them about

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Islamophobia'-a word that they would never use-they might say, 'I really am concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: about all that bombing and that killing that is going on in Iraq and Syria, and I don't want that

Speaker: NA
Text: stuff going on here.' Is that too hard to understand? It really is not too hard to understand.

Speaker: NA
Text: America with its politics, its economy and its culture are very different places to Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: but there are plenty of similarities. We are both advanced economies with cities that are fully

Speaker: NA
Text: embedded in the modern and international economy and regions that are in industrial decline.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: We have been trading nations that have enjoyed the benefits of trade with Asia and, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: case of the United States with Latin America, have been able to spread the benefits of that

Speaker: NA
Text: trade to jobs in labour-intensive sectors, particularly in resources and manufacturing. But now

Speaker: NA
Text: with the growth in Asian manufacturing capacity, it means that the region that was once the

Speaker: NA
Text: market for our goods is now the origins of our import competition. If you live in one of these

Speaker: NA
Text: big cities, the transition from the manufacturing economy to a service economy might have

Speaker: NA
Text: been less marked. But if you live in a region like mine, it has been extreme, and I know in

Speaker: NA
Text: your region, Deputy Speaker Vamvakinou, it has also been extreme. You see, the goods that

Speaker: NA
Text: you were once able to afford, which were the trade-off for those well-paid jobs-those goods

Speaker: NA
Text: have disappeared.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the heart of this discontent is economics, because the truth for Australia and for the

Speaker: NA
Text: world is that we have dropped the ball when it comes to equality. There is growing inequality

Speaker: NA
Text: right across the board, but nowhere is it greater than between city and regional Australia. In

Speaker: NA
Text: the Illawarra on the South Coast, unemployment rates are three to five times those in the

Speaker: NA
Text: capital cities. Income disparity is growing rapidly. There are unacceptably high suicide rates

Speaker: NA
Text: all across the country, but these are multiplied by two and three and four in regional Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the circumstance which is breeding discontent; it is inequality which is breeding

Speaker: NA
Text: alienation and discontent. It is the way that we respond to this inequality which defines us. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is the way that we respond to the exclusion and the fear and uncertainty which defines us as a

Speaker: NA
Text: nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: It would be quite open to us to use parliament and the privilege of our titles to stoke the fire

Speaker: NA
Text: of discontent. We could do that. We know that there are ready ears out there for that

Speaker: NA
Text: message-people who are already hurting, because they are not getting the benefits that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister talks about of these never-more-exciting times where we are 'nimble'. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: another world to the world that these people live in. We could convince people that the real

Speaker: NA
Text: cause-of unemployment, of homelessness, of rental stress, of the time they are spending in a

Speaker: NA
Text: traffic jam, or of the train that does not run on time-is these wretched souls that are

Speaker: NA
Text: languishing in detention on Manus Island and Nauru, and that all we have to do as a nation is

Speaker: NA
Text: stop them coming to Australia. We could convince people that that was the truth, but that

Speaker: NA
Text: would be a lie.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is the way that we respond to these things which defines us as humans. It defines us as

Speaker: NA
Text: parliamentarians. It defines us as people who have been sent here to uphold the best traditions

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australian democracy. Sadly, what we have seen on display over the last week is a long

Speaker: NA
Text: way from the eloquent words of the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition when

Speaker: NA
Text: they brought this motion into the House two months ago. This motion is the sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: bipartisanship that we need. It is bipartisanship around the best traditions of Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: democracy and not the worst.

Speaker: Mr KEOGH
Text: Burt) (12:43): It was 20 years ago, almost to the day, that then Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister Howard moved a motion, first proposed by opposition leader Kim Beazley, in the

Speaker: NA
