Text: same words as the motion we are debating today: to reaffirm the commitment of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian government and the Australian parliament to equal rights. Looking back on Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard's reflections in this place on that day does show that the more things change, the

Speaker: NA
Text: more they can stay the same. Mr Howard said:

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: It is natural that people, particularly those who feel themselves at the sharp end of challenge and

Speaker: NA
Text: anxiety in industries that have seen extensive job losses, should feel some sense of anxiety about

Speaker: NA
Text: immigration levels. It is our obligation to point out, where it is appropriate, the error in their

Speaker: NA
Text: understanding of the causation between immigration and job security.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is no coincidence that the need to reaffirm this House's commitment to equal rights,

Speaker: NA
Text: regardless of race, colour, creed or origin, has come at another point in our history where

Speaker: NA
Text: some Australians are feeling left behind and where inequality is on the rise. It is very easy for

Speaker: NA
Text: politicians and so-called leaders to talk to those people-those who are out of work or feeling

Speaker: NA
Text: the pinch of an economic downturn-about patriotism and the supposed threat of

Speaker: NA
Text: immigration. It is easy to create an enemy, and to whip up fear and ride that sentiment into

Speaker: NA
Text: power, but that does not solve the problem. Those people who you were talking to remain out

Speaker: NA
Text: of work, down on their luck and struggling. Those who have come to Australia from across

Speaker: NA
Text: the seas, most of whom have given so much to our country, are caught in the middle,

Speaker: NA
Text: demonised for crimes they never committed to appease people they have never met. This

Speaker: NA
Text: creation of fear is not leadership. It is not what we are here to do.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Beazley, on the day this motion was first brought, impressed upon this place the need

Speaker: NA
Text: for leadership. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: But each time each new wave of migrants came in - whether they were from southern Europe, eastern

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe, the Middle East and now more recently from Asia - there has been a requirement on the

Speaker: NA
Text: political leadership in this country to point out the advantage; to mould, insofar as we can, and without

Speaker: NA
Text: arrogance, community opinion that makes it acceptable and ensures that the community sustains its

Speaker: NA
Text: tolerant and decent traditions. There has been that requirement constantly upon us for leadership.

Speaker: NA
Text: Over the past 200 years, Australia has made enormous progress on racial tolerance led by a

Speaker: NA
Text: series of true leaders. From a nation state born in conflict with the original inhabitants of this

Speaker: NA
Text: great land-built then on a foundation of a White Australia policy-over 200 years, we have

Speaker: NA
Text: begun to bridge that conflict with Indigenous Australia. We have deconstructed the White

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia policy. We have moved away from a sectarian society, and opened our nation up to

Speaker: NA
Text: immigration from Europe first and then across the globe. It would be a tragedy of the highest

Speaker: NA
Text: order for us to abandon that progress, to walk away from the achievements of our forebears

Speaker: NA
Text: and walk back towards the fear and hatred of a sectarian society. Right now, our country

Speaker: NA
Text: needs us all in this place to stand up.

Speaker: NA
Text: The rights expressed in this motion are what our cousins in the United States would call

Speaker: NA
Text: 'self-evident truths'. They are the values that tie together our nations and bring together liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: democracies across the world. But being self evident does not mean that we do not have to

Speaker: NA
Text: fight for these rights. We must continue every day to press the case for a multicultural

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia; that our multicultural Australia is where we celebrate the practice of many cultures,

Speaker: NA
Text: but always consistent with and underpinned by Australian values.

Speaker: NA
Text: We must remind ourselves and our constituents of the contributions that different cultures

Speaker: NA
Text: have made to Australia: the Irish Australians who moved here in the 19th century due to

Speaker: NA
Text: famine, like my family; the Chinese at the turn of the 20th century; the Eastern European

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians who came out after the Second World War and helped to build the Snowy

Speaker: NA
Text: Mountain Scheme, or the orchards that surround my electorate of Burt and the hills of

Speaker: NA
Text: Roleystone, Karragullen and Pickering; the Vietnamese Australians who came as refugees

Speaker: NA
Text: and who have become leaders across business, politics and the arts, like the South Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Governor; the Lebanese Australians, like the former New South Wales Governor; and

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: businessmen and philanthropists, and so many more, as well as those coming to Australia now

Speaker: NA
Text: like those from India and South Asia, through the western areas of the electorate of Burt. All

Speaker: NA
Text: of these people have one thing in common: they are Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would close by noting another comment by Mr Howard in his speech 20 years ago,

Speaker: NA
Text: which, given some of the commentary from recent days by government ministers, seems more

Speaker: NA
Text: striking than ever.

Speaker: NA
Text: I remain very fond of the fact-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Howard said-

Speaker: NA
Text: that I was a member of the coalition government led by Malcolm Fraser which, in the late 1970s, chose

Speaker: NA
Text: to admit to this country tens of thousands of people from war-torn Indochina. Inevitably-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Howard went on-

Speaker: NA
Text: the character of Australia has changed as a result of this migration. Much of that change has been

Speaker: NA
Text: profoundly beneficial. I think this country owes an enormous debt to people who have chosen this as

Speaker: NA
Text: their home; people who have come from the four corners of the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: This motion 20 years ago articulated the Australia that we were becoming as we moved into

Speaker: NA
Text: the 21st century. Today, 20 years later, the prosperity and unity of our nation relies on us

Speaker: NA
Text: living the values of this motion, and I am proud to reaffirm our commitment to tolerance and

Speaker: NA
Text: diversity today.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr BRIAN MITCHELL (Lyons) (12:49): This motion to reaffirm Australia's bipartisan

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to equality irrespective of race, creed, colour or origin, was moved by the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister on 10 October, just 47 days ago. It was another era because, on 10 October, Donald

Speaker: NA
Text: Trump was not the President-elect of the United States and Steve Bannon, a close ally of

Speaker: NA
Text: America's Neo-Nazi movement, was not the new Chief Strategist in the White House. When I

Speaker: NA
Text: put my name down to speak to this motion, I never intended to talk about America, but we

Speaker: NA
Text: must talk about it. There is a direct relevance to what is going on in America and the subject

Speaker: NA
Text: of this motion in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Before becoming Donald Trump's campaign chief of staff, Steve Bannon used to run a

Speaker: NA
Text: political website called Breitbart. Breitbart started out publishing news with a conservative

Speaker: NA
Text: viewpoint-somewhat like a hybrid of The Australian and The Daily Telegraph newspapers.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was journalism but through a right-wing, wind-them-up prism with inflammatory headlines.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under Bannon, Breitbart became extreme, spreading the lies about Obama not being

Speaker: NA
Text: American. In July this year, Bannon bragged that he had transformed Breitbart into 'the

Speaker: NA
Text: platform for the alt-right movement'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Because of Bannon, the alternative right and its leader, Richard Spencer, gained notoriety,

Speaker: NA
Text: influence and access to the political mainstream. Last week-in fact, just days ago-a video

Speaker: NA
Text: emerged of an alt-right conference held in a federal building in Washington DC. This is how

Speaker: NA
Text: The New York Times newspaper reported Spencer's address:

Speaker: NA
Text: He railed against Jews and, with a smile, quoted Nazi propaganda in the original German. America, he

Speaker: NA
Text: said, belonged to white people, whom he called the "children of the sun," a race of conquerors and

Speaker: NA
Text: creators who had been marginalized but now, in the era of President-elect Donald J Trump, were

Speaker: NA
Text: "awakening to their own identity."

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: As he finished, several audience members had their arms outstretched in a Nazi salute. When Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Spencer, or perhaps another person standing near him at the front of the room-it was not clear who-

Speaker: NA
Text: shouted, "Heil the people! Heil victory," the room shouted it back.

Speaker: NA
Text: You do not have to take The New York Times's word for it; there is a video-Nazi salutes and

Speaker: NA
Text: all. So let us be clear: the alternative right is an avowed movement of white supremacists-a

Speaker: NA
Text: group described by journalist Shaun King, who writes for the New York Daily News, as 'the

Speaker: NA
Text: KKK without the hoods, skinheads with suits and ties'. The alt-right has been enthusiastically

Speaker: NA
Text: supported by Steve Bannon, and Steve Bannon is now the chief strategist for the White

Speaker: NA
Text: House.

Speaker: NA
Text: As journalist Shaun King reported earlier today:

Speaker: NA
Text: When you build, fund, and promote the online home for the modern-day Neo-Nazi movement, and

Speaker: NA
Text: openly brag that you have done so, that makes you a supporter and enabler of Neo-Nazis. If someone

Speaker: NA
Text: built, funded, promoted, and openly admitted to creating the online home for the latest iteration of ISIS,

Speaker: NA
Text: you know what they'd be called? Terrorists.

Speaker: NA
Text: So what does all of this have to do with Australia and the motion we are discussing today?

Speaker: NA
Text: We do not live in a vacuum. We cannot ignore what is happening in America, because it is

Speaker: NA
Text: happening across the Western world and it is starting to happen here-UKIP, Brexit, the

Speaker: NA
Text: deeply troubling rise of Le Pen's fascist National Front in France, far-right parties in

Speaker: NA
Text: governing coalitions across Europe and the re-emergence of One Nation in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: In just the past week, the immigration minister made a deplorable comment that the

Speaker: NA
Text: government led by Malcolm Fraser 'did make mistakes in bringing some people in'. The

Speaker: NA
Text: minister went on to refer to Australians as 'second and third generation migrants' and sought

Speaker: NA
Text: to justify his comments by stating that the children and grandchildren of Muslim migrants

Speaker: NA
Text: from Lebanon were overrepresented as national security threats.

Speaker: NA
Text: What the minister did not do was offer an explanation as to what mistake he believed the

Speaker: NA
Text: Fraser government had actually made. How, for example, would he have liked the

Speaker: NA
Text: government of the day to screen migrants? What was it about the screening process that was

Speaker: NA
Text: deficient? What magical device could have screened a migrant to check whether their child or

Speaker: NA
Text: grandchild growing up here might turn out to be a national security threat? I wonder whether

Speaker: NA
Text: the minister might make this wondrous device widely available so young couples can be

Speaker: NA
Text: screened now to see whether their children will end up being criminals. Perhaps he can screen

Speaker: NA
Text: me to tell me whether my future grandchildren will one day smoke pot-or worse, vote

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal!

Speaker: NA
Text: The code behind the minister's reprehensible comments was that the mistake made was that

Speaker: NA
Text: these migrants were Muslim or Lebanese, or both. If there is another way of reading it, I

Speaker: NA
Text: would like him to explain it to the parliament. So we have a minister this week criticising a

Speaker: NA
Text: decision to allow Lebanese Muslim migrants into Australia when, just 47 days ago, we had

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister move this motion to recommit to Australia's equality principle irrespective

Speaker: NA
Text: of race, colour, creed or origin. A lot sure has changed in 47 days.

Speaker: NA
Text: This motion is proudly supported by Labor. My preference would have been to use this

Speaker: NA
Text: speech to talk in more detail about the many great things that immigration has provided

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and how pleased I am that a commitment to equality continues to cross the political

Speaker: NA
Text: divide. After all, I am an immigrant. I arrived here in 1975, with my parents, at the age of

Speaker: NA
Text: seven. My brother was four. Our family became citizens. Of course, to run for election to this

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: place, I was required to surrender my dual citizenship with the United Kingdom. But, apart

Speaker: NA
Text: from being called a pom at school and learning that you do not wear socks with sandals, I

Speaker: NA
Text: never really felt like an immigrant. I have always known in the back of my mind that, when

Speaker: NA
Text: we talk about immigrants in this country, we are not really talking about poms or kiwis; we

Speaker: NA
Text: are talking about people who are not white or whose first language is not English.

Speaker: NA
Text: My parents left family behind when they brought us here, but the language, culture and

Speaker: NA
Text: religion were largely the same. I cannot begin to imagine what it must be like for people from

Speaker: NA
Text: Lebanon, whether Christian or Muslim, or the refugees from Vietnam, who arrived with just

Speaker: NA
Text: the shirts on their backs. But the vast majority of immigrants to this nation forged bright

Speaker: NA
Text: futures here. The success of Australia's immigration is testament to both the commitment of

Speaker: NA
Text: immigrants to their new country and Australia's willingness and ability to provide a

Speaker: NA
Text: welcoming new home. In the fields of science, mathematics, business, politics, education, the

Speaker: NA
Text: arts and others, immigrants and the children and grandchildren of immigrants-Australians-

Speaker: NA
Text: have made wondrous contributions. They deserve better than to be lumped in with the pitiful

Speaker: NA
Text: handful who have turned traitor.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have spent much of this speech talking about what is happening in America-because, to

Speaker: NA
Text: address a problem, you first have to acknowledge that there is one. And there is a problem in

Speaker: NA
Text: the White House when someone like Steve Bannon has the President's ear. As the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition said in his statement in reply to the Prime Minister: 'We need to do more than

Speaker: NA
Text: mouth words of respect. We must thoroughly and publicly reject racism wherever it occurs

Speaker: NA
Text: and whoever says it. There is no place in Australia for extremism no matter the party, no

Speaker: NA
Text: matter the agenda, no matter the importance of their vote.' I too believe we must call out

Speaker: NA
Text: racism when we see it, even-or perhaps especially-when it is given a home, a voice and a

Speaker: NA
Text: platform at the highest political levels of our most important ally and good friend, the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States of America.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sitting suspended from 12:59 to 16:00

Speaker: NA
Text: Equal Rights

Speaker: NA
Text: Consideration resumed of the motion:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) reaffirms its commitment to the right of all Australians to enjoy equal rights and be treated with

Speaker: NA
Text: equal respect regardless of race, colour, creed or origin;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) reaffirms its commitment to maintaining an immigration policy wholly non-discriminatory on

Speaker: NA
Text: grounds of race, colour, creed or origin;

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) reaffirms its commitment to the process of reconciliation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait

Speaker: NA
Text: Islander people, in the context of redressing their profound social and economic disadvantage;

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) reaffirms its commitment to maintaining Australia as a culturally diverse, tolerant and open

Speaker: NA
Text: society, united by an overriding commitment to our nation, and its democratic institutions and values;

Speaker: NA
Text: and

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) denounces racial intolerance in any form as incompatible with the kind of society we are and

Speaker: NA
Text: want to be.

Speaker: Ms VAMVAKINOU
Text: Calwell) (16:00): I am very pleased to be speaking to this motion

Speaker: NA
Text: on equal rights for all Australians that was moved by the Leader of the Opposition and

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: seconded by the Prime Minister. I want to start by saying that I was in your place, Mr Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, just before lunch listening to many of my colleagues speak to this motion. I

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly want to reflect on some of the comments that the member for Cowan made,

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly with a lot of emotion. She began her presentation by asking the rhetorical question:

Speaker: NA
Text: why in 2016 is it necessary that we talk about the preservation of rights and equality before

Speaker: NA
Text: the law for all Australians? I understood clearly where she was coming from. I might have

Speaker: NA
Text: asked myself that question too when I thought about speaking to this motion.

Speaker: NA
Text: We should never take for granted the battles that we have won and the society that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: built here in Australia-a democratic society that has enshrined in law equality for all

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians regardless of their race, colour, creed or origin. We should never take for granted

Speaker: NA
Text: those hard-fought battles by generations of people before us and indeed members of

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament who were in the parliament before us. We should never take for granted that those

Speaker: NA
Text: battles have been won and we no longer need to concern ourselves about these inequalities. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is probably not a bad idea in 2016, some 20 years after the same motion was moved by Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard when he was Prime Minister, to take stock and reflect on where our community is in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to the laws of our land.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to reflect on a couple of things. I want to reflect on the fact that this country has

Speaker: NA
Text: been built by waves of migrants from all over the world, including me. We are often

Speaker: NA
Text: described as a modern multicultural and open society and a democratic country. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: currently some seven million Australians who were born overseas. There are lots of things

Speaker: NA
Text: that unite us, but the one thing that enshrines our rights almost in law is the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Citizenship Act and the fact that we become Australian citizens and as Australian citizens we

Speaker: NA
Text: enjoy the same privileges and have the same obligations.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have a society that is based on some very strong institutions and laws that protect all of

Speaker: NA
Text: us. The Racial Discrimination Act was put in place over four decades or so ago. Laws passed

Speaker: NA
Text: by this parliament and other parliaments are aimed at ensuring everyone has equality and that

Speaker: NA
Text: we are all protected against things said by others that might be hurtful and offensive or that

Speaker: NA
Text: might degrade us. I understand that very much-and I understand where the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Cowan was coming from-because I grew up in this country as a foreigner, I became an

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian citizen and now I am in the Australian parliament. I think I represent what the

Speaker: NA
Text: modern contemporary Australian is today, and I am very proud of that. Obviously I am very

Speaker: NA
Text: keen to ensure that nothing interferes with future generations or current generations of people

Speaker: NA
Text: who are working their way through the integration process here in Australia and are becoming

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have often said to those in particular who are critical of multiculturalism and who argue

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is a divisive thing and we should abandon it-we have sporadic outbreaks of those sorts

Speaker: NA
Text: of debates, and we are having one at the moment; we have had many before in the past, and

Speaker: NA
Text: we will overcome it in the same way that we have overcome it in the past-that

Speaker: NA
Text: multiculturalism for me and for many Australians is really underpinned by these laws. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: also a process by which people become Australians. So it is not a divisive policy; it is 4½

Speaker: NA
Text: decades of government policy that has over the years enjoyed bipartisanship. There have been

Speaker: NA
Text: times, blips along the way, where there have been critics, but, by and large, there has been

Speaker: NA
Text: bipartisanship on this issue, and I think that that is what underpins the strength of our modern

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian multicultural society.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: We have also, in that mix, pursued a non-discriminatory immigration policy. We do not

Speaker: NA
Text: select people on the basis of their race or their colour or their creed or their origin. We do not

Speaker: NA
Text: exclude them, and we do not select them on that basis. We have a non-discriminatory

Speaker: NA
Text: immigration policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: If I look at the period when the White Australia policy was finally done away with, I see in

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate in particular the great Turkish-speaking Australian community that was able to

Speaker: NA
Text: finally come to Australia on the abolition of the White Australia policy. I am sure that at the

Speaker: NA
Text: time there would have been people in my community who would have thought that this was

Speaker: NA
Text: not a good thing-that we would not have wanted Turkish migrants in this country, that they

Speaker: NA
Text: would not have been capable of integrating or that they would have been future problem

Speaker: NA
Text: makers. At the time I probably was a very young child, but I am sure that in my

Speaker: NA
Text: neighbourhood in Broadmeadows there were people who would not have wanted the Turks to

Speaker: NA
Text: come to Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: But when you reflect-and we are now nearing 50 years of Turkish migration in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country-it cannot be said that, with the abolition of the White Australia policy, which then

Speaker: NA
Text: allowed Turks and other non-Europeans or nonwhites to come to this country, there has been

Speaker: NA
Text: a detriment to the Australian community. On the contrary, my community have made a great

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution, and they are continuing to make a great contribution as Australians of Turkish

Speaker: NA
Text: descent and as Australians of the Muslim faith. So the idea that at some point in time we

Speaker: NA
Text: reflect and we say, 'We shouldn't have let those people in because there are some problems

Speaker: NA
Text: today,' really puzzles me and concerns me. I will come to that a little bit later.

Speaker: NA
Text: The 17 per cent or so of my constituents who are of the Muslim faith do come also from

Speaker: NA
Text: Lebanon. I have many of them in my electorate who are actually very good Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: citizens and who are making, as I said, a very good contribution as Australians to this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition to that, I am also very pleased that we are to welcome a very large number of

Speaker: NA
Text: Iraqi Christians-in fact, the biggest number of Iraqi Christians to come to this country in

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria are living in the federal seat of Calwell. They have come to live here under the

Speaker: NA
Text: refugee program. I have spent a lot of my time interacting with them in trying to assist them

Speaker: NA
Text: and teach them about the Australian community that they have come to live in. And, yes,

Speaker: NA
Text: many of them come here with preconceived ideas and views about people of the Muslim faith.

Speaker: NA
Text: I can understand that. They have come out of the Middle East. They still have family who are

Speaker: NA
Text: being persecuted.

Speaker: NA
Text: But I have found that this is important to me as their federal member: rather than use that

Speaker: NA
Text: concern and fear that they have and stir my community, I realise it is absolutely critical that

Speaker: NA
Text: the leadership that I show in my local community is to ensure that I help them through a

Speaker: NA
Text: process of settling and integrating into Australia that helps them to have a positive experience.

Speaker: NA
Text: So I am very, very critical of anyone who chooses to hijack this debate and turn it into a

Speaker: NA
Text: political attack on other people. I am worried about the rise of a particular attitude in our

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian community and in this place because it has now found a political voice. I am very

Speaker: NA
Text: worried that succumbing to that attitude is going to be detrimental to the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: community. The biggest threat to Australia's security or social cohesion is not where people

Speaker: NA
Text: are born; it is rather the racism that often finds expression in this country and the failure of

Speaker: NA
Text: leadership to reject it.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Mr CREWTHER
Text: Dunkley) (16:10): I rise today to speak on the resumption of debate on

Speaker: NA
Text: the motion of the Prime Minister to recognise equal rights for all Australians. As the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister noted, 50 years ago Australia became an early signatory to one of the world's most

Speaker: NA
Text: profound declarations on human rights: the United Nations' International Convention on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination. As many of my colleagues have done

Speaker: NA
Text: already when speaking on this motion, I would like to take this opportunity to reaffirm my

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to the common values that I believe in and that I believe make our nation great.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a commitment to the values which ensure that, regardless of who you are, where you are

Speaker: NA
Text: from, your ethnicity, the colour of your skin, your chosen faith or your ability, no Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: should be denied equal opportunity. This is something that I and many Australians strive

Speaker: NA
Text: towards on a daily basis. This motion, which is of great importance to our society, clearly

Speaker: NA
Text: outlines the values of many Australians who support the importance of equal rights for every

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian, including being treated with respect regardless of ethnicity, colour, creed, origin

Speaker: NA
Text: or any other factor.

Speaker: NA
Text: This motion reaffirms our commitment to maintain Australia as a culturally diverse and

Speaker: NA
Text: open society united by an overriding commitment to our nation and its democratic institutions

Speaker: NA
Text: and values. The values recognised in this motion are common amongst many Australians-

Speaker: NA
Text: for example, notions of freedom which our ADF have fought for over a long period of time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Regardless of their individual background, ethnicity or location in Australia, each migrant

Speaker: NA
Text: who comes here to call Australia home is, in many cases, trying to achieve success for

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves and their families.

Speaker: NA
Text: Before I came into this place, I worked as an international lawyer through the UN at the

Speaker: NA
Text: Kosovo Property Agency in the former Yugoslavia, resolving claims for people who had lost

Speaker: NA
Text: possession of their properties due to the 1998-99 conflict. In Kosovo, there were about 43,000

Speaker: NA
Text: claims for farms, for houses and for businesses-by people who were refugees or internally

Speaker: NA
Text: displaced people, or others. We presented nearly 800 cases before an international tribunal

Speaker: NA
Text: every two months. This work assisted individuals and families who had become victims of a

Speaker: NA
Text: situation in which they were not given equal rights or opportunities in terms of the conflict. At

Speaker: NA
Text: the same time, this process of property resolution also enables that nation to move forward.

Speaker: NA
Text: For example, if you wish to invest in Kosovo, you want to know that the property you are

Speaker: NA
Text: purchasing is actually owned by the person who purports to own it. Not only is this resolution

Speaker: NA
Text: process helping people to return to their properties, sell their properties or rent their

Speaker: NA
Text: properties, it enables the country to move forward in investing in their future.

Speaker: NA
Text: Using what I learned during this time, part of the importance of my work now as a member

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Australian parliament is that I can be a voice for others and contribute to the continued

Speaker: NA
Text: success of our country. We can uphold what so many in our history have worked towards and

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that we are part of society which celebrates and values the diversity of our people and

Speaker: NA
Text: the rights of all to have equal opportunities. I, like many Australians, believe in the value of

Speaker: NA
Text: equality for all. In my maiden speech, I spoke about why I am a Liberal. I mentioned that I am

Speaker: NA
Text: a Liberal because I believe in equality of opportunity and reward for effort. All people,

Speaker: NA
Text: irrespective of background, deserve a fair go to achieve their best. I focused on this as my

Speaker: NA
Text: own family, like many in our country, came from humble beginnings and would not have

Speaker: NA
Text: been able to succeed if our people and society did not uphold the value of equal opportunity

Speaker: NA
Text: for all.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: My wife, Grace, originally came from South Korea and moved to Australia with her family

Speaker: NA
Text: when she was three years old. Australia opened the door for her as well as many other

Speaker: NA
Text: migrants from South Korea. Many South Korean migrants have been very successful in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia in both integrating into Australian society and achieving success. I am proud that I

Speaker: NA
Text: am able to share in my family that experience with my wife, Grace. As I mentioned in my

Speaker: NA
Text: maiden speech, she experienced the detriments of communism in North Korea when her

Speaker: NA
Text: great-grandparents were unfortunately killed by being thrown alive into a well under the

Speaker: NA
Text: communist regime. Fortunately, her family on one side were able to make it out of North

Speaker: NA
Text: Korea before the borders closed and then she had the opportunity later to move to Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: South Korea is recognised in my electorate as well with an increase in South Korean

Speaker: NA
Text: migrants locally. I was able to open recently the first South Korean restaurant in Dunkley,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is called Geonbae, which means 'cheers'. We are proud as a nation to have common

Speaker: NA
Text: values supported by all Australians, such as the importance of a fair go for all. Like my

Speaker: NA
Text: family, Dunkley locals are hardworking and aspirational, wanting the best for themselves and

Speaker: NA
Text: their families. That is why I believe in equality of opportunity. My electorate of Dunkley is

Speaker: NA
Text: full of people from vibrant cultural backgrounds and faiths. The make-up of Dunkley has a

Speaker: NA
Text: majority who were born in Australia. However, we also have a significant population of

Speaker: NA
Text: people who were born in England, New Zealand, Scotland, Germany, India, the Netherlands,

Speaker: NA
Text: South Africa, Italy, China, Ireland, the Philippines, the United States of America, Greece,

Speaker: NA
Text: Poland and more, as well as many whose parents also came from these nations.

Speaker: NA
Text: In September this year I had the privilege of hosting Senator the Hon. Arthur Sinodinos,

Speaker: NA
Text: the cabinet secretary, to my electorate. A part of Senator Sinodinos's visit to Frankston

Speaker: NA
Text: included meeting with the Frankston Greek Senior Citizens Club-a fantastic group of people

Speaker: NA
Text: who have made our community their home. Some made the Frankston community their home

Speaker: NA
Text: several generations ago and others in recent years. The fact that our society supports the rights

Speaker: NA
Text: of all Australians to enjoy equal rights and be treated with respect, regardless of ethnicity,

Speaker: NA
Text: colour, creed or origin, means that I was able to hear so many success stories from the

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Greek senior citizens, many of whom came to Australia with very little but

Speaker: NA
Text: were able to make the most of the opportunities our community had to offer, while also

Speaker: NA
Text: contributing to and giving back to the community in many ways, which we hope that all

Speaker: NA
Text: migrants to our country can do. The Australian way of ensuring equality of opportunity for all

Speaker: NA
Text: and a fair go has meant that Australia is full of vibrant, culturally diverse communities-

Speaker: NA
Text: something which has made our country and communities so much greater.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another example in my local electorate of Dunkley is the Ahmadiyyan Muslim

Speaker: NA
Text: community, with their mosque in Langwarrin. The Ahmadiyyan Muslim community is a part

Speaker: NA
Text: of the overall Islamic faith and in many Islamic countries is persecuted. Many have sought

Speaker: NA
Text: refuge in Australia and in many other countries around the world. They are an example of a

Speaker: NA
Text: community which has integrated locally in my electorate and is presenting a message which

Speaker: NA
Text: preaches love instead of hate.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have a proud history as an immigration nation. Each year over 200,000 immigrants, as

Speaker: NA
Text: well as over 18,000 refugees and people coming through the humanitarian program, make

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia their home. That makes nearly 220,000 people, which is nearly one per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's population, each year. Australia should be proud of its generous contribution in the

Speaker: NA
Text: world in settling migrants and refugees and others, particularly in terms of our settlement

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: services and our ability to integrate people into Australian society. We must continue to show

Speaker: NA
Text: order and continue to improve our settlement processes through our immigration programs

Speaker: NA
Text: and our actions recently through the great work of the Minister for Immigration and Border

Speaker: NA
Text: Protection, Peter Dutton, and assistant minister, Alex Hawke. If we control our borders and

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure an orderly process, that enables trust by the Australian people in our processes, which

Speaker: NA
Text: can increase generosity towards both migrants and refugees. This assists with further

Speaker: NA
Text: settlement into the future, in terms of settling those refugees and migrants, and we can

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to improve our settlement and other processes.

Speaker: NA
Text: The ADF also do a great job, not only in Australia but around the world, in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: preventing conflict at its source and in terms of protecting the freedoms that we all take for

Speaker: NA
Text: granted. This is part of our global efforts to stem the tide of those seeking refuge elsewhere.

Speaker: NA
Text: We currently have the largest population of refugees and internally displaced people around

Speaker: NA
Text: the world of more than 65 million people, which is greater than after World War II. We all

Speaker: NA
Text: have a responsibility, not only in Australia but in other countries, to enable the settlement of

Speaker: NA
Text: these people and to help resolve the issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am proud as an Australian and as part of this parliament to support equality of

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity, and I commend the Prime Minister's speech and this motion to the chamber.

Speaker: Mr DREYFUS
Text: Isaacs-Deputy Manager of Opposition Business) (16:20): This year

Speaker: NA
Text: marks the 41st anniversary of the Racial Discrimination Act, one of the great legacies of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Whitlam government. Passed in 1975, the Racial Discrimination Act makes it an offence to

Speaker: NA
Text: discriminate against a person because of their race, colour, descent, national or ethnic origin,

Speaker: NA
Text: or immigrant status. The act, of course, gave effect to some of Australia's international

Speaker: NA
Text: obligations under CERD, the Covenant for the Elimination of all forms of Racial

Speaker: NA
Text: Discrimination, and under the ICCPR, the International Covenant on Civil and Political

Speaker: NA
Text: Rights.

Speaker: NA
Text: Diversity is what makes Australia great. We do not merely tolerate or accept

Speaker: NA
Text: multiculturalism; we welcome and embrace it. Every new community that has come to this

Speaker: NA
Text: wide brown land of ours has added its own unique culture to the great multicultural fabric that

Speaker: NA
Text: is modern Australia. This diversity makes our great country stronger. It offers all Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: the chance to learn about the customs and traditions of others, making us all wiser and more

Speaker: NA
Text: civilised as a result. I cannot imagine an Australia that is not the multicultural community that

Speaker: NA
Text: it is today, because this is what we have become over the many decades of successive waves

Speaker: NA
Text: of immigration to our country. The multiplicity of cultures that we see around us, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: in our great cities, makes Australia an extraordinarily distinctive culture. Very, very few

Speaker: NA
Text: countries in the world can boast of the multicultural diversity that we have in our country.

Speaker: NA
Text: I welcome the Prime Minister's words in this House about his commitment to an

Speaker: NA
Text: immigration policy which is wholly non-discriminatory on the grounds of race, colour, creed

Speaker: NA
Text: or origin. I also welcome the Prime Minister's denunciation of racial intolerance in any form

Speaker: NA
Text: as being incompatible with the kind of society we are and want to be. I trust that the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister's words will be followed by swift action in support of the laws and policies that

Speaker: NA
Text: uphold the commitments that are contained in his words, including upholding section 18C of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Racial Discrimination Act, which provides protection for all Australians from being

Speaker: NA
Text: vilified because of their race or ethnic origin. It is exceptionally disappointing that the right-

Speaker: NA
Text: wing fringe of Australian politics, including some coalition MPs, have chosen to renew their

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: attack on a law which has served Australia particularly well in the 21 years that it has been

Speaker: NA
Text: part of our law.

Speaker: NA
Text: I note that the Prime Minister has yet to respond to a letter written by the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition inviting him to join all members of the Labor caucus in signing a parliamentarians'

Speaker: NA
Text: code of race and cultural ethics which pledges to discuss racial issues in a truthful and

Speaker: NA
Text: respectful way. This parliamentarians' code of race and cultural ethics is built on a document

Speaker: NA
Text: to very, very similar effect instigated by Senator Margaret Reynolds from Queensland in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1996, signed by very many members of both houses of the Australian parliament by 1998,

Speaker: NA
Text: which was prompted by what was, on any view, an outbreak of racial intolerance that had the

Speaker: NA
Text: potential to threaten the course and conduct of debate in this parliament. It is prompted by the

Speaker: NA
Text: potential for that same outbreak of racial intolerance that this new parliamentarians' code of

Speaker: NA
Text: race and cultural ethics has been brought into existence. I very much hope that the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister and the members of the joint coalition party room do respond to the invitation that

Speaker: NA
Text: has been extended by the Leader of the Opposition. What the Prime Minister's words in this

Speaker: NA
Text: House should lead to, but have not to date, is a swift denunciation of the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Dickson's recent derogatory and uninformed comments about communities that came to our

Speaker: NA
Text: country under the Fraser government. The words that he has used when speaking of 'second-

Speaker: NA
Text: and third-generation migrants' demonstrate his ignorance. The children and grandchildren of

Speaker: NA
Text: migrants are not secondand third-generation migrants; they are Australians, and the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Dickson should recognise that. He should be ashamed, as the immigration minister, of the

Speaker: NA
Text: phrases he has used.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Dickson's other statements, about the supposed immigration mistakes of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Fraser government, are equally ignorant and, of course, divisive. Let me make this entirely

Speaker: NA
Text: clear to the government and to the Australian public: Labor does not think the successive

Speaker: NA
Text: waves of immigration to this great country of ours were a mistake. When I walk down

Speaker: NA
Text: Douglas Street in Noble Park, one of the great multicultural hubs of my electorate, I see the

Speaker: NA
Text: successes of multiculturalism. When I talk to the Vietnamese Australian cafe owner or the

Speaker: NA
Text: Sudanese Australian butcher, I see the opportunities that Australia offers and the diversity and

Speaker: NA
Text: success that multiculturalism brings. When I speak to the Mayor of the City of Greater

Speaker: NA
Text: Dandenong, my friend Jim Memeti, who came to Australia from Albania at the age of two,

Speaker: NA
Text: and who built a successful business while giving his time to his community as a councillor for

Speaker: NA
Text: the last 11 years, I see the success of Australian multiculturalism. All three of these people are

Speaker: NA
Text: dedicated, hardworking people who give their time and their labour to make our great country

Speaker: NA
Text: even better. Nobody who met these people would think that their coming to Australia was a

Speaker: NA
Text: mistake. Each one of them has created jobs for Australians and has contributed in many ways

Speaker: NA
Text: to our community. And everywhere I go in my electorate I see that cultural diversity. People

Speaker: NA
Text: from over 180 nations have made their home in my electorate, and many other electorates in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia can say exactly the same thing.

Speaker: NA
Text: What is distinctive about the Australian community, notwithstanding the incredible number

Speaker: NA
Text: of countries across the world from which Australians have come, is the harmony in which that

Speaker: NA
Text: amazing diversity is able to exist. Elected representatives, and in particular ministers in the

Speaker: NA
Text: government of our great country, have a responsibility to set a standard of acceptance and

Speaker: NA
Text: civility for all Australians. I would be greatly saddened if the 'ignorant' and 'alarmist'

Speaker: NA
Text: comments by the member for Dickson-and I am there quoting the former Fraser government

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: minister Ian Macphee-were to be considered acceptable by young and impressionable

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians. We have to be particularly careful to speak in this place with care and

Speaker: NA
Text: compassion, and not with a view to divide and inflame, because, when an elected

Speaker: NA
Text: representative speaks, their words and their beliefs are legitimised by the very fact that an

Speaker: NA
Text: elected representative speaks them. I say again: there is a particular responsibility cast on

Speaker: NA
Text: elected representatives, particularly on ministers, to choose their words with care, and not-

Speaker: NA
Text: and this goes particularly for a minister of immigration in this country-to use words that

Speaker: NA
Text: have the capacity to divide and inflame and excite prejudice. The immigration minister of this

Speaker: NA
Text: country is the last minister who should be using the kind of language that, regrettably, the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Dickson has used in the last week and, might I say, has gone on using despite the

Speaker: NA
Text: storm of criticism that has rightly erupted over the comments that he made.

Speaker: NA
Text: Multiculturalism is the success of hope over fear, of opportunity over apprehension and of

Speaker: NA
Text: reaching out instead of staying in. As a proud Labor member and, more importantly, as a

Speaker: NA
Text: proud Australian, I stand here today in defence of multiculturalism, in defence of diversity

Speaker: NA
Text: and in defence of the continued commitment to denounce racial intolerance in any form as

Speaker: NA
Text: incompatible with the kind of society we are and want to be. What we need to hear from the

Speaker: NA
Text: government of our country, not just from the opposition, is the same defence of

Speaker: NA
Text: multiculturalism and diversity. What we need to hear is a sustained rejection of racial

Speaker: NA
Text: intolerance in any form-and not merely on occasions like the occasion of this motion jointly

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsored by the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition. Every time a minister

Speaker: NA
Text: speaks, every time an elected representative speaks, whether within this parliament or

Speaker: NA
Text: without, we need to hear a defence of multiculturalism and diversity.

Speaker: NA
Text: Instead of attacking the Australian Human Rights Commission the Prime Minister and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Attorney-General need to be defending that statutory agency when it carries out the statutory

Speaker: NA
Text: functions that it is charged to do. Instead of attacking the provisions of the Racial

Speaker: NA
Text: Discrimination Act which gives effect to Australia's obligation to outlaw race hate speech, the

Speaker: NA
Text: government should be upholding those provisions. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr HOWARTH
Text: Petrie) (16:30): I rise to speak on this motion today which has

Speaker: NA
Text: bipartisan support across the parliament. Of course, I follow the member for Isaacs. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: shame that he has chosen once again to attack the Minister for Immigration and Border

Speaker: NA
Text: Protection like he does so often. The member for Isaacs cannot help but engage in grubby

Speaker: NA
Text: politics in relation to the Minister for Immigration and Border Protection. He should 'take the

Speaker: NA
Text: 'log out of his own eye' because, in parliament, the member for Isaacs loves to divide, as do a

Speaker: NA
Text: lot of members on the Labor Party side. The question that was put to the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Immigration and Border Protection by the Labor Party the other day had as its very purpose to

Speaker: NA
Text: divide, to try and find a weakness, to get the minister to say something that they could exploit

Speaker: NA
Text: politically. That is the truth of the matter. It is absolutely grubby politics from those opposite.

Speaker: NA
Text: A division having been called in the House of Representatives-

Speaker: NA
Text: Sitting suspended from 16:32 to 16:45

Speaker: Mr HOWARTH
Text: As I was saying before, I was calling out the member for Isaacs for his

Speaker: NA
Text: divisive comments on this issue around the Minister for Immigration and Border Protection. I

Speaker: NA
Text: know the minister for immigration personally, and he is a very good man who cares deeply

Speaker: NA
Text: about his portfolio and cares deeply about Australian people from all walks of life. He has

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: done a great service to this country in his role. He has saved lives, particularly in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: stopping people smugglers.

Speaker: NA
Text: This motion, of course, I do support. That issue was originally raised by the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition. That was in relation to the fact that there were new One Nation senators in this

Speaker: NA
Text: place. I would have chosen to just ignore that fact. I think we already had strong bipartisan

Speaker: NA
Text: support on this issue. But I do support the motion, which the Leader of the Opposition and of

Speaker: NA
Text: course the Prime Minister have spoken on.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe Australia is a great country. It is the greatest country in the world to live in. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have a strong democracy, with freedom of race and religion. As a federal member of

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament, I have had the privilege of participating in many local citizenship ceremonies. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: great to see so many people wanting to move to Australia and embrace Australian citizenship.

Speaker: NA
Text: People want to come here. They want to live here. They want to build their lives here because

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is a country of opportunity.

Speaker: NA
Text: When I go to citizenship ceremonies in my electorate, I see how happy they are. People

Speaker: NA
Text: from right around the world, from different races, from different religions, take this pledge,

Speaker: NA
Text: where they say:

Speaker: NA
Text: From this time forward, under God, I pledge my loyalty to Australia and its people, whose democratic

Speaker: NA
Text: beliefs I share, whose rights and liberties I respect, and whose laws I will uphold and obey.

Speaker: NA
Text: If people become citizens and they mean that pledge and they embrace Australia, we welcome

Speaker: NA
Text: them with open arms. People need, of course, to respect our country and culture, and they do,

Speaker: NA
Text: even if people come from parts of Asia, parts of the Middle East, India or wherever they are

Speaker: NA
Text: from. Yes, of course, they hang on to some of their own traditions and beliefs from where

Speaker: NA
Text: they were born, the food they eat and everything else, but many of them make a big effort to

Speaker: NA
Text: adopt the Australian way of life and to learn and speak English as well. It is very important.

Speaker: NA
Text: They love this country very much.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think of Manmeet Sharma, an Indian bus driver who was murdered in Brisbane just a

Speaker: NA
Text: couple of weeks ago. I gave a speech on him in this place. He was a bus driver in Brisbane.

Speaker: NA
Text: He had a great work ethic. He worked really hard. He often helped new Indian people settle in

Speaker: NA
Text: to become Australian citizens here. He spoke at local functions in the electorate where he

Speaker: NA
Text: lived, and he sang as well. He was an Indian man-born Indian-who just settled into the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian way of life and embraced it very much. What happened to him was an absolute

Speaker: NA
Text: tragedy.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think of the Indian community where I spoke. There is a big Indian community in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate, particularly in the southern end. They had a memorial service for Manmeet the

Speaker: NA
Text: other day. They are Aussie people who love this country, and they play a big role in our area

Speaker: NA
Text: here.

Speaker: NA
Text: In relation to Indigenous people as well, section (3) of the motion is:

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) reaffirms its commitment to the process of reconciliation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander

Speaker: NA
Text: people, in the context of redressing their profound social and economic disadvantage …

Speaker: NA
Text: We know that a previous Prime Minister, the 26th Prime Minister of Australia, said sorry to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Indigenous people, and that went a long way to reconciliation. We love Indigenous

Speaker: NA
Text: people. I know quite a few. I have a big Indigenous community in the northern part of my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate, up around Deception Bay, and they play an important role.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: There are some great Indigenous Australians who have been succeeding at a high level for

Speaker: NA
Text: a long time. Not all Indigenous people are disadvantaged. I think of our first Indigenous

Speaker: NA
Text: senator in this place, the first Indigenous parliamentarian in the Australian parliament, a

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal senator from Queensland, the honourable Neville Bonner, who had little formal

Speaker: NA
Text: schooling, leaving school after he attained the third grade, apparently. In 1971, he became the

Speaker: NA
Text: first Aboriginal person to sit in the Commonwealth parliament when he was chosen to fill a

Speaker: NA
Text: vacancy in the Senate caused by the resignation of a Liberal senator for Queensland. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, Neville Bonner was returned at subsequent elections, from 1972 right through to

Speaker: NA
Text: 1980. Recently, his niece, Senator Joanna Lindgren, was also elected as a Queensland senator

Speaker: NA
Text: to this place. She is not here now, but she was elected.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last Thursday, we saw the release of the seventh Overcoming Indigenous disadvantage

Speaker: NA
Text: report from the Productivity Commission. The report found that significant progress has been

Speaker: NA
Text: made across education, health and economic participation. The Minister for Indigenous

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs, Nigel Scullion, 'said the progress was the result of concerted effort across

Speaker: NA
Text: government, but a great deal more needed to be done to address Indigenous disadvantage,

Speaker: NA
Text: including building the evidence of what worked'. He said that 'there are positives to take out

Speaker: NA
Text: of the report', specifically, reducing mortality rates of children, increasing year 12 attainment

Speaker: NA
Text: rates and school participation, and improving Indigenous employment rates and that 'this is

Speaker: NA
Text: good news and should be celebrated'. As the Minister for Indigenous Affairs, coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: minister Nigel Scullion, said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The progress we have made in these areas is a positive development and critical to overcoming

Speaker: NA
Text: Indigenous disadvantage, but … there is … more to be done.

Speaker: NA
Text: He praised all levels of government and different governments for their help.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, unless you are an Indigenous person, you came to Australia as a migrant or are a

Speaker: NA
Text: descendant of immigrants. We are a multicultural society. This is the foundation Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: was built on, and this does make Australia great. We have all benefited from it, and we all

Speaker: NA
Text: embrace it, whether it is eating out at Thai, Chinese, Indian-whatever it is, we are happy to

Speaker: NA
Text: embrace it.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to talk quickly about the Asian work ethic because I know that Asians are some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the most hardworking people around. In my business, some of my customers ran Vietnamese

Speaker: NA
Text: bakeries, and these men and women used to come in at three o'clock in the morning to start

Speaker: NA
Text: their bakery and would not leave until eight o'clock at night. This went on seven days a week.

Speaker: NA
Text: I said to a guy I know, Tran, who runs the bakery at Banyo, 'When was the last time you had a

Speaker: NA
Text: holiday?' and he said, 'Five years ago.' These people have a wonderful work ethic, and they

Speaker: NA
Text: really do make a big difference.

Speaker: NA
Text: I remember that in primary school, in years 2 and 3 at St Flannan's at Zillmere, there were a

Speaker: NA
Text: couple of brothers, Fretz and Jonathan. They were from the Philippines. They were very well

Speaker: NA
Text: respected by our classmates. When I trained in judo from the age of seven right through to my

Speaker: NA
Text: early 20s, I represented Queensland with a good friend of mine, a guy called Jason Gavin,

Speaker: NA
Text: whose mum was Malaysian. I mention that because, as a man in my 40s, I have grown up in a

Speaker: NA
Text: multicultural society, and we never looked upon these people that I grew up with as anything

Speaker: NA
Text: different than Aussies. Yes, they might have been born in a different country, but they were

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians. We are a country of opportunity, and, for anyone who wishes to make their mark

Speaker: NA
Text: in the story of Australia, we welcome them. I support the motion.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Ms CHESTERS
Text: Bendigo) (16:53): This is an important motion, and it is good to see

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the government add their names to the list to show their support for the words

Speaker: NA
Text: that have been moved in the House. It is a very important reminder at this time in Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: politics that this House recommits to equal rights for all Australians and reaffirms its support

Speaker: NA
Text: for all Australians to enjoy equal rights and to be treated with respect regardless of race,

Speaker: NA
Text: colour, creed or origin.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know that a number of MPs have stood in this place and said that one of the joys of being

Speaker: NA
Text: a federal member is being able to participate in citizenship ceremonies, and I too would like

Speaker: NA
Text: to add my voice to that call. We in the City of Greater Bendigo have had just over 280 people

Speaker: NA
Text: in our area take the pledge to become new Australian citizens. I know that that is not as many

Speaker: NA
Text: as in other electorates around the country. I know that in some electorates there are that many

Speaker: NA
Text: at every citizenship ceremony. But in Bendigo that is the number of people we were proud to

Speaker: NA
Text: celebrate taking the step to become Australian citizens.

Speaker: NA
Text: They have come from many countries to make Australia and Bendigo their home. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: asylum seekers and refugees from Myanmar. We have a number of skilled migrants from Sri

Speaker: NA
Text: Lanka, Bangladesh and India. We also have a number of people who have lived in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: for a very long time but only recently decided, even though they identify as Australian, to take

Speaker: NA
Text: that step to become Australian citizens-people from New Zealand, the UK and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Netherlands.

Speaker: NA
Text: In our part of the world we celebrate this event. It is always covered by the local media.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is always joy. There is a lot of nervousness. People are encouraged to wear dress from

Speaker: NA
Text: their original country at the citizenship ceremony. We hold these ceremonies not just in

Speaker: NA
Text: Bendigo; we also hold these ceremonies in the Macedon Ranges and Mount Alexander but

Speaker: NA
Text: less frequently than in Bendigo. It is a way that we in our community celebrate and

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledge our diversity. It is important that we in this place reflect and respect that

Speaker: NA
Text: diversity not just when we speak in citizenship ceremonies but every day that we are members

Speaker: NA
Text: of parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: When I get the great privilege to speak at these events-in fact, at any event in our

Speaker: NA
Text: community where we celebrate our diversity and the many cultures that make up the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian culture-I talk about how Australia is a rich tapestry of many cultures woven

Speaker: NA
Text: together to form the Australian culture. We do that through the traditional way-through

Speaker: NA
Text: food, music and sharing stories. We always encourage each other to share our stories and our

Speaker: NA
Text: journeys because that is the true Australian culture-many cultures woven together.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unfortunately, in Bendigo in the last few years we have had a few people invade our town

Speaker: NA
Text: and suggest that we are not a multicultural community, that we are not diverse and that we do

Speaker: NA
Text: not celebrate our diversity. The City of Greater Bendigo just over two years ago quite proudly

Speaker: NA
Text: approved the first application to build our city's first mosque. We have a growing Muslim

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian community in Bendigo and they did not have a place of their own in which to

Speaker: NA
Text: worship. They put forward plans to build a community centre that contained a small mosque.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unfortunately, the United Patriots Front, Reclaim Australia and a few other groups boarded

Speaker: NA
Text: trains to Bendigo and drove to Bendigo to protest against the building of the first mosque.

Speaker: NA
Text: These people were outrageous and at times violent. The United Patriots Front staged a mock

Speaker: NA
Text: beheading of a dummy out the front of the Bendigo city chambers. They posted this on

Speaker: NA
Text: Facebook. Whilst many community leaders and political leaders, people like me, condemned

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the video at the time, we really struggled to get Facebook to take down the video. This goes to

Speaker: NA
Text: the role of social media in this space. We note what happened recently in the United States.

Speaker: NA
Text: I hope that Facebook takes these concerns seriously because the people involved in this

Speaker: NA
Text: incident have since been charged by Victorian Police for serious religious vilification. We

Speaker: NA
Text: welcome that because it is very important that people in Bendigo and in Australia are not

Speaker: NA
Text: subject to the kind of vilification that this group have been pushing for. They say that people

Speaker: NA
Text: who practise the Muslim faith are not Australians. They are wrong. They say people who pray

Speaker: NA
Text: in mosques are not Australians. They are wrong. It says very clearly in our Constitution, very

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly in a number of our federal laws, that people are free in this country to practise their

Speaker: NA
Text: religion. That is one of the reasons I want to speak to this motion, to reiterate my strong

Speaker: NA
Text: support for maintaining respect within this place.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whilst this group's actions have been broadly condemned by many in politics, you can see

Speaker: NA
Text: how these groups do not see what they are doing is wrong when they are being encouraged by

Speaker: NA
Text: comments that are made by our immigration minister. His words in question time sent alarm

Speaker: NA
Text: bells and shock waves through our community, and it was not just in question time but also

Speaker: NA
Text: during the recent federal election. When the immigration minister said that refugees are

Speaker: NA
Text: clogging up our Medicare system, clogging up our unemployment system and taking

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian jobs in the way that he did, he did it purely and simply to incite fear and push

Speaker: NA
Text: people's buttons within our community. He is not being inclusive, he is not respecting our

Speaker: NA
Text: rules and he is not respecting the fact that we celebrate diversity and migration in our country.

Speaker: NA
Text: This week he also spoke about Australians who have Lebanese heritage.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to take a moment to acknowledge the way political leaders and members of

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament have taken to Twitter to tell the immigration minister why he should be sacked and

Speaker: NA
Text: to also tell him about their history. I would like to acknowledge Jackie Trad, the Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Premier of Queensland; Marlene Kairouz, a member of parliament in Victoria; and Steve

Speaker: NA
Text: Bracks, the former and much-loved Premier of Victoria-who all say they are proud

Speaker: NA
Text: Lebanese Australians. But let's make it clear: they are Australians with Lebanese heritage. My

Speaker: NA
Text: parents are from England, but I do not go around saying that I am a proud English Australian.

Speaker: NA
Text: I say that I am Australian with parents who were born in England. It is the same for these

Speaker: NA
Text: three celebrated MPs-they are Australians with Lebanese heritage.

Speaker: NA
Text: Migrants built our country; it is the history of who we are. It is important that all of us

Speaker: NA
Text: always practise that when we stand and make comments, that we are being true to that; that

Speaker: NA
Text: we reaffirm our commitment to maintaining a migration policy that is wholly non-

Speaker: NA
Text: discriminatory on grounds of race, colour, creed or origin. I want to see the immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: minister recommit to that, a value that for so long has been bipartisan but just this week we

Speaker: NA
Text: have seen him tear that up and go for the cheap political shots. He should be ashamed and

Speaker: NA
Text: apologise for his comments. He is saying these things to invoke fear and division in our

Speaker: NA
Text: community and that is something we should never accept in this place or the other place.

Speaker: Ms FLINT
Text: Boothby) (17:03): I am delighted to support this motion put by the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister today. Equality before the law is one of the fundamental pillars of our liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: democracy and one that I certainly support and hope that all members in this place and the

Speaker: NA
Text: other do as well. Hailing from South Australia, I am conscious of the nature of my state's

Speaker: NA
Text: founding, 180 years ago this year. I attended our Proclamation Day ceremony at Glenelg on

Speaker: NA
Text: 28 December last year and I thoroughly commend it to all South Australians and indeed

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: anyone visiting my home state over Christmas. As a free settled state, the only one in the

Speaker: NA
Text: nation, as we like to proudly remind everybody else, and a place that was to be the

Speaker: NA
Text: embodiment of the best qualities that British society had to offer-economic freedom and

Speaker: NA
Text: prosperity, freedom of association and the right to be free from religious persecution-I am a

Speaker: NA
Text: very proud South Australia. This is important because freedom, I believe, is a most thorough

Speaker: NA
Text: and capable instrument that we may use to achieve equality.

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australia was founded as a utopia for free settlers. It was home to many who were

Speaker: NA
Text: fleeing religious persecution from Prussia. Lutherans settled in and around the Adelaide Hills

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Barossa Valley, and wrote one of the first of many chapters in Australia's colourful

Speaker: NA
Text: and successful multicultural history. We have German migrants to thank for so much of our

Speaker: NA
Text: wonderful wine and food. It must also be highlighted that South Australia's proclamation was

Speaker: NA
Text: the only proclamation in the nation which included safeguards for Aboriginal Australians and

Speaker: NA
Text: their descendants, and thus proclaimed rights-albeit, rudimentary-for our First Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: Closer to home for me, South Australia was also the first jurisdiction in Australia to legislate

Speaker: NA
Text: for women's suffrage and the only state to grant women the right to vote and to stand for

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament at the same time.

Speaker: NA
Text: I mentioned that part of what we offered in South Australia was economic freedom and

Speaker: NA
Text: prosperity, and there is no greater tool to achieve equality than through freedom. One of our

Speaker: NA
Text: best examples of this was under the leadership of Sir Thomas Playford. Throughout the post-

Speaker: NA
Text: World War II migration era, South Australia's population exploded with non-English-

Speaker: NA
Text: speaking migrants, who have made a wonderful contribution to our state. Their inclusion in

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australia's life and community was facilitated by the demand for workers to work in

Speaker: NA
Text: the factories and in our economy at the time. These industrious migrants and their children

Speaker: NA
Text: have achieved equality and integrated properly into Australian life, and the credit must go to

Speaker: NA
Text: the principles of the Liberal democracy that my state and our nation were founded on.

Speaker: NA
Text: Half a century later, and Australia is still a place of refuge for those fleeing persecution.

Speaker: NA
Text: While the world is a far more complex place now, and our immigration practices have

Speaker: NA
Text: needed to keep pace, the principles of providing refuge to those who need it remain the same

Speaker: NA
Text: and are stronger than ever. Australia's humanitarian program is global and non-

Speaker: NA
Text: discriminatory. Last financial year, the government's refugee and humanitarian program

Speaker: NA
Text: delivered a total of 17,555 places, which included 15,552 offshore places. This is the largest

Speaker: NA
Text: offshore intake in more than 30 years. The number of special humanitarian program places,

Speaker: NA
Text: visas for families of Australians in refugee-like situations offshore, has grown from 503

Speaker: NA
Text: places in 2012-13 to 7,268 places in 2015-16. At the same time, the number of illegal

Speaker: NA
Text: maritime arrivals taking place under the program has fallen from 4,994 in the last period of

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor to one in 2015-16. Australia's annual refugee and humanitarian program will grow to

Speaker: NA
Text: 18,750 by 2018-19, one of the most generous permanent resettlement programs in the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: The coordinated efforts of the Australian government agencies and international partners have

Speaker: NA
Text: led to a steady flow of visa grants to Syrians and Iraqis from Australia's annual humanitarian

Speaker: NA
Text: program, an additional 12,000 humanitarian places. As a result, the number of Syrian and

Speaker: NA
Text: Iraqi humanitarian entrants arriving in Australia has also increased. The Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Immigration and Border Protection and the Department of Social Services continue to work in

Speaker: NA
Text: close cooperation to ensure that post-arrival settlement services and supports are in place to

Speaker: NA
Text: assist people as they arrive in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: It is important to note that we could not afford to be as generous in our refugee intake had

Speaker: NA
Text: we not managed to get our borders under control. Unfortunately, due to the failed Rudd-

Speaker: NA
Text: Gillard-Rudd Labor governments, our nation completely lost control of our borders and we

Speaker: NA
Text: incurred billions of dollars of spending. There was something like an $11 billion budget

Speaker: NA
Text: blowout as a result of this. Far worse than any monetary impact was the loss of 1,200 lives at

Speaker: NA
Text: sea. The moment I realised how crucial it was to have our borders under control was when I

Speaker: NA
Text: saw the footage, in 2010, of the 50 people who drowned in very rough seas off Christmas

Speaker: NA
Text: Island. Having grown up on the coast, along a coastline pretty similar to that of Christmas

Speaker: NA
Text: Island, it was one of the most devastating things I have ever seen. We cannot allow it to

Speaker: NA
Text: happen ever again; we just cannot.

Speaker: NA
Text: The results of stronger borders are clear: in the last six years of the Howard government,

Speaker: NA
Text: for example, just 288 illegal immigrants made it to Australia by boat. In the six years of Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Greens, 50,000 people flooded in via 800 successful people-smuggling ventures, and,

Speaker: NA
Text: as I have mentioned, 1,200 people were tragically lost at sea. I am very proud to say that,

Speaker: NA
Text: under the coalition government's policies, no boats have arrived in Australia for 840 days.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are no children in detention. That number is down from 8,000 children who were held

Speaker: NA
Text: in detention under Labor's policies. There have been 17 detention centres closed. This means

Speaker: NA
Text: that we can now take more refugees from refugee camps who have been waiting patiently for

Speaker: NA
Text: a better life here in our wonderful country. We have been able to assist those refugees from

Speaker: NA
Text: Iraq and Syria.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think it is very important to note that our migration program does not discriminate on the

Speaker: NA
Text: basis of ethnicity or religion. The purpose of migration is to build the economy, shape society,

Speaker: NA
Text: support the labour market, reunite families and provide protection in accordance with

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's protection obligations. The contribution of migrants to Australian society, culture

Speaker: NA
Text: and prosperity has been an important factor in shaping our nation. I hope that everyone in this

Speaker: NA
Text: place and the other place are acutely aware that we were all migrants once. My earliest South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian forebears arrived in my home state in 1838-two years after settlement. They did

Speaker: NA
Text: their small part to help build South Australia's economy and community, as migrants do every

Speaker: NA
Text: single day.

Speaker: NA
Text: Today, our migration program is designed to meet Australia's economic and social needs. It

Speaker: NA
Text: includes the skilled stream, the family stream and the special eligibility stream, along with the

Speaker: NA
Text: humanitarian component for refugees and others in humanitarian need. The size and

Speaker: NA
Text: composition of the permanent migration program is flexible and changes over time. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: changed from a smaller program with mostly family migrants in 1993-94 to a larger program

Speaker: NA
Text: with more skilled migrants in recent years. In recent years, roughly two-thirds of people

Speaker: NA
Text: migrating to Australia were skilled migrants and about one-third were from family visa

Speaker: NA
Text: streams. The total migration program outcome for 2014-15 was approximately 190,000

Speaker: NA
Text: places, compared to 62,800 in 1993-94. In recent years, the major source countries in the

Speaker: NA
Text: migration program have been India, China and the United Kingdom. We welcome all of these

Speaker: NA
Text: migrants.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am sure everyone in this place would join with me in saying that one of the great

Speaker: NA
Text: privileges of being a member of parliament is going to citizenship ceremonies, welcoming

Speaker: NA
Text: new people into our communities and acknowledging the very rich contribution that our new

Speaker: NA
Text: citizens make to our culture and that our migrants have made to our culture and our

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: community over the years. I again commend the Prime Minister's motion. I congratulate the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister and our current and former ministers for immigration for the work that they

Speaker: NA
Text: have done, particularly in securing our borders and making sure no lives are ever again lost at

Speaker: NA
Text: sea as a result of a government policy in this country.

Speaker: Mr DRUM
Text: Murray) (17:13): I too would like to echo the words of the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Boothby in relation to the incredible success that we have had in stopping the boats and the

Speaker: NA
Text: humanitarian aspect of that-saving lives at sea. We know that we still have a lot of work to

Speaker: NA
Text: do in this area. We can see that, sometimes, in these worldwide crises, we move the issue

Speaker: NA
Text: from our local oceans to the Mediterranean. We still have a worldwide issue, and we have a

Speaker: NA
Text: lot of work that needs to be done. However, it is great to see that we were able to work

Speaker: NA
Text: through this very complex issue. Everybody knows that, as soon as Australia blinks in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: to relaxing the current laws, the people smugglers will seize every opportunity to kickstart

Speaker: NA
Text: their industry once again. The better a job we do in protecting our borders, the more

Speaker: NA
Text: humanitarian and generous our legal intake of refugees can be.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was with great pride that I had the opportunity to speak on the Prime Minister's motion

Speaker: NA
Text: about the right of all Australians to enjoy equal rights and be treated with equal respect

Speaker: NA
Text: regardless of race, colour, creed or origin-and you can throw religion in there or whatever.

Speaker: NA
Text: Certainly, we are all privileged to live in this country. Only once people have travelled

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas does the real benefit of growing up in a country like Australia hit home. To have so

Speaker: NA
Text: many freedoms-to not have to worry about being attacked on the way to school, to not have

Speaker: NA
Text: to worry about being treated as a second-class citizen- is something we take for granted in

Speaker: NA
Text: this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: We also need to look very carefully at our Indigenous peoples because we have not brought

Speaker: NA
