Text: them along in the same way that other countries have been able to do. You need only look

Speaker: NA
Text: across to New Zealand; they seem to have been able to bring their Maori population along in

Speaker: NA
Text: a different way from what we have been able to do with our Indigenous peoples. Shepparton

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Goulburn Valley has a very strong cohort of Indigenous people, and there are some

Speaker: NA
Text: significant issues in this area as well. I am lucky to have very good relationships with

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal community leaders, who are able to enunciate a very clear vision for their people

Speaker: NA
Text: and have created so many positive initiatives within the Goulburn Valley and the Shepparton

Speaker: NA
Text: region. It is incredibly important that we continue to work with our Aboriginal communities

Speaker: NA
Text: to make sure that they are given every opportunity to pick up the education that most of us

Speaker: NA
Text: take for granted and to look at how we can give them employment opportunities that will

Speaker: NA
Text: change their lives, if we are able to do that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Today I had the great pleasure of hosting my friend Kevin Sheedy, who was up here

Speaker: NA
Text: spruiking the benefits of a country round of football for next year. Every time you get Kevin

Speaker: NA
Text: Sheedy on his own, he wants to talk about the Indigenous players that he was able to nurture,

Speaker: NA
Text: teach and encourage-and they repaid him in spades with brilliant football and brilliant

Speaker: NA
Text: careers. He was certainly able to increase the profile of Indigenous Australians within the

Speaker: NA
Text: sport of Australian rules football. Prior to Kevin Sheedy coming in as a coach in the eighties,

Speaker: NA
Text: we might have had 30 or 40 Indigenous AFL players. But within a short 20 years we have

Speaker: NA
Text: now had over 350 Indigenous AFL players-and they continue to bedazzle all of us. Again,

Speaker: NA
Text: that was just one man's passion to bring out their absolute talents.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Getting back to the Murray electorate and, in particular, the Goulburn Valley, it has always

Speaker: NA
Text: had a diverse multicultural break-up and mix. Growing up there as a school child, I had

Speaker: NA
Text: friends from every different European country. It did not matter whether they were Greeks,

Speaker: NA
Text: Italians, Macedonians or Albanians. Many people from European countries who migrated to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia after the Second World War came directly to Shepparton. They gave Shepparton a

Speaker: NA
Text: very multicultural feel, even before any of us knew what the word 'multicultural' meant. That

Speaker: NA
Text: sense has continued to grow; in fact, it is changed quite significantly. We still have all of

Speaker: NA
Text: those populations but in recent years we have had increased numbers arriving from Malaysia,

Speaker: NA
Text: Indonesia and Sri Lanka. With the break-up of Yugoslavia, we had more and more arrivals

Speaker: NA
Text: from those European areas. And in recent years we have people had come from a range of

Speaker: NA
Text: Arabic speaking countries. There are Iraqis and there are a lot of Afghanis who are trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: find their way in Shepparton.

Speaker: NA
Text: On a very serious note, Shepparton and the Goulburn Valley have done an awful lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: heavy lifting in relation to resettling refugees. Governments need to be very careful when they

Speaker: NA
Text: think that they can just plonk people in certain areas because there seem to be a lot of other

Speaker: NA
Text: immigrants and refugees in those areas, it all looks good and we will talk about it in such a

Speaker: NA
Text: positive light. To a large degree it is positive, but what we need to be very careful of is the

Speaker: NA
Text: issue called secondary migration. When we bring refugees into Australia we put a cohort of

Speaker: NA
Text: support structures around them, with language skills, housing support and employment

Speaker: NA
Text: support-there is a whole range-but, when those refugees migrate out of the eastern suburbs

Speaker: NA
Text: of Melbourne and decide they want to make Shepparton their home, the secondary migration

Speaker: NA
Text: takes place without the associated supports. That is where Shepparton is at the moment. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have had so much secondary migration. People have moved to the regions because it is

Speaker: NA
Text: cheaper to live there and there is a bigger cohort of refugees of like race, so they feel they can

Speaker: NA
Text: move into those areas and be amongst their own. But we need to be very cognisant of the

Speaker: NA
Text: continued need to put supports around these people. I would like to push the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: language is a very serious barrier for enabling people to further assimilate into whatever

Speaker: NA
Text: community they want, but it is an incredibly important part of us being able to welcome these

Speaker: NA
Text: people. These people will not come into our community groups, our community clubs and our

Speaker: NA
Text: community organisations if they do not have the confidence generated by being able to speak

Speaker: NA
Text: the language.

Speaker: NA
Text: When talking about being a great country in relation to this, whilst I am incredibly proud of

Speaker: NA
Text: the government's achievements with our borders, we need to be mindful of the damage that is

Speaker: NA
Text: done to individuals after prolonged periods in refugee camps overseas and in offshore

Speaker: NA
Text: detection. When we bring these people in and we are able to resettle them here, there are still

Speaker: NA
Text: significant issues and support that they need because of the separation from their family, the

Speaker: NA
Text: uncertainty about bridging visas and the uncertainty around temporary protection visas.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whilst I am incredibly proud of our record and what we have achieved, I am also incredibly

Speaker: NA
Text: aware that there is a real cost to dealing with this problem, and that simply means that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have to be very honest about all the associated issues when it comes to refugees being

Speaker: NA
Text: resettled here.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Goulburn Valley is an amazingly multicultural environment. It is a beautiful place for

Speaker: NA
Text: food. We have beautiful people from beautiful parts of the world making this beautiful food.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a real awakening when people come to Shepparton. They would not realise that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: all these amazing cultures and amazing opportunities for greater understanding. We have a lot

Speaker: NA
Text: of work to do and we need a lot of support. I am looking forward to the migration committee's

Speaker: NA
Text: work under Jason Wood. We are conducting an inquiry into resettlement. I want to reaffirm

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister's motion to the House.

Speaker: Ms BANKS
Text: Chisholm) (17:23): I am absolutely delighted to support this motion by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister, Malcolm Turnbull, today. This motion goes to the very essence of what I

Speaker: NA
Text: stand for. I am so proud to be here supporting this motion as the member for Chisholm,

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's third most culturally diverse electorate. Australia is the world's most successful

Speaker: NA
Text: multicultural nation on this earth. This is reflected in our celebration and warm embrace of

Speaker: NA
Text: different cultures in community and business life. The contribution of migrants to Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: society, including many in the electorate of Chisholm, is significant to the prosperity and

Speaker: NA
Text: harmonious way in which we celebrate our culture. In any one day in Chisholm-as I said,

Speaker: NA
Text: the third most culturally diverse electorate in Australia-many languages other than English

Speaker: NA
Text: are spoken and many cultural events and traditions are enjoyed, and this all happens in

Speaker: NA
Text: harmony.

Speaker: NA
Text: The embrace of multiculturalism and equal opportunity is intuitive and formidable under

Speaker: NA
Text: the Turnbull government. Our commitment is to a completely non-discriminatory policy and

Speaker: NA
Text: the rights of all Australians to enjoy equal rights and be treated with equal respect, regardless

Speaker: NA
Text: of race, colour, creed or origin, as is our commitment to the process of reconciliation with

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. Australia's migration program does not

Speaker: NA
Text: discriminate on the basis of ethnicity or religion.

Speaker: NA
Text: In recent years the major source countries in our program have been India, China and the

Speaker: NA
Text: United Kingdom. Australia is an immigration nation and we should all be very proud and,

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed, as in the words of our national anthem, we should 'all rejoice'. Today, almost half of

Speaker: NA
Text: us have a parent born overseas and more than a quarter of Australians were born overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves. We are much more diverse than the United States.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since 1949 more than 7½ million people have come from all corners of the earth to make

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia their home. Migrants from all over the world, including our newest Australians,

Speaker: NA
Text: have arrived under a broad range of visas-as skilled migrants nominated by employers, as

Speaker: NA
Text: refugees, as humanitarian entrants, as partners, as carers, as business owners, as regional

Speaker: NA
Text: skilled migrants, as people of distinguished talent, as parents, as children and as students.

Speaker: NA
Text: Each one brings a rich personal history that we have welcomed into our community. At the

Speaker: NA
Text: time that they formalise their commitment to our country, our values and our rule of law, they

Speaker: NA
Text: start their journey in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: This year marks the 50th anniversary of when Australia became an early signatory to the

Speaker: NA
Text: United Nations International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial

Speaker: NA
Text: Discrimination. It is a treaty that goes directly to a basic principle of respect for each other as

Speaker: NA
Text: fellow human beings and respect for each other regardless of race, colour or ethnicity.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is always important to reflect on history and see how far we have come as a nation. In

Speaker: NA
Text: 1966 that treaty was signed by the Liberal Prime Minister Harold Holt. Only months earlier

Speaker: NA
Text: the Holt government made significant changes to our migration laws, dismantling all laws

Speaker: NA
Text: allowing discrimination against migrants on the grounds of colour or race.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: In May 1967 Australians overwhelmingly voted to amend the Constitution to enable the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth to make laws for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians-a

Speaker: NA
Text: process that was begun under the Sir Robert Menzies government and was completed under

Speaker: NA
Text: the leadership of Harold Holt. These decisions under the Menzies and Holt governments

Speaker: NA
Text: removed the White Australia policy and embraced all the new and exciting opportunities for

Speaker: NA
Text: our country, which were underpinned by the people who came from far and wide. They

Speaker: NA
Text: sought to end discrimination, celebrating and reaffirming the Australian values of mutual

Speaker: NA
Text: respect regardless of ethnicity, race, colour or creed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Central to our democracy is the rule of law. The rule of law is empowering and

Speaker: NA
Text: constraining as it applies to every citizen and protects every citizen regardless of race, colour,

Speaker: NA
Text: gender or status. But harmony and security are not mutually exclusive. Indeed, they are

Speaker: NA
Text: intrinsically linked. To this, I discuss Labor's border failures, which are, in my view, Labor's

Speaker: NA
Text: greatest shame. Under Labor the criminal people-smuggling syndicates flourished. Eight

Speaker: NA
Text: hundred boats arrived, 50,000 people arrived and 2,000 children were in detention, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: greatest shame of all is that 1,200 people died.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the Turnbull government we have not had one boat arrival, no deaths at sea, we

Speaker: NA
Text: closed the detention centres and there are no children in detention. The Turnbull government's

Speaker: NA
Text: work in relation to border protection and securing our shores is lauded and praised around the

Speaker: NA
Text: world. Moreover, the fact that we have our borders under control is what has created our

Speaker: NA
Text: dividend to bring in refugees-those most vulnerable from Syria and other parts of the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: A total of just under 19,000 refugees have come to Australia recently as a result of our

Speaker: NA
Text: measured, controlled approach.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our proud migrant story has many chapters and is told in the waves of people who have

Speaker: NA
Text: come to our shores, and many of their stories are about their immigrant experience, stories

Speaker: NA
Text: and heritage. Last week I had the honour and privilege of presenting Australian citizenship

Speaker: NA
Text: certificates to many new citizens who have made Australia their home and who live in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate of Chisholm. In their pledge of citizenship they promise loyalty to Australia and its

Speaker: NA
Text: people whose democratic beliefs they share, whose rights and liberties they respect and whose

Speaker: NA
Text: laws they will uphold and obey. It gave me so much pride and heartfelt warmth to have this

Speaker: NA
Text: honour of officially welcoming people and congratulating them in joining our great nation,

Speaker: NA
Text: and to share this moment with them. The looks on many of their faces and the pure joy that

Speaker: NA
Text: was in that room as I handed their certificates was joyful. My parents and ancestors, like

Speaker: NA
Text: many-including the many in my electorate of Chisholm-have come, in the words of our

Speaker: NA
Text: national anthem, 'across the seas' and 'toiled with hearts and hands'. New citizens have come

Speaker: NA
Text: from the United Kingdom, China, India, Greece, Italy, Sri Lanka, Vietnam, Hong Kong, New

Speaker: NA
Text: Zealand, Korea, Taiwan, Ireland, Mauritius, the Philippines, and Malaysia. All those new

Speaker: NA
Text: citizens who attended the ceremony, like all those before them, have so many stories to share.

Speaker: NA
Text: But the one thing we all have in common is that we are able as 'Australians all' to rejoice-

Speaker: NA
Text: because this is the most successful multicultural nation on this earth.

Speaker: Mr LEESER
Text: Berowra) (17:30): I rise in support of this motion today, and I thank the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister for introducing it. This motion outlines one of the most fundamental principles

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australian society: that an individual should be judged according to their character, their

Speaker: NA
Text: ideas, their actions and their deeds, and not their race, colour, creed or origin. It is a particular

Speaker: NA
Text: honour to be the member for Berowra and to speak on this particular motion, because of my

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: illustrious predecessor, Phillip Ruddock, who served as member for Berowra for 23 years but

Speaker: NA
Text: served the Commonwealth parliament for 43 years; our second-longest serving member of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives ever. It is particularly good to be speaking to this motion here

Speaker: NA
Text: where my friend, the member for Bennelong who-like the member for Berowra-has been a

Speaker: NA
Text: great champion of multiculturalism in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the things about my predecessor-and this motion gives me an opportunity to pay

Speaker: NA
Text: some tribute to him-was his very strong connections with multicultural communities, along

Speaker: NA
Text: with his very deep interest in the diversity of Australia, and the nation-building that he sought

Speaker: NA
Text: to do throughout his political career. Phillip Ruddock's interest in multiculturalism goes back

Speaker: NA
Text: to the time in the early 1980s when he was shadow minister for multiculturalism. He was

Speaker: NA
Text: asked to produce a policy on multiculturalism, initially for the ACT, and became interested in

Speaker: NA
Text: getting to know some of the community leaders around the country. Phillip famously put his

Speaker: NA
Text: political career in the firing line, as it were, when in 1988 he crossed the floor to support

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia having a race-blind migration policy. I think, of the many important things he did in

Speaker: NA
Text: his career, this was actually the most important. This is a principle which is reflected in the

Speaker: NA
Text: motion today, but I think it is actually a fundamental principle of who we are as Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was very important to the making of Phillip Ruddock, in terms of his political career-not

Speaker: NA
Text: just as a very good local member and as someone who could forge a policy agenda but as

Speaker: NA
Text: somebody who stood for something that was very deep and very important. I really pay

Speaker: NA
Text: tribute to him for that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Philip was also our longest-serving minister for immigration, and he enjoyed that portfolio;

Speaker: NA
Text: he was also minister for Indigenous affairs, and that portfolio is also encompassed by some

Speaker: NA
Text: aspects of this motion. Phillip saw his role in the immigration portfolio as building the nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some people see the immigration portfolio as merely a border protection portfolio, but that

Speaker: NA
Text: was not how Phillip saw it. He saw it as both choosing the next generation of people to be

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians, and welcoming them, ensuring that they had good settlement services and

Speaker: NA
Text: ensuring that they became and felt part of the broader community. Having observed Phillip

Speaker: NA
Text: closely, I think that being immigration minister was something that left its mark on him. But it

Speaker: NA
Text: was also, undoubtedly, one of the most difficult policy areas imaginable. It was difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: because he had to make some tough decisions about Australia. He had to make some tough

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions about border protection when large numbers of boats came-and I think every

Speaker: NA
Text: immigration minister faces those difficult decisions. While I am paying tribute to Phillip, I

Speaker: NA
Text: also want to pay particular tribute to the present immigration minister, Peter Dutton, who has

Speaker: NA
Text: done a fantastic job-as his predecessor, Scott Morrison, did-in ensuring that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: public confidence in the migration program by ensuring that people continue to come to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia in an orderly manner; that we do not have the deaths at sea; that we do not have

Speaker: NA
Text: 50,000 people turning up on our doorstep; and that we do not have the large number of people

Speaker: NA
Text: in detention that existed under the previous government. The success of multiculturalism in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia today is really founded on the issue of public confidence. That was something that

Speaker: NA
Text: both Phillip Ruddock and Peter Dutton have stressed in their contributions to the public

Speaker: NA
Text: debate on this issue. Diversity is the goal. Diversity is fundamental to who we are, but you

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot have public support for diversity unless you have public confidence that we have an

Speaker: NA
Text: orderly system to bring people in.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: For me, the right to equality and the idea of a race-blind immigration policy is absolutely

Speaker: NA
Text: axiomatic. I am very proud to have been the first Jewish Australian chosen by my party from

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales to serve in the House of Representatives. It is an interesting fact that in the

Speaker: NA
Text: first Commonwealth parliament the people of Indi in northern Victoria chose Isaac Alfred

Speaker: NA
Text: Isaacs, one of the framers of the Constitution and later Chief Justice and Governor-General,

Speaker: NA
Text: the people of South Australia chose Vaiben Louis Solomon and the people of Fremantle, just

Speaker: NA
Text: out of Perth, chose Elias Solomon. Both Solomons were free traders, and Isaacs was a

Speaker: NA
Text: protectionist. Those two streams formed the modern Liberal Party, but it was another 115

Speaker: NA
Text: years before my party, or its antecedents, in my state chose somebody of my faith.

Speaker: NA
Text: Prior to becoming a member of this parliament, I served on the representative body for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Jewish community in New South Wales. I had a particular role as chair of the community

Speaker: NA
Text: relations committee of that body. The NSW Jewish Board of Deputies' community relations

Speaker: NA
Text: committee is absolutely fundamental, because its role is to build harmony and build

Speaker: NA
Text: relationships with other religious communities and other ethnic communities across the state.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is a very important thing in terms of a harmonious multicultural society-not just that

Speaker: NA
Text: you have tolerance and diversity, but that you have people making an effort to share their

Speaker: NA
Text: differences and to celebrate the similarities of what makes us Australian. That was a great

Speaker: NA
Text: privilege for me, because it gave me an opportunity, just as some of my previous work with

Speaker: NA
Text: Philip Ruddock had done, to interact with some of the great community leaders involved in

Speaker: NA
Text: the multicultural space. I particularly think of people like Stepan Kerkyasharian who is, if you

Speaker: NA
Text: like, the godfather of multiculturalism in New South Wales. He served on the Anti-

Speaker: NA
Text: Discrimination Board of NSW for many years, he served on what is now the Community

Speaker: NA
Text: Relations Commission as its president for many years, and he served on SBS multicultural

Speaker: NA
Text: radio to help create a sense of inclusion and a sense of multiculturalism across the broader

Speaker: NA
Text: community.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not just think of people like Stepan, I think of people like Sev Ozdowski, of people in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Chinese community like Benjamin Chow and Tony Pang, of people in the Indian

Speaker: NA
Text: community like Parveen Gupta and Pallavi Sinha, of Professor Agar and Sanjeev Bhakri from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Hindu Council, and of some of the other amazing people I met along the way. I am very

Speaker: NA
Text: lucky to represent a community that, like the member for Bennelong's electorate, has a great

Speaker: NA
Text: deal of ethnic diversity in it. About 40 per cent of people in my electorate were born overseas,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is consistent with the national population. There are significant Chinese, Indian,

Speaker: NA
Text: Korean, Italian, Lebanese and Malaysian populations in my community. It is that difference

Speaker: NA
Text: and that diversity that brings strength.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the things I find whenever I am speaking to people who have chosen to be

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians, who have come from other countries to settle here, is that they have an enormous

Speaker: NA
Text: pride in being Australian. Australians by choice are a great benefit to our country, because,

Speaker: NA
Text: very often, they have left circumstances, regimes and situations that are not as good as they

Speaker: NA
Text: find here. They are grateful and feel fortunate to be here, and they want to see our country

Speaker: NA
Text: prosper, because, if our country prospers, they too shall prosper. That is a great strength of our

Speaker: NA
Text: system.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the other aspects of this particular motion is the commitment to reconciliation with

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. I thought I might begin by talking a little bit

Speaker: NA
Text: about that. I have been on a real journey in relation to the issue of recognition of Indigenous

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: people in Australia. I must say, at the beginning of my journey I was opposed to any

Speaker: NA
Text: recognition of Indigenous people, not because I do not wish to see Indigenous people prosper

Speaker: NA
Text: and succeed, but because I was deeply concerned about the implications of adding words to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Constitution that might have unforeseen consequences.

Speaker: NA
Text: Over the last three or four years I have had the privilege of working with a group of

Speaker: NA
Text: Indigenous leaders, people like Noel Pearson, Megan Davis and Marcia Langton, to come up

Speaker: NA
Text: with a suite of proposals which I think will provide a good pathway to achieving

Speaker: NA
Text: reconciliation and recognition of Indigenous people. It involves an extra constitutional

Speaker: NA
Text: declaration of recognition, designed by Australians and voted on by Australians. It involves

Speaker: NA
Text: amending and updating the words in the race power so they reflect and codify current practice

Speaker: NA
Text: and that they change those words for being a power for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander

Speaker: NA
Text: affairs. It involves removing the spent provision in section 25 in the Constitution. Finally, it

Speaker: NA
Text: involves creating a body that can provide advice to parliament and advice to government on

Speaker: NA
Text: laws relating to Indigenous people.

Speaker: NA
Text: As we know, whenever you make a law you make a better quality law when you have

Speaker: NA
Text: consulted the people who are most affected by it. That is why some sort of body that provides

Speaker: NA
Text: a voice for Indigenous people, in the policymaking and law-making process, would be a great

Speaker: NA
Text: advantage. I commend the motion to the chamber.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr O'DOWD (Flynn) (17:40): I rise to reaffirm my commitment to the rights of all

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians to enjoy equal rights and to be treated with equal respect, regardless of race,

Speaker: NA
Text: creed, colour or origin. Equal rights and personal freedom are fundamental ideals of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian society, fought for by our soldiers in so many theatres of war across the globe.

Speaker: NA
Text: Despite a long proud history of tolerance and acceptance there is still-and always will be-

Speaker: NA
Text: more to do.

Speaker: NA
Text: While the bare-faced discrimination of the early days of Australian settlement has virtually

Speaker: NA
Text: banished from our society, as we stand here today, there is still more work to be done. As the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister said in his speech:

Speaker: NA
Text: Our achievement in creating a harmonious nation is not an accident. It has been carefully crafted, and it

Speaker: NA
Text: must be nurtured. And a necessary precondition for harmony is security.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is this security that binds our entire society and allows it to be so diverse. Security is easily

Speaker: NA
Text: identified in ways we interact with the rest of the globe.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have a history, and I think a proud history, of supporting the rights of those who are in

Speaker: NA
Text: peril through military action. In the First World War as a new nation we saw European

Speaker: NA
Text: countries-and it would eventually have led to our own country-under threat by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Germans. Our war started in New Guinea, where the Germans had a pretty strong base in

Speaker: NA
Text: Rabaul and other parts of New Guinea. Our first recorded deaths in World War I were in

Speaker: NA
Text: Rabaul, when five Australian soldiers were killed. But they did achieve what they set out to

Speaker: NA
Text: do: take over the communications that controlled all of the Pacific Islands. We then went on

Speaker: NA
Text: to Gallipoli, North Africa and those dreadful trench wars in France. But it was aggression that

Speaker: NA
Text: helped the Western world and the islands achieve their independence.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Second World War was similar, with German aggression again, including the

Speaker: NA
Text: extermination of millions of people based on their race. That was sad but we responded to the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: call. Those people now have the freedom that they longed for back then. They have it to a

Speaker: NA
Text: degree now.

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnam was our stance against the spread of communism and people being persecuted.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whether the Vietnam War was one we could have kept out of is up to the individual to make

Speaker: NA
Text: their own mind about, and there are two schools of thought. We thought we were doing the

Speaker: NA
Text: right thing by going in and helping the Vietnamese retain their freedom. With the current

Speaker: NA
Text: Middle Eastern wars, Australia has taken to assisting those whose rights and safety are under

Speaker: NA
Text: siege.

Speaker: NA
Text: Work continues to this day with the ADF against the scourge of IS. Australians can stand

Speaker: NA
Text: proud in the knowledge that their military tradition has fought for the rights of people when

Speaker: NA
Text: called upon, time after time. That security is also identified in Operation Sovereign Borders.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are two ways to come into Australia as an immigrant or refugee: the legal way and the

Speaker: NA
Text: illegal way. By keeping our borders secure, we take the market away from the criminal

Speaker: NA
Text: human-traffickers, thus allowing a more generous inflow of safe, legitimate, security-checked

Speaker: NA
Text: refugees.

Speaker: NA
Text: While the media likes to throw doubt at Australian society's acceptance of newcomers, I

Speaker: NA
Text: think the best indicator of our acceptance is just how keen migrant families are to become

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian citizens. All of us in this House attend regular citizenship ceremonies in our

Speaker: NA
Text: different locations. Each month, if I am available, I attend citizenship ceremonies at

Speaker: NA
Text: Gladstone and in other parts of my electorate of Flynn-Emerald and so forth-and I am

Speaker: NA
Text: taken aback by the passion and love that the so-called new Australians have for our

Speaker: NA
Text: community. I think these ceremonies are one of the greatest events you can attend as a

Speaker: NA
Text: politician. You see the expressions on their face change as the words 'You are now an Aussie,

Speaker: NA
Text: mate' are said. I think it is proof of how proud these people are to leave their countries of birth

Speaker: NA
Text: and come to a place called 'Australia'. They had never been here before. Maybe they had some

Speaker: NA
Text: family members who have been here. In essence, they had not been on Australian soil. They

Speaker: NA
Text: are here for the first time and they embrace the nation of Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: For the majority of them, all they want to do is become good Aussies, work hard and

Speaker: NA
Text: achieve what they could not achieve in their place of birth. These people often do so in order

Speaker: NA
Text: to escape terrible dangers, and they hope to make a new life in a safe and secure country. By

Speaker: NA
Text: offering them security and safety, we are able to welcome those new Aussies and the new

Speaker: NA
Text: economic windfall that they bring with them. That is where Australia benefits. We need these

Speaker: NA
Text: immigrants, on a regular basis. We are an ageing nation and we need these people to look

Speaker: NA
Text: after people like me when we go into retirement in the next few years. They will replace the

Speaker: NA
Text: baby boomers. They are an essential part of our immigration policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: This government is committed to equal rights and constitutional acknowledgement of

Speaker: NA
Text: Indigenous Australians. Recognition is overdue, and it is not helped by distracting comments

Speaker: NA
Text: from those opposite about a treaty. I think if we leave things as they are, everything will be

Speaker: NA
Text: fine. Recognition is an important step, but it is improving the life outcomes for all Indigenous

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians that will make a measurable difference to them and to Australia. Through poor

Speaker: NA
Text: health outcomes, Indigenous Australians have a lifespan that is, on average, 10 years shorter

Speaker: NA
Text: than for those in the non-Indigenous population. This is something that all governments must

Speaker: NA
Text: address.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: This comes back to safety and security. The Prime Minister was talking about every

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian. Every visitor needs security. By continuing the fight for security and safety this

Speaker: NA
Text: nation and its people will continue to see Australia as a welcoming and sought-after

Speaker: NA
Text: destination. My family, the O'Dowds, came from Ireland in 1949, just before the so-called

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Famine-the potato famine. It was a famine-the potatoes were diseased-but the

Speaker: NA
Text: English, who then ruled Ireland, sought to shut off all the fishing holes and lakes, exported the

Speaker: NA
Text: lamb and beef to England and let 5½ million Irish people die on the streets of Ireland. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: how my family came to Australia-to escape the famine of 1850.

Speaker: NA
Text: In those days, it was the Catholics against the Protestants. As a young child, I can

Speaker: NA
Text: remember that the Catholics and the Protestants were separated in religious classes in the tiny

Speaker: NA
Text: little schools they used to go to. That is a fact. Trinity College had an interesting story in

Speaker: NA
Text: Dublin. Trinity College is still there. It is a very old school and it was only for the Protestants.

Speaker: NA
Text: For hundreds of years, the Catholics fought to be able to attend Trinity College. When they

Speaker: NA
Text: finally got self-government, in 1920, they were told: 'Okay, you can now go to Trinity

Speaker: NA
Text: College.' The Irish response to that was, 'It's good to know that we can go there, but we don't

Speaker: NA
Text: want to go there now.'

Speaker: NA
Text: An honourable member: To be sure!

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr O'DOWD: To be sure! With that, I would like to endorse what we are here to talk

Speaker: NA
Text: about, and that is freedom for all, regardless of race, creed, colour or origin. Thank you very

Speaker: NA
Text: much.

Speaker: Mr LITTLEPROUD
Text: Maranoa) (17:50): Today, I stand in this chamber as a proud

Speaker: NA
Text: member of a government that throughout our nation's history has supported and respected the

Speaker: NA
Text: tolerance of others no matter what their race, religion or gender and it continues to do so

Speaker: NA
Text: today. I am also proud of the fact that this country is the most successful multicultural society

Speaker: NA
Text: in the world. This is something all Australians should be proud of. If you ask a person in the

Speaker: NA
Text: street what they think defines our Australian culture I am sure the words, 'mateship' and

Speaker: NA
Text: 'getting in and having a go' are likely to be the responses that you will get. In fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: narrative rings true here with this motion today, where both the government and the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition agree, just like it was 20 years ago when our former Prime Minister, John Howard,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the then opposition leader, Kim Beazley, spoke on this very motion.

Speaker: NA
Text: It would be remiss of me not to say that this generous, respectful and multicultural

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has been underpinned by giving our people peace of mind. When I refer to the

Speaker: NA
Text: giving Australians peace of mind I am referring to the efforts we take to ensure that Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: remains a harmonious multicultural society, underpinned by the focus on our country's

Speaker: NA
Text: national security.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have to say that I am extremely proud to be part of a government focused on the security

Speaker: NA
Text: of our borders and diligently managing our immigration programs. It is our ability to control

Speaker: NA
Text: our borders that enables us to live in a harmonious, well-balanced and multicultural society.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are definitely one of the luckiest countries in the world, and as a member of a functional

Speaker: NA
Text: global society this government recognises the need to do our part. I believe that the people

Speaker: NA
Text: who come to this country by visa, whether as a skilled immigrant, a refugee or as a

Speaker: NA
Text: humanitarian entrant; as partners or carers; as a business owner; as a regional skilled migrant;

Speaker: NA
Text: or as parents, and who agree to respect our country's sovereignty and laws deserve our

Speaker: NA
Text: mateship and an opportunity to contribute. Entry to our country through our humanitarian

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: program-a program that is global and non-discriminatory-provides hope for a better future

Speaker: NA
Text: for people and their families who are displaced by conflict.

Speaker: NA
Text: This government has committed to settling 12,000 additional humanitarian refugees who

Speaker: NA
Text: have been displaced by enduring conflict in Syria and Iraq. This government will work to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that refugees who are welcomed to Australia through our humanitarian program pass

Speaker: NA
Text: imperative security checks and meet health and character criteria. This government will be

Speaker: NA
Text: providing the necessary services to our humanitarian entrants to help them to build a life here

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia so that they too can become self-reliant and participate equally as members of our

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian society.

Speaker: NA
Text: My electorate of Maranoa is classified as regional, rural and remote and I would like to talk

Speaker: NA
Text: with the tangible benefits of ensuring that migrants successfully integrate in our regional rural

Speaker: NA
Text: and remote areas. On the ABC's Australian Story two weeks ago we learned firsthand about

Speaker: NA
Text: the benefits of encouraging multicultural integration in the small community town of

Speaker: NA
Text: Mingoola, just over the border in New South Wales-a town that my leader, Deputy Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister Barnaby Joyce, actually represents. This is a town which in many ways is similar to

Speaker: NA
Text: the sum of the towns in my electorate of Maranoa, in the sense that these communities are

Speaker: NA
Text: facing the challenges of a declining population and sustaining their essential services and

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities. Smaller rural communities like Mingoola, and the many communities across

Speaker: NA
Text: Mingoola, while facing challenges are also proud, community-minded and respectful

Speaker: NA
Text: communities, where people are friendly and helpful and care about the future of their town.

Speaker: NA
Text: Julia Harpham noticed the pressure placed on the future of Mingoola. It was a problem

Speaker: NA
Text: which almost resulted in the closure of the local Mingoola school. Instead of accepting a sad

Speaker: NA
Text: end, Julia worked to find a solution that would suit her community. In Julia Harpham's words:

Speaker: NA
Text: You don't like to see a community die. And there's not much joy in a place with no children.

Speaker: NA
Text: Together the community of Mingoola worked with refugee advocates to facilitate, with the

Speaker: NA
Text: help of this government, to bring refugee families from Central Africa to Mingoola.

Speaker: NA
Text: Families arriving here as refugees from countries in Central Africa, like Rwanda, often do

Speaker: NA
Text: not want the hustle and bustle of the city. They want a life on the land, to live in smaller

Speaker: NA
Text: communities to which they can contribute and for their children to enjoy a country

Speaker: NA
Text: upbringing. Earlier this year three families relocated to Mingoola, increasing the small rural

Speaker: NA
Text: town's population by 29 and saving the local school from closure. The relocation of these

Speaker: NA
Text: three families has also provided employment opportunities for people with local farmers and

Speaker: NA
Text: alleviated the pressure placed on farmers in the area in attracting a reliable workforce.

Speaker: NA
Text: By all reports this project is a success for Mingoola and is an example of how Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: humanitarian program produces good outcomes, particularly in regional, rural and remote

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. This outcome is exactly what the evidence tells us. When we integrate our

Speaker: NA
Text: immigrant population into our rural towns we broadened and revitalise our communities. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have people to utilise our schools and people to take job opportunities that we in rural

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia often find hard to place. Maintaining sustainable populations in our smaller

Speaker: NA
Text: communities means that all levels of government are able to ensure adequate investment in

Speaker: NA
Text: planning, infrastructure, programs and services in the country. In my first speech I spoke

Speaker: NA
Text: about infrastructure being important for unlocking our economic prosperity in Maranoa.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: In the three months I have been in this role I have been fortunate to attend two citizenship

Speaker: NA
Text: ceremonies: one in Dalby, at which the community welcomed 21 new citizens, and another at

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingaroy, where 23 citizens joined the South Burnett community. In fact, the citizenship

Speaker: NA
Text: ceremony in Kingaroy was one of the largest held by the South Burnett Regional Council. I

Speaker: NA
Text: watched proudly as our new citizens pledged loyalty to Australia, our people, our democratic

Speaker: NA
Text: beliefs and our rights and liberties and promised to respect and obey our laws. After speaking

Speaker: NA
Text: to some of Maranoa's newest citizens and learning about them, their children and their

Speaker: NA
Text: background I was able to fully appreciate the value of their contribution to the social fabric

Speaker: NA
Text: and the economies of their new regional and rural communities.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another issue which I have been focusing on in my electorate is the value of our

Speaker: NA
Text: passionate, dedicated and community minded volunteers in helping address community

Speaker: NA
Text: disadvantage, whether that be by reason of unemployment, disability or otherwise. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: been encouraging people to recognise good citizens-the people who donate their time to

Speaker: NA
Text: help others. In preparing my speech on this very important motion I was surprised to learn

Speaker: NA
Text: that, according to Volunteering Australia statistics from 2010, 36.2 per cent of people aged 18

Speaker: NA
Text: years and over participated in formal volunteering, so roughly about 6.1 million people or 27

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of the then 2010 population. Of that amount 1.44 million volunteers were people who

Speaker: NA
Text: were born overseas, and 840,000 of those were people who spoke a language other than

Speaker: NA
Text: English. I think these statistics truly reflect the fact that the opportunity we provide to people

Speaker: NA
Text: through our immigration programs is of benefit to Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would also like to acknowledge our Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders who contribute

Speaker: NA
Text: so much towards this country. I am grateful for our First Australians who are now saving lives

Speaker: NA
Text: as doctors, nurses and paramedics, teaching children, working with our unique Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: environment and serving the Australian people here in this place. But I am also cognisant that

Speaker: NA
Text: we must continue our work in bettering the lives and opportunities of our First Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our government is extremely committed to preserving our First Australians' history. While

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister was in Birdsville with me last month we met with Jean Barr-Crombie, who

Speaker: NA
Text: through Red Ridge received a grant to publish a book on the Indigenous language unique to

Speaker: NA
Text: outback Birdsville. This grant will ensure that our Indigenous languages survive the years to

Speaker: NA
Text: come and remain an important part of Australia's history.

Speaker: NA
Text: In closing, what we as a nation have achieved in creating the most functional and

Speaker: NA
Text: harmonious nation on earth is a great achievement but we can never take this for granted and

Speaker: NA
Text: we should be prepared to defend and preserve that achievement at all costs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: Federation Chamber adjourned at 17:59

Speaker: NA
Text: NA
